PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
- That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
- That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
- That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
- That in 1989/90 alone Medicare provided medical benefits for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dubois (from 14 citizens), Ms McHugh (from 101 citizens), Mr MacKellar (from 346 citizens) and Mr Snow (from 169 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
- That every human being, from the first instance of fertilization, is of unique and precious value, not only to him/herself, but also to his/her parents and to the community at large.
- That every abortion kills a human being before his/her birth.
- That the right to life of all human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights according to article 3 of the 1948 UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
- That the primary duty of the Parliament is to protect this inalienable right to life of all citizens, born and unborn.
- That in 1989/90 alone, medical benefits were paid for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost to Australian tax-payers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of all Australian citizens before birth by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising on Radio and Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon Honourable Members to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Bailey (from 65 citizens), Mr Reid (from 96 citizens) and Mr Reith (from 180 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
1. (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
2. creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
3. will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
1. By Act, Parliament ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
2. The Parliament take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia expressing complete opposition to the banning of political advertising, and regard any ban as:
- a denial of the freedom of speech;
- promoting the government in power by allowing the continuation of government department advertising;
- a guise to cover a move toward massive direct-mail campaigns which will make the removal of sitting members a virtual impossibility.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. The Parliament rejects any move to abolish political advertising; and

2. Parliament enacts legislation to abolish public funding of political parties, which costs taxpayers up to $13 million each election, and acts to artificially boost expenditure on political advertising.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:
We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the members the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your Petitioners request that the members in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a) outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b) lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c) cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which wars such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
(i) call on the Federal Government to outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations, government and private.
(ii) call on the Federal Government to lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the House will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon Honourable Members to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise political material on radio and television, believing such a ban to be arbitrary and discriminatory, a denial of freedom of speech and a curtailment of criticism (or support) of political parties and/or their policies.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I present the report of the Committee entitled A tour of duties: The final report of an inquiry into aspects of the Australian Customs Service, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I have tabled today is the second and final report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on an inquiry into aspects of the Australian Customs Service. The report focuses on the program management structure of the Service and the import-export control subprogram. In doing so, it gives an overview of the allocation of roles or duties within the Customs Service and examines the operations of the subprogram, whose first objective is the collection of the correct amount of customs duties and other revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1989-90, the Committee conducted an inquiry into the financial management improvement program (FMIP) of the public sector reform. At that time, the Australian Customs Service was recognised as being a leader in the implementation of its reforms. Following this inquiry the Committee has concluded that reputation continues to be a valid one.

The program structure introduced by Customs in September 1987 has proved to be a successful one for an organisation administering a range of programs in a complex and changing environment. While the Committee was impressed by the structure and the finetuning which has occurred since 1987, room for improvement was evident in some areas. Most notable was the need for refinement of performance indicators to more accurately measure the achievement of desired outcomes. This observation is consistent with the conclusions of the Committee's FMIP inquiry.

In relation to import-export control, the bulk of the submissions to the inquiry addressed amendments to the Customs Act which came into effect in July 1989. These amendments have been generally referred to as the CELA legislation-the customs and excise amendment legislation. In the view of many who gave evidence to the inquiry, the administrative penalties introduced in the CELA legislation are too severe. Administrative penalties are applied for errors in import documentation which result in short payment of duty, whether such errors are made knowingly, recklessly or otherwise. The existence of the penalties and their administration by Customs was also considered by many to have been a major cause of a reported deterioration in relationships between the Customs Service and the trading community.

The Committee has concluded that in its present form the legislation appears to be too harsh in its effects on owners and agents and has recommended that a formal review be undertaken in late 1991 by an independent body such as the Australian Law Reform Commission. Some specific changes have also been suggested. The first is that consideration be given to the introduction of a sliding scale of penalties to replace the present mandatory penalty of 200 per cent of duty short paid. The second is to include the recognition that what are now deemed to be classification errors could, in some cases, be interpreted as differences of opinion.

Having reviewed the reports of a downturn in relationships between Customs and its clients, the Committee believes that, while the penalty provisions provided the catalyst for complaints, other factors were also involved. Wider considerations such as customs recruitment, training and staff rotation practices and its consultative processes also have a significant impact on the response of Customs clients. The Committee has recommended that Customs address some real or perceived shortcomings in these areas.

Specific recommendations include a review of training programs to evaluate the success in achieving desired skill levels and, in particular, to evaluate their internal components. Several witnesses suggested that internal training was not sufficient. The low percentage of Customs personnel who have tertiary qualifications was of concern to the Committee. Customs management has taken steps to improve this percentage by encouraging staff to undertake further education. A studies assistance scheme is in place to facilitate study at universities and technical and further education colleges through the provision of bursaries for part time study and scholarships for full time undergraduates and postgraduate study. The Committee endorses these actions and has recommended that Customs also conduct a recruitment campaign at tertiary training institutions to increase the mix of educational qualifications within the Service.

The Committee was pleased to observe the Customs Service's decision to review the staff rotation policy. The Committee believes that the new staff mobility policy should ensure a more flexible and sensitively applied policy in accordance with the 18 principles negotiated last October between the Customs Service and the Public Sector Union.

To address a need for increased liaison with client bodies, the Committee has recommended the establishment of a Customs consultative committee. It is envisaged that such a forum will meet regularly at a national level for the discussion of customs issues. Such issues could include administrative procedures, changes in policy and draft legislation, where that is appropriate. Membership could be drawn from customs agents associations, the Law Council, customs consultants and importers' representatives.

The Committee concluded that there is a need for importers to become more aware of the policy and practices of Customs. Customs agents reported to the Committee that they experienced a degree of frustration with importers-particularly in their efforts to convince importers of the desirability of seeking early advice on classification, valuation and quota matters. The Committee, in fact, received many reports of inconsistencies in tariff classification rulings between States and allegations of its corollary, that is, port shopping. By this is meant the practice of routing shipments to clear them at the port providing the most favourable duty rate.

In the course of the inquiry, Customs announced its decision to establish a central dispute settling body in Canberra. The Committee supports this move. It believes that the existence of such a body will increase the confidence of importers and their agents by providing an increased degree of certainty and rulings. While the Committee found it difficult to establish the extent of port shopping, it believes its existence has been sufficiently substantiated to warrant further inquiry. To this end, the Committee has recommended that Customs conduct an investigation to gain an accurate measure of its extent in order to remove possible inequities and to gauge the potential loss to the revenue caused by such practices.

An aspect of import control which impresses the Committee is the area of electronic initiatives. Customs has placed considerable emphasis on the development of electronic initiatives in import and export processing, both within Customs and in the wider trading community. The Committee commends these developments and commends particularly the leading role played by Customs in its implementation throughout the trade network.

In view of the important role played by electronic initiatives in achieving waterfront reform and the integral role played by Customs in their development, the Committee has recommended that sufficient funding should be allocated in the Budget process to ensure that the overall project can be completed within the planned timeframe.

Two other issues were addressed in the report. They were the question of security at Sydney Airport and the provision of customs facilities at planned and potential new airports, particularly in Queensland. Both of those issues are canvassed fully in the report.

Despite some shortcomings highlighted in this final report, the Committee remains impressed by overall administration of the Australian Customs Service and by the commitment of its personnel to the achievement of corporate goals. The Committee has enjoyed its interaction with Customs and has appreciated the cooperation extended to it in the course of the inquiry.

I would like to take the opportunity to thank my fellow subcommittee members-the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the honourable member for St George (Mr Dubois), the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott) and the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear)-for their work in this inquiry.

I would also at this stage pay particular thanks to the secretariat staff for their assistance with the inquiry. I am pleased that they are here in the chamber today. I refer particularly to the subcommittee secretary, Ms Geraldine Skinner, and to Mr Darcy Abbey, a secondee from the Australian Customs Service who acted as adviser to the Committee. I am sure he learned as much about the processes of the Parliament as we learned about the Customs Service. We thank Darcy sincerely.

I also convey thanks to Ms Amanda Garlick and to David Elder, the Committee Secretary, who, as usual, considered the whole operation of our Committee work to the minute detail. In all, I think this again demonstrates the role that can be played by parliamentary committees in examining important topics, important exercises, which have ramifications for the Parliament and, indeed, government. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to speak on this report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which is actually a revisitation in two respects to the original report, Risky Business-the 37,000 Kilometre Challenge. The revisit is in connection with security at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The second matter I want to talk to is the establishment of international airports. I want to thank, particularly, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) for giving me the opportunity to respond. It appears that the first report was made at a time when too much reliance was placed on the Australian Customs Service evidence but too little on the players in the business of international airports. Perhaps it was unfortunate that the inquiry was held at the time during and after the very devastating effects of the air pilots dispute, which actually made international airports throughout all of Australia almost superfluous.

SPEECH.PARA: The airline pilots dispute, of course, drastically reduced international travel to the Whitsundays north of Mackay and almost excluded domestic travel to the region by air. Two international airports in the region might appear to be rather extravagant, but it has been indicated in many reports, including the Boeing report, that Mackay and areas to the north, particularly north Queensland, are being consistently targeted as growth areas for international and national travel.

No doubt the Whitsundays, the islands and the reef are paramount and central to this development; they are internationally famous. They would probably provide, as far as the tourist looking for a Mediterranean atmosphere is concerned, the best sun, the best sea and the best sand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Better than the Mediterranean.

—It is much better than the Mediterranean; much better than the Bahamas. I think anybody who was on the Committee formulating the report would agree with that, because the area is unique. It is unique because the whole area, just in this one particular location, offers a variety of on-reef, on-island, onshore and hinterland holidays and accommodation. For example, with Hamilton Island on the one hand and Proserpine on the other, there is a diversification of interest. They are single destinations in themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to report to the House some of the latest statistics on this particular area. For the year ended 31 December, Hamilton Island, of all the airports in Queensland-including the capital-recorded the biggest growth for that year: 45.4 per cent. When one looks at the quarter ended 31 December, it is interesting that one sees Hamilton Island's increase over that previous equivalent quarter is 173.9 per cent; Mackay is 190.6 per cent; and Proserpine 227.9 per cent. That is relevant because the latter statistics would have been affected by the record wet weather from December to March.

Further evidence given before the Committee showed there was a need for back-to-back charters, because international tourists these days are looking at travelling for a short time, going directly to their destination, spending their time there and going. It also indicates what is being done in connection with Hamilton Island.

I would like to recommend to anybody who is interested in this subject the evidence of Hamilton Island through Mr Keith Williams, on pages 442 to 455 of the transcript. This evidence shows the difficulty of trying to have an internationally recognised facility without an international airport. What has been done there is described in those pages, and it speaks volumes. The Hamilton Island airport can currently take Boeing 767s, and it was demonstrated during the evidence that there is a water hazard greater than Venice in trying to get people from the shore to the island and back again.

In connection with the Proserpine airport, there is a massive development going on there, with everything already in place. Evidence for Aqua Del Rey was given by Mr Chris Hughes and also the Ansett sponsor. They are prepared to add 1,200 metres of airstrip to the existing 2,000 metres, to take 747s. It was also indicated by the council that there is the Peter Faust Dam, which has infrastructure already in place, and there is a beach development. That again, with Aqua Del Rey, makes this a separate destination, and with a back-to-back charter arrangement everything would be great.

In actual fact, there is no dispute between Hamilton Island and Proserpine airports, but what has to be borne in mind is that in Australia, and Queensland in particular, there is a problem if an area does not have an international airport because the movement of traffic is different from that in Europe, where people can move about by bus or train. Tourists expect to get to their destination quickly, spend their holiday and go.

The people involved in these projects are the risk takers. I just mention again that the Mackay Port Authority also has plans for internationalisation. We cannot expect these people to develop markets, unless our policy is open enough to provide the encouragement for those people who are prepared to pay and provide the proper services to do so. The capital cost in this case would be borne, as would the Customs service costs, by the Authority.

I believe the recommendations are most welcome. I think they will be well received by those people involved, although they indicate, of course, that there is a responsibility on Customs even though their service is paid for. They should investigate the feasibility of part time Australian Customs Service employment, and the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), has already made reference to that trend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 309th report entitled Annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee initiated this inquiry into annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities in the context of, and in response to, the significant public sector reforms that occurred during the 1980s. The present guidelines for the content, preparation and presentation of annual reports by statutory authorities were issued in November 1982. However since that time the guidelines have been neither updated nor reissued to reflect the major changes to the reporting requirements of all Commonwealth entities.

SPEECH.PARA: From the early days of the inquiry, it was abundantly clear to the Committee that the current 1982 guidelines were out of date and did not adequately reflect the changes that had taken place in both the present day administrative environment and the legislative framework within which Commonwealth Government entities operate.

In the Committee's view, the annual report lies at the heart of the accountability process and is one of the most important vehicles for effective parliamentary scrutiny. Statutory authorities have generally been afforded more management autonomy and flexibility in financial administration than departments of state. This is particularly the case in the light of the ongoing reforms to public sector management and since the issue in October 1987 of the Government's Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises.

This increased autonomy and flexibility give rise to an even greater need for detail and proper reporting by statutory authorities of their performance so as to fulfil their accountability requirements to Parliament and, through Parliament, to the public at large. Accordingly, the Committee strongly endorses the existence of guidelines which lay the foundation for statutory authorities to prepare high quality annual reports that focus on the meaningful reporting of both financial and non-financial performance.

Furthermore, the Committee is of the view that no statutory authority, large or small, commercial or Budget dependent, should be exempt from meeting the minimum requirements set down by the annual reporting guidelines. The Committee is particularly concerned that, while many statutory authorities have specific annual reporting provisions in the Acts by which they are established and others are subject to the annual reporting provisions of the Audit Act 1901, there is no consistent or all embracing legislative requirement for every statutory authority to report to Parliament annually.

The fact that there is no statutory backing for the annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities is incongruous with the existence of statutory backing for the departmental annual reporting guidelines, by virtue of the Public Service Act 1922, and the requirements of the Companies Code in relation to annual reporting by private sector companies. In the Committee's view, the most effective way to ensure that there is a minimum level of quality information presented to Parliament each year by all statutory authorities is to give new annual reporting guidelines statutory backing and it has recommended accordingly.

Furthermore, in line with the current practice for guidelines for departmental annual reports, the Committee has recommended that the statutory authority guidelines and any amendments made to them from time to time be approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The Committee has also recommended that new annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities be prepared by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and that the Department be responsible for an annual review and update of the guidelines. A vast array of bodies can be classified as statutory authorities and as part of the inquiry the Committee closely examined the classes of statutory authorities to which the annual reporting guidelines should apply.

The Committee has recommended that there should be one set of annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities and that these new guidelines should clearly state the categories of statutory authorities to which they apply. These categories should include government business enterprises, statutory marketing authorities, other commercial statutory authorities and non-commercial statutory authorities. Furthermore, the Committee recommends that the guidelines should be presented on two levels: the first covering broad issues applicable to all authorities with an emphasis on accountability requirements for both financial and non-financial information; and the second divided into sections relevant to particular categories of statutory authorities which outline the reporting requirements applicable to each category.

The Committee believes that these recommendations will clarify the present state of confusion surrounding the annual reporting requirements for statutory authorities. All statutory authorities are accountable to Parliament for their performance and, as I have already mentioned, the reporting of performance takes on added importance in the context of the recent reforms in public sector management. In the light of the reforms, the Committee has concluded that the current annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities do not adequately emphasise the importance of results oriented reporting.

The Committee considers that currently there is inadequate guidance from central Commonwealth departments for production of performance information by agencies, but readily recognises that development of quality information is a dynamic process and is still in its relative infancy.

Against this background, the Committee has recommended that all statutory authorities be required to report on non-financial performance in their annual reports, providing as a minimum an outline of program objectives and desired results together with a description of key performance indicators. Comparative data over successive years should be presented where relevant.

During the inquiry, the Committee paid particular attention to the situation of statutory authorities with commercial operations. With the aim of improving the quality and timeliness of information to Parliament, the Committee has recommended that such authorities be required to present to the relevant Minister, on a half-yearly basis, interim reports on financial position. Furthermore, all statutory authorities should be required to report to relevant Ministers critical events which have a material effect on financial position as they occur.

In the formulation of the new annual reporting guidelines, the Committee has also recommended that stronger consideration be given in the annual reports to the treatment and disclosure of commercially sensitive information. Parliamentary scrutiny of annual reports is an essential link in the accountability chain. Such scrutiny can have direct benefit in improving the accuracy of information provided in annual reports and in promoting adherence to annual reporting guidelines.

The Committee also recognises the need for direct feedback to authorities from Parliament about the type of information presented in annual reports. Without such feedback, reporting entities are left in the dark about the quality of the information they have provided, how useful it is and how and where it could be expanded upon. The Committee considers that a valuable form of parliamentary scrutiny is that conducted by standing committees of both the Senate and the House of Representatives.

As a result of the Senate resolution on 14 December 1989, the legislative and general purpose standing committees of the Senate now undertake a systematic review of annual reports of all Commonwealth entities, although the Committee notes that the review process is somewhat uneven. The Committee also notes that scrutiny by the House of Representatives standing committees tends to be of a more ad hoc nature than that conducted by the Senate.

The Government, however, has indicated its intention to implement a recommendation made in the Committee's report No. 304, Guidelines for Departmental Annual Reports, that the House of Representatives standing committees formalise the scrutiny process. Against this background, the Committee has made a number of specific recommendations to bring about enhanced scrutiny by the Parliament. In this report, No. 309, the Committee has endeavoured to set the major parameters for the drafting of new guidelines for annual reporting by statutory authorities. While the report does not address all detailed issues in annual reporting--

—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the report.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, I was pleased to present the Committee's second report, entitled Change of status on grounds of spouse/de facto relationships. This report is part of the Committee's ongoing inquiry into the Migration Act and regulations as required by its terms of reference. Change of status from being a temporary resident to having permanent residency on grounds of marriage or de facto relationship has become more of an issue in recent years. Dramatically increased numbers of applications and allegations of fraudulent practices on the part of individuals and migration agents have heightened concerns that this means of remaining in Australia on a permanent basis is being abused.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee felt concerned about the increase in spouse applications because of the potential for abuse of the system. Applicants for change of status on spouse grounds are preferential applicants. They are given priority for assessment and they do not have to satisfy some aspects of the public interest test. It may also be said that the ability to change status from within Australia encourages people to do so in preference to their applying from overseas.

The amended Migration Act and regulations came into force on 19 December 1989. The legal regime established by that Act and regulations gave very little scope for visitors to change status on grounds of marriage or de facto relationship. However, it became clear very quickly that the new law was extremely harsh and operated unjustly in many cases.

On 15 February 1990 the previous Minister responsible for immigration, Senator Robert Ray, moved to institute a concessional arrangement for an interim period whereby visitors here legally could apply to change status on grounds of a spouse relationship with an Australian citizen. At the same time the Minister referred the whole problem to a working party of the National Population Council for consideration and recommendation.

The working party's recommendations were then referred to this Committee for its consideration. The working party recommended a return to the pre-December 1989 situation, that is, that visitors should be permitted to be able to change status on grounds of marriage or a de facto relationship with added measures to reduce fraud.

The Committee in November 1990 sent its own interim advice to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) essentially concurring with the recommendations of the National Population Council but recommending specific measures to reduce fraud and for the assessment of de facto relationships. The Committee also argued strongly for victims of domestic violence to be given special consideration for permanent residency, even though their marriages may have broken down.

Following the Committee's interim advice to the Minister, the Committee continued to investigate change of status and has made a number of conclusions and recommendations, principally in the following areas: collection and provision of statistical data; consideration of relevant cultural factors; marriage and immigration law; immigration marriage fraud; and marriage breakdown.

The Committee discusses at length the problem of immigration marriage fraud. The Committee notes that marriage fraud is of particular concern for the following reasons: firstly, the integrity of the immigration program is compromised when those who cannot qualify within the program secure permanent residence through a sham marriage; secondly, such sham marriages jeopardise the community goodwill which is necessary to sustain humane migration provisions facilitating family reunion; and, thirdly, prevention and detection of marriage fraud are expensive in terms of staff and time resources of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

The Committee attempted to assess the extent of the problem by analysing the statistical data relating to change of status; however, this proved to be difficult, given the unavailability of much of the data and the paucity of data provided by the Department, especially in its annual reports to Parliament. The Committee has commented particularly on this aspect of the inquiry in its report and has made several recommendations to rectify the situation.

Further, the Committee was unable to get a clear picture of the incidence of sham marriages, with much of the evidence being suggestive or based on departmental case officers' experience. The Committee has made recommendations in this area to ensure that the Department collects and maintains a more effective database.

The necessity for departmental officers to be made aware of the different cultural values and practices with regard to marriage is discussed in the report. Case studies discussed in the report illustrate the problems which can arise if officers responsible for assessing the validity of a relationship do not understand the relevant cultural factors. The Committee has recommended in the report that assessment officers receive appropriate training in cultural considerations.

The marriage issue itself is an inherently difficult one. Moreover, the current legislative procedures in place to assess the validity or otherwise of a relationship for immigration purposes have complicated the task that departmental officers are required to perform. The Committee is especially concerned at the lack of guidance in the procedures advice manuals relating to some areas of assessment; for example, the test for a genuine marriage for immigration purposes. The Committee regards this issue as central to the question of marriage and immigration and discusses it at length in the report. As well as recommending and endorsing a number of changes to the law, the Committee has recommended that the Department provide more data in its annual report and more support for its staff in the form of training and better guidance in the procedures advice manuals.

In January 1991, in response to the Committee's interim report, the Minister announced a number of changes to the procedures for changing status on the basis of marriage and de facto relationships. These included: increased evidentiary requirements through changes to documentary and interview procedures; a two-year period of conditional residence for eligible spouse or de facto applicants with limited sponsorship rights and permission to work; a requirement that a de facto relationship be in existence for six months prior to date of application; increased application fees; and provision for domestic violence victims to be granted permanent residence in certain cases.

On 15 April this year the regulations were amended to put into effect the changes announced by the Minister in January. The Committee welcomes the Minister's response to the recommendations made to him on this issue. However, the Committee does have some reservations about the 15 February amendments, particularly the mandatory condition that there be no material change in the circumstances of the applicant during the period of the validity of the visa. The Committee has recommended that such material changes be confined to changes in the nature of the marriage or de facto relationship, such as that the relationship is no longer genuine or continuing.

The regulations as a body continue to be a source of concern to the Committee given the complexity, frequency and number of changes being made. The Committee feels that such a degree of constant change to an already complex system, without the simplification foreshadowed by the Minister in May 1990, disadvantages all those involved in the immigration process, including applicants, departmental officers, community advisers and migration advisers.

All Committee members and staff have worked hard to finalise this report. I would like to express particular gratitude for the advice and assistance given to the Committee in its endeavours by Dr Kathryn Cronin, the Committee's legal consultant. Dr Cronin's objective and intelligent advice has enabled the Committee to pursue its inquiries effectively and has, without doubt, enhanced the quality of the Committee's deliberations. I would also like to thank the members of the Committee for the large amount of time they devoted to the work of this Committee. It is a very demanding and sensitive subject area. My thanks also go to the secretariat staff.

This report is the most comprehensive discussion of the issues in relation to marriage and change of status undertaken by any public body or institution in Australia. It compares favourably with other reports on this difficult issue prepared in the United States of America and the United Kingdom. I commend the report to all honourable members and urge that they study it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) for his comments. He is one of the members who have contributed to the development of this report by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. I compliment him on his very detailed exposition of the matters that have been addressed in this document tabled today.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be clearly understood that the report has been dealt with in two stages. The major problems associated with sham marriages, and the inability of the system to detect such situations when they occur and to make a proper assessment of the bona fides of parties entering into marriage relationships where immigration may be the principal objective, were addressed in an earlier report given by the Committee to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) and tabled in this House. The urgent questions that we thought were deserving of attention received some consideration by the Minister. A number of regulations, which have been detailed in this report, have been implemented to give effect to the decisions that the Government took in following the recommendations from the Committee. On behalf of the Opposition, I welcomed the decisions that the Government took as being an appropriate response.

We now have the more detailed report which deals with the way in which the Committee developed its recommendations. It gives the detailed evidence as to the situations which led to the recommendations that the Committee brought forward on the earlier occasion. Also in this report are some helpful comments about matters of detail, particularly the way in which the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs might develop its procedure and advice manual to ensure that officers are aware of the difficult cultural factors which impinge on marriage relationships and how they might be considered.

There is also advice in the report from the Committee in relation to the difficult question that arises where people are required to come forward two years after they have been given conditional entry, and where one party to a relationship may have been involved in some domestic violence, committed domestic violence or made the circumstances in which the parties' relationship was going to continue almost impossible for it to be maintained. In such circumstances-although I know we now have no-fault divorce in this country-obviously regard has to be taken of the possibility that a person who would otherwise have been able to obtain residency in Australia would be denied it because of being battered and bruised by a spouse in circumstances in which one could not conscionably believe that the individual should continue to remain in such a relationship. We did not want to see such people disadvantaged. There are recommendations dealing with those questions.

I want to go beyond those matters and raise questions that the Committee has brought forward, which are of very considerable and continuing importance and which are new. The first matter I want to draw to the attention of the Parliament is the significant absence of reliable data upon which conclusions can be drawn. The Committee helpfully offers the view that statistical data ought to be provided in annual reports in a standard format to enable comparison year on year. What is the situation? The situation the Committee found is that the Department changes the basis upon which statistics are kept. In some years it does not even publicly report information that it has been able to report before, and meaningful comparisons are not possible.

This matter needs to be addressed seriously by the Minister. The fact is that the very breakdown in administration in the immigration program that is occurring right now is personified by the problems we found in this area of change of status, marriage and de facto relationships. Of course, it is becoming obvious over time that the same difficulties are arising in other areas, particularly in relation to refugees and the decision the Government took in relation to Chinese students. The very border arrangements for this country are at risk because of the breakdown in administration. What the Committee is saying is that this material that is collected in the way of statistical data ought to be comprehensive and ought to be comprehensible, and we are concerned that it is neither comprehensive nor comprehensible.

The second matter I want to raise in relation to this report occurs in chapter 5. Essentially, what the Committee was there looking at was the way in which the Department deals with situations when it becomes obvious, after applications have been made for a change of status, that fraud was involved. I point out to the House those paragraphs of the report, on pages 70, 71, 72, 73, 74 and 75, dealing with the question of investigation following the grant of permanent residence.

While it is not a simple matter for immigration officials to refuse residence of spouse applications, the fact is that in the past the departmental officers, because of the possible administrative review of their decisions, have very often allowed people to apply for migrant entry to Australia on the basis of a spouse or de facto relationship where the officers seriously questioned the bona fides of the relationship but were uncertain about whether there was sufficient evidence. Because decisions could be challenged, because those people could go to the courts, the officers erred in favour of admitting people where fraud was likely to be involved.

Of course, when a marriage has involved fraud by one party alone, we have the situation where an aggrieved party will come along and say, `I have been taken. I didn't realise this was happening. My partner has obtained residence in Australia; he has walked out on me. What can you do about it?'. The fact is that inevitably in such situations people are aggrieved but the Department has been able to do very little about it.

Quite comprehensive reports are contained in this document of cases that have been before the Family Court where this has happened, cases where people have sought to have marriages nullified rather than enter into a divorce situation. Duped Australian partners came before the Committee and gave evidence of situations in which they had brought to the Department their concern and the Department was unwilling or unable to investigate such matters.

The Committee acknowledges that investigations after a spouse has acquired residence can be very difficult and that not all spouses reporting marriage shams are victims of marriage fraud. But what became apparent was that, while many reports are made, very few are investigated. Therefore, the Committee makes the recommendation that it is adamant that in clear cases when such bogus or sham marriages are detected the non-Australian partner, who has used the marriage to gain entry to Australia, be removed. The Committee particularly emphasises that the provisions that deal with overturning grants of residency in such cases ought to be used. The Committee also says that, in cases where people are involved in a number of marriages involving partners overseas and where they break down with rapidity, there should be some limitation on the number of spouses or de facto partners that people are, over time, able to bring to this country.

These are new issues that have been raised by the Committee; they are matters deserving of consideration. I certainly hope that the Minister will take on board the very positive and constructive recommendations offered by the Committee to ensure that the law in this area is effectively reviewed and repaired in order to ensure that our immigration system is properly operated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join the Chairman, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), and the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations in offering a few words on the presentation of the report Change of Status on Grounds of Spouse/De Facto Relationships. Firstly, I join with the Chairman in commending Dr Cronin and Robina Mills of the secretariat for the work they have done in presenting the report. Secondly, I say to the wider community that I think it is essential that reports of the detail included in this be available for greater scrutiny and consideration of future migration programs.

SPEECH.PARA: As a relative newcomer to this Committee, what has concerned me above all is that there seems to be so little accurate information available from which the public debate on immigration can proceed. It is an important issue; there are many strong views around the community as to the nature and character of our program; and, with the present horrific level of unemployment and the downturn in the economy, there are inevitably personal pressures against migration. It worries me that in so many instances our program has been developed on a basis of prejudice and lack of understanding and it seems almost to be a closed shop within the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Indeed, in this very area of change of status on the basis of marriage, there is a worry that in some instances the program is prejudiced by the degree to which overseas applications are expedited or delayed in their processing. There are a great many other factors outside the control of this Parliament and the program which influence where the program eventuates.

In the few minutes I have, I want to say a few simple things. The first is that both the Chairman and Deputy Chairman have referred to the availability of statistical data relating to change of status in the incidence of sham marriages. The Department has come along and said that it is a field that is rort with fraud, that there are a large number of instances occurring; yet there has been no statistical data to justify that allegation. I think that it is essential not only that the Department produces and collates data-it now claims to have the computer hardware and software to do so-but also that the data is published and available through this place to the public of Australia. Indeed, I think that the annual report should have attached to it statistical data that covers the whole range of circumstances affecting applicants, affecting each of the areas of the program, so that there is a better opportunity for the community to understand and reach conclusions upon it.

The report itself of course follows an initial letter submitted by the Chairman of the Committee and which is appended to the report. That letter, written on the basis that something needed to be done in the short term, highlighted a number of issues on which I feel strongly. The issue to which I refer briefly is that the letter, which, as I say, is attached to the report and is under the hand of the Chairman of the Committee, dated 7 November 1990, in referring to de facto relationships sets down a period of 12 months proven cohabitation as distinct from the six months that the Government itself has adopted.

That extra six months is desirable. I am most concerned that in this field of change of status there should not be a putting into place of an acceptance that marriage and de facto relationships are identical. In my view, 12 months cohabitation is far preferable, and I feel dissatisfied, therefore, that the Government has provided for only six months.

I am concerned that, in the nature of the overall circumstances of our program, there are many still unaware of the nature and character of how they will prove their change of status. In this report we have properly referred to the manner by which a genuine marriage for immigration purposes can be established. I commend that to the Department. Above all, to those in the community, as the Chairman has suggested, I make specific mention of the fact that there is a two-year waiting period within which they are allowed a temporary entry permit. That two-year waiting period is a qualifying period during which they must be seen to maintain their relationship.

In all, this report marks a number of practical and worthwhile comments in a field which is of high public moment. I commend the report to the Parliament. I wish that there were more time to speak on details of it. It is essential that the recommendations included in the report are accepted, and that the matters included in the dissenting report are used merely by the Department as matters of which it can take note during consideration of particular applications.

TALK.START.PARA: -The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Charles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Amendment Bill 1991 seeks to amend section 299 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, which deals with offences in relation to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Section 299 contains subparagraph (1) (d) (ii), which provides that a person shall not, by writing or speech, use words calculated to bring the Commission or a member of the Commission into disrepute. To contravene this subparagraph is an offence punishable, upon conviction, by a penalty, in the case of a natural person, of $500 or imprisonment for six months or both, and, in the case of a body corporate, of $1,000.

SPEECH.PARA: My Bill will omit section 299 (1) (d) (ii). That offending subparagraph gives to members of the Commission rights and powers and a form of protection not given to ordinary citizens, members of parliament, or, in fact, Justices of the Federal Court. That form of protection is a denial of freedom of the press and freedom of speech.

I am disappointed that I am today reintroducing a Bill which I first introduced into this House on 8 November 1990. It is disappointing that the Government has not seen fit to support my Bill and support the removal of this iniquitous section, this denial of basic human rights, from the Industrial Relations Act 1988.

However, it is appropriate today to examine the industrial relations debate in Australia as it relates to my Bill. Section 299 (1) (d) (ii) has been used only very selectively by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and its successor, the Industrial Relations Commission. I have noted previously the Commission's unsuccessful attempt to charge Mr H. R. Nicholls, editor of the Hobart Mercury, in 1911. In 1989 and continuing, the Commission has pursued Nationwide News, publisher of the Australian, and Mr Chris Gorrick, Federal Vice-President of Civil Air Operations Officers Association of Australia. However, it seems to me that those so-called offences were minor in comparison with statements reported in the daily press over the past few weeks since the Commission rejected accord mark 6.

The Victorian Secretary of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, Mr Wally Curran, is reported to have made one of the most blistering attacks of all time when he accused the Commission and the commissioners:
. . . of lacking ability, obvious bias, hypocrisy, impropriety and incompetence.

But Mr Curran said he unequivocally supported the role of the Industrial Relations Commission in central wage fixing; it is just that he did not like the selection criteria for commissioners in the recent national wage decision that had led to his attack. The Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Bill Kelty, when referring to that same decision, said:
It is a sickening decision but there is no reason for the trade union movement to eat the vomit.
The Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating), was reported in the Sunday Age as having said:

The problem is that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is thrashing around trying to find a role for itself in the new Australian economy. It's got in its mind a 60s role for itself in a 90s environment and it's just got to rethink its position or it won't have a position.
Asked if he was hopeful that the Industrial Relations Commission would see the virtue of the accord, Mr Keating said:

I don't need to be hopeful about them. They need to be hopeful about themselves. They're just a cog in a very big machine, and if they're feeling as though they're a tooth or two out of alignment with other cogs, well then they're feeling it correctly.
Clearly, those attacks on the Commission and commissioners have brought the Commission into disrepute. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) can either support my Bill or prosecute.

I suggest to the Government that it is timely that it support this private members Bill and rush it through the House and the Senate before the Federal Court is jammed with its mates and perhaps even a few of its members. If the Attorney-General allows section 299 (1) (d) (ii) to remain in the Industrial Relations Act and does not take action against those who are attacking the commissioners and the Commission, and clearly bringing the lot into disrepute, then he will be seen by the community as being derelict in the performance of his Commonwealth responsibilities.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 104a, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 April 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am very pleased to be presenting the National Measurement (Standard Time) Amendment Bill 1990 before the Parliament. I thank my colleagues the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), and the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), who I understand will speak on this Bill. In particular, I would like to thank the honourable member for Fairfax and the honourable member for Perth, who will be supporting the Bill. I would also like to thank the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), and a colleague from Western Australia, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who have played a significant role in the debate on this Bill. I also thank the National Standards Commission, and in particular, Mr John Birch from that Commission. He has been very helpful and has given expert advice on these matters.

The origin of time zones is significant. In the period up to the mid-nineteenth century, each town or city kept its own time. This time was determined by setting local clocks so that 12 noon corresponded to the sun being in its highest position in the sky. Travel from city to city took several days and the traveller was unaware of any problem. Local time, as it was known, persisted in most countries until the introduction of rail transport.

The experience in the United States was similar to that in other countries. Following the end of the Civil War in 1863, a multitude of railway and telegraph companies sprang up across the country. The introduction of these relatively fast forms of transport and communications caused difficulties when correlating time across large distances. A different time was kept by each railway for timetabling, and each city along the railway kept its own local time. The multitude of different local and railway times caused considerable confusion and led to the introduction of a system of time zones.

At the International Meridian Conference held in Washington in October 1884, the proposal that the longitude of the Greenwich Observatory be adopted as the prime meridian for longitude throughout the world was accepted. This resulted in the adoption of universal time based on this meridian and known as Greenwich Mean Time. A corresponding resolution provided for time zones based on a one-hour difference for every 15 degrees of longitude from the Greenwich meridian. These time zones have been adopted by almost all nations, with some variations for local conditions. Incidentally, I note that western and central continental Europe spans two time zones, but operates on a uniform time zone one hour ahead of coordinated universal time (UTC), that is, Greenwich Mean Time. This is done because it suits the business and recreational needs of western and central continental Europe.

The zone covers all members of the European Community except the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, Portugal, Greece and Turkey; all members of the European Free Trade Association, except Finland; as well as Yugoslavia, Albania, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland. In other words, all those countries choose to be in one time zone, and I know that the honourable member for Perth is aware of that too.

In November 1892 an inter-colonial conference of surveyors was held in Melbourne to consider the Washington proposals and it recommended the introduction of three time zones for Australia, in which the standard times would be the mean solar times of 120 degrees, 135 degrees and 150 degrees East of Greenwich. All States enacted time Acts in the 1890s, which defined the time zones and the mean solar times for use within those zones. It is under these Acts that the State and Territory governments have provided for daylight saving. I make the point that it arose only because at that stage we did not have a federal government.

The history of daylight saving is interesting. It was first introduced in Australia in World War I as an energy saving measure from 1 January 1917 to 15 March 1917. It was also introduced during World War II for the same reason: that is, as an energy saving measure. In 1967 Tasmania experienced a drought which depleted its water supplies for hydro-electric stations. In 1971 all States, except Western Australia and the Northern Territory, passed legislation for a trial daylight saving period.

I now turn to the arguments for daylight saving. The first, clearly, is the question of energy saving in a world in which energy saving is significant. We have seen the Tasmanian and wartime experiences, in which it was clear to everyone that energy saving was relevant. I believe that those arguments are still relevant and are particularly relevant across Australia, including Western Australia.

Secondly, there are recreational benefits. One can see in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne, for example, the enormous benefits to people of having those evenings in which they can undertake a range of recreations, be they walking the dog, sailing, playing tennis, going swimming or simply being together in the evenings. I know that from my colleagues and from talking to people in those other cities. It is something that we should also enjoy in Western Australia.

The micro-economic reform element is very important. When one talks to people in other countries, it is interesting to note that they place efficiency very highly in terms of their economic performance. If Australia is to have micro-economic reform, it is important that we look at issues such as this as ways of improving our performance. I believe it is central to the issue.

The fourth point is interesting: I talked to many people before taking on the issue of banning smoking on airlines. Many people said to me, `You should have a referendum about it'. I do not know of anyone who would argue now that we should have a referendum about it. In fact, the time for it had arrived, and the Government did the right thing in following the Caucus view, which was that we should ban smoking on airlines. I would also draw a parallel in the question of fluoridation of water. Were we to put to a referendum the question of fluoridation of water, it is interesting that we would find opposition to it, because there tends to be an opposition position. However, I do not know anyone to whom one speaks professionally or in terms of public health who would argue against the fact that fluoridation provides a public benefit. It does; it is something that needed to be done and it was important that it was done.

I now turn to the arguments against daylight saving, and the first is the question of States' rights. I would argue by analogy: if one says that the States are best at doing it, let us look at what a good job they did with the rail system in this country. We still cannot fix the mess, even with the national rail freight network, and we are still working on it. If the States are so good at it, that is one example.

My second point is: are people saying to me that the States should also have the power to set their own currency? Is that what they are saying by analogy? Section 51 placitum (xv) of the Constitution makes it clear that the weights and measures power is a power of the Federal government; it is not a power of State governments. Are people saying that State governments should have power over time and that they should also have power over currency? We would end up with an absolute mishmash both of currencies and of time. The position is clear and no-one has really challenged this constitutional right.

Incidentally, the legislation provides under clause 15d (4) that State Premiers and Chief Ministers can be consulted as to their views. I would reassure people who say that what we are seeking to do is to overrule the rights of the States that that is not the case. In fact, the big problem is in Western Australia, and this is the second argument about the role of State parliaments. The upper House in Western Australia actually blocked the corporations legislation that was designed to deal with corporate malpractice; it has also blocked this matter. However, it was the view of the lower House of the State Parliament and the Premier that daylight saving was important.

The answer to the third question-why do I not accept the outcome of the 1984 referendum?-is that that referendum was narrowly defeated. It is also important to observe that there is now a much greater consensus about daylight saving. In fact, there is now a very strong view in favour of daylight saving across eastern Australia. There are also more people now in Western Australia who are of the view that we need daylight saving, particularly for those micro-economic reform and efficiency benefits.

I am told that the dairy industry will suffer. That is extraordinary. No-one has told me that productivity in the dairy industry in eastern Australia or throughout Europe is below that of Western Australia; yet there is daylight saving in all those places. The argument has no substance. I accept that people do not like change, but sometimes there are changes one needs to make.

I am told that business people should get up earlier. We have tried to deal with that practically. Say a businessman starts his office at 7 a.m. In fairness to his staff, he tries to close the office at 4 p.m. However, there are people ringing up at 4.30 saying `Where have you gone?' and knocking on the door asking why the office has been shut. The answer is that his office starts at 7 a.m. and goes until 5.30 p.m. or 6 p.m. and he therefore pays overtime. If that is the logic of the argument, that is extraordinary. The point is that people have to deal with eastern Australia and with the local constituency, be they in business, parliament or other circumstances, and it makes sense to have rationalised time zones.

The next point I think is a sensible one. By being west of the meridian of longitude, Perth already experiences some daylight saving. I acknowledge that. It is also true of Melbourne vis-a-vis Sydney. That will arise whenever a meridian of longitude is the measurement device. Be that as it may, it is still necessary in terms of the overall argument to have this.

Finally, I have been told that I should not be talking about issues such as this, I should be talking about unemployment, inflation, et cetera. In fact, we already address those issues in the Federal Parliament. I resent people who would put up a smokescreen and say that we should deal only with those issues. This is an important issue. I believe it is one that we ought to be bringing before the Parliament. I thank my colleagues for their support. I think the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) will speak on this issue for the Opposition. In particular, I thank my excellent colleague the honourable member for Perth for his support in this matter. This is important legislation and I believe it should go through this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the National Measurement (Standard Time) Amendment Bill, but not because I am against daylight saving. I believe very strongly that, daylight saving having been instituted, it should at least be uniform around the country. I refer to 1989 when, from memory, the time was 9 o'clock in New South Wales, in Victoria and Tasmania it was 10 o'clock, in South Australia 9.30 and in Western Australia 6 o'clock. That is a disaster when one considers businesses having to cope with different times in different States.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a large continent-it is 4,000 kilometres across-so we have to accept time differences. I am rather disappointed that the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), for whom I have a great respect, has introduced this Bill. It proposes to do something to which I am opposed, that is, to force Commonwealth legislation on States which have clearly decided that they do not want this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it hasn't.

—I will read some of the reports which insist the State of Western Australia did not want daylight saving. The reports go back as far as 1975. As the honourable member for Stirling has pointed out, in 1975 there was a referendum. I want to read some reports of the results of that referendum. Fifty-three per cent of Western Australian residents voted against having daylight saving. The Canberra Times said:

SPEECH.PARA: The new Government decided to follow the lead of most of the eastern States this summer, but to cap the experimental daylight-saving period with a referendum asking the people to decide.
The people did have the time to see what they thought about daylight saving. After that the Government did go to a referendum. The article continued:
In retrospect it was the fairest thing to do, and no Western Australian can reasonably protest against the result.
Students of the democratic process are shouting hooray.
That was in 1975. The people made it very clear what they wanted in Western Australia, but the Government was not yet satisfied. Also in 1975, the West Australian said:
The people have spoken-and the result is binding.

But the result was not binding and the Government decided to have another go in 1984. Again the people were asked what they wanted to do about daylight saving. There was a referendum and this time 55 per cent of the people said they did not want daylight saving. That was an increase on the previous referendum. They had made up their minds. Be they right or wrong, the people of Western Australia had decided they did not want a referendum. On 9 April 1984 the West Australian said:
Despite the addition of quarter of a million voters to the State's rolls, the vote on Saturday was a virtual repeat of the 1975 result.
The Australian said:
The Premier, Mr Burke, said yesterday the result was clear-cut and the matter had been settled `for many years to come'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Burkie is no longer in charge.
—He is your authority, is he?

—I would hate to quote Mr Burke as my authority. If I could find a better authority, I would, but the fact remains that Mr Burke, whom honourable members opposite now repudiate, apparently-from the noise from the other side of the House, clearly repudiate-was then the Premier of Western Australia, and that was his comment on the referendum. The people in Western Australia made up their own minds; they made their decision. Whether honourable members opposite agree with it, or whether I agree with it, it was their decision. But it turns out that that is not good enough for the present Commonwealth Government.
—No, it is a private member's Bill, not the Government's.

—The honourable member for Stirling said that it is a private member's Bill and not a Government Bill. But the Government does seem to get into this. The West Australian of 8 December had a headline `Dawkins plan could force time zones'. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: CANBERRA: The Federal Government could force
notice the word `force'-
WA to adopt daylight saving, Education Minister John Dawkins said yesterday.

I realise it is not the responsibility of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), but, being a Minister in the Labor Government, he is certainly putting his authority behind this move to force Western Australians to accept daylight saving. The Minister had approached Western Australia on this matter and, perhaps in a particularly high handed attitude, had not even told the Premier. The article said:

Dr Lawrence said in the Legislative Assembly yesterday that she could not respond to Mr Dawkins' proposal because he had not had the courtesy to send her the letter before distributing it to the media.
It seems that unilaterally the Minister has decided that the people of Western Australia will have daylight saving whether they want it or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my Bill.

—The honourable member for Stirling keeps insisting it is his Bill. I would hate to take his Bill away from him; I give him back his Bill. I was looking at where the impetus for the Bill came from. On 25 February the Sydney Morning Herald said:

SPEECH.PARA: Late last year the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, raised the possibility of Federal legislation with Dr Lawrence.
A spokesman for Mr Dawkins confirmed that Mr Dawkins and the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Crean, had recently sought advice.
`The advice we have is that it is constitutional,' he said, `but you don't want to be seen to be imposing your will unnecessarily on something the States have always had a keen interest in.'

So here is not what really matters. I notice the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) is at the table. I am glad he is also interested in this Bill. There is then a rather key quote, which might refer to the claims of the honourable member for Stirling to own this Bill:
`It may be most appropriate if it came up as a private member's bill.'

It seems that the honourable member for Stirling got stuck with the Minister's Bill, so it has come up as a private member's Bill. That leads us to where we are now: this Government forcing the States and the people of Western Australia to do something they do not want to do. In giving the honourable member for Stirling his Bill back, I quote some of the comments he has made on it. He said:
`It still belongs to the fading curtains brigade-that somehow if daylight saving were introduced their curtains would fade,' Mr Edwards said.
That was in the West Australian of 19 April 1991. In his first reading speech, the honourable member for Stirling said:
Someone actually telephoned me and said, `My grass has been drier this summer, and if you bring daylight saving in it will get worse'.

I suggest to the honourable member for Stirling that he is trivialising some of the issues. This is a real issue to people in Western Australia where 55 per cent of the people voted against the Bill, and they did not vote on the basis of fading curtains.
I refer to another item in the newspaper about a Mr Johnson, who was directly affected by the daylight saving experiment. Mr Johnson is a farmer--

TALK.START.PARA: —He was travelling on the bus, was he?

—No, he was not travelling on the bus, and I do not know the relevance of the bus. Mr Johnson was getting up early in accordance with daylight saving to look after his cows. As the honourable member for Stirling might know, cows are found in the country and have to be looked after early in the morning. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Johnson stumbled in the dark at 6.15 am while trying to herd one of his cows into the milking bails.
His wounds became infected and he spent five days in hospital.
He was unable to resume milking until January 26.
Mr Johnson said he had to work in the dark during daylight saving because his cows needed to be milked before the tanker arrived at 8 am.

I have many more examples, not just of milking cows but of children in the country who have to go to school in the dark, who have to sit up late in the afternoon in the heat of the sun and who have to go home in the heat of the sun. There are radio broadcasts which do not come through very clearly in the dark or in the early hours of the morning. I have numerous examples here but my time has run out.

I simply make the point that the Western Australian people made their decision, be it right or wrong, that they did not want daylight saving in Western Australia. It is not up to the Commonwealth Government to change the game. It is centralism gone mad.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus), whose room is opposite mine across the corridor, and I agree on many issues. I think she understands that I am not necessarily a centralist, but she really has come up with a couple of puny arguments in respect of the National Measurement (Standard Time) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I wholeheartedly support the position of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). He is arguing here for a uniform system to exist across the country which is in place all year round so that we in Western Australia know that the time difference will be two hours and that it will be two hours all year round. This will mean that all those things which are in place-broadcasting and airline schedules-and which businesses have in place will be consistent and will not need to be redrawn every year. There will not be the need for the changes, the shifting and the swapping which occurs.
