The honourable member for Stirling has outlined very clearly the benefits, which occur principally in three areas: recreation, micro-economic reform and energy saving. Those issues are increasingly important--

TALK.START.PARA: —Interesting priorities.

—I did not put them in any particular order. They are increasingly important as our lives change. Honourable members opposite have to understand that the world has changed. We have the honourable member for Hawker talking about the circumstance 15 years ago and seven years ago, and talking about a popularity contest. In this place we are talking about making decisions, making judgments and passing legislation for the benefit of the whole community. We have to consider that. There are times when individual freedoms and individual choices, unfortunately, take second place; but that is because we believe the benefits to the whole community are substantial.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the arguments that have been thrown up are unbelievable. If I get the time, hopefully, I will be able to raise some of them in respect of this issue. What we need to consider first, and I will take it first, is the energy issue. It is an increasingly important issue. Environmental issues, land degradation, and the greenhouse effect are issues seminal to the future of our country and of our planet. They are important issues and need to be considered.

We have used daylight saving for energy conservation in war time and we have used it in times of particular need. In a country like Japan, one of the most energy efficient countries in the world, this issue is central in debate at the moment. It makes sense. I do not want to carry that any further, except to say that it makes sense, in terms of energy conservation, to introduce a move such as this. Honourable members on the other side of the House, over the last year or two, have been pushing the trolley of micro-economic reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Someone had to do it.

—The Opposition has been pushing it for two years; we have been pushing for it for 10. What I am saying is that it is important. If it was not an issue 10 years ago-when the honourable member for Hawker said that there should have been debates and referenda-it certainly is one now; and it is something that needs to be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to look at the disasters that have occurred in the past because we have not had some coincidence of view between all the States in this country. The honourable member for Stirling mentioned that we have never had a standard gauge railway system. In Western Australia recently we had the absurd position of the upper House rejecting the Australian Securities Commission legislation, which would have brought about uniform legislation for the protection of businesses and for company law in this country. We had an absurd situation where Western Australia wanted to go another way. All of the other States agreed. We had a coincidence of interests among all of the States; unfortunately, Western Australia disagreed. Eventually, because of public pressure and pressure applied by the Federal Government and other Liberal leaders in this country, to their credit, we have turned that situation around.

We have the absurd situation in Western Australia where we are trying to eliminate petrol rostering, which is an anachronism, an inefficient way of operating. It props up inefficient service stations. We have been trying, and the Minister for Consumer Affairs in Western Australia has been trying, to change that; but the upper House in Western Australia, controlled by the Liberals, for God knows what reason-certainly not for reasons of economic efficiency-is defeating that legislation.

Time and time again, if we look at the history of this country, we find those sorts of debates occurring and we find those sorts of obstructions. We are trying to smooth out the obstructions. This legislation is consistent with other Government decisions. I was at school in 1966, when we introduced decimal currency. I cannot remember whether there was a referendum held on decimal currency. I do not think there was. Is the Opposition suggesting that, if Western Australia had said, `No, we want to stay with pounds, shillings and pence', that position should have obtained? Of course it should not have obtained.

The introduction of metric measures was also mentioned. This legislation, indeed, comes under the Commonwealth purview of being in control of measurements and time. We introduced metric measures; we went to kilograms and kilometres. But there was no referendum to agree to that. We were talking about economic efficiency in this country, and we were talking about having a coincidence of interests right across the country. In many areas that has been the case. The suggestion by members of the Opposition that this is a States' rights issue is an absurdity. We get it thrown at us time and time again, but we have to look beyond the puny political advantage that may be gained by a few people in a particular position.

Some of the other arguments raised by the honourable member for Hawker were absurd. He suggested that school children will be unable to handle a change in the time zones. We only need to spend a summer in Europe to understand that it is daylight until 11 o'clock at night there. I do not hear those cries and complaints from families and children in Europe. People make adjustments. They are capable of making adjustments. We have to give them credit for having the ability to do so. It is absurd to suggest that they cannot.

The honourable member for Stirling mentioned farmers. Farmers in western Europe seem to be able to manage, even when it is daylight until 11 o'clock at night. Why is it such a problem if it is daylight until 9 o'clock at night in some places in Australia? It is absurd to put the view that we are not able to make these adjustments.

From Queensland we get even more ridiculous arguments. I will mention a number of them. Eidsvold Shire Chairman Peter Webster says that the daylight-saving trial led to grumpy and irritable people. Children had suffered by having to catch buses in the dark for long trips to school and it affected their concentration. Someone else in Queensland suggested that the divorce rate would increase because people would nag one another more because they would be awake longer. My God! It gets even more absurd. The doozey of them all was reported in the Australian on 14 August 1990:
One woman even advised an investigating task force, which recommended the introduction of two time zones, that her husband could be embarrassed if he had his morning erection on the bus to work . . .
There is some sense in Queensland. Most of the sense in Queensland comes, of course, from Brisbane.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Fairfax.

—The honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) is well known for his sensitivity and commonsense. A headline in the Courier-Mail says, `How daylight savers turn over a new leaf'. The Brisbane City Council reported a decrease in absenteeism with the introduction of daylight-saving. Not only that, but there was better work attendance and there were better work attitudes and practices. The other interesting thing it found out was that the use of Council facilities, including parks, bikeways, golf courses and swimming pools, all increased during daylight-saving.

SPEECH.PARA: This goes to the third element of those things that I mentioned-micro-economic reform, energy saving and, of course, recreation. This represents an important measure to unify Australia, not to set Australians apart. All of us who have to conduct business between the west coast and the east coast understand the difficulties that occur during the summer months.

This is an important piece of legislation. There are those who will disagree, but it is within the purview of the Parliament, it is consistent with our role here, to make changes to the way in which Australia functions to make us more efficient. It is absolutely central to our role. If we can improve the lives of people in Western Australia by giving them more recreation time, if we can improve the efficiency with which we operate and with which Australia does business with the rest of the country, and if we can save energy, then this important piece of legislation should be supported in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Somlyay Mr A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) has argued for uniformity. I believe that this is where his argument breaks down. If he wanted real uniformity across Australia, he would not have any time zone differences at all between Perth and Sydney if daylight means nothing.
—Uniformity all year round.
—I recall that when metric conversion occurred in Australia, it certainly did not happen without debate.
—There was no referendum.
—I recall a government member standing up in Parliament and saying that if God meant us to go metric, we would have had 10 apostles, not 12.
—We used to have troglodytes.
—Order! The honourable member for Perth!
—They are all on your side.
—Order! The honourable member for Perth will remain silent.

—I have been a supporter of daylight-saving very vocally in Queensland for quite some time. We achieved daylight-saving in Queensland recently. Daylight-saving was first trialled in Queensland in 1971 and quickly abandoned in 1972. As the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and the honourable member for Perth said with regard to Western Australia, the same happened in Queensland. Queensland experienced enormous growth in the following 20 years after the first daylight-saving trial, particularly in the south-east corner, where the growth was greatest. There was also massive growth in small business.

SPEECH.PARA: Summertime has only recently been reintroduced despite strong opposition. The division in opinion was clearly defined between the south-east corner of the State-the most populous area of the State-and the northern and the western sections of Queensland. Prior to Queensland's adoption of daylight-saving in 1989, business and tourism in the south-east corner of Queensland were affected adversely by the time differences during the summer months; there was no question about that. The community found it extremely difficult when dealing with its southern counterparts. In the southern States an hour would be lost in the morning waiting for Queensland businesses to open, with the reverse situation occurring in the afternoon where southern businesses closed an hour earlier than they did in Queensland. The worst situation was during lunchtime, when two hours were lost instead of one hour. The effective contact between the States was lost for two hours each working day.

Within the tourism industry-my electorate of Fairfax is a well-known electorate based on tourism and small business-the airline schedules had to be reprinted to take into account the different time standards between States. Summer tourists holidaying in border towns and cities of Queensland and New South Wales were continually changing their watches. I know my colleague the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) would agree with me. A lot of confusion occurred when people crossed the Queensland border into New South Wales at the Gold Coast. People were also inconvenienced by different trading hours.

The time difference was confusing for international airlines. I think we looked quite stupid in the eyes of the world when people arrived in Queensland for holidays via Sydney and found that they were getting to Queensland 15 minutes earlier than when they arrived in Australia. It was totally confusing.

With the reintroduction of daylight-saving in Queensland, the State has benefited both economically and socially. There is no question about that. From a business and economic standpoint, the introduction of summertime is in the best interests of the State as a whole. The phrase `the business of doing business' is vital to productivity and efficiency of the commercial and industrial sectors of the State.

The experience of past years when Queensland was not in the same time zone as the rest of the eastern seaboard showed that there was considerable disruption to commercial activities, with communications between interstate offices being particularly affected. In tough economic times-this is outside the scope of this Bill, but I am tempted to comment on the reason for our tough economic times-we cannot afford to be out of step with the interstate business community.

The problems in north Queensland and far-western Queensland are real. The honourable member for Perth and the honourable member for Stirling made funny comments and ridiculed people for their opposition to daylight-saving. But we cannot change nature's clock. That is a simple fact. The concerns of these people in the rural and remote areas are real and I have great sympathy for them.

The real problem is that we have to legislate for the good of the majority rather than the minority. That was the situation in Queensland. For instance, not many people would realise that Mount Isa, the most western city of Queensland, is almost due north of Adelaide. The sun rises in Mount Isa over an hour later than in Brisbane, yet Mount Isa is in the same time zone as Brisbane. Honourable members can well imagine the problems faced by children who have to get up before dawn to travel long distances to school in the dark, in some cases for a journey of more than an hour, and then return home in the heat of the afternoon.

The so-called benefit to north Queenslanders' social lives is an increase in leisure hours. With average temperatures in summer in the high 30s and low 40s it would be hard to imagine that anyone would take advantage of this leisure time. The southern States do not have the extremes of temperature that we experience in Queensland in our far north and west. As has been mentioned, with the sun not setting until well after 8.30 p.m., parents have the real problem of feeding their young children and getting them to bed during the heat of daylight hours.

Queensland did adopt daylight-saving and, as I said, I supported daylight-saving in Queensland. I believe it is important not to lose that competitive edge in business for five months each year. Daylight-saving in Queensland was championed by my Party-the Liberal Party of Australia-and, in particular, by Sallyanne Atkinson, the previous Lord Mayor of Brisbane. It was supported by the State Parliamentary Liberal Party, which influenced public opinion to the extent that the Ahern Government had no choice but to introduce daylight-saving.

The Queensland Government passed legislation in 1989 to trial daylight-saving for a year, and a committee was established to monitor the success or otherwise of the trial. It is now history that that trial has been accepted and daylight-saving is a permanent feature in Queensland.

Queensland legislation establishes a procedure to make it possible for local communities to seek to change the times of various activities such as school hours, hours of employment and trading hours, to lessen the perceived adverse effects of summertime. Local authorities are being asked to coordinate their submissions from their local communities suggesting ways to alleviate problems which might be seen as arising out of the introduction of summertime.

While the majority of people in Queensland believe that summertime is essential, they recognise that it does disadvantage others. A mechanism has been set up in Queensland-it could also be set up in Western Australia-to allow variation to trading hours, school hours or other hours which would help lessen their burden.

As I said, I support daylight-saving but I do have reservations. As my colleague the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) said, this is not a question of daylight-saving but a question of States rights. There are special circumstances in Western Australia, as the honourable member for Stirling has pointed out, in that Perth already has half an hour daylight-saving because of its geographic position. However, I believe that it is not a Commonwealth function to legislate for the people of Western Australia regarding daylight-saving; it is a State matter.

My colleagues from Western Australia the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), with whom I have discussed this, and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) support what I have said. They believe that it is a States' rights matter, and the people of the State have spoken on two occasions in referenda. If the circumstances have changed so radically, as the honourable member for Perth and the honourable member for Stirling claim, then perhaps it is time for another referendum on the issue.
Regarding the question of uniformity across Australia, I suggest that this House would be better served by--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for debate has expired. The Bill will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Industrial Relations (Membership of Associations) Bill 1990 will give legislative effect to the concept of voluntary union membership, voluntary membership of industry associations and the true end to the closed shop in Australia. The Bill is legislation at least two decades, if not more, out of its time. It is a Bill which should have been introduced in this House, passed and enacted in the middle of this century, not in its dying years.

Except for the Australian Council of Trade Unions, union officials, delegates, shop stewards, safety officers et cetera, who make up the union bureaucracy, there are very few people in this country who believe any longer that compulsory union membership-the closed shop-has any place in Australian industrial relations. It is largely the high degree of unionism in the public sector of our country which props up the entire system.

A research poll by the Roy Morgan Research Centre, published on 8 November 1989, indicated that 87 per cent of the general population believes that union membership should be voluntary and that 82 per cent of union members hold the same view.

There is, of course, no logical reason why individuals, groups of individuals, associations or companies should be compelled to join or be members of any association. Such compulsion is, in fact, undemocratic. This Bill is an act to ensure that in Australia, in the future, membership of associations will be truly voluntary. This Bill is clearly intended to give effect to community and individual concerns. We shall once and for all be finished with the outdated and draconian implications and costly practical results of the closed shop.

I remind honourable members that the closed shop is true restraint of trade and should represent a violation under the Trade Practices Act. Over and over I have said that this is 1991, not 1891, and the time has long since passed when we gave away those attitudes to industrial relations which were fostered during the industrial revolution, and as a result of what we would today call inhumane treatment of employees by business owners and managers during the late 1800s and very early 1900s. Those times have gone and the majority of management throughout the developed world well recognises the value and contribution of the human work force to any company or enterprise operation.

Over time we have become increasingly aware of the social responsibility of employers and the enterprise responsibility of employees. Both have learned that they must work together for the common good of the enterprise, and share the economic gains of the enterprise through wages and conditions of employment for employees, and a share of the profits for the owners who have invested in the enterprise.

In Australia today, as in general throughout the industrialised world, union membership is in a long term decline. Between May 1982 and August 1990 the proportion of employees belonging to unions in our country fell from 49.5 per cent to 40.5 per cent. The proportion of union membership in the private sector is down to 31 per cent. Among female employees it is down to less than 35 per cent, and among those aged 15 to 19 years it is down to 25 per cent and falling. Among casual employees it is only 19 per cent. No doubt, if the Public Service were to be freed up, union membership would fall even more rapidly.

I am led to believe that many on the other side of this House and those within the union bureaucracy view my contribution to the national debate on industrial relations as being to the extreme right. Personally, I find it difficult to understand the rationale behind such an hypothesis, as I view this private member's Bill as being nothing other than a moderate, middle-of-the-road proposal to give equal, individual human rights to individuals in our Australian society.

Many members of the Australian Labor Party constantly remind us of their lower or middle class socio-economic backgrounds. I share with those members opposite such a heritage. My three decades-plus of active working life began as a so-called exploited youth in a so-called industrial sweatshop. From that point, my working life spanned such experiences as labourer, carpenter, draftsman, welder, fitter and turner, trainee, foreman, engineer, manager and managing director. In my working life, which spans four continents and almost countless countries, I had not, until I arrived in Australia, discovered any system of labour law which was as incomprehensible and against the best interests of employees as the system of labour relations which we employ in Australia. That system is, of course, centrally, bureaucratically and legally controlled.

The fact that we legally allow, and in some cases legally enforce, compulsory union membership is beyond my comprehension. Even as a piece rate paid labourer in the potato fields of south-eastern Virginia, I could not imagine anything worse than being required to join a union of my fellows and allowing the union hierarchy to negotiate for me my wages and conditions of employment. Under the Australian system of national awards and an accord between those who were supposed to represent my interests and the Federal Government, I would not have had a job because no-one would have been able to afford to employ me. There is no possibility that any national agreement on wages and conditions of employment could have satisfied the economic imperatives of the potato industry in south-eastern Virginia.

It is indeed a sad reflection on our society that we allow in this day and age a violation of human rights wherein we require an individual to become a member of a union of his peers before he is entitled to accept a position of employment. How sad it is that a farmer who has been driven by economic circumstances from his farm to the city and who wishes only employment where he can use his skills and his ability and desire to work hard for the wages he is able to obtain is required to join a union and pay his union dues before he is allowed on a construction site in a major capital city in our country. If unions are for the benefit of employees, if they exist to advance the case of working men and women, then why should employees or contractors be forced to join a union when they are quite willing and able to look after their interests themselves?

As long as we allow and condone compulsory union membership, we allow and condone union management bureaucracy which is under no compulsion to look after the best interests of its membership. I have no doubt that unions have a place and a role to play in whatever system of industrial relations labour law we finally adopt in Australia. But that place should be one of service to its membership, not one of dominance, coercion or legal requirement for compliance in membership.

As companies must compete in the marketplace for purchasers of their goods and services, so should unions be required to compete for their membership in the market for labour. If employees decide to negotiate individually employment contracts with management, why not? If groups of employees decide to negotiate conditions of employment with management, why not? If employees decide to form groups of unions or join a national union body to negotiate with employers, why not? Why must we have any system of compulsion with respect to wage and employment condition determination? The answer is that we need not.

There are many on the other side of this House and many in the Senate who agree with my sentiments. I call on those members of the House and of the Senate who agree that compulsory union membership or compulsory membership of any association is a denial of basic rights to join with me and support my private member's Bill for voluntary membership of associations. I thank the House, and I look forward to honourable members' support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally oppose this private member's Bill-the Industrial Relations (Membership of Associations) Bill. I find it one of the most objectionable Bills that have ever come before this House. I am very proud to stand up and support compulsory membership of unions and of associations and to fight for the very principles we fought for 100 years to achieve in this country: that is, the right for working men and women to have decent conditions to live under. Those conditions have been achieved only through the establishment of the trade union movement in this country and the political arm of the trade union movement, which is the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past 6,000 years of civilisation we have seen slavery-and, sadly, still see it today in many nations of the world-people who are oppressed, and countries without freedom. It is only in those nations where we have a strong and viable union movement that we actually have democracy. I suggest to those people who support this Bill that they talk to Lech Walesa and the Polish workers, who got rid of communism through the strength of the union movement. Throughout the tough times of the last 10 years, members on both sides of the House were proud of the way in which those Polish steelworkers and shipbuilders stuck up for freedom.

This issue goes further than just a private member's Bill. It demonstrates what is different in philosophy between the Labor Party and the Opposition. There is a massive difference in attitudes towards the working men and women of this country. There is no doubt that, if compulsory membership is dissipated and the union movement membership becomes weaker, the unions will have a harder job financially representing the work force.

But it goes even further than that because there are other associations that are compulsory, and I have belonged to one. Canefarmers in Queensland belong to a compulsory union; we are all members of the Queensland canegrowers organisation. On this premise, of course, the levies they pay compulsorily would also be waived and we would see the great work that the Queensland canegrowers do disappear. If it were voluntary, people would simply say, `Well, things are tough; we won't belong to that association'.

I quote a statement by Mr Peter McIntosh, President of Burnett Queensland Grain Growers Association. This is the first time and probably will be the only time that Mr McIntosh and I agree. He certainly does not belong to my philosophy. About the grain industry he says:

The industry must make the freeloaders pay, because the QGGA members are sick and tired of contributing all the funds while other people sit back and let them pay, while the freeloaders get all the benefits for nothing.

I endorse those views, as I do with regard to the attitude that all canefarmers take about their association. Of course, what is repugnant about people who accept pay rises and the benefits that flow through from unions and their representation and from the members who actually contribute is that they are happy to have a free ride. It takes money to take applications to the Commission; it takes money to fight for workers' conditions; and if membership drops the unions are less able to do it.

I am fully aware that the philosophy on the other side of the House is to bring in voluntary agreements. No individuals, no five or six or 10 people, can represent themselves in any negotiation with employers as adequately as a union can. Firstly, they do not have the expertise; they do not have the skills. Worse than that, I challenge anyone who has the other view to tell me how, in a recession, a group of sawmill workers can sit down with their employer and negotiate anything that would be beneficial to them. The only income they would receive would be much less than they have now. What voluntary agreements do is take away the conditions that have taken 100 years of fighting to achieve.

It is interesting that the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) mentioned what it was like working in Virginia. While I have never worked there, I am fully aware of what it was like working in Virginia in 1860. The workers had voluntary agreements there too, but they were in chains, and it took Abraham Lincoln to change that structure. The honourable member mentioned other countries that he thinks have a more flexible and better system of working. We should also remember the Triangle fire in the United States. A group of women were working in a textile factory, where they were locked in for something like 12 hours a day. A fire broke out and they were burnt to death. Those sorts of things cannot happen any more, and certainly cannot happen in this country because we have a strong trade union movement.

Prior to 1891, of course, we did not have organised labour and we did not have a political arm to represent the working men and women in this country. The conditions that have flowed on since then have come only through the representation of the union movement and the Labor Party. If those things were to change and if we did not have a strong union movement today, we would go back to that very same position. Human nature does not change. People may become more eloquent, people may be better dressed, but the fact is that human nature has not changed in 6,000 years. Anyone who thinks it has need go only to places such as South Korea, the Eastern bloc countries and some of the countries in the South Americas and Africa to see that that is exactly what happens when there is not a strong trade union movement and a political party that is prepared to fight for the working men and women. Closer to home, in my city of Bundaberg I am very proud to say that my family has been involved in organised labour, as well as farming and the sugar industry, for some 100 years. In fact, my grandfather's brother, the late Fred Courtice, was the first organiser for the Sugar Workers Union.

At that time we had competition in the workplace between the sons of European immigrants who were looking for work and voluntary agreements set up by the early plantation owners. Those voluntary agreements were between the plantation owners and men from the South Sea islands. It was called Kanaka labour and it was slavery. They were paid 10 shillings per year and Fairymead plantation, which banned my great-uncle from entering because he was trying to fight for organised labour, actually set up its own religion. Kanakas were paid 10 shillings per year and were sold tickets to heaven for 10 shillings per year, and so the 10 shillings were taken back. They worked six days per week for nothing, and on Sundays, to get around the archaic laws of the day, they were released to wander around the district.

That went on until 1906. It was phased out after 1906, only because of the Sugar Workers Union, which became the Australian Workers Union in 1913, and with the election of the T. J. Ryan Labor Government in 1915. That is how those conditions changed. I quote from an article referring to what Uncle Fred said in those early days. It states:

At Bonna, men had to work from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. six days a week, the only concession being a 4 p.m. finishing time on Saturdays. He admitted Buss Brothers provided good food. At Avondale, 58 hours work was expected for one pound ($2) per week plus rations, with a tin of jam supposed to last the men for a week.
That is the sort of attitude that existed prior to the union movement and the Labor Party getting established, and that is the sort of attitude that would exist again.

I have no hesitation in opposing this Bill and opposing voluntary agreements. There is no doubt that we need to be flexible in the workplace, and the trade union movement has demonstrated that, but only the union movement can adequately represent the hopes and aspirations of the working men and women in negotiation with their employers and the Government. That is what has happened over the past eight years under the Hawke Government. We have seen commonsense between the workers, the unions and the employers.

That is why non-farm unit labour costs have been reduced by some 10 per cent in real terms since Labor came to office. That is why, with the support of the trade union movement, we have been able to see inflation come down, as was announced yesterday, to the historic low level of 4.9 per cent. Even if the figures for the next quarter are half as good as those of the last quarter, we will come in at about 3.8 per cent for the year. That gives companies an opportunity to be more competitive. It gives our economy a better opportunity to be placed in the world scene, and that has come about through cooperation between the trade union movement and employers, whether it be the Confederation of Australian Industry or the Metal Trades Industry Association and the Government. That is what it is about.

It is sad that there is a psychological attitude exhibited by honourable members opposite to still want to stand on the working men and women of the country, as has always been the case. The real difference in this House is that honourable members opposite represent capital and we represent labour. By that, I mean that honourable members opposite represent greed, and I am very proud to say that we represent manhood and womanhood. That has not changed, and it never will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in support of the Industrial Relations (Membership of Associations) Bill 1990 and I congratulate the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) on his hard work and initiative in bringing this Bill before the House. I find it interesting that the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) supports compulsory union membership. Most honourable members on his side of the House would say that compulsory membership of unions does not exist.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I wish to place on the record my disbelief that the need still exists in 1991 to debate this matter. It amazes me that, in a democratic society such as ours, freedom of choice with regard to union membership is not an entrenched feature of our industrial relations system. In 1991, compulsory unionism has no place in our society. This Bill before the House gives legislative effect to the concept of voluntary union membership, and I am certain that such a concept would have the support of the Australian community. Indeed, as the honourable member for La Trobe stated in his speech, a recent Roy Morgan Research Centre survey indicated that 87 per cent of Australians support voluntary unionism and that 82 per cent of union members support voluntary union membership.

This country has a proud history of upholding democratic traditions and supporting and encouraging the individual. Central to our democratic tradition is the right of freedom of association. As part of its industrial relations history, Australia has had a strong and active union movement. The right to form and join unions has been an essential part of our industrial system, but the right not to join a union has never been entrenched into our system. In 1991, it is time that we corrected the ledger.

The trade union movement has a legitimate and central role to play in the Australian system of industrial relations, and unions have achieved many worthwhile reforms and concessions for their members. As one who supports the great democratic traditions, of which freedom of association is a central feature, I would defend the right of any Australian to join a trade union but, equally, I would defend the right of any Australian not to join a trade union. Surely, in a democratic society, both rights must be guaranteed under the law of the land.

Unionism in Australia is declining. The decline has been caused by union bureaucrats who have lost touch with their own membership. Union membership has fallen to just over 40 per cent of the work force, and in the private sector it has slumped to 31 per cent. If it were not for de facto compulsory unionism which exists in the public sector, the union movement in Australia would be facing a complete crisis. The decline has come about because union bureaucrats have attempted to protect their own vested interests. They have forgotten that their main role is to secure a fair wage and good and safe conditions for their members.

To highlight my point that the trade union leadership has lost touch with its own constituency, I remind the House of the fiasco currently taking place in my home State of Victoria. Honourable members will recall the disgraceful actions of Martin Ferguson, President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), and John Halfpenny, Secretary of the Victorian Trades Hall Council, who in January of this year attempted to extort $10,000 from Tennis Australia in return for an Australian Tennis Open free of interference from unions and the anti-apartheid movement. The letter of demand appeared on ACTU letterhead. One can only hope that the Victorian Opposition pursues this matter to its rightful conclusions. Such actions by the ACTU highlight why ordinary Australians should not be compelled to join a union.

I believe that the vast majority of Australians-unionists and non-unionists alike-would be ashamed of the actions of Martin Ferguson and John Halfpenny. Yet under today's industrial relations system many Australians are forced against their will to pay subscriptions to unions affiliated to the ACTU. Hardworking Australians want nothing to do with the type of behaviour displayed by Ferguson and Halfpenny, and this is why this legislation is both necessary and long overdue.

Those who advocate compulsory unionism fail to realise that our industrial society has changed dramatically during the course of the last century. In today's industrial society, employers and employees need not be at loggerheads; in the vast majority of cases, management and employers are fully aware of the value and contribution of employees. In 1991, most employers and employees wish to work together for the common good of the enterprise so that all parties can benefit from the success of the business. In most cases, there is no need for unions to negotiate wages and conditions, as this can be successfully achieved between employer and employee. The fact that 60 per cent of Australians are not members of unions must be a clear indication that many employees are capable of negotiating satisfactory wages and conditions; so why waste money paying union subscriptions when employees can negotiate directly with their employers?

I am amused when I hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) attempt to denigrate the Liberal and National parties by describing those on this side of the House as conservatives. The truth is that the Australian Labor Party is the conservative party when it comes to the issue of industrial relations. It will not move with the times; it will not accept that many of the features of Australia's industrial system belong to a time long past.

In 1991, this Labor Government continues to support a centralised wage fixing system, outdated and inefficient work practices and compulsory unionism-as we heard from the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) a little earlier. It has immersed itself in an institutionalised labour system that it is afraid to change. The Labor Party is afraid to implement change. It owes too many favours to its mates in the union movement.

Many Australians are compelled and, in some cases, coerced to join a trade union. The trade union they are forced to join will be affiliated with the ACTU and, therefore, affiliated with the Labor Party. Many Australians are dismayed that a proportion of their union subscriptions are donated to the Australian Labor Party. This is surely most undemocratic and one of the most objectionable aspects of compulsory unionism in Australia. It clearly explains why this Labor Government is unwilling to introduce reform in this area and why the Labor Party will not support this Bill.

Earlier in my speech I said that I would defend the right of any Australian to join a union. I believe that unions have played, and will continue to play, a valuable role within our industrial relations and sociopolitical systems. However, the union movement must be willing to be part of a free market. Like business, it must be subject to the laws of demand and supply. If people wish to join a union, so be it-as long as it is of their free choice. There must be no compulsion. Unions must offer a service to their membership and, like businesses, they must compete in the market. If their product is good, they will have no trouble in attracting members. The days of institutionalised labour are over. The Labor Party must now move with the times.

This Bill offers a challenge to the Labor Party. This Government has espoused the virtues of deregulation with regard to the private sector. We have witnessed the deregulation of the banking industry. The Government has flirted with the concept of privatisation, and most recently we have listened to the Government preach about the removal of tariffs. This Bill offers the Government the opportunity to embrace the concept of deregulation within the labour market and to relegate the `closed shop' to the history book of Australian industrial relations. I urge honourable members to support this private member's Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in opposition to the Industrial Relations (Membership of Associations) Bill, which, I draw to the attention of the House, raises the issue of the denial of the right of free speech in a democratic society, which is surely a proposition that cannot be supported here. Any debate on this provision must be constrained by the fact that the question of the breadth of the particular provision which it is proposed to delete from the Act is currently before the High Court of Australia. However, we are of the view that the provision goes no further than the common law concept of scandalising the court and that the defence of fair comment is available to any action undertaken under the provision.

SPEECH.PARA: Such a provision is not uncommon in other Commonwealth legislation. A similar provision existed in the now repealed Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The same wording is used in provisions of legislation applying to the Coal Industry Tribunal, the Defence Force Disciplinary Appeals Tribunal and the local coal authorities. I wonder whether honourable members opposite suggest that all those provisions, and hence those tribunals and authorities, should be disbanded. But what is really at the heart of the repeal of this provision is a questioning of the whole notion of the rights of Australians in the context of the Industrial Relations Commission and the rights of Australians to join trade unions and to find support within that.

For us on this side of the House, the right to join a trade union, to participate in a trade union, and to find unity in the work force is at the very heart of our existence: it is at the heart of the Labor movement. Having just celebrated our centenary at Barcaldine, where we saw the troops brought in yet again to fight the work force-which saw the birth of the Labor Party-we hear now, 100 years later, the same proposition pursued by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in terms of the Opposition's industrial relations policy: `If waterfront reform does not happen, we will bring in the troops'. It is the same thing which saw the very birth of our movement and the right of ordinary men and women to work with honour and dignity.

I am constantly amazed at the discussions which emanate from the other side and in which they raise the issue of unions, unions which are affiliated with the Labor Party, and the way in which those processes operate. Of course, we never hear of the way in which big business is allied to business organisations which make very large donations to the Liberal Party. All of this is fair and just. This is what a democratic society is all about and it is what Australians have fought for-the right of free speech.

It is a nonsense to suggest that unified labour, which supports a particular Party on this side of the House, is wrong, and that big business, which supports a particular Party on the other side of the House, is correct. It is an absolute nonsense. It is the kind of confrontationist policy which we have seen, which I saw when growing up through the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s, and which has placed Australia in the kind of industrial backyard that it is in now.

We have heard much about the arguments for enterprise bargaining. Indeed, the difficulties with enterprise bargaining have come from the heart of the actual business corps. I am constantly amazed when we hear people ask, `Why should people join unions? They can negotiate with employers themselves'. Nonsense! We all have anecdotal evidence. We all know the kind of power that employers have over people, particularly in times when fewer jobs are available-workers are told they will take a cut or there will be no job. Reality!

I attend a chamber of commerce in my local electorate where local business people stand up and say, `Isn't it good. None of these people belong to unions. You can pay them what you like'. And they do. They espouse that as being something that is good, valuable and, even worse, a smart business practice. I say that it is exploitation. The need for our unions and the union movement to protect the rights of workers and the conditions under which they work is now as strong as ever.

It is true that the unions have declining membership. One of the reasons for that is that over a period of time, because of the struggle of unions for the kinds of rights that they have achieved, people take the conditions which they enjoy now for granted. They do not understand where their award wages came from; where sick leave came from; where recreational leave came from; or where any of their other rights and conditions came from. Many of our young people assume that they have always been so, not that some of them are only a mere 10, 15 or 20 years old.

When people are in crisis, whom are the first people they turn to? It is the unions. They say, `I am not a member of the union, but can you help?'. It is the same cry all the time. Those very same people who are not members of a union are quick to take the pay rises, to take the award conditions, to take the health benefits and to take the occupational health and safety benefits. If we are going to be preferential about such treatment, let us be fully preferential and say that only those people who are members of unions get the same benefits, in the same way as it is only members of business organisations who participate in their processes who get the same sorts of rights. But we have heard all the arguments about preferential clauses.

I am particularly interested to read that the father of laissez-faire business, Adam Smith, back in 1776-perhaps before the founding of Australia-exhorted all of us to look at the way in which people treat labour:
All for ourselves and nothing for other people, seems, in every age of the world, to have been the vile maxim of the masters of mankind.
Indeed, such a notion is still very much prevalent. Further he said:

Our merchants and master-manufacturers complain much of the bad effects of high wages in raising the price, and thereby lessening the sale of their goods both at home and abroad. They say nothing concerning the bad effects of high profits. They are silent with regard to the pernicious effects of their own gains. They complain only of those of other people.

How right that is! In this House we have heard constantly, and have read on the front pages of the printed media, that the reason manufacturers are unable to export is the high wages they pay their workers. That is a nonsense, and yesterday proved it, once again, in terms of the low inflation rate, which is lower than those of most of our competitors. Indeed the very countries which members of the Opposition emulate-Germany and Japan-have very strong and powerful labour movements. Indeed there are mega-unions within Germany which play a significant role in terms of negotiating or enterprise bargaining and membership of unions.

At the heart of the criticism of the Industrial Relations Commission, of its existence and of this very Bill is an onslaught on the whole notion of the way in which industrial relations in this country operate. It is imperative that members on this side of the House remain true to our tradition. It is often said that we on this side are now lawyers, teachers and doctors. Indeed we are, because for 100 years people in the labour movement fought and struggled so that we might have an education and have part of the gains in the society in which they worked. I have great pride in the fact that I was entitled and able to get a university education because I worked for it and because people fought and struggled. It was not because my parents were rich-they were not-but because we have a society which, through the hard work of the labour movement, has seen every Australian treated with equality and dignity. The notions of equality and of people being treated fairly and with dignity are inherent in the Australian Labor Party.

This industrial relations amendment Bill is an attempt to undermine the whole process in which the Industrial Relations Commission is part and parcel of the operation of the industrial relations structure with Australia. The Government rejects this out of hand, and hopes that the labour movement will go from strength to strength. I hope that we never see again the troops out fighting the workers of this country, which is the promise of the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 February, on motion by Mr Scholes:
That this House:
(1) is concerned at the enormous growth in the amount of goods stolen from private homes and the apparent failure of police forces to uncover the disposal networks which clearly must exist; and

(2) calls on the Minister for Justice to establish a special Commonwealth/State task force drawn from the various law enforcement organisations to carry out a comprehensive investigation into the movement of, and subsequent disposal of, the extremely large amounts of goods being stolen from private homes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion relating to the disposal of stolen goods, brought forward by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). I commend the honourable member for this motion. I know it is an issue that he has been concerned about for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the stealing of goods is imposing a massive cost on Australia of probably something like $200m in excess insurance premiums alone. I do not think that it is beyond the power of man's ingenuity to devise a scheme which would make it much harder for stolen goods to be sold or disposed of, or easier to be traced. It has been suggested that a lot of thieving is the result of drugs. Frankly I doubt that very much; it is much more likely to be, and has the hallmarks of, a well organised plan where groups of people move into a house, often in broad daylight, and strip it completely. That has a devastating effect on the owners of the property; it often puts them into a strained financial position if they are not fully insured. It leaves them with a sense of assault on their person, because many people regard their homes as very much their castles and extensions of themselves.

If we are to be genuine about tackling this issue, there must be a method of marking general household goods. I think it is feasible to stamp all Australian furniture sold with numbers that could not easily be removed, and that would lead to the furniture being traceable. Numbers are already impressed into electronic items, and if people were to take the trouble to register those items, it would help to protect them, and the country, and it would bring down the high costs imposed by this dangerous and discomforting practice of thievery.

In passing I note the comments made by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) who tried to turn debate on this sensible motion into an attack on the Victorian Government, as though this problem occurs only in Victoria. The honourable member cited the example of police staffing in Ballarat, but I would say many places in Australia could claim to be understaffed in respect of the police. I notice that the police staffing level in Ballarat is higher than that of Kalgoorlie, which is, I would suggest, a town that would have more problems requiring police attention than Ballarat. I wonder whether it is because Western Australian police are more efficient than the Victorians. I doubt that, although I note that Western Australia does many things much better than the rest of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks very much.
—There is no doubt about that. I could go on at great length about what Western Australia does better.
—Victoria has the best police force in Australia bar none.

—The Western Australian Police Force is also very good. It seems that in his attack on the Victorian Government, the honourable member for Ballarat is actually also attacking the Victorian police. If we were to devote our attention to this issue, we could tackle it. We are faced throughout Australia with a misallocation of police resources. I do not blame the police for this; in fact, I blame State governments. In my view road traffic infringement charges, for example, are used as revenue raising devices and not for road safety purposes. I note that the multanova camera, beloved of the Victorian State Government and introduced recently into Western Australia, is often placed in locations where everybody gets caught. On freeways, for example, there is a tendency for traffic to be moving at such a speed that everyone is caught. I do not see any addition to road safety at all in this, and it is a practice I would very much discourage. It locks up police numbers that could be better used in other areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I get back to this proposal to register all items or have a catalogue. I do not believe it is necessarily the role of government to become involved here. The big gainers here will be insurance companies, which, as big contributors to the fire-fighting capacity of Australia, have, I believe, a responsibility to look at this issue to see what they can do to remedy it or greatly reduce it. I know it can be done.

In Australia we are alarmed at the increase in the incidence of car theft. The same phenomenon occurred in Ireland some years ago. I spoke to a fellow recently who has some knowledge of the situation and who said that there was a large push in Ireland to get all vehicles fitted with antitheft devices. These varied in sophistication, but there is no doubt that this move massively reduced the incidence of car theft in Ireland. I believe the same thing could be done in this country and also in respect of household goods. I think the population generally has a responsibility to try to protect itself, and it is beholden on householders to make their houses as burglar proof as possible and to observe all the guidelines issued by the various police forces, which tell people what to do.

When we flaunt our absence from home we are asking for trouble, not only as it impacts on ourselves, but also as it impacts on the whole of society. It is simply not good enough to say, `I have a right to be left unaffected. I have a right to be safe from this sort of thievery'. Theft does occur in society; it is an unfortunate facet of society. We have a responsibility to make efforts to protect ourselves to the best of our ability. I believe that those efforts are, and should be, rewarded by means of insurance rebates. In respect of motor cars I believe that we should look at rebates on registration. After all, a large amount of work for police forces and others in society results from the stealing of vehicles, and the state would actually save money if it could discourage vehicle thefts.

Stolen cars are often taken by young people for joy riding. It will be very hard to stop the professional thief who seems to be able to keep up with the technology; but if we can delay people who steal cars for a joy ride, just for a few minutes, we will thwart them because they will go off and look for something else. I make the point-I do not think I can make it too strongly-that people have a responsibility to ensure that they protect their property and put it beyond the easy reach of thieves.

It is quite clear that the stolen goods must go somewhere. We hear of people having their houses cleaned out-lounge suites, beds, the whole lot. Those things are not flogged across the bar at the local pub; those things are not shoved off to the corner fence. Somehow or other, there must be a method of disposing of those goods. It has been suggested that these are thefts by people who want the stuff for their own use. It is possible that some are, but I believe that they are very much a minority. People in that desperate situation usually do not have the wherewithal to organise thievery on the scale on which it is occurring.

The honourable member for Corio cited some figures which showed that the loss to Australia from theft amounts to well over $1 billion a year. That is a real cost, just as the lack of waterfront reform is a cost. It is a cost that impacts on every facet of our society and imposes strains on the whole economy. It is something that we must look at. I commend the motion. I think the honourable member for Corio has done a great job. I know that it has been an area of concern of his for some time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) regarding the disposal of stolen goods, not because I believe that the task force he has proposed will achieve the aims he desires, but because, by introducing this matter for debate in the House, he is reflecting his community's concern at the rising crime rate in the area he represents. I also represent a Melbourne electorate, but I represent an electorate on the other side of the bay from Corio-the seat of Corinella. We are also understaffed in terms of police numbers in that electorate. We have the same problem that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) suggested exists throughout Australia-insufficient public funds to support the police forces in the way we would desire.

SPEECH.PARA: In a telephone conversation with me about this motion this morning, the honourable member for Corio said, `People are now worried about the protection of their own homes'. Today in Australia, community standards have been so lowered that it is not just a case of criminals stealing goods and wrecking homes-I will come to my own experience in a moment-but also these goods are being received by other people. Whether they are being ordered or sold in a hotel or sold on the street, I am not sure.

At the moment my inquiries of police officers I know are not suggesting to me that there is a major movement of goods across borders or into other townships. Goods are, rather, locally sold. That means people in the community are entering into crimes by buying stolen goods. People do not sell a $1,500 stereo television over the counter in the local pub. Obviously someone is taking orders for those televisions and then stealing them and delivering them to people.

I want to mention the experience of my family; I think the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) mentioned his experience. A number years ago we had a short holiday. Who knows how the people who robbed my house found out that we were having a short holiday? Was it through kids at school? Was there just a bit of loose talk about it? We do not see in the local paper any more that so-and-so is going on a holiday.

Our place was robbed, damaged, ransacked. What valuables were in the home-and I will not go into that-were taken. For anybody who is listening now who would like to steal again from my home, I would like to let them know that the colour television is about 10 years old and the video recorder is about four or five years old and is one of the old models which require buttons to be pressed. No other valuables are kept in the home.

What was there, including a modest coin collection of my wife's, is now gone. The coin collection went with the culprits who took the rest of the goods and destroyed the inside of the home. The television, which we picked up out of the front paddock at our place, is still there. There was considerable damage, but the hurt and pain that was experienced not only by my wife but also by the kids-being in an outer area and in a fairly remote spot-was very hard. We had to introduce all sorts of security measures.

I want to return to the Bill and what is happening in the area of crime. I am speaking not only of Victoria. Yes, Victoria is having a tough time financially because of the mistakes of the Cain-Kirner Government, but let us talk about what is happening in Brisbane. I was up there a few weeks ago and made some inquiries. As I knocked on a few doors with a friend of mine in the Nundah by-election, one of the major concerns that came forward was that in Brisbane there has been a 25 per cent increase in crime within the last six months, while at the same time youth unemployment has risen to 36 per cent, an increase of 10 per cent in one month. I do not know whether there is a correlation between those two, but I would put to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that sometimes idle hands are not put to the best use.

The honourable member for Corio said that 10 per cent of the population of Australia is affected by break-ins; between 1,700 and 1,800 dwellings per 100,000 were broken into in 1988-89. In 1989, as was suggested by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, purportedly the value of the goods stolen in burglaries was $1.2 billion across Australia. That means one in 100 Australian homes will be burgled this year, with an average loss of $1,000, and every Australian will pay an extra $50 in insurance because of these burglaries.

Burglaries are happening in every street in every township across Australia. We as a community have taken a stand via our taxes, through our police forces that we cannot afford to fund enough. We as a community have introduced such programs as Neighbourhood Watch. I commend anybody who has taken part in Neighbourhood Watch and the Rural Watch program that is now working in Victoria. Many members of this House have supported the programs in their own areas, as I have. I was one of the inaugural members of Neighbourhood Watch in our area. We have achieved dramatic gains and are very well supported by our local police force.

But we as a community are buying the stolen goods. Somebody is buying the stolen goods. We must be prepared to raise our standards and not to look at the criminal as a victim, as we often do. How many times do members of the public say that the people who have been robbed are the victims, that they would like to see stricter penalties, would like to see people brought to account and would like to see the police given more powers. As we make contact with our constituents, as in Nundah in Queensland and Corinella in Victoria, we find that this is a major concern of people.

The first concern of people in the Nundah by-election is the Hawke-Keating Government. People are not voting on State issues; they are going to send a message to this House via that by-election. But the second concern is law and order. There is a great concern in our community for law and order. Representatives in this House and in the State Houses are being asked to have regard to the issue of law and order.

I come back to my situation in Victoria. A promise of 10,000 police was made by the then Minister, Mr Crabb, to support the concern he obviously noticed throughout the community. To this date there are only 9,200 police in Victoria. In 1990 there were 800 recruits, but there were also 457 resignations and 81 retirements. So there is frustration within the force also about its responsibilities in this matter.

Today in Australia we have many social problems. This is only one of them. I would like to think that, because this motion has come before the House, there will be renewed efforts for changes in our community to stop this breaking into and pillaging of homes. I have experienced this and I know the discontent it creates. The concern is not only the major items we lose that are resold; in our case we lost a Mickey Mouse money box that had been in our home for 20 years. I thank the State Bank of Victoria. When it became known, through one of my friends, that my wife had lost that money box we received from the State Bank display department a brand new Mickey Mouse money box.

We have now lost that bank. Those Mickey Mouse money boxes will not be going into households in Victoria because that bank is now owned by the Commonwealth Bank. I hope the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), who is about to speak, has received a letter from me telling him that the Commonwealth Bank is about to retrench people in that display department. There was a promise from Mrs Kirner and from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that there would be no forced retrenchments in the State Bank of Victoria. In fact, the officer concerned said, `We want you all out'. That is a shame for the State Bank people because they are experts in their field, on the technical side, in support of the State Bank of Victoria.

The fact is that we are now losing $1.2 billion in goods and, although the honourable member would like a national task force, I do not think it would achieve his aim. However, I believe that Australians will be better off because this matter has been drawn to the attention of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion before the House, although I must say that I have reservations about it, mainly because I believe the topic is one more readily addressed by State governments than by Federal governments. I agree with many of the other speakers that, to the extent that we have stolen goods taken from houses throughout Australia, I doubt whether there is a large, national organisation doing the stealing. Therefore, the scope for the Federal Government to become directly involved may be more one of coordination than addressing the day to day problems of crime.

SPEECH.PARA: I read the speech of the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), who made a number of very good points. Like the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent), my house has been broken into and I have also had a car stolen. So, like the honourable member, I speak from personal experience. In my case I was rather fortunate in that no damage was actually done to the house, except for a broken window where the thieves entered the house. The State police who came along to investigate did tell me that they were not surprised to get a call from my house. Prior to my house being broken into, a lady two suburbs away came home after dropping her children at school and actually interrupted the thieves, who by that time had the stolen goods on the back table ready to take them out of the property. Because they were interrupted by the occupant of the house, the police thought, `Well, they have an order for these goods, so they are bound to steal them from someone else.'

In my case, I lost a couple of television sets, the video, the hi-fi, a camera and a few other things. It is the belief of the police that these people take orders. There are people out there willing to buy the stolen goods at a much reduced rate. The thieves go into the homes and take just the items they are looking for. As I said, in my case I was lucky as they did not do any damage to the house apart from a broken window; but they did make a mess and it is not one of the most pleasant experiences in life to come home and find that one's house has been broken into. Luckily, I was insured and the insurance company was very good in that it replaced the goods within a week.

There is no doubt that housebreaking is a community problem. I do not think that talking about the numbers in our police force is the only answer. Of course, it is always good to have more resources rather than fewer. The honourable member for Corinella touched on the Neighbourhood Watch programs that are in operation around Australia. Because housebreaking is a community problem, those programs hold out the best hope for addressing the problem. In my electorate of Canning, we have started up several Neighbourhood Watch programs and they are going particularly well. As local members of parliament, I believe we could play a valuable role in helping Neighbourhood Watch. Certainly, we have the resources to help get the message out to the people in the areas concerned and I have been able to do that.

Like a lot of other people, I had been to Neighbourhood Watch meetings a number of times and heard police constables talk about how we should mark the valuables in our houses with our driver's licence numbers, but I never actually did it until it happened to me. The new equipment that I received from the insurance company now has that mark on it, and I wish I had done it before. It asked me at the time whether I had recorded the serial numbers anywhere. I said that I had not. I have now recorded them in a book which I keep separate from the goods.

One way in which we might be able to establish a trail is to require retailers-I know retailers have enough to do-to record in a book serial numbers of goods such as television sets sold by them against the names of the purchasers. In my case, I did not record a serial number and did not have a clue what the serial number was. I would say that the majority of people in Australia do not record the serial numbers of goods purchased. We can always remember where we bought the goods and about when we bought them. If we remember that and have a way of finding out the serial number of the goods that were stolen, then at least the police have something to go with to establish a trail to trace some of these stolen goods. Certainly, if people are to help in combating break-ins, Neighbourhood Watch is the best way of going about it. The police play a very active and valuable role in that.

The $1.2 billion worth of stolen goods that the honourable member for Corio spoke of is a huge national problem. That is a lot of money. To the extent that insurance companies have to make good the losses, we all bear the cost. It did not surprise me when I got my insurance premium notice for my house and contents policy to find that this year it had gone up by about $80. That $80 cost is built in and we will be paying it every year that we insure our houses.

There may well be a case for Federal Government involvement where cars are stolen and stripped, made up again and sold interstate. I think there may be a case for that. Certainly, a report I read in a newspaper in the last couple of days showed how that could be done. The article was very plausible. It would seem that if a car is stolen in, say, New South Wales, it may be sold in any other State after those who know what they are doing go through a fairly simple process. It may well be that the task force that the honourable member for Corio spoke of, the joint Commonwealth-State task force, may be able to play a valuable role where that happens. As I said before, I do not think that there is an established, nationwide network dealing in furniture and electrical goods. They seem to be more the province of local gangs who work in their own areas.

If anybody is going to steal these goods, there has to be somebody willing to buy them. I do not know and have not heard in any of the speeches so far what the penalties are for people who order stolen goods. It may well be that a toughening-up of those penalties may deter people from going to the local thief to get their goods instead of going down to the retailer. Without those orders, there is no real reason for people to steal the goods. There has to be a market there somewhere. If a task force is to be established, the penalties for people who order stolen goods and therefore create the market for them should be addressed.

The honourable member for Corio also said that the arrest rate was about 10 per cent. He admitted that the figures were fairly sketchy, but if we accept them at face value, they show-as my experience shows-that where there is no way of identifying the goods it makes it very hard for the police. Finding goods that have been stolen, if they are unmarked or the serial number is not known, is like looking for a needle in a haystack. Previous speakers put up a case for more police. Certainly that is one way in which we could go. But when we talk about more police, we talk about more taxpayers' money. I am not sure whether that is required in terms of this motion. Certainly, if the police can get together with Neighbourhood Watch and Rural Watch, I think that is the best way of going about it. As I said at the outset, the Commonwealth has a fairly limited role to play in this, nevertheless it could be an important one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) raises in this motion the distressing national problem of burglary and household theft. He said that every year one family in 100 is affected by break-ins and having goods stolen. That is a tragic statistic for all Australians. It is a particularly shattering experience for those families which are involved. Their possessions-often irreplaceable treasures and items of great sentimental value are taken. Perhaps more importantly from a psychological point of view, many families feel that their privacy has been violated and in other instances the damage done by those breaking in is even greater in value than the cost of the items that have been lost.

SPEECH.PARA: These days, break-ins and burglaries have become such regular occurrences that they rarely even make the news. But certainly, it is a tragic experience for the families who are involved. The honourable member for Corio mentioned that in 1989 burglary cost Australia $1.2 billion. It is a major industry, but it is an industry of misery and despair. Not all families are covered by insurance. In those circumstances it guarantees that the families will move into a period of considerable debt-hire purchase bills still have to be paid and, in many instances, families are financially ruined as a result of the actions of somebody breaking into their home.

The motion refers to `disposal networks which clearly must exist'. In that regard, I guess the honourable member is referring particularly to professional gangs. I do not deny that those particular enterprises exist. Much of the burglaries, break-ins and robberies are committed by amateurs-people who act on impulse, sometimes under the influence of alcohol or drugs or perhaps even as a pub-room dare. Sometimes a burglar is seeking a specific item; at other times, as a result of personal financial crisis a burglary is entered into in a desperate attempt to make ends meet in the home of the burglar.

In that regard the Government is not without responsibility. The economic crisis is certainly a circumstance which tempts people to crime. In a consumer society where we offer and expect everything, people who do not have everything are sometimes tempted to take what others do have. I think poverty, of all things, is clearly the mother of crime. In the dreadful economic circumstances of our country at present, more people are placed in that circumstance.

When 844,000 people are unemployed there is a lot of idle time. In such circumstances many people use that idle time unproductively. I think that is particularly a problem for juveniles. Much of the breaking and entering that goes on is a result of young people having time on their hands. The Prime Minister said that no child would live in poverty, but we all know that the number of homeless children-the number of children living on the streets-is increasing. It is very easy for children who are homeless and living on the streets to use that idle time to do damage to other people's property. Whether it is in the pursuit of drugs or other personal needs, many young children and juveniles are leaders in this whole area of breaking and entering and causing tragedy to so many Australian families.

That is really an indictment on our whole society. We have failed to support the family unit; economic circumstances force parents out to work to earn enough to raise their children and meet their basic needs; and single parent families sometimes battle or are unable to cope with young adults and crises in the family. There are also many other tragic stories of children being left abandoned as their parents move off to a new life. Recently I read a tragic story of children coming home from school to find that their family home had been abandoned and their parents had moved away. Those kinds of tragic circumstances put children in a situation where they are forced to fend for themselves. They are often led into a life of petty crime and who knows what else after that.

Children are expected to be more independent but sometimes the rebel heroes encourage them to get involved in this kind of a circumstance. Robbery is a symptom of a breakdown of our family and community way of life. I think it is essential that we look at our society as a whole. If we can resolve some of those difficulties we will go a long way to resolving the problems of petty crime as it appears in every community.

In a productive country like Australia it should never have come to this. There is plenty for all; there are plenty of opportunities. We need to give our young people, in particular, the opportunities to take advantage of the wonderful life that Australia can offer.
