This motion draws attention to the role of the police. The police, of course, have a thankless profession. They are criticised for not making enough arrests but when they do make arrests they are accused of brutality or fabricating evidence or corruption; if they happen to arrest an Aboriginal, they are accused of being racist. That kind of attitude does not help them in carrying out their responsibilities.

Like previous speakers, I commend community policing programs like Neighbourhood Watch which have helped to involve the community in ensuring their own protection. The police can do their job effectively only if they have widespread community support. These kinds of programs can be very helpful in breaking down the regime of crime that is present in so many communities.

Inquiries such as the Fitzgerald Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct have done a great deal of damage to law and order in our community. They have helped to destroy the confidence of the community in its police force. Perhaps more particularly they have damaged the police force's confidence in its future. In many regards these sorts of inquiries really fail to come to grips with corruption, but many innocent reputations are destroyed. Queensland at present has a Police Minister who rarely supports his own force when it is under criticism and that kind of thing is a scandal. More often than not, he takes the opposite side. We imported a new police commissioner from Victoria and often the commissioner, too, fails to back his own men. They prefer to believe left wing academics and do-gooders rather than recognise the difficult role the police have in our society and the need to give them the kind of support that they need.

Those sorts of things are important. Communities need to support their police forces; in particular, they need to identify with their responsibility for ensuring that each member of a community cares for his own property and keeps an eye on his neighbour's property as well so that we are all ready to take the action that is necessary to stamp out these kinds of offences. I support others who call upon the whole community to make an effort to recognise their responsibilities in this regard.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to participate in this grievance debate. I point out to those listening to the debate-especially those in the press gallery-that, as one who is involved in the chamber of the House of Representatives, I suspect that this is a much misunderstood chamber. The impression that the public has is that there is very little cooperation in this chamber, that there is very little sense of perspective about what the nation's destiny ought to be and very little endeavour on the part of all members to push in the same direction.

SPEECH.PARA: This perception is not aided by the press gallery. During debates on private members' business, the gallery is usually empty. On this occasion a representative of the Australian Associated Press (AAP) is present. It is a matter of great concern to me that when confrontation in this chamber is at its worst-Question Time-the public galleries are packed and the press gallery is packed. For the rest of the day, when debate takes a constructive mould and people are concerned about the direction the nation is taking, it is difficult to find people in the press gallery, the public galleries or even the chamber itself.

In referring to the cooperation that exists in this chamber, I do not want in any sense to understate the difference between the two political parties on issues such as the capital gains tax, broad-based consumption tax or the future of the Department of Social Security. Of course, there are total differences in perspective.

There is across this chamber a recognition of the problems that are facing Australia and an attempt by the major political parties to be accountable for the things that they advocate. It is rare, if not unknown, for any one of the major parties to choose to deliberately sabotage the direction being taken by the other party. For all the nonsense that is frequently spoken in this chamber-I do not excuse or exonerate myself from any of that-there is, as the 148 of us would agree, an underlying sense of accountability and perspective.

Against this backdrop, I want to refer to a debate that occurred in the Senate this week, a debate on Austudy and assets testing, where the Australian Democrats sought to deliberately sabotage the Austudy scheme. In spite of a joint parliamentary inquiry, which only last month handed down its recommendations on student financial assistance, recommending that the assets test for Austudy ought to remain and in spite of the fact that the Australian Democrats voted for the original assets test which is still in place, they propose to abolish the assets test completely because they sense an air of electoral appeal about that action.

The Democrats' proposal to abolish the assets test was, of course, motivated principally by what they saw as the present severe disadvantage being faced by farming families. Had their disallowance motion gone ahead they would have rubbed out the assets test for not only farming families but other families as well. All of the effort that was made to target Austudy to those in real need would have been lost at a cost conservatively estimated at $57m. They did it hoping they would have the support of the Opposition, seeking to embarrass the Government, simply because they supposed that the Government would then be forced to reintroduce the assets test amendments in a changed form.

I suggest to you that the Government would have been sorely tempted simply to maintain the confusion that would have then surrounded the entire Austudy scheme and blame the Opposition for it. As if that were not irresponsible enough of the Democrats, Senator Bell proposed to disallow regulation 61, under which the rate for Austudy benefits is set. If he had succeeded, no-one could have received Austudy because no rate could have been set.

In rising in this grievance debate to take issue with the action of the Australian Democrats, I do not want in any way to appear to be siding with what I think has been the Government's inaction on reforming the Austudy scheme. I simply want to reinforce my initial argument that there is in this place a measure of cooperation and I call on the Government in the interests of rural Australians to review the Austudy scheme.

Frankly, rural Australia is hurting and there are children in rural Australia who will be denied a tertiary education because of the present impact of the assets test on Austudy. To have supported the Australian Democrats' motion would have been to sabotage what the Government was about and to put the entire Austudy scheme at risk. The fact that we failed to support that Democrat motion does not, in any sense, take the Government off the hook. The Government has an obligation to review immediately the Austudy scheme.
In recognition of the present disadvantage that rural Australians are facing, the Opposition and the Democrats successfully moved the motion:

That the Senate calls on the Government to immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions so that families excluded from Austudy by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds.

The Government should not suppose that the Opposition is content merely to move that motion. We are not pussyfooting around on this issue. We demand action from the Government in the interests of rural Australians.

The call for hardship provisions is something that the Government can act on immediately. Hardship provisions allow the Government to recognise the irrefutable fact that the assets test, wherever it applies, can sometimes be unfair. In fact, it allows the Government to ensure that people who are in hardship are able to access tertiary education no matter what their assets may be. It allows the Government to offer help to the rural constituents of Wakefield-and of Grey, let me add. Hardship provisions already exist for the assets test on pensions and benefits. The very least the Government can do is to apply these hardship provisions to the assets test on Austudy.

The rural crisis cannot wait while the Government reviews the Austudy scheme once again. The rural crisis is now. I know it, the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) knows it, and the Government needs to act upon it. Unsympathetic Government members have suggested that a $700,000 assets test in rural Australia is fair enough. `After all, if you have got $700,000 without the house, without the curtilage around the house, surely anyone can go to the bank and borrow $20,000', I have heard from people opposite.

But an assets test, set as it is at $695,000, bears no recognition of the cash flow which is, in many cases, negative in rural Australia. Let us say that a farm is valued at $900,000 without the house. That is perfectly conceivable. But let us say what is equally conceivable-that the farmer has a debt, as most farmers do, of $205,000. The owner of that $900,000 property has not got a hope in Hades of servicing that $205,000 debt in the present crisis, much less of being allowed to offer to his children the support they need in order to access a tertiary education.

Farmers are in trouble-not because of anything they have done, but because of Government policy on interest rates; the failure of the wool floor price scheme, particularly the failure of major markets, and the failure of wheat marketing around the world with subsidised wheat. The all too ominous reality of a drought means that they face the uncomfortable fact of having to take their children out of tertiary courses.
This Government, which so proudly calls for a clever country, owes it to rural Australians to introduce hardship provisions on the Austudy assets test and to do so immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me say that it is a pleasure to follow my friend the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), who always puts a constructive case. I do not argue with him at all on the issue that he has raised because it is something that I have spoken about in the House on a number of occasions and on which I agree with him. Today, however, I want to speak about a different subject. During my time as a member of this House, I have often spoken of the multicultural community that I represent and of the pride and esteem in which I hold it.

SPEECH.PARA: As most honourable members assembled here would know, the largest city in my electorate, Whyalla, boasts 65 different nationalities living in a population of less than 27,000-and, I add, living in complete and utter harmony. My electorate of Grey is a veritable melting pot of nationalities from all over the world. Communities in all parts of my electorate are proud of the differing cultures and traditions interacting with the Spencer Gulf region and the outlying communities, the population of which has a high migrant content. They have every right to be proud. They are an example not only to the rest of Australia, but to the world.

Australia, as we know it today, is a culturally diverse society. Our country's migrants originate from over 120 different nations around the world. The United Kingdom and Ireland have provided Australia with a large number of settlers over the years. However, the remaining migrant population has brought a combined total of over 100 languages to Australia. The majority of settlers, excluding those from the United Kingdom, come from European countries.

We, as Australians, are fortunate to live in a democratic society. Those of us born in Australia are very often not aware of the trials that some of our migrant population have faced. Prior to coming to Australia, many of the migrants had not experienced the freedom of living in a democratic society. The fear of civil war, acts of violence or prejudice are things which we, having been born in a democratic society, have not experienced personally and, therefore, cannot fully understand. Acts of violence being perpetrated on innocent people each day in other countries of the world-often because these people have merely voiced an opinion-are things that we only read about or see on television. This is truly unfortunate as, having not undergone such experiences, some of us do not understand the importance of exercising our democratic right. There are some of us who take such rights for granted and who actually see these rights as an imposition on us, whereas individuals in other nations of the world are prepared to spill blood or give their lives to obtain these rights.

Australia has been enriched by the contribution provided to our nation by its migrants. Under the migration system, migrants are accepted into our country regardless of race, colour or creed. Participation in Australian life and acceptance by Australians are prime factors in the settlement of these newcomers to our country, from which we as a nation will reap the benefits. It is saddening, however, that there is a small minority within our community that is opposed to this policy.

New arrivals are not prevented from contributing their talents and skills to the Australian way of life. On the contrary, they are encouraged to share these skills and talents with the community, enriching our way of life and subsequently forming part of our Australian heritage. Protection of individual rights, such as participation and integration in the work force, is recognised and plays a large and important role in enhancing this nation's future.

We, as a nation, still require migrants to assist in our economic recovery, but to a much lesser degree than in previous years. To keep in line with our country's rapid economic and social changes, the immigration policy has been gradually adjusted and modified, in line with our ever changing socio-economic needs. It is, however, of grave concern that a number of Australia's permanent residents fail to apply for Australian citizenship. In failing to do so, they are in fact denying themselves the opportunity to participate in our country's democratic process.

I believe that all residents of Australia should show their commitment to Australia, its principles, its ideals and its way of life. That should be a two-way commitment between Australia and its migrant population. As I represent a multicultural constituency, each day either I or my electorate staff are approached by constituents who are eligible under our criteria to apply for Australian citizenship. They are eager to know what steps must be taken to fulfil their commitment and allegiance to the country that now means home to them. These people genuinely wish to become Australian citizens and assume the rights and responsibilities associated with becoming a citizen.

One would think that this would prove to be an easy exercise; however, there are barriers. What we have done is to increase community awareness of the importance of participation in our democracy. Having succeeded in raising awareness through a massive and costly advertising campaign we then turn our backs on the very people we have targeted and who are now showing their willingness to become citizens. How, you may ask, has this been done? We have raised a barrier-a major barrier-which is insurmountable for the disadvantaged people in our community. In other words, we have succeeded in changing attitudes to obtaining Australian citizenship.

However, the mighty dollar dictates participation in citizenship as we put out our hand saying, `This privilege will cost you $35, mate, unless you are a pensioner, because we have recently granted a $15 concession for pensioners'. But the bulk of the people miss out and these people are Australians in every way, having made this country their home for most or all of their adult life. In all aspects they have actively participated in our way of life, contributed their taxes and paid their dues. They have every right to believe themselves to be Australians in the true sense; they lack only the paperwork.

I am firmly of the opinion that we are doing these people an injustice by making them pay for the privilege of citizenship. While the cost factor may not seem to be beyond the budget range of most people, it must be remembered that families living on low incomes or relying on social security benefits and who wish to obtain Australian citizenship simply cannot justify such an outlay from their limited budget. In some instances, when more than one family member wishes to obtain citizenship, the cost is doubled or trebled. We have families where one or two members are citizens, but the balance of the family are not, simply because they cannot afford it.

We are holding these people to ransom. We tell them that they may work for the good of Australia and participate in our way of life on a cultural and social level; however, they must become citizens if they wish to participate in our democratic process. If they cannot afford the $35 fee, they have no say in our country's future. Are we in fact saying that only the rich have the right to be part of Australia's democratic process?

It is inconceivable to me, as a member of a democratic socialist party and a Government whose record is renowned on social justice issues, that this situation has been allowed to develop. The disadvantaged in our community are being denied their basic right for the paltry sum of $35. This is totally unacceptable for a party which bases its own structure on democratic rights and professes to be the defender of basic human rights and civil liberties.

I put it to this House that this situation must be rectified. I call upon the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) to implement an amnesty of at least three months duration, making citizenship free. I feel it would be fitting to present these certificates to those availing themselves of the opportunity during such an amnesty on Australia Day, 1992.

This would be a real cause for celebration of our nation's birthday and will show our commitment to our multicultural society. If we are truly genuine in our beliefs, and want people to embrace our nation and its democratic process by becoming Australian citizens, it is our responsibility as a government to ensure that cost is not the prohibitive factor in determining a person's commitment to this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of my grievance today is the corruption of the community resulting from corrupt politicians. Whilst there is no excuse for members of the general community who seek favours from politicians in an improper fashion, the simple fact remains that the corruption occurs when the politician cooperates. The Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters, the WA Inc. royal commission, has put a focus on this matter that has probably never been so stark. The shock waves have not stopped at the West Australian border, but have raised a storm here in Canberra as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) ineptly and unconvincingly attempted to distance himself from events and people from whom he had previously sought reflected glory.

SPEECH.PARA: The current events also raise queries as to the competence, energy and, in fact, integrity of the West Australian media, who seemed, amongst other matters, so incompetent as to fail to discover the simple fact that a senior West Australian Cabinet Minister had paid a $13,000 cash deposit on a house, notwithstanding that such news would have rocketed around that real estate office within seconds of the writing of the receipt.

More amazing was the evidence given by the Premier and Deputy Premier of their habit of keeping large amounts of cash in such containers as manila envelopes or initialled briefcases. I considered this an unlikely story, until I discovered that the practice was more common amongst Australian Labor Party (ALP) members of parliament (MPs) than I had first realised. I came to this conclusion when I re-read a New South Wales police report in my possession, which is dated 21 February 1982, prepared by Detective Sergeants Ferguson and Harvey, Detective Keene and Constable Laverack. It reports the theft of a sum of $3,600 in Commonwealth bank notes, a sum of $1,000 in United States (US) currency and, most surprisingly, a quantity of travellers cheques, quoted in the report as `bank and number unknown'. That someone who was reporting the theft of personal property could not remember the bank upon which they drew their own travellers cheques is inconceivable. It appears that the person concerned did not want the police to know the origin of those cheques.
Also of interest to me are the circumstances of the theft, which are described under the heading of `Information'. The report states in part:
The offenders forced open a combination lock on a dark brown leather briefcase and removed the above

That means, of course, the money and travellers cheques. Here is another briefcase bank, another large sum of money left carelessly lying around in a vacant hotel room for all and sundry to steal or misuse. The briefcase, of course, belonged to Robert Hawke and the offence occurred at the Boulevard Hotel in quite bizarre circumstances. Everyone in the Labor Party in Australia has queried the Prime Minister's determined defence of his mate, Brian Burke, but this situation throws a new light on the subject. Clearly, from his own actions, the Prime Minister finds nothing unusual in politicians, whose salary is paid by cheque and who have no other means of income, wandering around with thousands of dollars in cash, equivalent in this case to 16 per cent of annual salary, in their briefcase. Nevertheless, there are a number of other questions that should be answered.

The first is that, notwithstanding that Mr Hawke's room at the Boulevard was the only room burgled that night, suggesting an inside job, the police have never made an arrest. In fact, it has been reported that they were forbidden even to discuss the matter amongst themselves-hardly the best way to solve a crime. The second is the matter of the origins of the US currency and travellers cheques, particularly as access to foreign currency was strictly limited at the time by section 5 (1) (a) of the Reserve Bank Act.

The issue has been raised in this Parliament before but, in the light of more recent revelations in Western Australia, it is time the Prime Minister gave an explanation to this Parliament as to the circumstances of his having these funds. In particular, he should explain whether the funds related to his lobbying of Queensland MPs on behalf of Eddie Kornhauser and his casino application-as reported in the press-which he was conducting at that time to the embarrassment of the Queensland ALP. This was expressed in a telegram on 9 March 1982 to the Secretary of Caucus, Ros Kelly, by the then Labor spokesman on justice and police, Bob Gibbs. This was reported, along with a response from the Prime Minister, in the National Times of 4-10 April 1982. I quote from that paper both the response of Mr Hawke and the remarks of Mr Gibbs:

In his telegram sent on March 9 to the secretary of the Caucus, Ros Kelly, Gibbs said that he was lodging ``the strongest of protests at the unwarranted interference by one of your Caucus members, namely R. J. Hawke, on the Queensland casino licence issue''.

``Following exhaustive discussions with people in Melbourne, and having perused the findings of the 1954 New South Wales Royal Commission on Liquor Laws, I laid certain information relating to one of the applicants, Kornhauser, before the Queensland Parliament.

``I find it absolutely extraordinary that a prominent member of the parliamentary Labor Party should then come to Queensland and attempt to coerce the State secretary, State president and State parliamentary leader to use their influence to shut me up.''
In November last year, Gibbs said in Queensland Parliament that a ``stench'' hung over Kornhauser's application.
On March 2, when the State Parliament resumed, Gibbs again attacked Kornhauser alleging that he had laundered illegally collected money.
The following evening Gibbs was summoned by the State Opposition Leader, Ed Casey, to his Parliament House office. Casey asked Gibbs to meet with Hawke, who was coming to Brisbane.

Casey has told the National Times that Hawke wanted to speak with Gibbs about his attack on Kornhauser. Casey said that Hawke was not happy with what Gibbs had said and that it was wrong that Hawke was travelling to Brisbane specifically to speak to Gibbs.
According to Gibbs, he said that he would not discuss the matter with Hawke and refused to meet with him.
Gibbs said that Hawke had also telephoned his residence in an endeavour to speak to him.
Further on in the article-and I will quote Mr Hawke to make this balanced-it states:
When Hawke was contacted by the National Times,
I make the point that he did answer the allegations-
he refused to discuss the Gibbs telegram.
Hawke said that he did not go to Queensland seeking to speak to Gibbs. He said: ``That matter arose and I sought to speak to him and found it singularly difficult to find him.
``I tried him at Parliament House, I tried him at home and couldn't speak to him.''
Hawke said that he spoke to Casey and Beattie. Hawke said he told Casey that Gibbs was acting on wrong information on Kornhauser.
``Mr Casey took the opportunity provided to him to look at the police file and he issued a public statement.
``I am indebted to Mr Casey for having clarified that matter.''
Hawke denies that he asked Casey and Beattie to take disciplinary action against Gibbs.
``Casey did what was necessary.''
That is what Mr Hawke said.
He denies that he met or spoke with the Queensland National Country Party minister, Russ Hinze . . . over the matter.
``I have known Kornhauser for a very long time.
This is a quote from Hawke again-
From when I first met him he has, over a long period of time, been a substantial helper of the Labor Party in Victoria.''
Asked if Kornhauser was a financial backer of the Labor Party, Hawke answered that``he has provided assistance over time, yes''.
Further on the article states:
Hawke says that he saw Kornhauser and stayed with him on the Gold Coast.

Of course, there has been substantial movement in both Queensland and Western Australia regarding matters of this nature. Mr Kornhauser certainly did not come out of the Queensland Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in very good shape. In fact, he came out of it in dreadful shape. But the issue before the Parliament now is: should the Prime Minister further explain why he could not or was not prepared to remember where those travellers cheques came from? If they were his own, we can feel sorry for the fact that he lost his money out of his hotel room. I add that it was the most expensive room in the place-I think it was the Lady Forrest Room or something -costing about $185 a night, which is a remarkable price for a backbencher. I certainly do not use those rooms when I go to Sydney.

The reality is that things have changed. What has changed is that, when this matter was raised before, it was considered to be a scurrilous personal attack. That was the defence used in Western Australia. Every time the Opposition attempted to come up with queries of the early stages of WA Inc., it was attacked for mud-slinging. It was all so dreadful to suggest that the Premier of Western Australia might be giving people favours and misusing ALP funds. It was all too dreadful to suggest that a cheque given by the failed teachers credit union for $5,000 had been donated to the ALP after it decided that the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia would bail it out. Others, amongst them the Leader of the National Party, accused the Liberals of mud-slinging and told them to `put up or shut up'. They eventually put that cheque up.

The point I make in all these matters is that, had all that funny business been stopped in the early stages, Western Australian taxpayers would have been saved $1 billion-$1,000m-because the PICL, the Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd, disaster and all those that followed as an attempt to cover up would never have occurred. This is the tragedy and this is why the Prime Minister has got to tell us a bit more about his working to get Mr Kornhauser a licence to run a casino-which, fortunately, he did not get, partly through the honest efforts of members of the Labor Party in Queensland whom the Prime Minister, as Mr Gibbs said, tried to shut up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian people have a fundamental commitment to uphold the rights of man. Indeed our Constitution, our legal system and our way of life are all based on that principle. Therefore, Australians would be appalled to learn that evidence has been revealed of a Chinese gulag, used for the production of goods and services for export.

SPEECH.PARA: Asia Watch, which is an internationally recognised human rights organisation, has obtained official Chinese documents which it claims prove the existence of a Chinese gulag enslaving as many as 20 million people. The Chinese authorities do not permit international human rights groups to inspect the labour camps or any other prison facilities in China. It is therefore difficult to discover the true number of gulag slaves.

It is alleged that many of these prisoners are used to produce goods to sell to the United States, Japan and West Germany. Asia Watch obtained and translated articles from a restricted circulation journal for Chinese prison and labour camp officials entitled `Theoretical Studies in Labor-Reform and Labor-Re-education'. These articles from issues published in 1989 and 1990 were written by prison officials or officials of provincial bureaus of labour reform. Asia Watch released the articles and its own overview on 19 April this year.

Included among this prison population are large numbers of political and religious detainees and other prisoners of conscience. Asia Watch says it recently uncovered a secret directive issued on 25 August 1983 by the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party revealing that political dissidents have all along been one of the main targets of an eight-year-long campaign to `crack down on crime'. This confidential party document states:
active counter-revolutionary elements who write counter-revolutionary slogans, fliers, liaison messages and anonymous letters are to be dealt resolute blows and given severe and prompt punishment.

The human rights group claims that millions of those who have served out their sentences since 1949 remain in the Chinese gulag as a captive labour force as a result of China's `forcible retention' policy. This forcible retention policy is commonly applied against inmates who have allegedly remained unrepentant even after they have completed their sentences. Political dissidents are included in this category as well as some individuals with skills that authorities do not wish to lose.

There is no reference to goods produced by such people forcibly retained being sold in Australia. However, it does not require a great stretch of the imagination to assume that, if the Asia Watch report is accurate, goods produced by slave labour in China are finding their way into overseas export markets. Australia could also be on the receiving end of such inhumane practices.

Chinese statistics have Australia ranked as China's tenth largest trading partner by value after Hong Kong-Macau, Japan, the United States of America, West Germany, the Soviet Union, Singapore, Canada, Taiwan and Britain. Australia's exports to China in 1989-90 totalled $1.192 billion, while imports were valued at $1.24 billion.

Since China first permitted direct private investment in 1979, Australian companies have established approximately 40 joint ventures in China. These joint venture companies produce for both the Chinese domestic and export markets, including re-export to Australia. I repeat `including re-export to Australia'.

I am not suggesting that Australian companies are involved in-or are even aware of-the use of prison labour by China, but this question must be asked. Are products produced by prisoners in forced labour camps in China finding their way into Australia? Asia Watch maintains that the use of forced labour in China is central to government policy. It is not a policy developed on an ad hoc basis by labour reform units and coastal provinces where a large portion of the goods are produced.

In September 1983, the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce produced a two-volume report entitled Prospects for Trade Between Australia and China. This Committee's inquiry was considered timely because the then Department of Trade believed that trade and investment links between Australia and China were poised for steady and solid growth over the following 10 years. The Department's prediction was well-founded. Two-way trade between Australia and China in 1982-83 was $899.8m compared with the $2.432 billion in 1989-90. Australia cannot accept trade at any price, especially when that price may be accounted for in terms of human lives and suffering. The Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce in its 1983 report said:

China's policy of equality and mutual benefit in foreign trade probably results from recollection of exploitation by foreign companies in the years before the Revolution. The principle of self-reliance reflects China's determination not to be dependent on foreigners nor to be subservient to trade relations. It has been repeatedly stated, for instance, that foreign investors in China must respect China's sovereignty and abide by its laws, policies and decrees.

If China's policy of equality and mutual benefit in foreign trade results from recollections of exploitation by foreign companies in the year prior to the Revolution, as the Committee suggests in this report, that is not an excuse for any country to condone China's exploitation of its own people under a policy of forced retention. There is no excuse for Australia to permit any of its trade to be tainted with human rights abuses.

Australia was China's first bilateral aid donor when it signed an agreement for Technical Cooperation for Development on 2 October 1981. This agreement aimed to support China's modernisation through specific activities addressing priority Chinese sectors in which Australia had significant expertise. The Australian program has been augmented by other forms of aid-funded cooperation.

Apart from trade relations, Australia and China have achieved much in recent times in the field of development assistance. Relationships between Australian States and Chinese provinces, science and technology relations, cultural relations, and legal, education, military and other specialised exchanges have been vastly improved.

Our association with China-except for the substantial set-back caused by the Chinese Government's appalling actions in June 1989-has been one of warmness and mutual support. But now a heavy cloud hangs over the progress made in Australia-China relations. We cannot and must not countenance the continued use of slave labour in China. We must voice our protest in the strongest possible terms. Asia Watch has urged the United States Customs Service to require certification from importers that products arriving in the United States are not the result of forced labour.

The organisation has also urged the United States to request that the Chinese permit the inspection of all prison factories and farms so that a complete picture of China's export industry can be obtained. The United States State Department, in a statement issued by Mr Richard Boucher, had this to say:

We have suspected for some time that some Chinese prison products were making their way to the U.S. market. We've been cooperating with the Customs Service for over a year now to investigate the extent of such imports and whether they violate the Tariff Act of 1930. Should those investigations uncover exports in violation of U.S. laws we will take firm steps to enforce those laws.

Australia needs to adopt similar measures. Our conscience demands that we take action and if we fail to do that Australia will be properly criticised in the United Nations and other international forums for condoning what is a blatant abuse of human rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw to the attention of the House today the continuing fiasco which goes under the name of the Government's export education policy. At the very least it can be described as a shambles which, despite the best efforts of the Government, is not going to go away just because it hopes it will or by its ignoring it.

SPEECH.PARA: The education of overseas students in this country is an ongoing debacle which is ruining lives, putting decent young people into debt for years, sending businesses to the wall, losing this country hundreds of millions of dollars of overseas earnings, and making Australia a target of ill will and ridicule, particularly in South East Asia and the Pacific. The picture is one of total confusion and unfortunately that confusion still exists.

The extent to which the Government is ignoring the problem is highlighted by the fact that since his return last month from Beijing, where the angst and dissatisfaction is understandably most prevalent, the Minister for Education, Employment and Training (Mr Dawkins) has not, to my knowledge, made one public statement on the subject.

The seriousness of the problem and the extent of the bewilderment in the industry was brought home to me earlier this month when I visited an English language school in my electorate. It is a perfectly responsible and well-run college that is having difficulties staying in business; it is operating on the brink of viability, and faces the possibility of going out of operation unless there is a brisker and more efficient turnaround of visa applications and it is able to increase its student roll. Two years ago, it was operating at full capacity. Early last year when the visa rules were changed, the school was half full; now it is operating at about three-quarters capacity, but it has had to shed four teachers. To demonstrate the amount of money that is being lost to Australia, this one school alone, if operating at full capacity, would put more than $2m of overseas earnings into our economy in 40 weeks.

The owners and operators of this school were very good, reasonable, responsible and polite people. They outlined to me a litany of government mismanagement and incompetence; constant and irrational changes of the rules; frustration; lack of direction; a shameful lack of understanding of industry problems; a very apparent inability of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to communicate with the industry and with each other; and no control from the Minister-in other words, a damning indictment of a government which has made a complete botch of the whole thing. It has washed its hands of the havoc that is has wrought.

The Government thought that all it had to do was sit back, do nothing and let the money roll in. Instead, at a time when Australia should be earning its share in an industry which worldwide is worth $12 billion a year, we have seen earnings drop from $300m in 1988-89 to $103m, with every indication that things are going to get even worse.

In the last two years, we have seen four sets of visa changes, some of which were retrospective, so that there is confusion not only here, but also overseas among the students we should be attracting. Foreign students, quite reasonably, are going elsewhere. The intake from Thailand, which in 1988-89 amounted to 1,765 fee-paying students has virtually disappeared, with New Zealand picking up much of this business. In fact, Canada and New Zealand, which only entered the industry over the last two years, now outstrip Australia in the number of students they receive.

Also in the 1988-89 period, the number of students coming from Hong Kong and Taiwan fell by 45 per cent; from Indonesia, 33 per cent; from South Korea, 27 per cent; and from Japan, 16 per cent. What a tremendous example of the efficacy and credibility of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The attitude of the Government towards China is a perfect example of the woolly government thinking which is crippling colleges.

Following the horrendous Tiananmen Square killings in mid-1989, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), off his own bat, made the emotional decision to offer four-year visa extensions to 20,000 Chinese. Since that time, student visa regulations for Chinese have been successively tightened on three separate occasions. The Immigration Department is now rejecting 95 per cent of Chinese applications. Is it any wonder, given that situation, that Australia's reputation is very much on the nose in China and that thousands of potential students are very angry because they borrowed money for their full courses, paid in advance and then found themselves frozen out of Australia because this Government suddenly changed the rules? It said to the students, `We are very sorry about that; it is just too bad'. One result of all this, of course, is that Australia's immigration program is in a complete mess and some day we will have to face the consequences in the form of a very gravely distorted total intake.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is distorted now.

—As the shadow Minister says, it is distorted now, but it will become increasingly so, dependent upon the decisions which are taken in the next couple of years about those thousands of students and the refugee component which is also adding problems to the total situation.

SPEECH.PARA: That emotional Chinese student decision was made by the Prime Minister without any knowledge of the flow-on effects, the history, the difficulties and sensitivities in the immigration area just because he felt like it at the time. It was almost like the streaker's defence offered by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) on one occasion during his career: it seemed like a good idea at the time. Seriously, this has disturbed the potential migrant flows in the future and, of course, the attitude in the whole of the student area has only exacerbated the problem.

There is no doubt that a number of buccaneers and people who should not be operating colleges have been and still are in the industry. But it is not good enough that the Minister should stand idly by and say good riddance as the schools go broke and throw the problem in the lap of the States by saying that education is a State responsibility. If one followed that logic through, of course, one would probably come to the inevitable conclusion that Australia does not need a Federal Minister for Education.

The Minister, although he appears to choose to ignore it, has an obligation and that obligation is to rein in and control an industry which he has allowed, by his apathy and incompetence, to run out of control. By working together with the States, he has an obligation to bring in legislation which will protect the nation's interests in terms of immigration, the colleges and, most particularly, the trusting, genuine foreign students who wish to come here for an education.

This area could bring great benefit to the students who wish to study in Australia. It could bring to the country as a whole great benefits in terms of international relations as those students go back and make their ways in their own country. It could bring great benefit in terms of the economies which will be extended by the people coming to Australia. At the present time, unfortunately, we have a situation where all is confusion. On 8 May 1991, the Embassy of the People's Republic of China issued a news bulletin on the collapse of English colleges.

TALK.START.PARA: —A credible source?
—It is a credible source because at the bottom it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Chinese Embassy hopes that the Australian Government, setting store by the international credibility of its education export, take effective measures to improve the management of and rectify the remaining English colleges so as to avoid more unnecessary losses on the part of the Chinese students.
What an indictment of this Government and this Minister's handling of an extremely important and sensitive area of administration. It really is appalling and the Government stands condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last fortnight, there has been a very unfortunate domestic tiff between the National and Liberal Party leaders of New South Wales about the question of high temperature incinerators. In the course of that the New South Wales Premier made the profound comment that if it were in his electorate he would want it to go somewhere else. Equally, in the same process he has undermined the one person who has attempted over a long period to overcome the huge cracks in credibility within that Government over environmental matters-the New South Wales Minister for Environment, Mr Moore. The axe has been taken to his credibility, in so far as the Premier has announced that the question of the siting of this incinerator will possibly have to go back to square one, and the original report, which actually said that high temperature incinerators are a good idea, might have to be looked at again. As well as that, the New South Wales Premier has certainly questioned a number of the siting situations.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue of high temperature incinerators is a bit more serious than the question of siting and perhaps the Ministers involved previously, under both governments, should have tackled it a bit more thoroughly. But I am particularly concerned with this matter because of the report, Management and Technologies of Waste: A Perspective for Australia 1990, published by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and written by Kerry Hubick. There is a number of interesting comments about this very issue in that report. One of the two alternative technologies-the starved air method-is mentioned on page 77 of that report. It states:

The starved-air method of incineration works well under conditions where continuous operation maintains uniform temperatures and in large-scale operations where wastes are fairly uniform because of mixing.

Starved-air incineration has a poor reputation for excessive emissions. Some international experts believe that the poor reputation derives from an inadequate ability of the technology to deal with very heterogeneous wastes, particularly for the types of medical wastes produced at hospitals.

Obviously, the whole starved-air technology is questioned by this Federal report. Yet, as it points out, New South Wales does not seem to be too inclined to let a thousand flowers bloom. The approach of the party of liberalism and lack of restrictions and controls is described on page 124 of the report, which states:

In Australia, the New South Wales Government appears to be embarking on an unusual regulatory route concerning incineration. The draft regulations for the incineration of pathological/biomedical wastes include a specification of the technology to be used. Such an approach contrasts with the usual type of government regulations where emissions are to be controlled. Further regulations of this nature can only serve to stifle the development of new, improved technologies.

So New South Wales is saying that there is only one road to go down in this new area of technology and that is the starved-air technology. That, of course, emerges in the draft guidelines for pathological and biomedical waste incinerators of the New South Wales Government.

I am interested to note that the authorities it cites in support of this starved-air technology are Calvin Brunner and C. H. Brown and their article `Hospital Waste Disposal by Incineration' in the journal, Air Pollution Control and Waste Management. When we go to that article to find out why New South Wales should have this starved-air technology, we find that on page 1304 those experts state, `Avoid the starved air/pyrolysis process.' That is the advice of the experts the New South Wales Government cites in support of its technology line. It went on to say:

With the extreme variation inherent in biomedical waste feeding, the stoichiometric requirement is constantly changing. It is virtually impossible for a starved air process to be maintained when the stoichiometric air demand ratio ranges from less than 2 to greater than 15.

As I say, there seems to be some question about why the New South Wales Government went down this road. It cites an internationally acknowledged authority whose reputation was enforced recently in my electorate by the decision on 16 April of the Bankstown City Council to veto the building of an incinerator based on this technology. Despite the fact that the New South Wales Government thought that we should go down only this one road, it was so unconvincing that the Bankstown Council threw it out the door in five seconds and rejected the technology.

It is interesting to note that this form of technology is used by only a minority of incinerators in the United States; of the 130 units in the States, a mere 10 to 15 use it. Messrs Dean and Collom of the Air Branch of the State Pollution Control Commission, on a whirlwind tour of the United States of America to provide background material to the New South Wales Government for its policy position, for some unknown reason looked at only those plants that utilised this technology. Similarly, as I understand it, in their visits to other countries, they were very selective about the plants they visited.

As I have said, there is a very big question mark as to why this Government has gone down this road and there is a very big question mark over its selective support for a company called Clinical Waste Australia Pty Ltd, which has a plant in Auburn in my electorate. In 1990, when a rival company, Scholer Incineration Co. Pty Ltd, approached the State Pollution Control Commission, it was given an abundance of conditions and requirements. The State Pollution Control Commission noted in point (h) of its letter of 18 January 1990:

Should the waste be made up of significant amounts of chlorinated plastics . . . then we would consider the need for the proponent to carry out tests for dioxins. Nevertheless, we would require tests for particulates and acid gases to be carried out, within one month of the incinerator being commissioned and thereafter, at three month intervals.
So there was a requirement on the Scholer company, seeking to build a plant in January 1990, that it look at three-monthly and then at further six-monthly tests.

But what were the requirements put on the company Clinical Waste Australia? What performance did the State Government require of that particular company? I think it has been noticeably different. In actual fact, we are still awaiting the first report, more than two years after it established its plant in Silverwater, Auburn. It still has not produced one public document with regard to the figures of its pollution levels.

However, it has produced a document by a company called Auckland Environmental Protection Agency Ltd. It just happens, by a series of interlocking relationships amongst managers in Liberticorp Holdings Ltd, Waste Technology (NZ) Ltd, Auckland Environmental Protection Agency Ltd and Rahiri Holdings Ltd, that it has commissioned a report on the waste levels from a related company. That is the kind of evidence that this State Government in New South Wales requires.

But I am still amazed that this company is allowed by this State Government to continue to operate, because the figures even in this report, two years after it was set up, and which was not produced publicly by the Minister, cast great credibility problems over the company.

I will just briefly note a few results of that report: cadmium, lead and hexavalent chromium are not reported in the document; it deliberately obscures the issue of pollution levels by utilising unconventional units of mass per actual cubic metre; it does not state the temperature at the sampling point; and it does not mention the stack flow rate which is required to change the analysis of pollutant concentrations to emission rates in mass per second. When we get on to the actual figures that this document did come out with, it gave these statistics: hydrogen chloride was above the State required guideline of 400 milligrams per cubic metre-it actually reached 520. In regard to dioxins-I think everyone would appreciate that this is quite a serious by-product-this company-commissioned, internal company document showed levels of 42 times the dioxin level that would be allowed at the Corowa plant.

Finally, it is very interesting to note that, whereas this great draft report by the State Pollution Control Commission requires a level of 1100 degrees centigrade for burning off, this document by the Auckland Environmental Protection Agency states that it must be only over 1050-no doubt because it was burning at only 1085. So, once again, it was below the State requirement.

We have a situation here where Springbok tourist enthusiast Mr Winston Churchill McDonald, despite being gaoled for two years for embezzlement in New Zealand, is allowed to be a company director in New South Wales-at the very centre of this company that is getting such selective support from the State Government of New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not have escaped the attention of the honourable members of this House that there is a State election on in New South Wales. I think that became abundantly clear from the comments of the previous speaker. It is also abundantly clear that, because of the performance of the Labor governments in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania, the people of Australia have become disenchanted, to a degree, with the mainstream of politics. Therefore, it is obvious that there has been quite an upsurge in the number of Independents in the State election in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: What I would like to say to the people of New South Wales, and indeed to the people of Australia, is that Independents can be a very weak reed to rest upon. They have no input whatsoever into policies and they do not even have any policies. They have no input into the expenditure of the government or into constructive policy generation by oppositions. In fact, they are orphans in the parliamentary sense; they just sit there, not even like a voice in the wilderness. So what I would like to do on this occasion is to say to the people of New South Wales in particular that, before casting their vote on Saturday week, they should give very serious consideration to not wasting it by voting for an Independent.

I know that Independents have been the flavour of the month in some places and I even know of one Independent in one of the State electorates in my area who was promising to model himself on the New South Wales Independent, Mr Frank Arkell. It is interesting that, from the end of 1986 to 29 April 1991, Frank Arkell asked absolutely no questions without notice in the Parliament, and that in that whole period of many years from 1986 to 1991 he made a total of nine speeches. Just as a point of comparison, the candidate for Port Macquarie, Wendy Machin, who is a great member of the New South Wales House, asked 17 questions and made 78 speeches, which was quite a valuable contribution.

I find it very difficult to understand why any person seeking to enter politics, to participate in the governments of this country, would do it outside the mainstream because, unless one is in one of the mainstream parties-my own National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia of which the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) is a member or the Australian Labor Party of which the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) is a member-one can achieve very little indeed.

I just want to say again to the people of New South Wales, and in particular to the people on the north coast-that growing area-that we have a strong National Party team of members, starting at the southern end: John Turner, Wendy Machin, Bruce Jeffery, Andrew Fraser, Ian Cawsley, Don Page, Bill Rixon and Don Beck, that it is a great team of hardworking men and a woman who have done enormous amounts for their electorates and are working strongly within the whole of the Government's activity.

I would just like to go through a few things which are important and relevant when people are considering how they are going to vote. For instance, let us look at electricity generation in New South Wales since the Greiner-Murray Government came in. It has cut off the fat, the non-workers and the non-productive people. Employment is down by 33 per cent, while productivity is up by 78 per cent. If we look at county councils, employment is down by 17 per cent, while productivity is up 61 per cent. Not one Independent had any say in that at all.

Within the State Rail Authority, employment has been cut by a massive 46 per cent, as it had to be, because it was losing $3m a day. It had to take the knife to it and cut it back. Productivity for Countrylink is now up 100 per cent, and freight is up 109 per cent. It is worth noting that, although there was a great deal of anguish about rail services, particularly on the north coast last year at the time of the Federal election, no station up there has closed in the lower area; local use has increased by 10 per cent; and the people that I talked to who are actually using State Rail are now expressing great satisfaction.
We are all concerned about law and order. The Murray-Greiner Government has increased the police force by 1,600 since the election of 1988. That is a great number of people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixteen hundred?

—Yes. There are 950 extra police on the beat, some of them in Port Macquarie-and no Independents had anything to do with that. The police budget for 1991 is 50 per cent higher than Labor's last Budget and is now more than $1 billion a year. That shows a total commitment to law and order that is essential in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I, like other members, particularly those who are in the chamber at the present time, am very concerned about health. This is another area in which the Greiner-Murray Government has really shone since taking office. Orthopaedic surgeons have been able to return to the public hospitals and 10,000 additional operations have been undertaken since that time. Waiting lists have dropped 6,000 in the last two years. The average waiting time is three weeks-still too long but a drop of two weeks under what it was with Labor.

Capital works are up over 80 per cent, particularly on the north coast which is a great growth area that had been neglected by the previous Labor Government. In Port Macquarie, at the southern end of my electorate, construction of a new hospital is about to commence at a cost of $80m. Projects at and improvements to the Hastings District Hospital over the last three years amount to nearly $6m. Of course, the previous Government's spending on that hospital was only about $2m. This was not the expenditure for just one year. From 1983-84 to 1987-88 a total of under $2m was spent, whereas up to $6m has been spent over the last three years under the present Government.

North coast health funding has been enhanced by 8 per cent already and over this decade the north coast will receive an additional $52m for new services. This is recognition of the needs and the growth of the north coast. But the Independents have not had one bit of input into getting that going.

Education is very important. The future of this nation rests on what we do for our children's education. A record $4.134 billion has been spent on schools under the Greiner-Murray Government. Maintenance is up 50 per cent to $89m in 1988-89 and to $90m in 1989-90. These are tremendous steps forward. There were hiccups with the way in which the education system was tackled when the present Government came to office but they have been sorted out. The schools are working well; the teachers are doing a good job; their salaries have been increased; an extra $40m has been provided for computer education over four years; and $142m has been allocated especially for rural education over the four years. In Port Macquarie itself, stage two of the Westport High School-a new technology high school-is on track.

In the State electorate of Port Macquarie, $10m has been spent already on capital works-this is quite apart from the $80m for the new hospital at Port Macquarie and another $60m for the new Coffs Harbour hospital. The Greiner-Murray Government has made an outstanding and tremendous contribution to the rejuvenation of New South Wales in general and, in particular, to the north coast of New South Wales.

We all bleed about unemployment. But we know from the unemployment figures released last week that the level of unemployment in New South Wales was only 8.6 per cent against a national average of 9.9 per cent and figures in the other States of 10 per cent and up to 11.1 per cent. Without New South Wales, the average unemployment figure would have been well over 10 per cent.

The Independents had nothing whatsoever to do with that. They never can because they have no policies; they do not have the opportunity to have an input into either Government policy or Opposition policy. The Independent member for North Sydney (Mr Mack), who sits behind me in the chamber, made the point a couple of days ago that he can ask in this place only one question in 125. We in the Opposition can ask at least seven questions a day in which our views can be put and the issues that we consider to be important can be pursued. I want to say to the people of New South Wales and to the north coast, in particular: vote for a team that has produced the goods.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially in Tamworth.
—Especially in Tamworth, as my colleague says. It is not the time to go back on success: do not turn your back on success; stay with the winning team-the National Party and the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs JAKOBSEN (Cowan) (1.39 p.m.) In the short time remaining, I would like to speak about minds in overdrive. I am sure that most members of the House would be aware that this is Schizophrenia Awareness Week. Last night the Australian Broadcasting Corporation screened a sensitive and informative documentary on this most misunderstood mental illness. The documentary was called Spinning Out. Last week the Bulletin magazine ran a feature entitled `Schizophrenia-A Fine Kind of Madness'.

I count myself fortunate to have a friend who is a schizophrenic. He is a clever, gentle, hardworking and good humoured person of whom I am extremely fond and to whom I am very grateful. The worth of his work, wit and general understanding of problems in the community is greatly appreciated by me, my husband and my staff. I believe that our close association over a number of years with this person has enabled me to became more familiar with the manifestations of this illness and the problems which can be associated with its treatment, as well as the pressures which the condition places upon the family members and the individuals themselves. Schizophrenics suffer from an unspecified disorder of the brain. Development of the condition does not result from bad behaviour on the part of the person affected or a bad upbringing on the part of that person's family. It seems to be a chemical abnormality which is genetically transmitted.

It is suggested that this chemical abnormality produces a change in the way the brain functions so as to alter its ability to filter or screen information. As a result, many sufferers experience a phenomenon best described as an overload of stimuli-that is, their head is full to overflowing with information; their brain is flooded with stimuli of all sorts and sizes; and their mind is in a state of overdrive. They are unable to select out the things that really matter from those that are just ancillary objects in their mind.

The flood of messages to the brain makes it extremely difficult for the schizophrenic person to make sense of the world, even at the best of times. The disorder in the brain distorts experience and thinking. Schizophrenia is not a split personality. It is not a Jekyll-and-Hyde syndrome. Fear and ignorance in society mean that schizophrenia is, however, considered to be a stigma and that stigma makes things even more difficult for the sufferer and for the members of the family who are desperately trying to cope with the disease and its worrisome side effects.

A mind in tumult produces anxiety and fear on the part of the sufferer. He or she will often experience thought disorders, paranoid delusions and exhibit some other bizarre behavioural symptoms. They frequently talk about hearing voices or having auditory delusions of that nature. Sometimes they have visitations from ghosts and other hallucinations. The vast majority-that is, 99 per cent-of schizophrenics are much more likely to hurt themselves than anyone else and depression and confusion are commonly experienced by them.

Schizophrenia is an illness dogged by despair. Between 10 per cent and 15 per cent of sufferers commit suicide. As caring human beings and elected representatives in this place, members of this Parliament have an obligation to do everything they can to reduce that percentage and the sum of human misery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member. I am convinced that much more needs to be done to assist with research into this illness and to better educate people in the community about its manifestations and treatment. Early intervention is essential and a family's request for help with a sufferer should be responded to quickly and sympathetically by the authorities and by medical practitioners.

SPEECH.PARA: One per cent of the general population will suffer from schizophrenia. Twenty-five per cent of sufferers will have a single attack and recover completely. The remaining 75 per cent will suffer for most, if not all, of their lives. This disorder affects men and women in equal numbers but men seem to suffer at an earlier age, that is, in their late teens or early 20s, while women tend to be struck down in their mid-to late 20s.

Medication is a prerequisite to sufferers coming to grips with their illness and making the decision to get their lives back together. Unfortunately, it may take many years before this point is reached and in the interim the sufferer can exhibit a marked reluctance to take medication on occasions. Many schizophrenics are homeless and it has been estimated that between 30 and 50 per cent of homeless people in our cities are mentally ill. Unfortunately, self-help and support groups are still few and far between in Australia and hospitalisation is not a solution for most sufferers.

Schizophrenics are human beings with an illness. They deserve to be treated with consideration by the community and the medical profession. They deserve to be able to participate usefully in our society, to the extent that their illness allows, along with everyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr GOODLUCK (Franklin) We hear many speeches in the House and my friend the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) made a very good speech a few minutes ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, a good member. One can be ecumenical in this place and one can give praise to the Australian Labor Party when it deserves it. Much of the time it does not deserve it, but on this occasion it does. I have been thinking about speeches. Lately, a lot of people have written to me saying, `Bruce, we have listened to your speeches in the House during the 16 years; some are good and some are bad'. The last person who wrote to me asked, `Bruce, can you sing?'. Well I can sing: `The autumn leaves'. One is not allowed to sing in this House but I can sing.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am making is that a lot of people listen to us and want us to tell them the good things as well as the economic woes that are occurring in Australia. If we have an opportunity to speak in this House, we should not waste the time of the Australian people. We should come to the point and tell them exactly where we stand on issues. We should try to point out, as our good friend the honourable member for Cowan did, some of the plights people face in Australia today who really need help. If we draw attention to such things, then we are earning our money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to highlight today one of our nation's greatest assets, libraries. Fifty per cent of all Australians make use of one or other of the nation's 15,000 libraries. In fact, every year some 122 million library items are borrowed from public libraries alone, making libraries among the most heavily used of public assets. This fact may surprise some, but each year more Australians use libraries than attend sporting fixtures.

SPEECH.PARA: Information is critical to the future of the Australian economy. It is in fact as critical as any other form of capital investment.

Whenever decisions are to be made that will affect the future of any enterprise or organisation, information is needed-information that is accurate, timely and concise. It has to be current information, regularly updated, and easy to access and use. The servicing of that information need is provided by Australia's 15,000 libraries. The Australian Council of Libraries and Information Services needs the support of people in this House to ensure that the importance of libraries is valued, supported and funded accordingly.

Libraries do many things for this country. They assist industry; they aid export enterprise; they help to maintain Australia's defences; they help to educate tomorrow's professionals; they help to formulate public policy; they support the rural economy; they help to save lives through medical research data and information; and they help to enhance efficiency by giving access to design data and maintenance manuals. They are important to this nation's successful future.

SPEECH.PARA: The buckets poured on Mr Goss from within his own Party this week are indicative of panic by the ALP in both seats. In the last four weeks the Liberal Party candidate in Toowoomba South has shown himself to be by far the best performer on the hustings and one who understands grassroots people power. SPEECH.PARA: We have a situation where there is obviously very close collusion between the New South Wales Government, which has an inability to face up to the breadth of technology that is possible in this field, and the selective support of this company to the point where the State Pollution Control Commission is sitting back, allowing dioxin levels way above what is allowed and allowing acid rain levels above what is allowed. It is not looking at the temperature levels under which this plant is operating, and it is not looking at the input of materials. We have a situation where, as I say, it is far more serious than this debate between the two parties in New South Wales as to whether it be in Corowa or Bathurst or Maryland. We have a situation they have repudiated--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Ronaldson

The Municipal Association of Victoria have advised the Council of the City of Ballarat that the Treasurer and the Australian Taxation Office are considering the imposition of PAYE tax instalments on allowances paid to Councillors, and to imposing Fringe Benefits Tax upon alleged benefits (such as meals provided at Council meetings,) and the attendance of Councillors at Civic functions. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pay tribute to the firm Electro Optics in Queanbeyan, which is an example to investors throughout Australia-investors who are all to often nervous Nellies in Australia. Dr Ben Grene and his team at Electro Optics have developed a laser radar tracking system, which is going to bring millions of dollars to Australia as a result of its unique export market. The tracking system is already being sold to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in the United States, to Saudi Arabia, and now to the United States defence forces in an evaluation test for a range finder.

Yesterday, Dr Ben Grene, along with Senator Button and I, made it clear that this has come through research and development tax deductions through this Government of 150 per cent. While people are investing in property, while people are sending their money overseas, a firm like this is setting the example. With a staff of 16 people, with employment going into other areas because of its high use of Australian contents, and because it is an entirely export industry, it is showing Australia where investment should go. It is going to yield a great return for Australia, and a great return for Australian employees in this region. So here we have a former Canberra public servant with a bit of imagination--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
