TALK.START.PARA: —It is the duty of members of this House to ask questions of Ministers about matters of public interest concerning their administration. I suggest that it is an equally important responsibility of Ministers to answer those questions. When a Minister's answer to a question placed on the Notice Paper is so brief, uninformative and evasive as to amount to a non-answer, then I do not believe that Minister is doing his job.

SPEECH.PARA: A classic non-answer was recently given by the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) to a question I placed on the Notice Paper on 11 March. I asked the Minister a detailed question in 11 parts which sought information about the Government's proposed resource security legislation, which was not then and is not now available. The Minister's answer on 18 April gave none of the information I asked for. It made very little effort to even address the points that were raised. It gave a reply that was remarkable for its brevity, evasion and irrelevance. I suppose the penalty for governments that become too arrogant is a political one. But there is more to it than that. A non-answer contributes to the widespread impression that the Parliament is irrelevant, and that we come here to waste our time and large amounts of public money. It helps to undermine our political system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of improved medical technology, and because of the postwar baby boom, we are all aware of the extent to which the aging problem has been accelerated within Australia. It is interesting to compare the relative handling of that problem by respective governments. In the last year of the Fraser Government, the sum total spent on aged care accommodation was $5.6m. Since this Government has come to office, the average expenditure per year has been about $160m per year. One can judge from that which side of the House genuinely cares about the care of the aged.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), the Minister at the table, is present in the chamber at the moment. In the last six years, in the electorate of Hunter, where nothing has been spent for so many years, at long last we are getting somewhere-$10m has been spent to provide nursing home and hostel beds in my electorate. It is a tribute to this Government that it genuinely cares for the aged, whereas before, nobody had any respect or care whatsoever for the aged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —To follow the advice of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) that we should take account of what we say in this House and use the time effectively, I wish to draw the attention of this Government to the problems that some of my constituents are having due to this recession that we had to have. I mention Becky, who is 19 years of age and works in Dandenong. She and three other employees, due to this recession, have had their work cut from five days to two days a week. They are not recorded on the unemployment benefits list. Becky has found another part time job, one day a week, to pay for her food and to run her car to and from that job. That money also pays for rent.

SPEECH.PARA: John is a good mechanic who has been retrenched, in the words of his boss, `Due to what is happening in Victoria at the moment'. He has a disabled son and a wife who has not worked because she has had to look after their son. John is unable to find a position in the motor car industry at the moment. Dennis operates a quarry truck. His business is down 70 per cent. Where he had six to eight loads a day, he is now doing one load.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—I inform the House that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner, is attending a meeting of the Torres Strait Regional Council and will be absent from Question Time today. Questions which would normally be addressed to Mr Tickner should be directed to the portfolio Minister, Mr Dawkins.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. This morning the Treasurer, in a call to arms, told all Australians to get on with it. When will the Prime Minister and the Government get on with introducing genuine labour market reforms and enterprise bargaining? When will they get on with introducing full competition into telecommunications? When will they get on with mining Coronation Hill? When will they get on with building the third runway at Sydney Airport? When will they get on with scrapping their illogical three-mine uranium policy? In short, if they do not get on with it, how can the rest of Australia? If they will not get on with it, why do they not get out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a devastating opening over. First of all, let us look at how we-that is, the Government and the community together-have been getting on with this question of labour market reform, because the Leader of the Opposition seems to imply that we have not been doing that. Let us see what we have done together to this point in the area of labour market reform. We started in 1983, when we inherited that dreadful mess that the Opposition left us-and we started immediately. We did not have to wait until the Opposition came along. We had to deal with the mess that Professor Hewson and the honourable member for Bennelong had left us. The economic adviser, Professor Hewson, left this unique achievement. No-one else had ever been able to do what Professor Hewson had done. He left us simultaneous double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. That was his achievement. We started from day one to rectify it.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us see what we have done together in rectifying that mess that the Opposition left. It is quite useful, I think-particularly in terms of the pathetic speech that the Leader of the Opposition made on the censure motion the other day in this place-to quote what he had to say in that respect. This was just about the only accurate thing he said in his speech:
There is nothing more compassionate that one can do for people in Australia than to give them a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to give them a job?
—I take you up. I think you are right. There is nothing more compassionate that you can do than to give them a job. I will tell you what you did when you had the responsibility.

—You had a rate of job growth over the whole of your period of office of 0.7 per cent per annum. We started the job that the Leader of the Opposition asked me about in this question from day one. As a result of the things that we have done together in the area of labour market reform, I can say, after eight years in office, that as against the Opposition's 0.7 per cent per annum rate of job creation we have 2.6 per cent per annum. Even the Leader of the Opposition's relative incapacity in the area of numeracy would allow him to understand that a relationship between 0.7 per cent per annum-the Opposition's rate of growth-and our 2.6 per cent per annum shows that we have a rate of growth nearly four times as high as that of the Opposition.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor!

—In other words, putting it as simply as I can so that the Leader of the Opposition and those behind him may be able to understand, the simple fact is that, if we had only replicated in our term of Government the same rate of job creation as the Opposition did, there would be one million fewer Australians in employment today.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar!
—If the rate of employment growth under the Hawke Government had been 0.7 per cent, which was the one the Opposition engineered, there would be one million fewer Australians in work today.

ANSWER.PARA: There is the answer as to what we are going to do. We have done almost four times better than the Opposition, and we have done it basically because of what we have done in the area of labour market reform. Instead of having confrontation, we have consultation. We have a situation where, in regard to the Opposition's rate of industrial disputation, we have reduced the area of industrial disputes by 60 per cent compared to what the Opposition did. We have reduced real non-farm unit labour costs by over 10 per cent. We have shifted the miserably low profit share which the Opposition inflicted upon this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—We have lifted the profit share to significantly higher levels, which led to record levels of investment as a proportion of gross domestic product as well as in absolute terms. That is what we have done. We do not have to sit here listening to those opposite telling us what to do, because we not only listened to what they had to say but we were also the inheritors of what they did. They made the worst mess of economy in the history of this country. Only Hewson and Howard were able to do it. Only they were able to produce record unemployment and record inflation simultaneously. It is because we sat down immediately with the trade union movement and with the employers that we transformed the industrial landscape of this country. May I finally say in respect of two of the issues that the Leader of the Opposition has raised, that is, Coronation Hill and the third runway--
—And uranium.
—I will mention uranium, if the honourable member likes. If he wants to talk about uranium, we will talk about that as well. Let us take the three issues.
—Tell us about that one.
—Order! The honourable member for Gilmore!

—In regard to Coronation Hill, we established under the law a process for investigating the various claims and positions of people in the community with interests as to what should happen. We had a lengthy Resource Assessment Commission process whereby the developers have had the full opportunity to put their case. People concerned with the environment have had the opportunity to put their case. And those representing Aboriginal interests have had the opportunity to put their case. We have now received that report from the Resource Assessment Commission. The Cabinet and the Government will consider that and make a decision accordingly.

ANSWER.PARA: I would suggest that the people of Australia would infinitely prefer that process-a process whereby all people are given an opportunity to put their case before an independent commission-than that of those opposite, who would mine everything and cut everything down. If that is what they want to do, they should go to the election in two years time saying that is what they want to do: do not worry about having an independent process; just dig it all up and cut it all down. We will be quite prepared to face them on that.

Secondly, in regard to the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, we are operating according to the law. The facts are quite straightforward. Presumably, those opposite would want to ignore what has happened in regard to the environmental impact statement processes. We now have a situation where under this Government, following the law, 2,000-odd public submissions have been received on the draft environmental impact statement, with some 14,000 specific comments. They canvass a broad range of technical, economic and environmental issues. They require investigation and analysis.

According to what those opposite are saying, presumably they do not give a damn about the environment; they simply say that they will make that decision-they will not give people the opportunity of putting their position and having it independently heard. As far as we are concerned, we will allow those submissions to be made. I believe that we will be in a position to make a decision on this matter well before the end of this year. That is a process which I believe is appropriate and should be followed. The honourable gentleman raised the question of uranium. Let us have a look at the question of uranium. The position is known-we have a three-mines policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is illogical.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—Let me say that within the Party, we have had a committee looking at this and the Party will examine the outcome. I am quite prepared to compare the position of this Government and the care it is prepared to take in regard to safeguards with the position of the Leader of the Opposition.
—Have you ever heard of the Ranger inquiry?
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.
—Let us look at how careless the Leader of the Opposition would be in regard to the selling of Australia's uranium.

—Mr Speaker, I have a point of order. Of all people, the Prime Minister is abusing Question Time. This is the first question of the day, he has taken 10 minutes, and he is not yet part through his answer.
—Does the honourable member for Hume have a point of order?
—I ask you, Mr Speaker, to require the Prime Minister to draw his answer to a close.
—Order! The Prime Minister was asked a very wide ranging question and he is answering the question.
—And the Opposition kept adding to the question throughout my answer.
—Mr Speaker, I have a point of order on the question of time during Question Time. Is an honourable member entitled to ask eight questions in the guise of one, not even related?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The Government is proud of the fact that we have, in regard to the sale of uranium mined in Australia, the most stringent safeguards in the world. Our policy, which I believe would have the overwhelming endorsement of the Australian people, is that we should not recklessly intrude Australian uranium into the international fuel cycle, which is a fundamentally important consideration. Against that position, which we have religiously followed, the Leader of the Opposition wanders off and says that he would be prepared to consider selling uranium to Taiwan.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say this: this Government will not sell uranium to any country without an appropriate bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement. We require, as a minimum, that a non-nuclear weapon country be a party to the Treaty for the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, and that it has concluded a full scope safeguards agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency. Taiwan does not meet those requirements.

It is very ironic that it was the Liberal Party, under Malcolm Fraser, I might say, which developed these safeguards in an era of concern about nuclear proliferation. That concern certainly could not have lessened over the succeeding decade. This is what Malcolm Fraser said in this Parliament:
We urge the universal adoption of a safeguards standard of similarly high quality.

What a pity it is that this latest Liberal Party Leader does not share those same principles. We do, and we will not recklessly add to the dangers of the international fuel cycle by being prepared to sell uranium to people who do not meet those safeguard standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Would he please advise the House of the economic implications of today's one per cent reduction in official interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of my colleagues interjected, the implications of it are all good. And they are, because what we have seen today is the Government and the Reserve Bank of Australia taking the view that official interest rates should be reduced by one percentage point in its cash rates, which brings the fall in cash rates now to 7 1/2 percentage points. We have seen the bill rate, which is a measure of commercial interest rates, fall from 11 per cent before the release of the consumer price index the day before yesterday to 10.4 per cent this morning, and the 10-year bond rate falling to as low as 10.5 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: I might just add that although I am not comprehensively informed about this, the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, at least, moved down its housing and prime lending rates this morning, and other banks no doubt will follow because there is no reason why that one per cent cannot go straight through into prime lending rates and housing rates. This will help economic recovery. It will lower the cost of capital to business; it will lower the cost to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the level of the real interest rates.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting!
—The honourable member said, `I don't understand the cost of capital because real interest rates are not falling'. God, he is devastating!
—He is a lost cause.
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

—The lower cost of capital will help business and the lower mortgage rates will help every person who has a mortgage. The benefit for someone by the time of the last-the Prime Minister has given me the numbers; the monthly repayments--
—Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—They are very handy.
—Is that a list of the 18?
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—The monthly repayments on a mortgage of $100,000 at 17 per cent were $1,438 over 25 years, and they are now down to $1,128-a $310 a month difference. That is down from the peak and is $70-odd a week. At 15 years, for the same $100,000 mortgage, repayments have gone from $1,539 a month at 17 per cent to $1,265 at 13 per cent-or $274 a month difference. That is a very substantial benefit to employees and to people who have a mortgage and, of course, those lower rates must affect employment positively.

ANSWER.PARA: The most substantial thing the Government can do to produce a recovery in the economy is to reduce nominal interest rates, which we have now done by 7 1/2 percentage points. The point I made today, which the Leader of the Opposition picked up and which I am happy to repeat, is that the Government is saying to Australia now that rates are down a long way, and Australians should not accept any gloomy analysis that there is a recession here and there is no way out of it. There is a way out of it, and the best way out of it is for them to take the opportunities which are there now and to get cracking with them-take up those opportunities which official policy has now provided.

This is another significant fall in interest rates which I think will be passed very quickly through the banking system, all underpinned by a genuinely lower rate of inflation with inflationary expectations coming down to match and the 10-year bond rate, which is fixed in the market without any reference to the central bank's market operations, falling to 10.5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I am asking this question on behalf of one of my constituents, one of the millions of Australians now suffering under this Government's mismanagement. Frank is over 50 years of age. He was one of seven people retrenched from an insulation company in Dandenong after 31 years due to this recession we had to have. His wife continues to work part time. He is a broken man living for the first time with his wife as the breadwinner.
—Order! The honourable member for Corinella will get to his question.
—What can the Prime Minister say to this man, and why does he not do what most of his backbenchers want him to do and resign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The conclusion of the question is as inaccurate as the beginning of it. I would say to Frank and his family, as both I and the Treasurer have said, that the decisions that had to be taken in the last two years to tighten monetary policy to reduce the level of activity in this country were not decisions that we had any pleasure in taking, because we knew that they were going to cause hardship. We knew that this country was in a position-honourable members opposite have heard the Treasurer and me say it time after time; it is a simple statistic that the Opposition has refused to acknowledge and understand-where its expenditure was rising twice as fast as its production. If one has that situation, one cannot allow it to continue.

ANSWER.PARA: So we had a position of existing tight fiscal policy, a tighter fiscal policy than we had ever seen before, where we had turned the Budget deficit around into a Budget surplus. We had a tight wages policy where wages were not increasing as fast as inflation. In that situation, if we were going to slow down the economy we had to have a tightening of monetary policy.

We have rehearsed those facts with Opposition members on many occasions. They know as well as we do that, if we had not taken the decisions we did to tighten monetary policy, the world would have visited upon Australia an infinitely more draconian solution. My answer to the honourable member's constituent and other people around this country--

TALK.START.PARA: —Frank! Frank!

—I have already identified him-is that we regret that he is suffering at this time; that in fact it would have been infinitely worse, not only now but also for far longer into the future, if we had not taken those decisions. I would also ask the honourable member to say to Frank, if the honourable member has the honesty to be able to do it, and I doubt it--
—I have.
—All right. Then, will he undertake--
—Order!
—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. Is the comment the Prime Minister made, without any provocation or justification, in order or parliamentary? Why is he not required to withdraw that allegation?
—Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Bennelong will resume his seat.
—I took a point of order, Sir.

—Order! It probably is to the benefit of the House that honourable members do not use that sort of language. In a number of interjections that are passing on my left there are words used which it would take honourable members on both sides a great deal of effort not to use.

—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo. I warn the honourable member for Gippsland. If members on both sides do not stop using those sorts of phrases, I will take action against them. It might suit the House, I am sure, if the Prime Minister did withdraw the remark, and then we will also ensure that honourable members on both sides use language that is a little more fitting.

—I withdraw the observation that I doubt whether he will do this. I said that I doubt whether he had the honesty to do it. I withdraw that. Therefore, I look forward to his undertaking that he will convey these facts to Frank. Will the honourable member please tell him that he is a member of a Party which had the responsibility for looking after him and the rest of Australia, and the best he could do--
—No, come on.
—Order! The honourable member for Pearce will cease interjecting. I warn the honourable member for Corinella.

—I assume that the honourable member will tell him what I am suggesting-that in fact the Hawke Government has created one million more jobs than would have been created if we had done no more than meet the Opposition's standards.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I again draw your attention to the standing order concerning relevance. We want the Prime Minister to send a message to Frank--
—Order! The honourable member for Hume will resume his seat.
—About what Frank can do about losing his job.
—The Prime Minister is answering the question. The Prime Minister is relevant to the question.
—I would also ask that the honourable member convey to Frank the position currently of his Party that, in respect of its policy--
—I warn the honourable member for Isaacs.
—I warn the honourable member for Franklin as well.
—Tell Frank that it is the policy of those opposite that after he has been on the unemployment benefit for nine months they will throw him off it.

—If they will not tell him that, perhaps they will point out how much the implementation of that policy will mean not only to Frank but to the rest of his fellow Australians, because this is what is contained in the statement made by the Leader of the Opposition in 1990. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Why not cut off unemployments? We challenge him.
That is, he was challenging the Treasurer; and he continued:
Cut off unemployment benefits after nine months and match our policy.
These are the words of the Leader of the Opposition. So do not give me this business of shouting out and saying, `Not true'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not.
—If the honourable member for Corinella interjects again, I will name him.
—What was the Leader of the Opposition saying when he said it? He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Why not cut off unemployments? We challenge him. Cut off unemployments after nine months and match our policy.
Those are the words of the Leader of the Opposition. So if those opposite are saying it is not true, then they are saying that the Leader of the Opposition is not telling the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections.
—Just to give honourable members some idea of what would be involved in that, he went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: We are saving about $750m from that change.

Those opposite cannot have it both ways. They cannot say that they are going to be saving $0.75 billion from cutting off unemployment benefits and saying they do not mean it. They are saying that they are going to save $0.75 billion, but now they get up and say to me that they do not mean it. All I can say is that if the honourable member for Corinella, when he meets Frank, will tell him that he is a member of a party which is going to save $0.75 billion by throwing him and others off the unemployment benefit after nine months, then I will be very satisfied.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Prime Minister table the document from which he was reading?
—Is the Prime Minister quoting from a document?
—Mr Speaker, I will make the quote available to the Leader of the Opposition.
—No, the document.
—Is the Prime Minister quoting from a document? Is it a confidential document?
—Very, very confidential.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The Prime Minister claimed to be reading from a speech made by the Leader of the Opposition and then claimed it was his personal document. That is impossible.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.
—He should table it.
—There is no point of order.

—Can the Treasurer advise the House what contribution the Government wage-tax arrangements made to yesterday's historically low inflation rate? What action does the Government intend to take to ensure continuing low inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The lower inflation number recorded yesterday would simply not have been there without the wage-tax arrangements under accords mark 5 and 6. I demonstrate this claim by making the point that in 1989-90 average weekly earnings on a national accounts basis came out at 7.1 per cent, at a time when employers were offering 15 per cent wage settlements. National average weekly earnings were held at 7.1 per cent into that period and, of course, had a pipeline of only about 5 per cent running into 1990-91.

ANSWER.PARA: To secure that number, the Government introduced two tax cuts-one from 1 July 1989 and one from 1 January 1990. Honourable members will remember that they were split, with the top marginal rate falling on 1 January 1990. They cost $5.76 billion; they were worth $26 a week to the average taxpayer around average weekly earnings; and they were worth a wage equivalent of 5.2 per cent of average weekly earnings.

That is why wages were held at 7 per cent during 1989-90 and did not blow to 15 per cent in a boom. On 1 January 1991, we spent on an annual basis another $3.5 billion, or $18 a week, for such a person's average weekly earnings, with a wage equivalent of 3.1 per cent to wage and salary earners. Between the two tax cuts, the wage equivalent was 8.3 per cent, which was brought out by the strength of the Government's surplus and by its operations under the accord. If that 8 per cent were in the wage system today, we would be looking at an inflation rate of around 11 per cent to 13 per cent. The reason inflation is now at 5 per cent is the accord and the wage-tax trade-offs. While there is some deflationary influence, obviously, from the recession, the great bulk of the fall in inflation has not come from the recession itself, but from the accord.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—How can the honourable member say `Rubbish' when I have just read the figures to the House?
—Because you always talk rubbish.
—The bald iggle over there has just come up with a scintillating piece of repartee.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: what did Kristine's mate just say? Now, let us get this straight. The Treasurer made a personal attack on the honourable member for McPherson and that should be withdrawn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I name the honourable member for O'Connor.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the honourable member for O'Connor be suspended from the service of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for O'Connor is suspended from the service of the House.
—We have not had a vote on it yet.
—I just put the question and declared it carried.
—I want to vote-I call for a vote.
—No-one supported you.
—Order! I put the question that the honourable member for O'Connor be suspended and the motion was carried. Does the House want a vote on it?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor is therefore suspended from the service of the House. The Serjeant-at-Arms will remove the honourable member for O'Connor.
—I won't go.
—Order! Both sides of the House will come to order.
—I will not go. Don't come here, Phil. I won't go without a vote.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is a division required?

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Treasurer completed his answer?

—Taking away from the Government the credit for a massive fall in inflation funded by fiscal policy built on cuts in government spending is a very paltry thing for the Opposition to try to do. We have had an historic breakthrough on inflation, and yet what we find is that the Opposition wishes to pin this on the recession only and not on the strength of the Government's wage policy under the accord. I make the claim again: the accord is the principal reason why inflation has fallen and it will be the accord which will be the principal reason why inflation will remain low, coupled with a sensible monetary policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to the statement of the Treasurer made during the election campaign of 1990 on his Government's new unemployment policy, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we've got to go now and intensively interview them . . . make them apply for work. If they don't apply for work, we'll bump them off.
What was meant by the statement that he would `bump them off'? Is it not a fact that Frank will not get his job back until the Prime Minister loses his?

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Treasurer was saying, in shorthand form, was that the Government had taken a decision, which I think was applauded generally at the time, that we would tighten up the work tests. Thus we would have the situation that if a person were in a position of applying for unemployment benefit but had not satisfied the increased stringency of the work test or were not in a training or education program, in those circumstances, and those circumstances alone, unemployment benefit would not be paid. Of course, if in fact that person had sought to get a job, could not get one, met the work test and was not in a training or education program, there would be no question that that person would get the unemployment benefit, and would get it indefinitely while those conditions were met. The Treasurer, in shorthand terms, was referring to that. That was the factual situation of which the Treasurer was aware.

—I ask the Treasurer whether he is aware of suggestions that the Government should set an inflation target of zero to 2 per cent? What are the implications of such a suggestion and, in particular, what would the implications be for monetary policy with the adoption of such a target?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The notion of having an inflation target to be policed by a central bank without any recourse or reference to the state of the economy is something which is unreal and for which this country has no institutional framework for delivery. There is no way that a group of appointed officials in a central bank can simply decimate the economy without reference to the parliamentary processes and the democratic processes that go with that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition yesterday suggested that he should expropriate the Government's low inflation rate and then take it down to a range of from zero to 2 per cent. The inflation rate for the March quarter for Japan is 4.1 per cent; for the United States, 5.2 per cent; for Germany, 2.7 per cent; and for France, 3.4 per cent. If it was so easy that one just waved a magic wand and told a central bank, `Here is your target, zero to 2 per cent; go get them and get the rate down', how is it that Japan, which has a very subtle economy, a properly managed monetary system and sitting with 4.1 per cent inflation, Germany with 2.7 per cent inflation and the United States with 5.2 per cent cannot do it? The answer is that there must be a national consensus to bring inflation down. It cannot be brought down simply by a central bank.

The notion that one can just hand across, by some legislative amendment, control of such an inflation target to a central bank, when we have seen the economy recessed and unemployment rising in order to get inflation to 4.9 per cent with the wage tax trade-off and, as I said earlier, with nearly $9 billion of tax cuts in place to do it-to think that one can just click one's fingers and down it goes to zero or one per cent has no basis in reality.

The Opposition may seek to traffic in it as a way of promoting itself, but it has no basis in reality. That is why, particularly without any recourse to the labour market, without any recourse to the trade unions, particularly outside the context of an incomes policy, it is fairyland stuff. However, on top of that, the Leader of the Opposition wants to add 15 percentage points to prices through a consumption tax while he is going to zero inflation. He wants to take inflation down to zero while he is adding 15 percentage points through a consumption tax.

Last night on television he said that it was a one-off increase that would pass through the system. Well, Chernobyl was a one-off event; but the radiation is still passing through the Swiss cows three or fours later. That is what would happen to our inflation rate. It would be a one-off shock, but it would take a while to pass through the Australian economy as we floated back to 15 per cent. As all the dairy herds of Europe are living with the one-off effect of an event in their lives, we would be living with the one-off effect of this simplistic nonsense that we can have a 15 percentage point addition to the price system and zero inflation.

It is rubbish. It is not even reportable rubbish. To be proposing at once a zero inflation rate and a 15 per cent consumption tax to go with it is such rubbish it does not even deserve reporting. And this is all at a time when this Government's policies produce an inflation rate of under 5 per cent, coming from the 11 per cent those opposite produced in similar circumstances in the early 1980s. There is no possibility of the Opposition having a realistic--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you not ask a question instead of interjecting all day. You sit there and mumble, interject and talk under your breath. You never ask a question.
—You should address the Chair.
—He is addressing me and I am addressing him in return.
—Order! The Deputy Prime Minister will not respond to the interjections and the Leader of the Opposition should not interject.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—The right honourable member for New England has a point of order.

—Mr Speaker, it is, as you know, well against our Standing Orders for a person to engage in derogatory remarks about any other member of this House. I suggest to you that the nature and character of responses given by the Treasurer are quite contrary--
—Order! Members on my right will cease interjecting!
—Oh, Sinkers! They are all laughing at you.
—Order! The right honourable member for New England on a point of order.

—Mr Speaker, the remarks made by the Treasurer, as you would know, are quite contrary to the intent of our Standing Orders. I would suggest to you that he be required to desist from them instead of not only engaging in across the bar conversation but ignoring you in the presentation of his reply.

—Order! I am sure that members of the Opposition will also take on board what the right honourable member for New England has said-that interjections across the table are unparliamentary. Ministers should not respond to interjections, but often, I am sure, even the right honourable member for New England might have been known to have responded to an interjection. We are probably less likely to have this problem if members of the Opposition do not interject while Ministers are giving their answers.

—The audacity of the right honourable member for New England has taken my breath away. I have one sentence left. I can only say that the Leader of the Opposition's anti-inflation policy is simply a nonsense.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the wage deal he negotiated with the wharfies will, together with national wage increases and other bonuses, ultimately give them more than $100 a week extra on top of the $45,000 they now receive? Is it also a fact that the average farmer will earn this year less than $100 a week? Given the Prime Minister's comments yesterday about social divisions, how does he justify a weekly wage rise for the wharfies which is greater than the income of the farmer? Is this what he means by bringing the nation together?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume from the question by the honourable gentleman that he believes there should be some indexing or correlation between farm income and the income of wharfies. What a remarkable situation that would be! He knows very well that the income of farmers, by the very nature of their occupation, is highly variable.
—They have been reduced, but that is not happening on the waterfront.
—Order!

—Unfortunately, it is the case that at this time the income of farmers has been massively reduced-and massively reduced predominantly because of what has happened to the prices they receive for their products. The honourable gentleman well knows-and has been good enough on occasions to acknowledge it, and I think publicly-the work that the Government is doing to try to tackle the problem. When I go to Europe in a few weeks time, as requested by the members of the Opposition, I will be directly talking to leaders in Europe to try to bring them to their senses on this issue so that our farmers-I believe the most competitive in the world-will be able to do what they would do in an uncorrupted international market for agricultural products, and that is take on and beat the best in the world. The honourable gentleman knows the truth of what I am saying-that the predominant determinant --
—It is a domestic matter to deal with before you go overseas.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party!

—The predominant determinant of the present position of low farm incomes is what is happening to prices. The honourable gentleman knows that and he knows, when he is prepared to talk directly on these things, that the Government is doing all it can to address that problem.

ANSWER.PARA: If the honourable gentleman wants to suggest that somehow or other, whether with regard to wharfies or any other employed people in the community, there will be an indexed relationship between what happens to farm income and the income of these other people in the community, then that would have to take the blue ribbon prize for stupidity in what is already an array of stupidity from the other side of the House with regard to wage fixing.

I have already had cause to quote from the recent issue of Australian Business of 15 May with regard to the waterfront where the employers point out that the increases in remuneration will flow not merely from the arrangements in which I was involved but will also involve, in particular, incentive and productivity, enterprise-based agreements still to be negotiated. Employers believe that they are appropriate because of the massive increase in productivity which will come from these arrangements.

As I said in the House the other day, it is acknowledged in the industry by employers that there will be productivity improvements on the waterfront of the order of 60 per cent as a result of these changes. It is appropriate that the workers involved who will be engaged in relocation, retraining, undertaking more productive duties in a more productive way-and the employers themselves recognise this-should receive some of the benefit of those increases in productivity. Of course, it is appropriate that they should; that is the very essence of getting effective structural reform in this country.

We will not get effective structural reform-effective micro-economic reform-if we go along to employees and say, `Look, you are going to be in a position where a whole lot of your workmates can be put out of a job. You are going to be retrained, you are going to have to undertake to work with new machinery in new ways, in more productive ways but'-parenthetically-`we want to tell you that you are not going to get anything out of it, you are not going to get any contribution'.

This is a fundamental absurdity. It is my profound hope that the Opposition will not change from the position it has adopted now, and that it will go into the next election with the proposition which underlines the question I have just had put to me; that is, with regard to employees, whether they be on the waterfront or elsewhere, if they are involved in restructuring and reform which produces massive productivity increases, the position of the Opposition will be that those employees get no reward whatsoever for it. I tell the Opposition this: if it goes to the next election with that as its policy, it will be decimated as it deserves to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. Can the Minister inform the House of the significance of the lower domestic inflation rate on Australia's trade performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As all honourable members would recognise, the achievement of this lower inflation rate will clearly improve the international competitiveness of our industries and, particularly, I think, the growing competitiveness of Australian goods-I will indicate some figures on that in a moment-will be given further enhancement by the comparative position on inflation.

ANSWER.PARA: Our inflation rate is now 4.9 per cent which is well below the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average of around 6.3 per cent, and also lower than the average of the seven major industrial economies which include some of our major trading partners. It is important to note that there has been a long term decline in the inflation rate in this country over the last three years, and that has tended to run against the international trend which has been moving in the other direction.

Our inflation rate reached some 7 per cent in late 1988, and at that time the annual inflation in the seven major industrial economies was running at around 3.5 per cent. Of course, that gap between inflation in this country and in the seven major industrial powers overseas was much commented upon by the media in this country. We have now reversed that relationship between our inflation rate and those of the major industrial countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the first time in six years.
—Moreover, that lower domestic inflation--
—I am referring to the trend.
—As I say, but trending over time--
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong.

—May I make the comment that, as I have already said, that is something that has been trending over time and running contrary to the general movement in the OECD countries. I think we can look forward to a further welcome boost to our trading position as a result of this. We are already running a significant surplus on merchandise trade. Trade surpluses have been recorded in 10 out of the last 12 months. Despite very weak commodity prices and major problems in two of our major export industries, we have been running a significant surplus on merchandise trade.

ANSWER.PARA: If we look at the figures over the last year, exports rose by over 10 per cent in March 1991 compared to the March 1990 figure. Even more importantly, given our emphasis on the nations of the Association of South East Asian Nations, over the last year there has been a 30 per cent increase in export trade with those countries; that is, up from $3.2 billion to $4.2 billion. We can look forward to a further competitive advantage in relation to our trading partners as a result of this inflation change.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. What is the future role of the Industrial Relations Commission in wage fixation in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is something that will be determined by the evolution of events in the course of this year.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—As I said, it will be determined by the evolution of events. We have a situation where the Commission has, for the first time since the accord has been in place, refused to implement the accord. Of course, that is the absolute right of the Commission. It is an independent body and it has the absolute right, if it so wishes, not to accept the arguments of the parties supporting the accord and to come to a decision of some other kind, which it has done in the national wage case. That is the Commission's absolute right. However, it must accept that if it does that and the parties still believe that the accord is in the national good and should be pursued despite the Commission's decision, and that they have an absolute right to do that, the Commission's role must necessarily change.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commission's importance has been enormously enhanced in recent years by the accord. The Commission's historic role was not to determine the absolute level of wage increases year by year; its role was to establish award conditions which were minima, on top of which there were additional conditions of employment, including additional wage increases, built in in the marketplace. That was the role it played. It was a part role, not the whole of the role. But through the accord, what has been happening is that the Commission, through its decisions up until now to implement the accord, has been determining not just the minimum increases that would apply but also the absolute level of increases that would apply year by year. That has given it an enhanced role over and above that which it has historically had.

The Commission's absolute right to make the decision in the national wage case a month ago not to continue that process carries with it the implication that the role that it has had in the last six or seven years will no longer apply, particularly in light of the view of the parties to the accord that they wish, for reasons which I and the Government believe to be very good ones, to proceed with the accord. It will be carried out without the involvement of the Commission, I suspect. Of course, it may be that the Commission, in the light of events, would still see that perhaps it should carry out a role. In some respects I guess it will continue to do so, but in general we must expect that the outcome, until there is a further review of the principles, will be that the Commission's role will be a reduced one. How it develops after that depends on what further principles are developed by the Commission and the parties' response to them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TECHNICAL AND FURTHER EDUCATION: NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of reports that the New South Wales technical and further education system is in chaos, with large numbers of both intending and continuing students being unable to obtain places in TAFE? What contribution does the Commonwealth Government make to TAFE in New South Wales? What does the reported situation in New South Wales TAFE suggest for the national training task?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am bound to agree with the assessment that the New South Wales TAFE system does find itself in a state of chaos. The New South Wales TAFE system has historically played a very important role in providing post-school opportunities for young people seeking to enter the work force. Unfortunately, the New South Wales Government has decided to reduce its funding commitments to the TAFE system in New South Wales, thereby reducing the number of opportunities available for people desiring to enter TAFE and even in relation to those people in the TAFE system in TAFE courses desiring to complete them.

ANSWER.PARA: If we look at the report of the Auditor-General in New South Wales, we find that in 1988 there were 474,000 places. By 1990, this had fallen by nearly 100,000 places to 373,000 places, growing only slightly back to 400,000 places in 1991. This is as a result of the New South Wales Government pursuing a policy which introduced fees extensively into the TAFE system and relying on the development of courses for which it could either charge fees through that system or, in other ways, charge industry. I think this has had appalling consequences for young people. It means that the queues outside TAFE colleges have extended. Worse than that, people halfway through their courses have been obliged to discontinue those courses.

The honourable member asks what the Commonwealth's role has been in this area. As he would know, the Commonwealth has a minor role in the funding of TAFE throughout Australia. But to the extent that we have been funding TAFE, our funding has increased in real terms in recent years, in terms of our commitment to both recurrent and capital expenditure. I remind the House that in the March statement the Prime Minister announced that we would increase our funding for TAFE in New South Wales by $16.6m in order to increase by some 5,000 the number of places in prevocational courses.

This is a serious matter, not only for those people who are affected but also for the training effort which is so crucial to Australia's future development. In an area which is more centrally the Commonwealth's obligation, that of higher education, between the period 1987 to this triennium ending in 1993 we have increased the number of university places by more than 26,000 at a time when the New South Wales Government has chosen to reduce the number of places in TAFE. For a party and a government which prides itself on good management, this is a very poor example of management of its own financial resources and, more importantly, appalling planning in terms of the human resource requirements of New South Wales in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to advice that the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, has provided to the Government. He said that the political advertising ban contravenes article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Does the Government still maintain that the role of the Commission is to act as a public watchdog for the Government on abuses of human rights? If so, can he explain the seemingly inexplicable, namely, why the Government refuses to make Mr Burdekin's advice public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Burdekin, has made his views known both publicly and privately from the time the Government announced its decision to introduce legislation to regulate broadcasting of political advertisements and to provide for effective disclosure of political donations. Relevant Ministers have always been concerned to ensure that the proposed legislation would be consistent with Australia's international obligations under the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Burdekin's advice was provided before he had seen the Bill, which was introduced into the Parliament on Thursday, 9 May. On receipt of Mr Burdekin's advice, the Government considered whether it should proceed with the Bill. It was satisfied that the issues raised by Mr Burdekin concerning freedom of speech were those which had been considered by Ministers during the preparation of the legislation and, therefore, were matters of which the Government was fully aware.

The Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, sent copies of the Bill, the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech to the Human Rights Commissioner and has sought a meeting with him to discuss any concerns which Mr Burdekin might still have considering the Bill. I assure the honourable member that the Government will review the position in the light of those discussions between Senator Bolkus and Mr Burdekin.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the meantime, would you table his advice?

—I am not prepared to give that undertaking. I will have discussion with the relevant Ministers and see whether it is appropriate to provide it. I know that the honourable member has asked the question seriously. I think the important thing is to say that those discussions will be held with Mr Burdekin to see whether, in the light of what the Government has done, he still has those concerns. We will review the position in the light of the discussions between the Minister and Mr Burdekin.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The House, I am sure, would be aware that the Minister has recently announced the establishment of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the appointment of a chairman designate as part of the Government's recovery plan for the wool industry. I ask the Minister: what indeed is the role of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically, the role of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission is to clear, on behalf of the wool industry, the wool industry's debt and to clear the stockpile in the most sensitive and the most commercial way possible. During the life of the previous reserve price scheme, on two occasions about two million bales of wool were cleared, but in the present circumstances we have a far different situation from any we have ever had before.

ANSWER.PARA: Following the Vines committee report and a range of other advice to the Government, we decided that the best way to handle this unprecedentedly large stockpile and debt was to set up a Wool Realisation Commission at some distance from the Wool Corporation itself, but certainly in conjunction with it as far as the Wool Corporation's ongoing role is concerned. We think that, once we have the Wool Realisation Commission selected, it will get on with the job in as transparent a way as is possible with removing the stockpile and putting it out onto the market.

I have already made announcements about the Government's strategy in this regard, and the transparency is very much contained within the approach of a debt reduction schedule. The reason why the Government put in a loan facility of some $200m up front-that is, effectively some $45m cash up front-was so that there is no undue pressure put on the Realisation Commission to put wool onto the market in the first year or two of the Commission's activities.

This is all a question of balance; it is all a question of estimation; it is all a question of commercial adaptation to circumstances as they unfold. At present, there are all sorts of estimates around, for example, of the size of the wool clip in the year ahead. Some estimates are now down to 900 million kilograms, and of course there are all sorts of estimates around as to the price that will prevail in a free market; and it is because we are dealing with conjecture that there is a need for commercial flexibility as well as transparency.

In passing, I point out that there has been a lot of discussion about whether or not the wool tax or levy should be 12 or 15 per cent, and what everyone ignores, of course, is that we do not understand what 12 or 15 per cent is going to be of. In other words, we do not know the price. If the price averaged 400c for the season ahead, the difference between 12 and 15 per cent is exactly 12c. That is why, when the Leader of the National Party says that 15 per cent is pure thuggery, 12 per cent is okay and 8 per cent is delectable, it is a complete nonsense. An amount of 12c is not going to send 25 per cent of the wool industry broke, as the Leader of the National Party would have us believe.

These are all matters for a very fine commercial judgment. I believe that with the setting-up of the Wool Realisation Commission and the appointment of Mr David Clarke of the Macquarie Bank, an astute leading financial figure, as Chairman of that Commission-he has accepted the position-we will certainly see the most sensible path being taken in getting on with the job of getting rid of the stockpile, getting rid of the debt and re-establishing the wool industry to fit the role that it once played in our economy.
