DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the detailed response to the recommendations from the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, Not Dollars Alone.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
REPORT OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION-``NOT DOLLARS ALONE''
COMMITTEE RECOMMENDATIONS AND GOVERNMENT RESPONSES
Recommendation 1 (paragraph 4.21)
The Committee recommends that departments:
- accord high priority to internal devolution of the running costs system including to regional offices; and
- increase their efforts in identifying the results to be achieved with given resources and in linking resource allocation decisions to those results.
Government Response

The Government is determined that devolution of responsibility within the public sector will remain a key thrust of the reforms introduced under the Financial Management Improvement Program. In particular, it believes that future progress in this area will depend on the internal devolution of administrative responsibilities for running costs appropriations within departments and agencies, including their regional offices.

The Government also will continue to encourage departments and agencies to focus attention on the link between resource ``inputs'' and the achievement of program results. It also should be recognised, however, that the Parliament, through its scrutiny of the efficiency and effectiveness of programs has an important role to play in achieving ``value for money''.
Comment
The Government's response to recommendations dealing with devolution are dealt with in detail in relation to Recommendation 9.

With regard to the inter-relationship of devolution and running costs, the Government considers that the introduction of the overall running costs system has provided agencies with a medium-term, predictable base for resource allocation decisions, together with the flexibility to manage within broader-but tighter-budgetary limits. The flexibility of the system allows program managers freedom to make transfers between various inputs, including between administrative expenditures and salaries and-within prescribed limits-between financial years.

The Government shares the view of the Committee that devolution within agencies-including that to Commonwealth Regional Offices-has scope for improvement. The Government has a commitment to further encouraging agencies to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the FMIP reforms. This will include the further devolution of authority and responsibility throughout their administrative structures.

In relation to the better linking of resource ``inputs'' and the ``results'' achieved by programs, the Government considers that the manner in which Program Management and Budgeting (PMB) has been introduced has acted to focus managers' attention on the issue of``value for money''. The Government is confident that the framework is now in place by which strategically-focused, outcome-oriented objectives will work to bring about increasingly cost-effective ``results''. This framework will also provide a firm basis for the reporting of performance-both internally and to the Parliament-and aid both portfolio Ministers and those concerned with central budgetary decision-making in determining resource allocations and the setting of priorities within Government.
Recommendation 2 (paragraph 4.39)
The Committee recommends that the DOF
- take steps to improve its marketing of `the efficiency dividend' policy to public service organisations; and
- continue to take careful account of the merits of exceptional cases in applying the `efficiency dividend' policy.
Government Response
The Government accepts the recommendation of the Committee.
Comment

The Government has repeatedly espoused the obligation on the Public Service to generate on-going efficiencies in its general operations, and the prerogative of governments to decide on the distribution or utilisation of the savings generated by the efficiency gains. In a letter to public service union officials in 1988, the then Ministers for Finance and Industrial Relations stated that the:
``. . . Government's policy to seek efficiency gains . . .
was designed to provide departments with a medium term perspective and a stable planning environment rather than subject them to arbitrary and last minute savings measures.
``The justification for the efficiency dividend rests

on the very substantial improvements in the management environment in recent years . . . It is necessary both for central budgeting, and also for management and planning in each department, to set annual targets and to anticipate the achievement of those targets in departmental budgets.''

The Government believes that there is scope for efficiency improvements in the public sector as elsewhere and has therefore decided on an annual `dividend' of 1.25% of running costs to be returned to the budget by all agencies, bar a small number of explicit exemptions. This procedure imposes an even-handed degree of discipline on agencies for the efficient use of operational expenses and delivers an incentive for managers to utilise the opportunities provided by the financial management reforms. There are other direct incentives for efficient management deriving from the ability of agencies to retain savings over and above the dividend and other revenues arising, for example, from retention of some receipts earned discretionally by agencies.
Recommendation 3 (paragraph 5.29)

The Committee recommends that departments and agencies should have in place appropriate management information systems to provide accurate costing information either in conjunction with or as soon as possible after the introduction of charging.
Government Response
The Government accepts the recommendation of the Committee.
Comment

As discussed further in relation to Recommendation 11 of the Committee's report, the Government recognises the importance of effective Management Information Systems (MISs). Such systems are considered essential to the successful implementation of a range of reforms introduced under the FMIP including; the devolution of responsibility; performance monitoring and the subsequent internal and external reporting of results for accountability purposes; evaluation; and user charging.

With specific regard to user charging, the Government notes that, as detailed in the Committee's report, tangible incentives are now available through receipts retention for departments and agencies to benefit from a proportion of the receipts arising from the sale of goods or services. Any receipts retained by agencies, however, will involve only those monies over and above the costs incurred in the production of the goods and services sold.

This situation will send powerful signals to the individual managers involved. The Government is confident, therefore, that managers will respond to these signals and ensure that Management Information Systems which can provide accurate costing information on production activities are in place, or soon will be set in place, at the time of the introduction of user charging.
Recommendation 4 (paragraph 5.50)

The Committee recommends that there should be a case by case determination of `public interest' elements of government programs and that the DOF accept responsibilities for the consistency of the criteria applied.
Government Response
The Government accepts the recommendation of the Committee.
Comment

The Government agrees with the Committee's view that the Department of Finance, as the central agency with particular responsibility in this matter, should take a consistent approach in the determination of ``public interest'' elements within Government programs. Clear, central guidance will enable individual managers in departments and agencies to assess their particular circumstances and take advantage of the opportunities available following the introduction of user charging and the related retention of receipts.

At the same time, however, it should be recognised that criteria produced by central agencies such as Finance necessarily will provide only general guidance to agencies and individual managers. In the final analysis, determination of the public interest elements of government programs resides with the individuals who manage those programs.
Recommendation 5 (paragraph 5.69)

The Committee recommends that DOF give particular attention to reviewing the revenue retention arrangements for research organisations such as the Defence Science and Technology Organisation to ensure that those organisations receive adequate financial returns and incentive in commercialising their innovations.
Government Response

The Government notes the Committee's recommendation. In response, it points out that, on 7 November 1990, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel announced that the profits arising from the commercial activities of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) would be retained by the Defence portfolio and, in the first instance, would go toward providing working capital for developing DSTO's commercial activities. (The text of the relevant News Release is attached.)

The Government is confident that the new arrangements announced in relation to DSTO will form a broad model by which national research organisations can receive incentives to further commercialise their operations and subsequent innovations.
Recommendation 6 (paragraph 5.88)

The Committee recommends that DOF should review reporting requirements in relation to user charging under Explanatory Notes and other statutory reporting requirements with a view to resolving any unnecessary duplication.
Government Response

The Government is committed to ensure that proper accountability information on program performance and activities is available in the various reporting documents with the least practicable duplication. In relation to Portfolio Explanatory Notes, the Government considers that, subject to the on-going inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration (SSCFPA) into Matters Relating to Estimates Committees' Documentation and Procedures, the current guidelines for the presentation of information relating to receipts from user charging will require only marginal changes into the medium-term.
Comment

The Government notes that the present guidelines for the preparation of Portfolio Explanatory Notes require that, for each program element reporting in the Notes, all details of staffing and other resources available are set-out for scrutiny by Parliament. Further, this specifically includes ``receipts included in net annotated appropriations'' which would encompass most agencies' receipts from the implementation of charging for services. (Attachment A to 1990-91 Portfolio Explanatory Notes Guidelines, issued as Estimates Memorandum 1990/17, page 13 refers.)

In the case of larger commercial activities within agencies, the Government notes that the current inquiry by the SSCFPA into Matters Relating to Estimates Committees' Documentation and Procedures will report on the effective parliamentary scrutiny of Trust Accounts. This will inform future Government decisions on the reporting mechanisms for public sector Trust Accounts.
Recommendation 7 (paragraph 5.89)
The Committee asks to be informed of the present policies applied by DOF in the following areas:
- revenue retention;
- budget supplementation;
- public interest' issues;
- external charging;
- charging under competitive conditions; and
- incentives for good performance.
This information is to be made available shortly after the end of each financial year between now and the end of the 1992/93 financial year.
Government Response

The Government welcomes the opportunity to regularly inform Parliament and parliamentary committees of the changes which are, and have been, taking place within the Commonwealth public sector. With regard to the actual format and timing of such briefing, however, the Government is of the view that this would be best left to further negotiation and agreement between the Department of Finance and the Committee itself.
Recommendation 8 (paragraph 6.29)

The Committee recommends that further streamlining of the budgetary and regulatory framework should have regard to a demonstrated and significant improvement in performance information and evaluation and accountability practices within the public sector.
Government Response
The Government accepts the recommendation of the Committee, and points to past achievements in this area.
Comment

A common theme of the budgetary and other major public sector reforms has been the expectation that efficiency and effectiveness would improve if individual Ministers and their departments assumed more active control over their program resources and outcomes-that is, through the devolution of responsibility for these matters to the individuals who are best placed to take necessary decisions.

This is being done by a lessening of many of the detailed and prescriptive controls exercised by central agencies, and encouraging departments to use the greater flexibility now available to them to actually manage (as opposed to administer) their functional responsibilities; managing the resources given to them; managing the risks that may be inherent in their activities; and accepting the fact that they will be called to account for the results they achieve.

Devolution is not an end in itself, but rather a means to achieve improved performance. Quite properly, those who are devolving authority expect improved reporting on how devolved powers are being used to enhance performance. Thus the reforms have also given major emphasis to the issue of accountability. (Aspects of accountability are also dealt with in response to the Committee's Recommendation 13, below).

In terms of the actual reporting of program performance, the Government believes that the quality of performance information available for proper accountability to internal management, the Executive and Parliament has been materially enhanced. There has been a deliberate attempt to focus accountability on performance and what is being achieved with the resources made available. This contrasts with the previous system of accountability which concentrated almost exclusively on reporting inputs and processes. (A further discussion of Performance Information is offered in response to the Committee's Recommendation 10, while a detailed treatment of the issue of the evaluation of programs is given in response to Recommendation 12.)
Recommendation 9 (paragraph 6.53)
The Committee recommends that departments:
- review the appropriateness of the devolutionary steps taken to date and identify where further devolutionary steps (if any) are justified;
- plan and train staff to ensure that devolution is undertaken effectively; and
- progress the development of relevant information, communication and evaluation systems.
Government Response
The Government accepts the view of the Committee.
Comment

The need to provide public sector managers with greater authority has been a consistent theme running through reports on public administration since the mid-1970s (eg the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration [1976] and the Reid Review of Commonwealth Administration [1983]). A common concern has been an imbalance between authority and responsibility. Of perhaps greater importance has been the low level, and diffuse nature, of both these concepts. Budgetary and regulatory reforms have paid particular attention to placing decision-making in the hands of those best placed to make particular decisions. At the same time, however, increased devolution of responsibility must be matched by an enhanced level of accountability for the decisions which have been taken.

In terms of centralised controls, the Government believes that devolution of budgetary and financial management authority from the traditional ``watch-dog'' agencies to ``line'' departments has gone as far as it can. The total resources available to each agency from the budget must continue to be set by Ministers collectively, with agencies having incentives to achieve savings within that total and, in some cases, to pursue additional revenue through charging. Within this framework, portfolio budgeting means that all but the more politically sensitive and costly resource allocation decisions are now in the hands of individual Ministers and their portfolios, subject only to ratification by Cabinet.

The Government is aware, however, that devolution of responsibility within agencies has substantial scope for improvement. As recognised by the Committee, devolution can be a protracted process, which may be extended by ``some attitudinal and systemic obstacles to implementation of devolution which will take time to overcome'' (paragraph 6.52). A major impediment to devolution at this level has been the lack of adequate information systems. Another impediment has been the attitude of many managers, which is sometimes the result of inadequate training and development. At the same time, senior departmental management has had to grapple with getting the right balance between devolved decision making and corporate management.

As made clear in the response to the first recommendation presented by the Committee, the Government will continue to encourage agencies to overcome these obstacles to introduce further devolution within their administration. In this regard it should be noted that the Management Improvement Advisory Committee (MIAC), the structure and function of which is detailed in response to Recommendation 11 of the Committee, has given priority to investigating current practices as they relate to devolution. The results of the MIAC review will contribute significantly to the development of strategies to encourage further, effective devolution within agencies.
In light of this, the Government welcomes the recommendation of the Committee on devolution and endorses its view that ``devolution must lead to improved performance and systems'' (ibid).
Recommendation 10 (paragraph 7.23)
The Committee recommends that:

- Departments and agencies should make a concerted effort to develop performance information that assists decision-making and accountability. There should be a demonstrated improvement in this regard by 1992; and
- the Department of Finance should increase its practical assistance to departments with emphasis on development of performance information relating to program effectiveness.
Government Response
The Government accepts the premise of the Committee's recommendation.
Comment

As noted in the 1988 FMIP Report, the report originally referred to the Committee, ``the task of change and improvement has just started.'' (pp 83) Three broad areas were then identified as requiring priority in the period ahead, namely:
- performance information and enhanced accountability;
- performance incentives; and
- the development of departmental management systems.

It was indicated that these will be areas to be given priority in further developing the overall FMI Program. The Government is confident that, on the evidence of past improvements in performance reporting, departments and agencies will meet the challenge of further, ``demonstrated'' improvements by 1992.

With regard to the future efforts of the Department of Finance, the Government notes that, as the agency with primary responsibility for implementation of the FMIP, it is itself open to the scrutiny of the Executive and Parliament. The Government, therefore, would direct attention to the basic accountability documentation provided by the Department of Finance, most notably its Portfolio Explanatory Notes and Annual Report. The Government invites monitoring and scrutiny of the activities and associated results which Finance must achieve over the stated reporting period.
Recommendation 11 (paragraph 7.46)
The Committee recommends that:

- departments and agencies should make consistent and substantial efforts to develop appropriate management information and reporting systems that facilitate monitoring of performance, decision-making and accountability; and
- the monitoring of developments within departments and agencies and the identification and dissemination of `best practice' should be a priority focus of the MIAC's annual work plan.
Government Response

The Government accepts the Committee's view regarding the development of MISs within departments and agencies. With regard to the work priorities of the MIAC, the Government points out that the MIAC itself has nominated ``best practice'' as the focus of its efforts.
Comment

As noted by the Committee, line managers at the operating levels of departments and agencies require detailed information relating to basic transactions, inputs, workload, standards, activities and outputs. Higher levels of management meanwhile-within the same organisation and concerned with meeting the same basic objectives-require information which is more condensed, relying on disparate sources and identifying the critical factors affecting overall program or organisational performance. In particular, higher-level management have a need for access to information on outcomes. It is up to the organisation's Management Information System (MIS) to service the information requirements of all managers so that soundly-based decisions can be taken at all levels.

The Government endorses the view that the development of appropriate management information systems is essential to devolved management, implementation of user charging, monitoring of performance, good evaluation practices and the meeting of internal and external accountability requirements. The Government acknowledges the Committee's view that departments' and agencies' achievements in this area to date have been limited, but is confident that MIS development will be a focus for future efforts.

With regard to the future work of the Management Improvement Advisory Committee (MIAC), the Government notes that the Committee was specifically formed as a body to provide advice to the Management Advisory Board (MAB) across a broad range of management issues and to ensure that individual managers have access to examples of ``best practice'' or ``models of success'' as an underpinning to their development of management systems and practices.

The Government considers the formation of the MIAC, and particularly the emphasis placed on structuring the Committee to be representative of the public service as a whole, to be a valuable initiative in improving public administration. It is confident that the MIAC will contribute manifestly to the future success of the FMIP.
Recommendation 12 (paragraph 7.62)
The Committee recommends that:

- departments and agencies should make a consistent and systematic effort to develop their evaluation planning processes and link these more consistently to their decisionmaking and priority setting. There should be a demonstrated improvement in this regard by 1992;
- the Department of Finance should:
- increase and more effectively target its practical assistance on evaluation to departments; and
- ensure that departmental evaluations are linked into the decision-making of the central budgetary processes.
Government Response

As previously discussed in relation to performance information (recommendation 10), program evaluation has been identified by the Government as a priority area for further work in implementing the FMIP reforms. The Government is confident, therefore, that the challenges set out in this recommendation can be met.
Comment

The development of systematic evaluation is integral to the Commonwealth budgetary and financial management reforms. Systematic evaluation is important to those reforms and to public sector management generally, because of its key role in linking program implementation with planning and budgeting and its ability to allow individual programs to demonstrate their achievements against planned outcomes.The primary purpose of program evaluation is program improvement. Evaluation also is intended, however, to aid resource allocation decisions-at each of the program, agency and Cabinet levels-provide a basis for accounting for the utilisation of public funds and enhancing the basic knowledge which managers possess of their program's operations and outcomes.

While there has always been a significant amount of evaluation activity in Commonwealth departments and agencies, it has not in the past been an explicit, planned and systematic part of public sector management. In response to this, the Government, in November 1988, endorsed a broad strategy aimed at incorporating systematic evaluation as part of public sector management. Specific requirements of this strategy included:

- each department and agency was required to develop evaluation plans covering all of their evaluation activities which provided that all programs would undergo a major evaluation over a rolling five year period-
this was intended to promote the better linking of evaluation to other agency-based plans (eg Corporate Plans);

- each portfolio was to prepare a rolling three year Portfolio Evaluation Plan (PEP) for major evaluations-with terms of reference to be included for evaluations in the first year-which would be provided to the Department of Finance-

this was intended to promote portfolio co-ordination of evaluation activity, and enhance actual progress in evaluation through developing a documented commitment to be fulfilled. It should be noted that the definition of ``major'' evaluations in terms of the PEPs embraced those evaluations which were deemed significant in resource or policy terms.

The Government acknowledges that there has so far been considerable variation in the performance of departments and agencies in both evaluation planning and practice. The Government is satisfied, however, that evaluation will become established as a normal element of management through the ``management cycle''. In particular, it would point out that:
- the quality of terms of reference for evaluations has improved since the 1988 strategy was announced;
- an increasing number of evaluations are directed toward testing achievement against planned outcomes;
- portfolios and agencies across the Commonwealth public sector are taking active steps to expand evaluation-related knowledge and skills amongst staff; and
- the results of evaluations are increasingly being linked to decisions on future resource allocation decisions both within portfolios and at the level of the budget itself.

Much effort within evaluation continues to focus on de-mystifying the subject. Perceptions that evaluation is an intricately complex process, not readily understandable by, or accessible to, program personnel is not uncommon. Reducing such barriers to the adoption of good evaluation planning and practice is not a simple matter. Clear articulation and shared agreement with relevant parties of purposes of a particular evaluation, involvement of program personnel in identifying the questions an evaluation should answer etc, are all approaches currently being encouraged as aids to this process of de-mystification.

It is in this context that the future involvement of the Department of Finance should be discussed. As part of the strategy announced in 1988, the Government directed that Finance was to contribute, within the framework of the FMIP, to enhancing evaluation processes and skills in portfolios by:
- acting as a catalyst and co-ordinator to identify and promulgate best practices in evaluation;
- producing guidelines booklets on program evaluation and cost benefit analysis;
- making available Department of Finance resources to provide economic, statistical and methodological advice on program evaluation issues;
- participating in selected joint evaluations with portfolios where that would serve to enhance Service-wide evaluation skills and promulgate best practices; and
- assisting in the development of management information systems to support evaluation.

Progress made by Finance in what is now a key element of its overall functions is reported through the major accountability documents produced by the portfolio-Portfolio Explanatory Notes (to be re-titled as Program Performance Statements, as called for in Recommendation 14, below) and the Department of Finance Annual Report. The Government suggests that the discussion of the results achieved in this regard will provide valuable, on-going information on the progress of evaluation within the public sector, and of Finance's role in fostering this progress.
Recommendation 13 (paragraph 8.54)
The Committee recommends that:

- the Department of Finance, in consultation with the Parliament and its committees, undertake a regular program of seminars to inform members and staff of the Parliament about FMIP changes and their accountability implications;

- the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet consider revising the `Government Guidelines for Official Witnesses Appearing Before Parliamentary Committees and Related Matters' to better reflect the accountability requirements of public servants that arise from the FMIP changes; and
- an arrangement be formalised for parliamentary committee chairpersons and deputy chairpersons to meet on a regular basis to discuss parliamentary committee objectives and interrelationships.
Government Response

The Government welcomes any moves leading to the more effective operations of parliamentary committees and therefore encourages better co-ordination between the committees as well as better informing members and their staff of important reforms within Commonwealth administration.

The Government does not accept the recommended revision of the Government Guidelines for Official Witnesses Appearing Before Parliamentary Committees and Related Matters, considering that the enhanced information facilities called for under the recommendation will itself improve the actual process of accountability to Parliament.
Comment
The Government strongly endorses the Committee's statement that:
``Within the FMIP framework, parliamentary committees are seen as crucial in focusing attention on issues of the performance and effectiveness of government programs.'' (para 8.33)

However, it also notes the Committee's comment that ``Parliament has its own accountability agenda and does not see its role in terms of bedding down the latest public service management reforms . . . [however] the Parliament's accountability agenda is a broad one and embraces issues of efficiency, effectiveness and policy.'' (para 8.35)

The Government does not seek to restrict the ambit of parliamentary committees. Indeed, it considers that the recent public sector reforms introduced under the FMIP have added the major new element of performance to the traditional spectrum of parliamentary accountability. The Parliament must be aware, however, that individual managers within the public sector-for whom outcome-oriented reporting of performance has become the primary focus of internal mechanisms of accountability (that is, within agencies)-have received no clear picture of overall parliamentary demands for accountability, nor the extent to which performance information in terms of effectiveness and efficiency might fit.

This situation might be expected to lead to the view-expressed in testimony to the HORSCFPA-that parliamentary committees continue to concentrate on the compliance aspects of accountability rather than focusing on improved performance, efficiency and effectiveness. It was also charged that, in the opinion of some individuals, committees have not fully understood the changes (particularly the concept of risk management) which have come through the FMIP.

With this as background, the Government strongly endorses the calls made in Not Dollars Alone for the signals being given to the Executive about Parliament's demands for accountability to be clarified.

In relation to the first point raised by the Committee under this recommendation, the Government notes that some training of committee staff has occurred over the past few years, which would have led to a positive impact in the subsequent conduct of committee inquiries. These training courses were contributed to by the Department of Finance and dealt with subjects such as:
- budgetary processes and the related public sector budget cycle;
- a general introduction to the FMIP and Program Management and Budgeting (PMB);
- the process of objective setting within the public sector and its links with performance information; and
- evaluation methodologies, preparation for-and the conduct of-evaluations, and evaluation within policy programs.

The Government welcomes the opportunity to ensure that the FMIP changes and other reforms affecting the public sector are more fully explained to the Parliament, individual Parliamentarians and their staff. Also, in relation to the third point made by the Committee, the Government would encourage an increased level of co-ordination and co-operation between parliamentary committees.

With regard to the recommendation that the Government Guidelines for Official Witnesses Appearing Before Parliamentary Committees and Related Matters be amended, the Government notes that the supporting discussion included in Not Dollars Alone, while representing a welcome indication of the openness of the Parliament to make use of the new accountability mechanisms made available under the reforms, signal a basic mis-reading of the issue of proper accountability. The Committee, in reaching the conclusion expressed in this part of the recommendation, stated that:

``. . . the greater demands for accountability may be made of public servants by Parliament as greater attention is directed towards issues of performance. Public servants may be called increasingly to account for the effectiveness of programs as well as their efficiency.'' (paragraph 8.52)

The Government is of the opinion that, while the broad principles are clear, the detailed application of the accountability of the public sector to Parliament presents a number of difficult issues. At their heart lies the requirement that those who are to be held accountable, and what they are accountable for, must be identified.

The Government believes that the correct approach to the issue of the interaction of ministerial and public service accountability is to consider it in terms of a spectrum. At one end, there are those matters for which Ministers clearly expect to be held accountable; at the other end are matters for which public servants can be held directly accountable. Nevertheless, the process of accountability for public sector operations must be exercised through the Executive arm of Government.

This approach to the vital issue of accountability leads to a rejection of the proposed amendments to the related guidelines. The Government would welcome the increasing interest of parliamentary committees in issues of program effectiveness and would encourage public servants called before those committees to contribute as much as possible to their understanding of related strategies and administrative efficiencies.

As encapsulated in the Statement by the Prime Minister when tabling the current Guidelines for Witnesses on 28 November 1989, however, it will remain the unambiguous responsibility of Ministers for policy; ``. . . it is Ministers and not officials who are responsible for public promotion or defence of government policies.'' (House of Representatives Hansard, pp 3027)
Recommendation 14 (paragraph 8.70)
The Committee recommends that:
- the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Finance give high priority to resolving the purposes, content and overlap between the explanatory notes and annual reports;

- the House of Representatives, through its committees, should increase its scrutiny and use of performance information in the explanatory notes by making greater use of the information in their general inquiries;
- the preparation and distribution of Explanatory Notes reflect the wider usage of the documents by parliamentary committees and their name be changed to `Program Performance Statements'; and

- the House of Representatives, through its committees, should increase its scrutiny of departments and agencies by reviewing their annual reports. Consideration should be given to joint reviews of annual reports with relevant Senate committees.
Government Response

The Government is confident that the specific recommendations made by the HORSCFPA for the further development of the parliamentary committee system form a valuable basis for discussion. With regard to the other areas mentioned under this recommendation, the Government accepts the suggested re-titling of Portfolio Explanatory Notes and points to recent work undertaken to clarify the required contents of both Annual Reports and Program Performance Statements.
Comment

With regard to the concerns expressed at the perceived degree of overlap between Portfolio Explanatory Notes and Departmental Annual Reports, the Government notes the previous recommendations on this issue arising from inquiries of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration (The Timeliness and Quality of Annual Reports) and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (Report No 304, Guidelines for Departmental Annual Reports).

The Government is confident that the guidelines to be issued in the near future for the preparation of Annual Reports and Explanatory Notes will reduce the extent of overlap between the two documents, while ensuring that the amount of relevant information made available by agencies will be maintained or extended. The revised guidelines, clarifying the different uses, audiences and overall responsibility for the two documents, will allow individual managers to take more informed decisions on the choice of information to be provided.

It is expected that progressive improvements in quality will come from this clarification. Parliament and relevant parliamentary committees are invited to continue to monitor the two documents to form judgements on the pace and direction of future developments in this area.

The Government accepts the recommendation that Portfolio Explanatory Notes should be re-titled Program Performance Statements. This recommendation was previously put forward in the report of the SSCFPA, The Timeliness and Quality of Annual Reports, which considered that the changed title would more accurately reflect the actual role and function of the document. In this regard the Government points out that, in its first submission to the current SSCFPA inquiry into matters relating to Estimates Committees' documentation and procedures (in January 1990), the Department of Finance-which, under the direction of the Senate, is responsible for the preparation of the guidelines pertaining to the present Explanatory Notes-agreed that the re-titling was desirable.

Finally, in relation to the Committee's recommendations on the activities of parliamentary committees, the Government would encourage any changes leading to an enhanced level of effective accountability. It is for the House and Parliament as a whole to determine if the recommendations presented by the Committee provide such a basis for enhanced accountability.
The Department of Finance, on the invitation of the Committee, will be pleased to discuss with committee staff ways to advance this issue.
Recommendation 15 (paragraph 8.77)
The Committee recommends that:

- The ANAO be given adequate resources to conduct more efficiency reviews of government programs, incorporating consideration of the adequacy of performance indicators and management information systems.
Government Response

On 6 December 1990, the Government tabled its response to the independent review of the Australian National Audit Office conducted by Mr Tom Sheridan. Overall, the review concluded that initiatives already undertaken by the Auditor-General, or suggested in the review, could lead to significant additional resources-equivalent to some 60 full-time staff-becoming available for efficiency auditing over the next two years or so. These resources, in the order of $3m per annum, could be released through the adoption of risk-based auditing; gains from information technology; release of resources following completion of the ANAO's Information Technology Project; and improved management and control of resources.
Recommendation 16 (paragraph 8.88)
The Committee recommends that, in establishing management information systems, departments and agencies ensure a close linking of the information for internal and external accountability reporting.
Government Response
The Government accepts the view of the Committee.
Comment

As indicated in the response to Recommendation 11, the Government accepts that the development of Management Information Systems within departments and agencies is an area of future priority in the development of the FMIP. It also accepts that such MISs can bring about real benefits to the management of Government programs only if they provide a close alignment between the information developed for internal management purposes and that required for effective accountability to the Executive and the Parliament.

This is because of the importance of clearly stated, outcome-oriented objectives leading to the derivation of specific strategies for their achievement and the concurrent development of key results areas and related performance information. Program Management and Budgeting, as practised within the Commonwealth public sector, seeks to high-light all these areas as being of the highest priority for effective management. Furthermore, this sustained focus on results within internal management will lead to the effective scrutiny of Government operations by Parliament and the public.
Recommendation 17 (paragraph 9.23)

The Committee recommends that the APS Management Advisory Board give consideration to encouraging departments and agencies to include human resource development goals and objectives in their corporate plans.4
Government Response
The Government would encourage the APS Management Advisory Board (MAB) to take account of the Committee's recommendation in its future work.
Comment

The Government has a strong and continuing commitment to the development of the public sector's human resources to achieve an Australian Public Service that is effective, efficient, equitable, innovative, professional and independent.

The Management Advisory Board (MAB), has an important role in attaining this objective. Under the Public Service Act, the MAB is charged with advising the Commonwealth Government, through the Prime Minister, on significant issues relating to the management of the Australian Public Service. It also acts as a forum for consideration of major management activities affecting the Service as a whole.

The Government notes that most departments and agencies in the Australian Public Service already are putting in place Human Resource Development Plans which link their HRD activities to the meeting of their strategic objectives. The Public Service Commission has, over the last two years, placed particular emphasis on promoting the use of HRD Plans as a critical strategic tool in increasing organisational efficiency, effectiveness and productivity in the public sector. The impact of this is reviewed regularly through specific surveys of HRD activities within the public sector. The broad findings of the 1989-90 HRD Survey are discussed in relation to Recommendation 18, below.

While not seeking to interfere in the continuing work-load and current priorities of the MAB, the Government considers that the Committee's recommendation will lead to a better linking of the strategically-focused management emphasised by the FMIP reforms and the priority given to human resource development. The Government strongly endorses the thrust of the Committee's recommendation and would encourage the MAB to work towards its fulfilment.
Recommendation 18 (paragraph 9.28)
The Committee recommends that:

- departments and agencies take account of the wide scope of human resource development and strengthen their planning in this regard so as to relate training more directly to program activities and objectives;
- departments and agencies include resources for resource management training in their allocations for human resource development;
- the government continues supplementary funding for training through the Public Service Commission and the Joint APS Training Council; and
- departments and agencies collect information on training expenditure and budgets and advise these in Annual Reports and Explanatory Notes respectively.
Government Response

The Government accepts the broad thrust of the various specific recommendations made. With regard to the specific recommendation made on the Joint APS Training Council, the Government has provided in the Forward Estimates for three years' funding for the Council and the PSC's work; future decisions on funding are for the Government's determination. In reaching these decisions, the Government will take account of the Council's levels of achievement against the objectives which have been set.
Comment

As discussed in relation to Recommendation 17, the Government is committed to enhancing the quality of the public service through extensive Human Resource Development (HRD) training. Specifically, the endorsed objectives to be met in this regard are:
- to increase the effectiveness of the HRD function in the Australian Public Service by initiating service-wide HRD policies and organisational strategies;

- to assist the Joint APS Training Council-responsible for advising on the priorities for service-wide training initiatives arising from the Structural Efficiency Principle (SEP)-so that subsequent training strategies set in place will support the introduction of integrated and linked classification structures;
- to enhance the role and skills of the ``middle management'' within the APS by promoting the development of HRD programs, focusing on
- people management;
- managing change; and
- effectiveness in serving the government and the community; and
- to enhance the role and skills of HRD practitioners to increase their contribution to productivity and the management of change within the APS.

Fulfilment of these objectives is fundamental to the long-term attainment of the full range of benefits made available under the FMIP even at this, relatively early, stage in its implementation. The Public Service Commission, as the agency with primary responsibility in shaping Servicewide human resource management practices, will continue to report on the achievement attained against the objectives stated above. Such reporting, through the relevant accountability documents-the agency Annual Report and related area of the Portfolio Explanatory Notes-will allow the level of actual progress to be monitored and assessed.

The Government also notes that the Public Service Commission, through its regular conduct of Human Resource Development Surveys, provides a continuing broad indication of the state of HRD in the Commonwealth public sector, and of the resources being applied to the training effort. It is apparent from the 1989-90 survey, as provided to the MAB, that there has been considerable progress in most areas previously identified as requiring action, including:
- clearer linking corporate objectives and HRD (as called-for by the Committee in Recommendation 17, above); and
- greater emphasis on effective evaluation and monitoring mechanisms.

The MIAC (referred to in relation to Recommendation 11 above) is currently scheduled to prepare a report on actual human resource development practices within agencies, particularly in relation to the development of middle management within the public sector. The report, when released, will provide a clear picture of at least this aspect of HRD.

Finally, with regard to the inclusion of information on training expenditures in Annual Reports and future Program Performance Statements (ie Portfolio Explanatory Notes), the Government notes that the draft Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports specifically call for the provision of information in accordance with the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990. This imposes a minimum training requirement on employers, including departments, set as a percentage of the employer's annual national payroll.

As specified under the draft guidelines for annual reports, departments and agencies will be required to provide information on the sum total of all training carried out during each financial year and the sum minimum training requirement placed upon it under the Act. Also, departments will be required to provide details on the number and broad categorisation of staff participating in relevant training as well as a listing of the kinds of activities undertaken.
Recommendation 19 (paragraph 10.38)

The Committee recommends that a full-scale, independent effectiveness review of the FMIP be undertaken in 1992. The review could be undertaken under the direction of the Management Improvement Advisory Committee. The review should give close attention to:
- a quantification of the savings which are resulting from the program;
- the achievements of departments and agencies with the program; and
- the views of clients as to the impact of the FMIP on service delivery.
Government Response

The Government endorses, in principle, the proposal for a further evaluation of the FMIP and broadly supports the scope and timing of the evaluation. The Government will await the advice of the MIAC itself, and other relevant bodies, however, before assigning responsibility for the oversighting of any such review.
Comment

As stated previously in relation to Recommendation 11, the Management Improvement Advisory Committee (MIAC) was established in December 1989. The MIAC brings together a number of senior officers to provide advice to the Management Advisory Board across the range of management issues affecting the Australian Public Service. Importantly, the Committee has been structured to be broadly representative of the Service as a whole; in particular, it includes a strong regional representation.

The Government notes that, in discussing the actual issue of a future evaluation into the FMIP, the HORSCFPA placed more emphasis on the ``independence'' of the review team from the Department of Finance. The Government accepts this particular aspect of recommendation, and endorses the broad timing and scope of the proposed review.

Before finally determining responsibility for any such future evaluation of the FMIP, however, the Government will need to take account of the considerations of the MIAC itself. In particular, the Government will need to receive the MIAC's views on its ability to oversight any review, and the effects which this might have on its on-going work program. This advice is expected to soon become available to the Government; the Parliament will subsequently be informed of the final decision taken regarding the proposed evaluation.

NEWS RELEASE (No. 176/90)
MINISTER FOR DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL
Gordon Bilney, MP
Wednesday, November 7 1990
MINISTER ANNOUNCES DEFENCE TO RETAIN PROFIT FROM DSTO COMMERCIAL ACTIVITIES

The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Gordon Bilney, today announced that he had obtained the agreement of the Expenditure Review Committee for Defence to retain the profit from the commercial activities of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation.

``DSTO has a budget of more than $200 million a year, much of which is spent on research and development in areas like aeronautical engineering and communications, which have significant economic potential and we have a responsibility to ensure that economic potential is realised,'' Mr Bilney said.

``Because DSTO's primary role is to support the Australian Defence Force, it has previously operated under a self imposed limit of using only 1% of its budget for commercial activities,'' Mr Bilney said.

``To ease that constraint and to encourage commercialisation I have obtained the agreement of the Expenditure Review Committee to Defence retaining any profit from DSTO's commercial activities rather than it being returned to Consolidated Revenue as it was in the past,'' Mr Bilney said.
``In the first instance any profit will be used to provide working capital for DSTO's developing commercial activities,'' Mr Bilney said.
``DSTO can make a major contribution to Australian industry through commercial use of its intellectual property, facilities and services,'' Mr Bilney said.
