DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The chaotic state of the Government's wage fixation policy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer (Mr Keating) approves of a discussion! At long last the Treasurer agrees with the proposition that his own Government's wages policy is in a state of chaos. Well may the Treasurer do that. It is a very serious moment in the economic, industrial and political life of this country. There is, indeed, just one issue that is at present marginally more important than the shenanigans going on inside the Australian Labor Party over the leadership. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was wandering around the back benches; he was looking for Squeaky. But he could not find him. Squeaky was out there toting up the numbers; Laurie has lent him his motorbike. I wonder whether Laurie will run away with the ballot box containing the Caucus ballots on the leadership, just as he did when he helped to rort the Treasurer's pre-selection in Blaxland in 1969?

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the chaotic state of the Government's wages policy and away from the chaotic state of the Labor Party: in Question Time, we had from the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations in this place, one of the more significant comments on industrial relations and wages policy to have come from a Minister in this Government over recent months. In effect, what the Minister said put beyond any doubt that we are now in the no-man's-land of wage fixation in this country.

I had always believed, and, I imagine, the great majority of the Australian community had believed until a few weeks ago, that the Labor Party's notion and the Hawke Government's notion of wage fixation in this country was that there was a centralised industrial relations system, there was an award structure, there were parties to those awards-employers and unions-and sitting at the pinnacle of that wage fixation system was the body that was there to ensure that all was fair and just in the great Australian egalitarian tradition, the body that was there to stop the downtrodden being exploited by the rich and powerful in our community, the body whose integrity had been defended month after month, year after year by the Prime Minister: the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

If anybody had ever entertained any doubts about that, surely those doubts were dispelled 18 months ago when the Prime Minister went into the bunker. Remember that historic battle between Captain Hawke and Captain McCarthy over the pilots? What did the Prime Minister say then? He said that what the Australian Federation of Air Pilots was doing was akin to war on the Australian community. He said that what the pilots were trying to do was to destroy the wage fixation system in Australia.

What was the sine qua non, the essence, of the Prime Minister's repudiation of the pilots-of the Prime Minister's virulent attack on the pilots? It was that the pilots had disobeyed the Industrial Relations Commission. That was the gravamen of the Government's attack. Day after day he went on every current affairs program in Australia. He worked himself up into an incoherent lather. He said to the pilots, `You are destroying the great industrial relations system'. He said, `I will destroy the tourist industry; I will destroy the airline industry and I will bring the tourist industry of this country to a standstill'-all in the name of defending what? All in the name of defending the Industrial Relations Commission.

If the Prime Minister had asked me I would have advised him not to do that because I have never believed in an industrial relations system that has the Industrial Relations Commission at its pinnacle. I have always believed that free men and women ought to make free bargains. It is a very simple proposition. Free men and women ought to have the right to decide with whom they associate. They should not be compelled to join organisations-be it the trade union movement, the Anglican Church, the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the Masonic Lodge. I do not care what the organisation is. Ours is a free, egalitarian society.

But no, the Australian Labor Party has never had that libertarian view on the freedom of association. The Labor Party always believes in compulsion. I must have been living in another world and so must all of my colleagues on this side of the House and the great majority of the Australian community, because, unless I was hearing things, 18 months ago the Prime Minister was prepared to bring this country to a standstill to defend the authority of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

That, of course, was 18 months ago, when it suited the Prime Minister to defend the authority of the Industrial Relations Commission. But now, when it does not suit the political convenience of this Government to defend the authority of the Industrial Relations Commission, what is the Government's reaction? The Treasurer says the Commission is dredging around for a role, and he does not really give a damn whether it has one or not. The rather more mild mannered Minister for Finance, who is at the table, is even more steeped in the folklore of the industrial relations club than most honourable members who sit behind him. In Question Time today, in his laconic style that we have grown used to-and on occasions quite fondly so-he said in effect, `Look, we do not like their decision and we are not going to take any notice of it because it does not suit Bill, Paul, Bob and Ralph'. Basically, that is what the Minister said today.

In Australia the old order has been destroyed. The old order was the Industrial Relations Commission sitting at the pinnacle, founded on the harvester decision. Justice Bournes Higgins might roll in his grave at the things I say about the harvester judgment but, after he has been betrayed by his lineal descendants in the faith, his body would spin in the grave-after what has been heard from the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. If ever there has been a betrayal of the faith, a repudiation of the orthodoxy, it is now. The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance deserve to be excommunicated from the industrial relations club of this country for what they have done.

I am not burdened by that stain of guilt, because I have never applied for and never wanted to be a member. But, very seriously, we have a total breakdown, a chaotic, indecisive, indeterminate, irresolute wasteland of wage fixation at present. On the one hand, we have the Prime Minister spending 19 hours-my God, 19 hours with the Prime Minister!-in a room negotiating with the stevedoring companies and the unions to try to get a settlement on waterfront. At the end of the day, what is the irreducible minimum of that decision? The parties have to go back to the Industrial Relations Commission. They have to go back to it. That is the absolute irreducible minimum. The deal negotiated by the Prime Minister extols the fairly extraordinary notion that the bigger the rort the greater the pay increase; that was the substance of the answer given by the Prime Minister today at Question Time.

But let us look at the conflict. The parties involved in the waterfront have to go back to the Industrial Relations Commission to get the Commission's imprimatur a la the pilots dispute. But people should not worry; the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) will not have any of that-the honourable member for Blaxland who is so touting his leadership wares now that the situation is becoming a pathetic joke around this nation. The Sydney Morning Herald got it right: `Hawke or Keating? MPs choose their poison'. Basically the people of Australia regard both Hawke and Keating as poison; they just cannot make up their minds whether they would rather have incoherent poison or rat cunning poison.

The truth of the matter is that, while that sideshow is going on, we have the fortuitous intervention of a fall in inflation that we had to have because we had a recession. As Peter Smark so eloquently put it in the Sydney Morning Herald the other day, `Dead men are not troubled by high blood pressure'. We have a comatose economy and of course there will be a fall in inflation. But it offers us a fortuitous opportunity to take advantage of it. We are now crying out for a coherent wage fixation system.

I say to the Minister, and I say to the Prime Minister, that there are really only two models in this country. There is the orthodox, authentic centralised industrial situation with all its faults-and it has many. I am loud in my criticism of it, but with all its faults it at least has a consistent, predictable mediocrity about it. One always knows it will produce low productivity outcomes, one always knows what the wage adjustments will be, and therefore there is a predictable mediocrity. But the no-man's land that we have at the moment is incoherent, unpredictable, confused mediocrity, and that is the worst mediocrity of all. It is either that, or it is our system: one of genuine enterprise bargaining built on the notion that free men and women are entitled to make free bargains in this country. It is built on the notion that we are able to do that.

I know the honourable member for Gellibrand of old, and not entirely without some warmth. He and the Treasurer are getting their heads together. He is getting a little bit of advice, `Laurie didn't really take the ballot-box with him; it was really Squeaky'. It was really Squeaky who took the ballot-box with him that night in 1969. The honourable member for Gellibrand grins because he knows it is right. Lindsay North was there too, and so was brother Ducker. Brother Ducker was there as well. The mates were all there.

Anyway, to return to the mateship of the industrial relations club, I say to the Minister that he has to sort out his act. Either he has to go back to the faith or he should really become a non-conformist. In other words, he has to embrace a truly decentralised wage fixation system which asserts the proposition that free men and women are entitled to make free bargains. If we encourage people to do that, if we encourage a break-out of Power Breweries or Mudginberris or SPCs or all of those great historic wage fixation systems, we will really have a productivity break-out in this country the like of which we have never seen.

I have one further piece of advice for the Minister: do not waste a quarter of an hour of the time of this House in going back over events. He goes back to 1981, he goes back to 1891. Every single problem this country has now is the fault of people who were once in office. If it is not John Howard or Malcolm Fraser or Phillip Lynch, it is John Curtin or Ben Chifley or Alfred Deakin or Jack Lang or Sir Henry Parkes. The Government members go back to the Boer War, they go back to the Peloponnesian Wars, and so it goes on.

I say this to the Minister, and through him to the Prime Minister, and I say it very seriously: for those 830,000 people who are out of work at the present time I do not think it will do any earthly good or offer them any earthly comfort to engage in a pointless exercise as to which statistic was relevant in 1981 or 1970. What comfort is it to somebody who is now out of work if the Government is able to prove temporarily, for the next month, that its unemployment rate at the moment is slightly below what it was in 1982? It does not get that person a job. In any event, in a couple of months time the Government's unemployment rate is going to be higher than it was in 1983.

The other thing I advise the Minister not to do is to spread that great Labor lie that what we now propose is a rerun of what happened in 1981. What we now propose by way of a wages policy is light years away from what occurred in 1981. As the Treasurer more than anybody else knows, the real culprit of 1981 was not the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia, it was not the Fraser Government, it was not the Industrial Relations Commission, but it was the good old boy from Belfast, George Campbell of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union.

It was at the 1986 Hobart conference, when the Treasurer was paying out on the Left, that he got up and said, `George, don't you make a contribution to this debate; you have 100,000 dead men hanging around your neck'. The reference to 100,000 dead men was a reference to the 100,000 manufacturing jobs lost through the mad, marauding wages activities of the metal unions, aided and abetted by Bill Kelty, aided and abetted by Bob Hawke, who sat on his hands and used the politics of industrial relations in 1981 to undermine Hayden. He cared not a jot about the national interest; he was only interested, as he always had been, in his own personal political agenda.
Discussion interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not rise to support the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard); I rise only to say that if the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) was offended by my remarks about his head, I apologise and say that I understand his sensitivity because I am rapidly joining him. He has sent over to me a caricature that is a very good likeness of himself, but I am not sure about the figure underneath it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last quarter of an hour the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has convincingly demonstrated the chaotic state of the Opposition's wages policy and the fact that it has learned nothing at all in its period in office about wages policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Reith interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Flinders.

—The fact is that the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, like the shadow Treasurer the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and all of those concerned with the economy in the Opposition, totally fails to understand anything about wages policy, as demonstrated convincingly by him in his comments about the pilots dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of his remarks the honourable member for Bennelong was moved to say that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others had been vehemently denigrating the actions of the pilots in 1989 in the name of defending the Industrial Relations Commission. What we were doing was not so much defending the system, or the Commission per se, but defending the wages policy. He said that he would have been totally hands-off. He said that he would have let the pilots do their own thing. What they were seeking to do was to achieve a wage increase of 30 per cent at a time when the wage outcome was running at around 6 or 7 per cent. They wanted a 30 per cent increase at a time when the economy was operating at a very high level of activity, such that in normal circumstances one would expect that there would be a high level of wage increase; but that did not occur.

If we had had conditions like they were in 1980-81 and the wages policy operating at that time, we would have had the 17 or 18 per cent wage increase that happened under the previous Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong; but we did not have that because we had the accord. We had a system operating where the unions were saying, `Despite the fact that there is a very high level of economic activity and a high level of employment growth, we are not going to be out there seeking further wage increases because we are accepting the outcomes under the accord'.

Through that came the pilots saying, `To hell with all that. We're going to have 30 per cent'. If they got 30 per cent, or anything like it-and they probably would have had a pretty good chance of getting it if the Government had not cracked down pretty hard-others would have said, `How about us as well?'. There would have been the likelihood of a severe wages break-out a la 1981.

That is something which the Opposition completely refuses to accept. But there is no reason to believe that that would not have been the outcome, certainly on the basis of historical precedent and on the basis of one's understanding of the way in which industrial relations occur in this country. Even if there was a system operating such as the Opposition says that it would bring in, the same situation would apply. There would be nothing to prevent the pilots, or anyone with acute bargaining power at times of a high level of economic activity, seeking a 30 per cent increase and, if they could get it, stimulating a lot of flow-on claims. The Opposition would have nothing in place which would inhibit outcomes of that kind and, by having nothing in place, would have to expect a volatile wages system which would bring about substantial wage increases at times when it is propitious for those in substantial bargaining positions to obtain those increases.

As we saw periodically under the Fraser Government, under any future Opposition government there would be a wages surge and the destructive impact that that would have on the economy. If we had had that kind of wages break-out, we would not be looking now at a recession of the kind that we are looking at, but at a much more acute one-certainly one of the kind that we had in 1981-82 or 1982-83, when we had the coincidence of double digit unemployment and double digit inflation. We do not have that now. We have inflation below 5 per cent. The reason why we have it below 5 per cent is that we clobbered the pilots. We refused to let the pilots dictate the wages policy, break the wages policy, smash the accord, bring about a wage break-out and have devastating effects on the economy.

The previous Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, said that he would have allowed all that to happen. That is enormous evidence of the outlook of the Opposition and its total incomprehension of the industrial realities, despite the fact that one would have thought that it would have learned something through all the years of the accord. But it has not, and every time members of the Opposition open their mouths it becomes more and more obvious that that is the case. One should bear in mind that if the Opposition were ever to get back into government there is no reason at all to believe that it would not do it all again as it did before. To simply say that we would have a system in place where one could opt out of the awards would make it easier to have wages breakouts, not more difficult. There would be no inhibitions at all.

The Government strongly believes that the accord has been enormously beneficial to this country. I will not weary the House with a long dissertation about that, but I must mention a couple of points. Firstly, I believe that the fact that we have had such strong economic growth and enormous employment growth since we have been in office has much to do with the fact that we have been able to get continuous growth, year after year. This is because there has not been a wages break-out, the accord has been in place and there has been a transfer of real income from wage earners to profits. The profit share has held up, even in the context of the current recession- obviously reduced somewhat, but historically much higher than it was in the last recession. There has been that very substantial growth in employment.

As the Prime Minister said at Question Time, if we had had the same rate of growth of employment as the Fraser Government had, we would have now in Australia 1.083 million fewer people employed than there are at the present time. That is a staggering difference. It is not just some percentage difference of one per cent increase under it and 2 1/2 per cent under us; it is a staggering difference in terms of people actually in jobs. About 1.1 million people who are in jobs now would not be in jobs if the Opposition's rate of growth had continued throughout the 1980s. I think that speaks volumes for the policies pursued by this Government.

There has also been a dramatic reduction in industrial disputation. I mention this particularly because in Question Time the honourable member for Bennelong was shouting, `Liar, liar' at the Prime Minister when he said that there had been a 60 per cent reduction in industrial disputation under this Government, and that is absolutely correct. The point made by the honourable member for Bennelong in a so-called personal explanation after Question Time simply misses the point. The fact is that the annual average number of working days lost per thousand employees since March 1983 is now 230, which is 61 per cent lower than the average of 591 recorded during the period of the Fraser Government. That is not a lie. It is an absolute fact that the average number of working days lost per thousand employees under this Government because of the accord has been 61 per cent lower than it was under the previous Government. I do not want this stuff about lies. There are no lies. They are absolute facts.

I think it is deplorable for the honourable member for Bennelong to try to denigrate what has been one of the great achievements of this Government-one of the unsung achievements-that there has been a massive reduction in industrial disputation. We have become used to the fact that we do not have high levels of industrial disputation any more. We have less than the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average for industrial disputation now on working days lost per thousand employees. People have become used to that and they might believe the Opposition spokesman when he says that it is a lie to say that we have had such a reduction. We have had it.

When the previous Government was in office we had a much more chaotic system in this country. There were disputes all over the place. There was much more in the way of industrial upheaval. That is the reason why there was much less economic and employment growth. Associated with that are the wage outcomes, which ensured that that was also the case.

Under this Government we have been able to generate an enormous amount of structural change, none of which occurred under the previous Government and much of which occurs in association with the accord. Because of the accord we have the acceptance by the unions of structural change in a whole host of areas, although I will not spend time going into those now. The accord enabled that to be brought about without disputation. We are getting a dramatic transformation of the economy without disputation. Not only are we having high rates of economic growth and employment growth, which in normal circumstances would bring about more disputation-under this Government we have had 61 per cent less; but this is also associated with an amazing transformation of the economy through structural change the like of which we have never seen, with no disputation and accepted by the unions in very large part. Those are enormous changes. I do not want to spend any more time on the accord, but I think it has been enormously important to us.

The point I wish to make in terms of the wages policy debate about the future is that in the current circumstances the Government has to decide whether the accord is worth keeping or whether it should stick with the Commission's decision. I made the point in Question Time-I will not go over it-that the Commission, in deciding not to adhere to the accord, was making a decision, in effect, to play a lesser role. The Government believes, with the ACTU, that the accord should be maintained. If we cannot have that implemented through the Commission, that obviously is unfortunate. We would much prefer it to be done in that way. If the Commission makes its decision, and it has every right to do so, and says that it does not want to implement the accord, for whatever reasons-it spelt them out in the national wage decision-then the Government and the ACTU have the right to say that they will implement the accord anyway.

The unions are not obligated to seek the Commission's wage increases. It would be quite immoral for the unions to accept the Commission's wage increases and then not adhere to the conditions-that is, go out and get some more. They are not doing that. They are saying, `We will not accept these wage increases that you are offering on the conditions on which they are offered'. They have that right. There is no legal compulsion to go to the Commission and apply for a wage increase. If they decide not to do that, that is their right. Of course, they do not get the awards adjusted and that is the defect for them, but that is a decision they have to make on balance as to what they should do. They have made that decision. In that circumstance, the Government has to decide: Is it to be the accord or should we stick with the Commission and to hell with the accord?

The Government believes that the accord, having been so beneficial to this nation and offering the prospect of continued benefit through a controlled wages system, which in the future will continue to give us the kind of wages policy that has enabled us to have inflation reduced to 5 per cent and the other outcomes I have mentioned, is worth keeping. We will seek to implement it without the Commission, if necessary. We would still like the Commission to be involved. The extent to which that will happen depends on various things-the attitude of the Commission in certain circumstances, the attitude of the unions, and so on.

The accord parties will continue to pursue a wages policy which is not in a state of chaos. There is no chaos except in the mind of the honourable member for Bennelong. There is no chaos about wages policy; it is very much under control. Wages will be increasing in a line which will certainly be compatible with the continued economic recovery of this country and will not give us an inflationary break-out. Accord mark 7 will be negotiated in the not too distant future. That will provide for an outcome which will be economically responsible and wage increases that occur will be within the context of that accord.

Today we have announced guidelines that will apply for the future in respect of our position as a government, as an employer, for Australian Government employees. Those guidelines will apply to Australian Government employment. They will also set an example for the rest of the economy. We have also set down some general guidelines to apply for enterprise bargaining.

A major factor in the concern of the ACTU and of the Government with respect to the Commission's decision was that it failed to set down guidelines for enterprise bargaining. That was extremely unfortunate and very regrettable. In the guidelines we are establishing we have set some general guidelines for enterprise bargaining which focus on achieved productivity and profitability stemming from restructuring. There is a clear instruction in the sense that we are expecting that in the future wage increases, apart from the $12, will come through achieved productivity or profitability flowing from the continued development of award restructuring. That is a very responsible wages policy.

I absolutely refute the argument of the honourable member for Bennelong that we can have only the old centralised system or the system that he proposes. That is arrant nonsense. The system which is evolving is one which will provide for enterprise bargaining but will also maintain the award system so that we will not have the gross exploitation which would come with the Opposition's wages policy and be a major detriment to social justice in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is a huge continent, rich in land and soil resources, rich in mineral resources, with plenty of clean air and water available, occupied by an educated people enjoying good health and a stable political system. That ought to be a recipe for a prosperous and progressive society living at ease with itself. But it is not the picture of Australia that we have before us today. Despite all the abundances with which we find ourselves blessed, we are a divided and restless people facing a ballooning level of indebtedness, including over $130 billion owed abroad in net terms; a situation of 850,000 people, or 10 per cent of our population, out of work, with the almost certainty of more to come; the situation of rapidly collapsing living standards for those who do still have a job; and the reality, according to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, in a paper it put together a little while ago called Competitiveness: the Policy Environment in Australia, that Australia's wage levels are now the fourth lowest among 21 industrialised countries.

SPEECH.PARA: We have squandered our good fortune and we deserve, unfortunately, the scorn of many of those nations who with so much less than us have done so much better than we have in recent years. There can be no doubt, surely, that if we had worked together in genuine national consensus we would not have slipped away so badly from the position at the top of the pile that we once enjoyed. But the story of our failure to get it together is the story of our failure to develop a mature and rational industrial relations environment in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor's failure.

—Labor's failure and the club's failure. Who stands in the way of the development of a new culture in this country today? The club, and the Government is part of the club. On the face of our obvious national failure, the Government proposes, as opposed to its rhetoric, essentially more of the same-more of that which has led to the failures we face. I am talking about continued centralised control of the wages system and continued confrontation. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) claims to be a convert to the values of enterprise based agreements (EBAs). If I may quote from something he said on 6 April, it is amazing to contemplate what a marvellous transformation it actually constitutes. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is only through enterprise bargaining that we can obtain the great productivity increases available from changing workplace arrangements and conditions and it is only through enterprise bargaining that we can make the wage system more responsive to the changing conditions of demand and supply or to different skills in different regions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The Treasurer said that. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: But just a moment because there's a problem. The problem is, you see, that you can't trust ordinary Australians because, in the words of the IRC, we're a pretty immature lot to do it without being managed.

We have to be managed and controlled. The Treasurer, seeing something of a problem here, suggests that, since they cannot possibly be managed, a central tribunal is needed; but that might create a few problems as well. He says:

I mean, how would a central tribunal handle a judgment or an examination, rather, of an agreement around a productivity increase for a change in practices for hundreds of thousands of enterprises. The drab hand, or the damp hand, of the club must not be withdrawn.

Amazingly, the Treasurer suggests that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) should be given the task of overseeing the establishment and the running of EBAs. I suggest that perhaps we need no longer refer to the idea of Dracula being left in charge of the blood bank; in future we will simply be able to talk about the ACTU being left in charge of wages policy.

Today the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) told us in answer to a question from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) that he did not know what was to become of the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC). I would suggest that perhaps all he needs to do is refer the question to the Treasurer, because he knows what is to become of the IRC: it is to become subservient to the ACTU.

The Australian Labor Party believes that the way Australians work and are paid and so forth has to be controlled because their basic approach to industrial relations is confrontationalist. It plainly believes that the Australian worker will break out and act irrationally, irresponsibly, against both his interests and the national interest if he is given the basic freedom to make a few choices and to negotiate working arrangements, pay rates, holiday loadings, profit shares, or whatever it happens to be he wants to negotiate about.

It must believe that because it keeps talking about the wages blow-out that would unquestionably take place, in its view, if our policies were to be implemented. If those policies were implemented, of course, we would see some basic freedoms and some basic rights given back to Australians.

I was interested to note the horrified response in here last night from some members opposite when we started to talk about basic freedoms such as choice. I see one of the honourable members on the other side nodding in agreement, because he heard it. Instead of choice, what we actually hear in the rhetoric from the other side-and we got it from the Minister of Finance again today-is language about industrial realities. Can we not credit Australian workers with any capacity to behave other than militantly if the current stifling controls are lifted? Is it not possible that Australians just might be capable of understanding that the raising of living standards is more appropriately achieved by working harder, by raising productivity and by lowering the price and freeing up the availability of goods rather than holding up their hands in pursuit of more inflationary wage increases all the time?

When those opposite are not talking about a wages blow-out, other honourable members there are talking about the way the bosses will strip away the `hard-won'-I love that term-conditions. What about a bit of hard-won prosperity or the lack thereof that so many Australians are finding at the moment? Those opposite say that they will reintroduce sweat shops. Thus not only Labor's inconsistencies in this debate but also, I would suggest, its basically low and patronising view of the Australian worker are confirmed.

The refusal of those opposite to look at the successful models that now rather abound is also reflected. The proof that Australians can respond with intelligence and with commonsense is to be found in any number of examples. Whether one wants to talk about Powers, Metways, Paveway, Lincoln or SPC, the evidence is there: Australians-surprise, surprise-can think. Witness, however, the Queensland Government's antics as they seek to preserve the power, the interests and the prestige of the industrial relations club by winding back enterprise-based agreements in Queensland. I guess that is a model of what we might expect to see in the future.

We see the shallow attempt to paint us as confrontationalists, yet in reality it was the Government which declared war on the pilots and then brought in the military. It was the Government which declared war on the IRC last month when it dared to show an independent turn of mind. It was the Government which joined with the ACTU and the wharfies in an attempt to bludgeon the waterfront employers into submission. It was Kelty, I believe, who told Brian Noakes that they were at war-a highly irresponsible attitude when Australia is on its knees. The chaotic state of the Government's wage fixing policies indeed!

These policies give lie to the claim by those opposite that they are the Party of social justice, because the policies in fact advance the strong at the expense of the weak. In my own home town a couple of weeks ago, 94 coal mining jobs disappeared. Why? Primarily because freight and transport costs were too high. Could it be suggested in fact that one wharfie's pay rise is another coalminer's job? I wonder how any wharfies worry about that.

Most Australians would say that those wharfies, despite what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said today, could do a great deal more work for the 20 or 25 hours work that they do and the $850 a week that they earn, and that there is little justification for them being offered an increase which will amount to more than the average family farm worker will earn in the next 12 months.

As a farmer, I utterly reject the Prime Minister's statement to the effect that the prime determinant of farmers' incomes is but price variations. I happen to be a farmer and I can tell honourable members that the biggest problem that has developed over the last few years has been cost increases.

The truth is that a radically new attitude is needed urgently in this country. Our policy provides both the legal framework and the positive incentives within which that can develop. Again, there are four basic principles. The first is the right for individual employers and employees, if they choose-that is, they have a choice-subject to minimal wage and health and safety standards, to formulate their own workplace-relevant enterprise agreements. The second is the abolition of the closed shop and compulsory unionism. Honourable members will remember that only 30.8 per cent of the private sector work force now choose to belong to a union, and that will drop rapidly unless they become more relevant. The third basic principle is enterprise unions for those who want them-the very antithesis of this Government's approach with its super unions. The fourth and final principle is equality before the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) ended as he started, with simplistic slogans and a very superficial look at industrial relations. I wish to address my comments to some of the substance that has been raised in this matter of public importance but, more importantly, some of the substance that has been raised outside of this place in the debate which the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and others have been pursuing in industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bennelong was at pains to try to paint a picture of confusion in the current industrial relations situation and referred to a no-man's-land. He also made that reference earlier today on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program The World Today where he said:``
. . . this . . . no-man's land is just confusing the public, the unions, the Commission and certainly potential investors who Mr Keating reckons are going to flood the country, they're confused too.

It would seem from his comments that, regrettably, the honourable member for Bennelong is more confused than most on this issue, although I give him credit for understanding the position far better than he has articulated it to date. He has made reference to the concern that investors have about the state of our current industrial relation system. The honourable member for Bennelong and those opposite know as well as anybody that those factors which relate to industrial relations, which are important to investors, are not cheap political tricks in a debate such as this. They are the hard facts-in particular, the hard facts of unit labour costs and the hard facts of days lost through strikes. The honourable member for Bennelong knows that as well as anybody.

As the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), who is at the table, pointed out, our record in the area of days lost through strikes is substantially better than the record of the Liberal-National Party when it was in government. During Question Time the honourable member for Bennelong sought to raise a point of order, complaining about the base year that was being selected. He referred to 1982 as the base year when he should have been using 1983. Of course, he can pick any year and he will get a different result.

The Minister at the table has pointed out that, if all the years are averaged, the figures arrived at are those that the Government has been putting forward. I suggest to the honourable member for Bennelong that he should leave well enough alone-1982 was not a bad year to use. If we go back to 1981, instead of 370 days being lost, 780 days were lost. If those opposite do not like that year, they should go back to the year before, when they were in government, because 630 days were lost. If they do not like that year, I suggest they go back to 1979, because there were again 780 days lost that year. The fact is that the record of those opposite on industrial relations throughout the period of the last Liberal Government is absolutely appalling.

Unit labour costs, which is the other industrial relations indicator that foreign investors are concerned about, have fallen in real terms-that is a matter of fact which cannot be denied-to a level lower than they have been for a decade. The honourable member for Gwydir and some other honourable members were hinting at that as being somehow a negative and talking about the hurt that it has generated.

What he has failed to understand or at least accept in this debate is that, because of the accord, other provisions have been made available which provide real and tangible assistance. I mentioned some of them the other day during the debate on the industrial relations legislation. I do not propose to go over all of them, but they include things such as family allowance, family allowance supplement, Medicare and child-care fee relief. They provide very substantial increases in the disposable incomes of Australian working families. They are part of the accord process and they substantially improve the quality of life of Australians.

It is about time the Opposition started to acknowledge the benefits that have flowed from the accord. One reason why the Opposition has refused to accept the facts, refused to accept the reality of the benefits of the accord, is that it knows that under no circumstances is it in a position to create an accord. The Opposition does not have the policy, the wit or the rapport with the employees-nor the employers, I might say-to generate an accord that could produce the same benefits to the country or the same benefits to individuals.

I turn to the question of enterprise agreements, because the Opposition has made great play of that and I think it is important that it be addressed. There is no doubt that central to the current accord is a commitment on the part of the Government and the trade union movement to introduce more decentralised enterprise based industrial agreements and awards to regulate salaries, hours and conditions. But when we talk about doing this, we should not just rush headlong into it and say, `Well, let's just clear the decks and have enterprise agreements because everyone will play the game according to the rules'.

I seem to recall honourable members opposite complaining about excesses and, in fact, honourable members on this side of the House quite rightly also complaining about excesses in some of our other institutions when the markets were freed up. Not all of the players do play by the Queensberry rules. If we are going to talk about the very livelihood of Australian families-their wages and salaries; their hours of work; whether they have a holiday and, if so, whether it is three weeks or four weeks; whether they get holiday leave loading; whether they can take leave if they are pregnant; whether they can take leave to travel, all those sorts of things-we want to be damn sure we have got it right before we condemn Australian working people to an alternative set of conditions.

That can be done only if enterprise bargaining is done on an equitable and fair footing. It requires equity within known guidelines and rules. Clearly, there is a role for the Commission in that process in both determining the question of guidelines and ensuring that equity prevails through the system. Honourable members on both sides of this Parliament could be quite adept at citing examples of excesses of unions or management in particular cases that have occurred in the past. There are no brownie points for doing that. That is not the real debating issue. The real debating issue is how things will operate for the bulk of ordinary Australian men and women.

A laissez-faire approach that eliminates trade unions, that eliminates the Industrial Relations Commission from the process, and that says to individual employees, `You negotiate your conditions with your employer and you wear the outcome for yourself because you are a free and intelligent person and you should have `free choice' ignores the facts of life and the reality. Even the American system of bargaining requires legislative commitment that genuine bargaining occur.

We cannot have genuine bargaining when a truck driver who works for Mayne Nickless or one of the other large transport companies decides that he wants to go down to the boss's office and negotiate his salary a la Liberal Party policy. That is not going to occur. There is no balance in the negotiating process there. It is not a question of negotiation. It will be a question of who is going to dictate the terms.

Everyone in Australia knows that that is the outcome of the sort of enterprise bargaining that the Opposition is talking about. That is, in fact, the history of what occurred in Queensland with voluntary employment agreements. Power Brewing is often cited as the great example of what we can do with enterprise bargaining. I do not have the time here, today, to talk in detail about that. I simply wish to place on the record that the Power agreement was unique for a whole range of reasons and was created because of some problems which quite frankly were generated on both sides-and probably more on the union side than on the employer side. It is not typical of voluntary employment agreements, nor is it typical of the enterprise agreement which would be generated under the Opposition's policy.

The fact is that in Queensland the great bulk of voluntary employment agreements were in the hospitality and tourist industries where juniors, women and people desperate for jobs were told by employers, `You will work longer hours, for less pay, with no holiday, whether you like it or not'. That was the standard. There are any number of examples that can be illustrated. We can go through the records and check all the voluntary enterprise agreements in Queensland that now can be checked-they could not before, because they were all secret documents-and we will find that that is the case. Equally, it is not the profile of agreements that are going to exist in New Zealand. I understand that most of the front bench of the Opposition have been to New Zealand in recent weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not me.

—The honourable member should go. I understand that virtually the entire front bench has been there and has seen the new order created in New Zealand which has, in one fell swoop, eliminated awards, eliminated any standard hours of work, created $NZ245 as the basic wage for all New Zealanders, taken one week's annual holiday off of them, and said, `You're entitled to only five days sickness a year; that's it. After that, you can get what you are individually able to negotiate with your boss'. There is no equity in that.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is about responsible social reform and economic reform-a reform process that is done in negotiation with employer and employee organisations and one which will guarantee not only a prosperous future for this nation, but an equitably distributed prosperous future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is concluded.

That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 28 May 1991, at 2 p.m., unless Mr Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting.
