DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Griffiths, for Mr Beazley) agreed to:
(1) That the resolution of appointment of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade be amended by omitting ``4 subcommittees'' from paragraph (8) and substituting ``5 subcommittees''.
(2) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting its concurrence.
Bill presented by Mr Griffiths, for Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The clear-English Social Security Bill 1990 was introduced into the House of Representatives during the Budget sittings 1990 and reflected the 1947 Act, as it stood at the end of the autumn sittings 1990. The Social Security Bill 1990 is now the Social Security Act 1991 and will come into operation on 1 July 1991. Amendments made to the 1947 Act during the Budget sittings 1990 and the autumn sittings 1991 will need to be incorporated into the 1991 Act before it comes into effect. This involves a straight translation of existing policy and will be done in two stages.

First, the Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill 1991 will provide for amendments made to the 1947 Act by the Social Welfare (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Act 1990, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1990 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act 1990 to be incorporated into the 1991 Act. This covers initiatives such as:
- tax file numbers;
- deeming (loans and deposits);
- liquid assets tests for sickness beneficiaries;
- recovery of overpayments;
- employment entry payment for sole parents;
- disaster relief payments;
- extension of qualification criteria for remote area allowance;
- extension of qualification criteria for carer pension;
- pharmaceutical supplement and allowance; and
- the amended international social security agreement with the United Kingdom and the new one with Malta.

The Budget 1990 initiatives which affect the unemployment benefit and Job Search allowance structure in the 1947 Act are incorporated into the new provisions for Job Search allowance and Newstart allowance to be inserted into the 1991 Act by the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 18 April 1991.

The Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill 1991 will also provide for some minor technical refinements to be made to the 1991 Act to make sure that it correctly reflects the current legislation and policy.

In the second stage of updating the 1991 Act, amendments made to the 1947 Act by the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991-introduced into the House of Representatives on 13 March 1991 and dealing with initiatives such as exemption from the income and assets tests for certain funeral bonds, approved scholarships and compensation recovery-will be incorporated into the 1991 Act by the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No 2) 1991.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is the second of three Bills required to give effect to the `plain English' rewrite of Part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. It provides the necessary legal machinery for the transition from the former Part III to the new plain English Part III. In keeping with the promise I gave to the ex-service community, the Bill contains no changes to policy. It does, however, ensure that changes to the Veterans' Entitlement Act arising from the 1990 Budget sittings are included in the rewritten Part III.
The primary objective of the Bill is to:
- make the necessary savings and transitional provisions to ensure that existing rights are protected;
- add `plain English' indexation provisions and 1990 Budget amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991 (the Rewrite Bill);
- make consequential amendments to other Parts of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, other Veterans' Affairs legislation and other Commonwealth Acts; and
- make minor technical amendments to the Rewrite Bill.
This Bill will ensure that:

- service pension processes begun under specific provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act prior to the commencement of the rewritten Part III on 1 July 1991 will continue to be operative after that date under the equivalent provisions of the rewritten Part III without any break in continuity;
- all legislation containing references to the former Part III are updated to reflect the structural and other changes to the rewrite of Part III; and
- the Rewrite Bill as introduced is amended to correct any minor drafting or unintentional errors.

As I said, the Bill reflects the undertaking I gave to the ex-service community at the beginning of the exercise in 1990 that the rewrite of Part III would not involve any policy changes. My Department has discussed the development of the Bill with ex-service organisations.
This Bill has no financial impact for the Government or veterans and their dependants. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1991[COGNATE BILL:INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 April, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1991. If there is no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point to be made about the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 and the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1991 is that the explanatory memorandums are prepared in a way that represents a great advance on similar material with which we have had to grapple in the past. That is probably just as well because the proposed amendments are again in one omnibus Bill and in another which is much more specific and narrower in its provisions. Because the radically altered format of the memorandum does not match the order in which the clauses appear in the Bill, there seems to be a need for that to be changed in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The index to the explanatory memorandum in this case, I am sorry to record, also contains a number of cross-referencing errors. This should be carefully edited to ensure that all references to page numbers are, indeed, correct. For ease of reference, I might suggest to those responsible that such indexes should in future be at the front of the main body of the memorandum. As well, it seems that the diagram on page 131 of the explanatory memorandum for Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 relating to new tax file number arrangements is incorrect. The primary investor should be quoting the tax file number and the interposed entity quoting the investment body remitter number.

On page 135 of the explanatory memorandum, the diagram showing the system of quotation where an investment is made through an interposed entity is also incorrect. The correct quotation of a tax file number should be by the primary investor to the investment body. Also on page 135, the reference to subsection 128(3) should be subsection 128b (3).

Once again, the time made available to the coalition parties is clearly nowhere near adequate, given the breadth and complexities of these proposals. As has happened all too often with earlier omnibus tax Bills, the lack of time for the widest possible consultation with interested parties, other than those favoured by the Government, does not lend itself to sound legislative practice. It is a measure of the Government's priorities and approach to legislation generally that little more than two weeks is allowed for complex tax measures, while other Bills have been on the Notice Paper for months.

On top of that, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has subjected the debate on these Bills to the guillotine, effectively preventing honourable members from having anything like the time needed to canvass all the issues. Of course, he did the same last year at the end of the autumn and Budget sessions. The omnibus Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 is composed mostly of proposed amendments contemplated by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) as long ago as August last year and, in one case, a series of proposed changes which he foreshadowed on 13 December last. More of that later.

This Bill sets out to start the process of including those who earn income in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands into the mainstream of Australian taxpayers. Tax concessions applying to other Australians living in remote Australia and its Territories will apply to relevant income and consequential taxes. Altogether, the move is welcomed. So, too, is the care that is intended to be taken to ensure provision to not tax termination payments retrospectively. This Government has not always been too fussy about imposing a tax obligation retrospectively; hence our appreciation. The Opposition does not oppose these provisions.

Other proposed amendments include provisions to change tax laws on certain income earned from foreign sources. Specifically, it will amend provisions designed to tax income to controlled foreign corporations (CFCs) as defined.

It was only during the latter half of last year that the measures it is now proposed to change were debated and eventually passed by the Parliament. No sooner was the ink dry on the Governor-General's assent than the Treasurer (Mr Keating) foreshadowed further amendments. He did that on 13 December 1990. When the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill 1990 was debated last October, the coalition made it abundantly clear that further changes were required. Here we have the first batch today, but watch this space because there are still more to come, such was the Government's incompetence in framing the original legislation.

In properly setting out to counter schemes or devices to get around the intentions stated last year involving what are called arrangement transfers, there is created a possible and presumably unintended distortion. Indeed, the practice that it is sought to circumvent might well be successfully tackled under part IVa of the principal Act. Alternatively, a more specific amendment should be proposed to avoid taxing inoffensive transactions, as will flow from the amendments proposed.

The thin capitalisation amendments are welcome also as far as they go. However, there is some force in arguments that the scope of the relevant existing clauses and proposed new section 159gzlb should be extended to a number of foreign owned corporate groups independent of resident banks as a matter of equity. The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) acknowledged the issue and clauses involved as long as two or three years ago. For reasons known only to the ATO, if not the Treasurer, there is no indication that any accommodation is imminent. Our advice is that if the will existed the inequity could be rectified by simply extending the operation of section 159gzla. Similarly, a technical anomaly to do with certain transitional year eventualities could have and arguably should have been remedied in this Bill.

The Bill provides for the extension of the present provisions allowing for the deductibility of expenditure designed to prevent land degradation. Specifically, the new amendment will allow primary producers and rural businesses to deduct those expenses involved in erecting fences that separate different classes of land and so prevent land degradation by livestock. In order to be eligible for deductibility, the separation must take place in accordance within an approved farm plan with the principal purpose of preventing the degradation of land.

This raises a dilemma with the operation of this legislation that is common to all tax concessions of this nature. The amendment introduces direct cross-compliance arrangements which are, of course, necessary to ensure the accountability of this new tax expenditure. For obvious reasons we need to ensure that deductible expenditure is being used for the purposes intended in general, and intended specifically by the provisions in this Bill. But at the same time, direct cross-compliance arrangements introduce significant compliance costs into the administration of the new tax deductibility arrangements.

In legislation such as this, we seek to strike a balance between the need for accountability in the expenditure-or taxation expenditure, as it is euphemistically known-and the desire to make the compliance burden of that expenditure as minimal as possible. The National Farmers Federation (NFF) has already expressed its concern that the arrangements that have been made for the approval of farm plans may be inadequate. I venture to suggest that it may also be unnecessary. The NFF has stressed that the approval of farm plans needs to take place as quickly, fairly and cheaply as possible if the goals of this tax expenditure are to be realised.

There is some doubt as to whether the existing land conservation agencies will be able to cope with the demand for farm plan approvals under the new amendment. This will be of benefit, of course, to those consultants approved by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to carry out farm approval plans. Unfortunately, these consultants are also relatively expensive for primary producers to use. It has therefore been proposed by the NFF that State farm organisations be incorporated in the legislation to enable them to approve farm plans in recognition of the major role that these organisations play in land care issues.

Given the position of the NFF and other opinions which will be mentioned by my colleagues later, it will be necessary for the coalition to seek in the Senate to have this Bill generally referred to a committee. That committee will specifically want to consider these measures and I would not be too sure that we will not be discussing an amendment to it after it has gone through that process. Should it not be amended, it will be necessary to monitor the operation of this amendment to ensure that it does satisfactorily achieve its objectives with a view to amending the legislation subsequently, should that need arise.

The Bill also gives effect to the 1990 Budget decision to allow tax deductibility of expenses incurred in the rehabilitation of exploration, mining and quarrying operations. This amendment is a desirable way of encouraging firms to clean up land that has been utilised for mining operations and which would otherwise be abandoned to the detriment of the environment. Also, in this connection, we hear a whisper that there are to be amendments introduced by the Government in the Senate. If that happens to be true, it is just further evidence-if further evidence were needed-of the ineptitude of the Government in framing amendments to taxation laws of this kind.

It is common for mining rights to be granted with clean-up conditions attached. However, this regulatory approach to environmental protection provides an incentive to do only the minimum required by the terms of the mining grant. The amendment will provide firms with a positive incentive to clean up the results of their activities. It does, however, introduce a major anomaly into the tax laws in that these provisions are restricted solely to the mining industry. Obviously, many other industries have occasion to upset the environment and yet these industries are not going to be treated to the same tax incentives that this amendment will confer on the mining and quarrying industry.

This legislation is slightly wider in scope than that anticipated in the Budget Papers; it does not go very far in addressing what are some major disincentives to environmentally responsible behaviour under existing tax laws. A taxation institute survey of seven Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries has found a more tax concessional approach to the environment in most of them. This puts Australia at a competitive disadvantage compared to the rest of the world. But it would appear that we have reached the limits of the Government's efforts at making the taxation system more environmentally friendly-certainly in the amount of paper it needs to print the taxation legislation these days, it is not very friendly.

There are a number of difficulties in using the tax system to promote environmentally responsible behaviour. These difficulties have been highlighted by Senator McMullan and others on a number of occasions. They include the problems of targeting, the potential for abuse, additional compliance and collection costs and the inconsistency of such measures with the goal of broadening the tax base. These considerations should not be allowed to stand in the way of removing anomalies from the system that encourage environmentally irresponsible behaviour.

There is also some concern that the requirements of this amendment to restore a mine site to its pre-mining condition or to a reasonable approximation of that condition may be too restrictive. This may arise, for example, in the case of the decommissioning of offshore oil drilling platforms where an environmentally acceptable outcome may not require the full restoration of the site in question but merely the removal of some equipment.

Under the heading `Securities Lending Arrangements', the Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Crean) in his second reading speech stated that existing concessions will be extended, affecting sales of shares-cum-dividends and certain securities lending transactions. These changes were not foreshadowed in any way by the Government, in contradistinction to some of the others we will be discussing. Perhaps that fact, along with a lack of sufficiently wide consultation with experts in the field, accounts for the very firm opinions of some that these provisions will not achieve the stated intention and will have presumably unintended consequences in the form of avoidable problems.

Since the Bill became available for widespread scrutiny after 18 April, the Australian Taxation Office will have been made aware of what appear to be serious justified concerns. Amendments to securities lending arrangements (SLAs) suffer from both a number of flaws and a failure to come to grips with the need to deal adequately with the number of fairly common transactions relevant to security lending practices. As to the former-that is, major flaws-the amendments will run the chance of completely defeating the claimed intention of extending taxation relief for securities lending.

There is a crying need to get all these drafting deficiencies corrected before the measures are passed by this Parliament. The responsible Minister should have done the sensible thing and deferred debate and introduced further amendments before sending the Bill to the Senate for its concurrence. That would have been the sensible way to go. Common sense in managing its legislative program in general and tax law amendments in particular does not figure as a priority under this Government. It is likely that the Senate will again be called upon to do the mopping up, and we will once again be required in this House to discuss the Senate's amendments; we will probably also be required to do that under the guillotine. Proposed changes in the taxation law affecting scrip lending and cum dividend shares require complex clauses to make them compatible with the principal Act.

At least a couple of analyses which became available to the coalition strongly indicate that the level of thoroughness of any consultative procedures in connection with these provisions in the Bill have been well short of what was needed. Let us have a quick look at some of the language in those analyses. I am afraid a quick look is all that is possible because the guillotine will savagely curtail debate on the second reading of the Bill and is likely to prevent any clause by clause scrutiny in Committee. The Government in its characteristic arrogance will not allow that to happen in the House, and that task will once again be forced to the senators.

Throughout the comments and views on securities lending arrangements are phrases such as `requirements of the selection not be met'; `there is nothing to displace or modify (a) general law provision'; `the provision may possibly be inadequate'; `there is no logical reason for this possibility to be ignored'; `lack of precision in the wording'; `the wording is imprecise'; and `impossible to satisfy the conditions of (a particular) section'. Adding to those comments, some of which are repeated throughout but which relate to different proposed sections, the authors of these analyses have expressed themselves in words such as `the wording . . . of (the) subsection will need to be changed' and `suggested drafting amendment'.

The purpose of reciting these considered opinions by qualified parties is to demonstrate that gross inadequacies remain in the relevant clauses of this Bill. Because of the Government-imposed inability of the House to consider securities amendment arrangements in a substantial way, we are limited to debating and illustrating generalities.

To give some insight into the actual clauses in the Bill, it might be useful to list the sections, subsections and subparagraphs to which one or more of the conclusions just referred to apply. Generally, section 26bc figures prominently. Proposed subsections of relevance include 26bc (3) (e) (i); 26bc (3) (c) (ii), (iii) and (iv); 26bc (9c); 26bc (9d) and (9e); 26bc(9a), and perhaps others. In all, if the reservations and recommendations are justified for reasons available to the Government, through me on behalf of the coalition, we are faced with the totally unsatisfactory prospect of seeing totally inadequate legislative proposals passed for consideration in the Senate.

Provisions affecting cum dividend share contracts appear to be based on fundamental misconceptions that professional advice suggests will render them completely unworkable in practice. There is good reason to believe that the relevant proposals are ill thought through. For example, for new division 6a, section 160aqua to apply, it must be able to be said that the registered shareholder was under an obligation to transfer to another taxpayer the share in respect of which a franked dividend is received.

In the case of shares in a listed company, generally specific performance will not be ordered for a contract of sale of a share. This is because damages are regarded as an adequate remedy. For this reason, even where the vendor is the registered holder of a particular share in a listed company, it cannot generally be said that there is an obligation to transfer any share, let alone the share held, to the purchaser. Accordingly, as a matter of strict law, section 160aqua can never apply to a cum dividend contract. Furthermore the provisions do not appear to cover short sales of shares that are eventually transferred cum dividend.

In other common enough situations arising from securities lending arrangements, new division 6a will be deficient. By way of illustration only, take the case of borrowed securities which are transferred before the relevant book's closing date. In the absence of any contractual provision in the SLAs to the contrary, the operation of new division 6a will be entirely dependent on the actions of the borrower. In at least one circumstance, the operation of the division will be avoidable. Time available simply does not allow the Opposition the opportunity to flesh out the reasons for serious concerns about the efficacy of the proposals for SLAs, which are far from limited to those matters touched upon in my remarks.

It is proposed in these amendments to extend access to tax information to be provided by the Australian Taxation Office by the addition of the Australian Bureau of Intelligence, the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales and the New South Wales Crime Commission. At present such access is confined to the Australian Federal Police, the police forces of a State or the Northern Territory, the Director of Public Prosecutions, the National Crime Authority, the National Companies and Securities Commission, and a corporate affairs commission of a State or Territory. By provision in the principal Act, information may be provided if the Commissioner is satisfied as to the existence of a couple of criteria. Essentially, information can be passed on if the Commissioner believes a serious offence may have been committed or if he is satisfied about the making of an order under the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987.

A serious offence is defined to mean an indictable offence. This, in turn, means an offence which carries a penalty of 12 months imprisonment or more. That enables application of the provisions for a wide range of offences from the relatively trivial to the very serious. Strict secrecy obligations extend to the recipients of such information from the Commissioner.

The coalition believes that caution should be exercised when widening the scope for access to this type of sensitive information by Federal and State bodies. We cannot be entirely satisfied that due caution has been exercised in deciding on this measure because both the Minister's second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum to the Bill are silent as to the reasons. In the circumstances, we are left to urge the Government and the Australian Taxation Office to take special care before and when providing sensitive information and to subject the procedures involved to the very closest of scrutiny.

The Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill gives effect to comprehensive double taxation agreements between Hungary and Kiribati. Several questions arise which may affect arrangements in common with both Hungary and Kiribati, although doubts implied in these questions especially apply to the agreement with Hungary.

The first query of several that we would like the Government to clarify in the Minister's summing up concerns article 2 (1) (b) of the schedule. It refers to profit tax in Hungary. The meaning of the term is far from clear, given other definitions in the schedule. For example, article 2 (1) (a) stipulates the inclusion of both income tax and petroleum resources rent tax for these purposes. Article 13 refers to gains from alienation of property, which presumably is just another way of describing a capital gains tax. The terms `income tax' and `capital gains tax' strike some as being mutually exclusive, if only because all over the world such taxes are separate and separable. It seems that, where article 23 refers to income, profit or rates, capital gains tax could be included twice. Because it appears that the agreement with Hungary includes more than just income tax, some further explanations are required.

What about taxes which exist in Hungary and not in Australia, or vice versa? Hungary imposes a tax on the assets of an individual where the value of assets exceeds a stipulated threshold, irrespective of whether those assets earn income. Is such a tax embraced in this Bill? What about death duties? Hungary levies heavy death duties. Are only taxes required by the central governments of each country affected by the measures we have under discussion? Municipal taxes in Hungary raise revenue to finance some services which, in Australia, are financed from Canberra. Are they to be included? The Minister might like to put on record that there is no reciprocity for State and municipal taxes.

Finally, provisions for the exchange of information covered in article 26 leave many who are likely to be directly affected feeling extremely nervous. While it is apparently too late to drop article 26 altogether, the exchange of information about otherwise private affairs of individuals should be heavily burdened by a strict privacy clause. Hopefully, the Minister will clarify the matters raised.

Unfortunately, I have not covered each item in the Bill and, by a quick glance at the clock, I could not possibly have done so. Other measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and referred to in chapters 10, 14, 15, 17 and 19 in the explanatory memorandum simply cannot be dealt with due to insufficient time being made available by the Government for debate and discussion.

It is fair to say that had this Bill been debated without the constraints of the guillotine, the same circumstance would have applied. Had that been the case, there would have been two saving graces: we would have had a chance to go through the Bills clause by clause in the committee stage of the debate and other members from our side would have had the opportunity to make some detailed contribution to the debate. As it stands, this Bill almost certainly will be referred to a committee of the Senate. Regrettably, that is the only way we can responsibly deal with the legislation before us. Hopefully, that Senate committee will identify and verify the problems and shortcomings of this legislation to which I have referred and will propose suitable amendments which, as I have already indicated, we will have to deliberate on again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I want to indicate to the House that my remarks tonight in the course of this cognate debate concern, in particular, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1991. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and comments thereon I will leave to my colleagues, save for the general plea, which I make every time amendments come before this place dealing with the Income Tax Assessment Act: when will we see a total rewrite of that Act so that the four-foot high amendment stage can be reduced to something that is workable, meaningful and written in plain English so that we can all understand it? This plea not only has been made in this place by members on both sides of the Parliament but also has been reflected time and again in a number of committee reports emanating from my committee, the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, with support from both sides of the House. That is the final comment I make on that particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill is to provide the legislative framework for agreements for the prevention of double taxation and tax avoidance between Australia and Hungary and Australia and Kiribati. Lest the Opposition again accuse this Government of ramming through legislation which has, of course, the aim of protecting the integrity of the Australian taxation system, I note that the agreement with Hungary which is being enshrined in this legislation was in fact signed on 29 November 1990 and the agreement with Kiribati on 25 March 1991. The details of each of those agreements were, in fact, announced and copies were made available at the time of signature. Therefore, to suggest that no-one knew about it is patently not correct.

The agreements allocate taxing rights over all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and Hungary and Australia and Kiribati respectively and substantially accord with the terms and purpose of other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years. Indeed, Australia now has agreements with a number of countries, including France, West Germany, New Zealand, the United States, China, Papua New Guinea and the United Kingdom. All of those agreements have, as their common aim, the prevention of double taxation and taxation avoidance. In that respect, I remind honourable members that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has completed three reports into the issue of taxation avoidance and international profit shifting. The most recent of those reports was tabled in this place only a few weeks ago.

In particular, two of those reports, Taxpayers or Taxplayers and Follow the Yellow Brick Road, canvassed those issues. In fact, I would like to refer to some of the recommendations of those reports as I think they have a great bearing on the legislation which we are considering this evening.

The actual double taxation agreements give the country of residence the exclusive right to tax certain categories of income and to allow the remaining income to be taxed by the country in which it was sourced. If the income is then taxed by the country of residence, it must allow a credit for tax paid in the country of origin.

The agreements with Hungary and Kiribati reflect the current tax agreements entered into with the other countries I mentioned. For example, income from land will be taxable in the country where the land is situated. Business profits may only be taxed in the source country if the entity has a permanent establishment in the country. I think that probably overcomes some of the concerns mentioned by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in respect of local government rates and taxes, given that they are in fact based on land held in local government areas.

Dividends, interest and royalties may be taxed by either country, but there are limits on the tax charged by the source country. Pensions, generally, will be taxable only in the country of residence. The provision to assist schemes designed to attract investment to these countries will be included in both agreements. I think that that is a welcome change and something which should be actively pursued.

Anti-avoidance measures will be concentrated on the exchange of information between tax officials in Australia and the country concerned. However, no country will be obliged to provide information that could not be obtained under the laws of the country to which the information is to be supplied or to disclose information that would be contrary to public policy. In that regard, I again draw the attention of the House to recommendations contained in the report Follow the Yellow Brick Road, the final report on an efficiency audit by the Australian Taxation Office on the subject of international profit shifting dated March 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a very good report too.

—As my colleague and fellow committee member the honourable member for Parramatta remarks, indeed it is a great report. I refer honourable members to the section dealing with exchanges of information and particularly recommendations 11 and 12 of that report. The report Follow the Yellow Brick Road says that we made the recommendation that the establishment of comprehensive taxation agreements be pursued actively with countries which have a comparable tax regime to that of Australia-not only countries identified in tonight's legislation, but all countries-as a result of the changes that have been introduced by this Government in our taxing arrangements with comparable countries.

SPEECH.PARA: We also went on in recommendation 12 to make the observation that, in order to further facilitate information sharing with treaty countries, ATO officers should be posted to selected treaty countries to coordinate and, with the approval of the overseas tax authority, collect data on behalf of the ATO offices in Australia. We have indicated that such a move would signal that the ATO is serious in its efforts to chase down information from overseas jurisdictions in order to prevent tax avoidance arrangements.

That recommendation No. 12, together with recommendation No. 11, in my view-and certainly in the view of the Committee, as it was a unanimous report-was worthy of further consideration. I hope that the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Crean), who is at the table, takes note of those matters and that the Taxation Office looks into the matter very carefully.

Our conclusion of an agreement with Hungary mirrors our support for that country's newly installed democratic institutions and its moves towards a market based economy. I believe that this legislation will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade and investment and widen relations between Australia and Hungary. I hope that it does.

This legislation also signifies this Government's goals and achievements in overhauling generally our tax system by making it simpler and, more importantly, more equitable. Unfortunately, it has also made it longer. As a result of this Government's efforts by introducing dividend imputation, the fringe benefits tax, the requirement for substantiation and the capital gains tax, we now have a taxation system which is much more honest and, of course, principled.

As I indicated a little earlier, the issue associated with the question of profit shifting between Australia and other countries, the efficiency audit which was undertaken into the Taxation Office and the changes that have been put in place, plus the foreign source income legislation introduced into this Parliament previously-after a great deal of deliberation, and the existence of exposure drafts for public comment by people out there in the marketplace, including the practitioners and so on-again illustrates this Government's commitment to close off every possible and, hopefully, conceivable loophole.

It is an unfortunate fact that, whilst the Australian Taxation Office is constantly monitoring problems of this nature, there are always smarties who are trying to be one step ahead of it. It is an unfortunate set of circumstances, which often leads, as has been discovered in the course of the inquiries to which I have already referred tonight, to problems. Once rorts in the system are exposed-whether they be international profit shifting or because a double taxation treaty, such as the ones we are talking about in this legislation, does not exist-then the ATO obviously is at a disadvantage, the taxation system of this country is at a disadvantage and the fair and reasonable amount of tax which is due and payable to Australia, to the Australian revenue, to be redistributed by the Commonwealth Government to provide all the services that it must provide, is obviously disadvantaged.

In my view, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill goes farther along that road to improving a situation which was identified not only in the reports to which I have referred but also by the Taxation Office itself. It is aimed at combating tax avoidance and providing information between tax regimes of comparable nature with those of Australia. As I have suggested, perhaps it is something we need to investigate further in taxation treaty negotiations that are presently under way.

I would also comment, as we have done in the report, that in the course of any negotiated treaties in the future there is a need to look at other problems that might arise, particularly in the withholding tax area. Many recommendations contained in this report go to that matter.

Most Australians, where possible, will endeavour to minimise tax. That is legitimate. However, often the unfortunate consequence of some unscrupulous people and corporations endeavouring to minimise their tax obligations is tax avoidance-illegal evasion on many occasions-and unfortunately the burden often falls on the pay as you earn taxpayers, who simply do not have the resources to do anything about it; their tax comes out of their pay every fortnight. The legitimate public policy expectation is that the taxation base will be secure and broad and will catch within its net all those people who have a legitimate obligation to make a contribution to the social fabric of our country. This legislation goes that way. It is timely, it is appropriate and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to expand on certain remarks made by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Income Tax (International Agreements) Bill and perhaps help the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) in his endeavour to get this four-foot high pile of legislation reduced slightly. I hope that the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Crean), who is at the table, will take some notice of these suggestions, because it may be that some other arrangements will be made about the Bill in the Senate before it is finalised.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not take up much time. The first matter refers to clause 30, subsection 1a (b) of the part of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) referring to deduction of expenditure on prevention of land degradation. It says that the expenditure must be incurred by a taxpayer:
. . . who carries on a business, other than one of primary production or mining or quarrying, for the purpose of gaining or producing assessable income from the use of any rural land . . .

That is an expansion of the old definition, which really referred only to the business of primary production. I understand the purpose of that expansion and I think the purpose is a commendable one. In other words, the intention is to prevent the degradation of land where possible by allowing people other than simply primary producers, miners and quarriers to be able to use that section. However, it does seem to me that it is loosely worded. It requires, as I see it, three tests. One is that the person has to be carrying on a business; secondly, one has to be doing that for the purpose of assessable income; and, thirdly, there has to have been some degradation to rural land.

As I said, it seems to me that the interpretation of this expansion under these words is open to abuse. It has been pointed out to me that one could claim a deduction for fencing in or out the inmates of a rural brothel as long as the land on which that use was occurring would be degraded-which it no doubt would be in the circumstance. I understand the reasons for the clause, but it would seem to me that the land should be associated with some agrarian or other legitimate rural purpose and I suggest that the Government should address this matter.
In regard to the second matter, which I think also requires some attention from the Minister, clause 30 (a) (1b) (e) requires that, to qualify for deductions, the expenditure must be incurred in:

. . . an operation consisting of the erection of fences (including any extension, alteration or addition to fences) to separate different land classes on the subject land in accordance with an approved whole farm plan in respect of the subject land;

This matter has been alluded to by the honourable member for Curtin. I would simply say to the Government that there should be no reason why this clause should then be subjected to a whole lot of people to approve such a whole farm plan. For example, further in the Bill this is stated:
an approved whole farm plan, in relation to land,--
(a) has been prepared by:
(i) an officer of a land conservation agency having authority for the preparation of such plans; or
(ii) an approved farm consultant; or
(b) has been approved in writing by:
(i) an officer of a land conservation agency with authority to do so; or
(ii) an approved farm consultant;

TALK.START.PARA: —All `ors'.

—Yes, of course-if they happen to be approved farm consultants and happen to have been approved by the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, which is what is says further on in the Bill. We get to a point where in fact we have a whole army of approvers and some people approving the approvers. Then we go to subsection (17), which says:

SPEECH.PARA: In deciding whether to approve a person as a farm consultant, the following matters are to be taken into account:
(a) the qualifications, experience-
this is getting back to the subject raised a minute ago-
and knowledge of the person in relation to land conservation and farm management;
(b) the standing of the person in the professional community-
whatever profession-
(c) any other relevant matters.

I just say that one of the relevant matters will be that, if all those procedures have to be gone through, the farmer or the conservator will go broke before he ever gets to a whole farm plan or to submitting that to the relevant agency and the Taxation Office. What will happen will be that people will not go about the business of conserving degraded land; it will be too expensive and it will be a long drawn-out procedure.

In the interests of furthering the cause of the honourable member for Macarthur, to actually reduce the size of the taxation arrangements, I suggest that the Government should simply look at wiping out all those qualifications. It should leave the section in, get rid of the approved farm plan qualification, get rid of the authorities and the army of people who have to approve it, and do what is done with all the rest of the tax Act, that is, simply allow people to sign off on their return as they normally do in regard to all the other activities, capital or otherwise, which they submit in that return. After all, in this country we are looking more and more to self-assessment. I think that is the way the Government should be moving in regard to this particular subsection of these amendments.

I will not take much more of the time of the House. It seems to me the Government should be looking at this. It should not be creating more bureaucracy, more red tape. It could wipe out whole pages of this particular amendment. In fact, it would then be encouraging people to fence off degraded areas of land, and it might even start a fashion. On the other hand, if one has to go out there to get whole reams of approvals from people as yet not even appointed or thought about, it will be a great disadvantage to the purpose. I commend the purpose, but I do not commend the method.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill, which are before the House, particularly Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), I would like at the outset to take up some of the issues raised by the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), particularly relating to the land care initiatives that the Government has taken and included in the amendments dealing with the issue of land degradation, and the effective provision through the tax system for concessions relating to the rehabilitation of those areas. The honourable member for Barker has tried to paint the picture that the arrangements in these particular areas are complex, and that the sort of detail that is required there is unnecessary.
—And expensive.

—I would like to suggest to him that I think the notion of a farm plan such as is required in the legislation is probably something that most people who are keen to be efficient and contemporary in running a farm enterprise would regard as part and parcel of their normal farm enterprise operation.
—Not for this purpose.

—The honourable member for Barker is suggesting that it all has to be done because of this particular tax Bill. I would suggest that that is a nonsense. Surely it is only something most of them would be engaging in to a great extent anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: What is being sought in terms of that particular farm plan? By preparing a farm plan it is sought to show the location of existing fences, soil types, land systems, drainage lines, et cetera. It is an important step in determining how farm activities might be more suitably located and managed, to match present and future farm needs based on the geographic features, and other issues such as soil types, land capability, et cetera.

The preparation of that plan does not represent an added imposition. Fundamentally, it would be seen by most as part and parcel of the efficient operation of the farm, particularly by farmers who are engaged in land care groups, as many farmers are, and for which they are to be commended. It is the sort of thing they would be doing as a matter of course. To suggest otherwise, and to suggest that it is an imposition because of the tax arrangements that are proposed in this legislation, really is going off on a great tangent.

The honourable member for Barker in the course of his speech read out a series of things that people applying for the tax concession in this area would have to comply with. He kept saying, `And, and, and'. In fact, in many of those instances it is a case of doing one of the things to get the approval, not a case of getting the whole situation as the honourable member for Barker suggested. That paints a very different picture if looked at from that point of view.

It is important to note the arrangements relating to the land care area. First of all, they represent an important part of the Budget process for 1990-91 and a continuing commitment, recognised by the Government as well as by many responsible people from the farming community, towards the protection of land so as to cope with the difficult problem of soil degradation, which is undoubtedly one of the great environmental problems that our continent faces.

If we are going to introduce a tax arrangement like this, it is clear that there has to be an effective compliance provision. To suggest otherwise is to create a circumstance which would be untenable. Eventually we would be coming back to the House saying, `Well, there has not been compliance; the system is being rorted in some way unfairly; it has lost the spirit of what the original legislation was about'. By inserting the compliance provision we are able to deal with that problem.

Bodies such as the National Farmers Federation (NFF) have raised concerns that they should be more directly involved as part of the approval process. I wish to take up some of these suggestions because both the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) and the honourable member for Barker were effectively relating concerns of that sort. It is suggested that somehow it is difficult to get appropriate bodies to approve the plan, either the State authorities or appropriate farm consultants. The NFF suggested that it should be much more integrally involved in that process.

The legislation in fact allows farm organisations to be very direct participants in that process of the approved farm plan, but it ensures that the final approval process has to be through one of the approved authorities, be it through State organisations or through the approved consultant process. The NFF can obviously be an active participant in helping to facilitate the preparation of those plans for farmers who are seeking to apply for the tax arrangement. It has a clear role there if it chooses to take it up.

It should not be seen that it would be appropriate for the National Farmers Federation to have control of the whole approval of a tax arrangement and to be able to give the ticks to whether a farm complies with the requirement. There needs to be some arm's length built into that process. I notice that the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), is here today. He was here yesterday when we heard about a conflict of interest of an organisation in the debate on the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill. We received a long dissertation from the Opposition about the need to maintain an arm's length arrangement between the board of a research body and those actually receiving research grants.

The National Farmers Federation has suggested that, far from an arm's length approach in this field, it should have carriage of the whole deal. The Government, quite rightly, I believe, has provided in this legislation the circumstances which allow the National Farmers Federation or other farm organisations to have an active role in the preparation of those sorts of plans, but at the same time it says that the final approval of that process, in order to ensure its consistency, its clarity and its uniformity, is through the obtaining of approval of the Secretary of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I think those points are important to make in response to the comments that the honourable member for Barker made in the debate.

There has also been comment expressed that somehow this legislation has the effect of removing the status of organisations and that there was a need to develop a closer sentiment towards the farm organisations. Far from its being seen in this way, I would have thought the fact that we do have provisions which give very positive and active encouragement to the protection of our rural lands is something that should be supported and encouraged across the Parliament.

Some of the provisions throughout this range of measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) are fairly complex; nevertheless, the Landcare initiative-which I am talking about now-and also the provisions in respect of mine rehabilitation sites do represent a significant effort on the part of the Government to ensure that the tax system matches the broader political agenda of a keen and concerted interest in environmental protection matters. For those reasons, I think they are important measures. They demonstrate not only the concern of Government but also the concern of so many farmers to be a very active participant in that environmental awareness and environmental protective process. That is what those arrangements are all about.

In the limited time left in the debate I would like to touch on a couple of other measures contained within this legislation. Other members have spoken in the debate about the need to ensure a greater simplicity and clarity in our tax laws as a whole. I do not think anyone would dispute that that need does exist. But it is important to say that the measures contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) do go a considerable way towards ensuring that there is a greater clarity and simplicity in the areas that are covered by the Bill.

I particularly want to refer, as did the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), to the tax havens issue. There is no doubt that one of the cancers which developed in our tax system, and one of the reasons why it fell into disrepute in the late 1970s and early 1980s, and one which we have had to correct, is the whole area of tax havens-their proliferation and the fact that they helped to undermine the basic integrity of our tax system. There was recognition on the part of the Government, and on the part of the Parliament, as demonstrated by the parliamentary committee reports, of the need to move to ensure that the haemorrhaging of the tax system that the tax havens did allow was brought to a stop.

So the measures contained in the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill, now before the House, are a further demonstration of the Government's determination to ensure that those tax havens that were the cancer and had such strong public exposure are being brought to heel, and rightly so. For those reasons, I think the legislation is particularly important. I feel it is doubly important that we get to a stage where we can say that our tax system is making its rightful contribution to the overall objective of creating a fairer society and one which all taxpayers across the spectrum, be they pay as you earn taxpayers or others, feel that the tax system is fair and that it is one which gives equality of treatment to all who participate. We are, through the various measures contained in this legislation, making an important contribution to that situation. For that reason, I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sustainable agriculture and soil conservation are two of the great issues of the 1990s. We certainly do recognise the problems of soil degradation, erosion and salinity, whether it is irrigation or dry-land salinity. I do not class soil acidification as a soil degradation problem. I see that as a farm management problem because it is coupled with approved farm practice in respect of fertiliser and subterranean clover, which lowers the Ph and can be corrected quite easily by liming, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: I also dispute some of the calculations of the cost of degradation. One of them is the calculation of nutrient lost through products sold from the farm, which takes no account of what is applied, in the sense of fertiliser, or what occurs naturally through the soil process. There is little recognition of the tremendous improvements in farm productivity; that is, in the production from our soils and the advances in our soils, through better management practices. There is no better example of this than a comparison of the Mallee region of Australia in the 1940s with the Mallee region today.

The two main Government forms of assistance and encouragement are Landcare, involving about $25m per year, which has the support of both sides of the Parliament but is basically off-farm work and, therefore, is marginal to the real action of sustainable agriculture. Regarding encouragement for on-farm practices, section 75d, which provides for immediate deductibility in the year of expenditure, is the main one. I am very pleased to have been part of a broadening of that in about 1980, together with John Carrick and Peter Nixon, which in my area alone, the irrigation area of northern Victoria, has resulted, through the use of the laser technique, in dramatically improving, at a great rate, the efficiency of irrigation and a reduction in access to the water table through run-off and better redrainage processes, which I believe will do more to reduce salinity in the Murray than many of the major works.

There is a real problem, with low incomes on farms now, that much of that work will not be done because there is not much point in having a tax deduction if there is no real cash flow. That in itself is the main reason why there will be problems with the use of this farm plan. I believe we have to look at better methods of encouragement, such as tax rebate or credit systems, if we are going to get work continuing on farms during these difficult periods.

The point of requiring a whole farm plan approved by an agency or consultant is both unnecessary and wrong, and it will have the wrong effect, because it will restrict the applicability of it. It will take time. There are only a certain number of people who can do it. It will be at a tremendous cost because it requires a soil map. If a farm with thousands of acres has to have a soil map before it can get approval for fencing, we are talking about thousands and thousands of dollars. The average farmer does not have thousands and thousands of dollars, so it will not be used. No farmer is going to spend any money on fencing if there is no value in doing it.

I believe that that fact alone will mean that he would use that fencing ability that now corrects an anomaly that was created by this Government by changes to section 75d in 1985 without the need for any compulsion or cross-compliance. The National Farmers Federation (NFF) has been concerned about it and, as recently as yesterday or the day before, in its conference in Canberra, voted against a compulsion or mandatory requirement for a whole farm plan, because if one is doing something to correct a soil degradation problem, surely it is sensible to allow the fence to be put up around it without having a whole farm plan.

A whole farm plan is not needed to know what should be done with regard to fencing to overcome or prevent some problem. The NFF and others have been recognising that this will be used very little by genuine farmers. It will not offer the encouragement that we desperately need to farmers to take these measures now, and it should not be proceeded with. I ask that a possible amendment in my name be incorporated in Hansard as a second best in trying to broaden the approval basis for approved farm agencies so that more can be done in a given time and the possibility of a monopoly situation can be reduced.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer specifically to clause 19 in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which deals with exemption of income earned in overseas employment. I say at the outset of my remarks that there appears to be nothing in the amended section 23 which requires measurement of a continuous period of service for a time commencing on or after 1 July 1990. It seems that where a continuous period of service begins before, but extends beyond, 1 July 1990, the total period of foreign service should be taken into account in determining the exempt income of foreign earnings derived in the 1990-91 income year.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is so, the foreign earnings derived in the 1989-90 income year should be fully exempt, regardless of whether they relate to a continuous period of more or less than 365 days, otherwise the taxpayer will be required to perform complex calculations to determine the proportion of foreign earnings subject to the exemption during the 1989-90 income year. I put it to the Committee that this suggestion would be in keeping with the intention of proposed amendments to simplify the section 23ag exemption.

Existing section 23ag (3) is to be deleted which provides that the foreign earnings should not be exempt in any foreign country, and if the Commissioner is satisfied that the tax has or will be paid in order to qualify for exemption. The reason for removing this section is to allow, as I understand it, foreign aid workers, whose foreign earnings are exempt overseas, to get an exemption. The omission of this requirement appears to have been made inadvertently because it is completely out of character with the stated intentions of the measure and with other sections of the proposals before the Committee.

I would like to return to land degradation provisions and tax exemptions for restoration of mining sites. I mentioned briefly in my speech in the second reading debate that the petroleum exploration industry is concerned about these provisions. Their effect is unclear and they seem not to be far-reaching enough to have some application.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to concerns expressed by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association (APEA) in connection with Division 10AB of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which involves rehabilitation and restoration of mining, quarrying and petroleum sites. The issues of concern to the Association surround off-shore platforms, definition of site for Division 10AB deductions, priority for deductions under Division 10AB, eligibility of taxpayer for Division 10AB deductions and restrictions on section 51 deductibility.

SPEECH.PARA: The APEA is concerned that the legislation, as drafted, does not adequately cover the situation of off-shore platform decommissioning activities. It is of the opinion that it therefore does not truly reflect the announcements made in the Budget statements in August of last year. Given the special circumstances relating to off-shore operations and separate announcements made by the Government, the industry has expected that the decommissioning of off-shore platforms and similar installations would be treated separately in the mine site rehabilitation legislation. That did not come to pass.

There are a number of technically feasible options for the partial or total decommissioning of platforms and other off-shore petroleum facilities which may be legally and environmentally acceptable. It may not be necessary wholly to restore a site to its pre-mining condition, this being at the discretion of the relevant government authorities.

Some of the options for consideration include removal of equipment and any hazardous material, and leaving the platform in place for some period; partial removal, leaving at least 55 metres clear water above the remaining structure in accordance with international guidelines; in situ toppling, in which the platform is collapsed on site; and removal of the whole structure either to shore or, preferably, to a deep water dumping site. All of these options would leave some structures on or in the seabed, including pipelines, sealed and abandoned wells and the piles used to secure the platform to the seabed.
There is some concern that the definition in the principal Act-section 124bb (1)-shall apply. It states:
. . . restoration of a site . . . to, or a reasonable approximation of, the pre-mining condition of the site.

It seems that there is some justification for the wording of the Bill to be amended to provide explicitly for any form of removal or decommissioning of off-shore platforms and other fixed off-shore petroleum facilities. Such explicit separation of platform de-commissioning and general rehabilitation-related activities would be in line with the Budget policy announcement on this matter.
