DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is now considering some important legislation relating to Bass Strait in particular and the introduction of a resource rent tax (RRT) on the Bass Strait oil resources. That is not something entirely new for other offshore areas, but of course it does represent a massive change in the taxation structure for Bass Strait, not only in relation to oil but also for gas and ethane. In other words, it is a major piece of legislation of considerable significance to the petroleum and mining industries.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the mining industry is well represented at Parliament House tonight. It has just launched a series of very sensible advertisements with the theme: `Mining, it is absolutely essential'. And it is, in terms of the standard of living of all Australians. I think the campaign by the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC) will put some balance into the debate necessary in the community at large over these critical decisions on mining and oil exploration, production and distribution and the cost thereof.

In respect of this piece of legislation, the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill has been delayed somewhat, given that the original announcement of this decision was in the Budget in August of last year. August of last year is a long time ago, yet the House has had to wait until May this year before seeing the legislation. In terms of the Opposition and the industry, the final draft version of the Bill has been available for exactly seven days. It was introduced into this House by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) this time last week, and now the debate has even been subjected to a guillotine. So much for legislation by careful discernment and consideration; this is a legislative process associated more with a sausage machine. It is not good for getting legislation right. This is quite complex legislation with far-reaching ramifications not only for BHP and Esso but also for many others, especially in Victoria and indeed beyond.

Bass Strait was a new beginning for Australia in relation to oil. It was the great breakthrough that has for many years contributed so much to the standard of living of all Australians and to the oil and gas supplies of Australia-oil across Australia; gas, of course, more particularly to Victoria and just beyond to southern New South Wales and elsewhere.

Considerable government revenue has been received from Bass Strait over the years. Potential investors in Australia's oil industry are watching closely to see whether they should continue to invest in oil exploration and development in Australia and to what size and extent they should continue to invest. In this legislation they are seeing a change in the rules of the game for reasons various-some proper, some that perhaps would not be regarded so happily by others-but nevertheless changes of the rules of the game whilst the field is still in production.

I think perhaps even the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) would agree that, where possible, changing of the rules of the game should be avoided. The problem is, of course, that the complexities associated with Bass Strait, and with taxation on oil more generally, go back a long way. I accept that both sides of politics have been involved in terms of the Federal Government's role in relation to Bass Strait, so I simply say that the right signals ought to be sent in terms of assurances about consistency of the rules of the game. The Minister might like to take the opportunity in his response to indicate to what extent he would anticipate even further changes with regard to Bass Strait. I hope his answer will be, by and large, nil, so that we might stabilise the circumstance of change associated with Bass Strait oil taxation.

The other factor of overall note in this legislation is the extent to which it provides an incentive to explore frontier areas of Australia so far as the RRT regime is concerned. Bass Strait is in decline. We must recognise that, no matter what happens with this taxation legislation, Bass Strait will be in decline. The rate of decline will vary, depending on decisions made by BHP and Esso and responses to this taxation regime. Of course, Australia has many other areas of prospectivity which require more research, and that is to be encouraged at every opportunity.

Those who would argue that there is an excellent level of oil exploration going on in this country might like to counterbalance that against equivalent prospective areas around the world. I am advised that many of the areas in Australia that are denoted as having good prospectivity have a negligible amount of drilling and exploration activity, following seismic work, compared to equivalent provinces elsewhere in the United States, Canada and other parts of the world. That being so, I believe that in the assessment of this legislation, and this taxation regime of RRT more generally, we must evaluate very carefully its impact on oil exploration, its encouragement of oil exploration and production, and the development of oil fields so discovered.

Turning more specifically to the legislation, RRT is to replace the current excise and royalty regime on oil and gas production from Bass Strait from, significantly, 1 July 1990. All expenditures prior to 1 July 1990 are deemed to have been deducted and the Bass Strait region is considered to be a single project-the two key joint venturers being BHP and Esso. Exploration expenditure incurred after 1 July 1990 can be transferred to other projects liable to RRT in which the company also has an interest. In other words, there will be company-wide deductibility. The compounding rate for development expenditure associated with RRT will be reduced from 15 per cent plus the long term bond rate to just 5 per cent plus the LTBR.

The change in taxation arrangements is expected to decrease Commonwealth revenue by $305m in the financial year ending 30 June 1991 and by some $450m in the next financial year ending 30 June 1992. The opposite will pertain after those two financial years, and it seems clear enough that companies will end up paying more by way of taxation than would otherwise have been the case under the excise and royalty regime. However, that has to be judged against the fact that there will be a considerable reduction in the amount of taxation required to be paid for this financial year and next financial year.

The Liberal and National parties have responsibly examined this legislation in the time available, that is, the seven days since the Treasurer stood at the dispatch box and introduced the Bill. I announce that the coalition will not be opposing the RRT legislation and notes that it is a Budget and taxation Bill which was introduced following the announcement of these measures in the Federal Budget pertaining to this financial year.

The coalition welcomes the decision of the Government to follow, in part, the path of coalition policy in broadening exploration deductibility provisions. It is a significant reform which will encourage exploration in many parts of Australia. The application of RRT to Bass Strait is a significant change. The clear advantage of RRT over the old excise and royalty system must be carefully weighed, but it is nevertheless an advantage which will allow investment decisions to be based more on the quality of the resource. This was not previously always the case, and that resulted in perhaps less than optimum production from the Bass Strait region overall and the many oil fields, some quite separate from each other, contained within Bass Strait.

A further consideration is the uniformity which will arise in degrees from having all offshore areas, except the North West Shelf, subject to RRT. In fact, all green field sites will be subject to RRT where they come within the Commonwealth jurisdiction and are offshore. Further opportunities for companies will be created because of the company-wide exploration expenditure deductibility.

The coalition, however, is not yet convinced that the reduction in the compounding rate for development expenditure-that is, the 15 per cent plus LTBR to 5 per cent plus LTBR-is an essential and positive aspect of this legislation. We are also very concerned about the application of the so-called five-year rule and its appropriateness in all the circumstances, especially from its dating processes. We therefore reserve our policy positions on these aspects whilst, in the context of this Budget legislation, agreeing not to oppose the Bill.

I will be moving at the close of my comments a second reading amendment highlighting some of these areas of concern. Also, in the Senate the coalition will seek to place the Bill before the legislative committee process which exists in that chamber. That will give a delightful opportunity to Government advisers and others to give evidence to the Senate in respect of these quite complex provisions so that they can be properly fleshed out and examined. It will also give us more time to properly assess the detailed provisions of this important legislation.

It is important that the whole package is looked at in terms of the overall benefits to each company, the industry as a whole, the Government, the community and direct users of the products flowing from Bass Strait. In many ways, RRT is a considerable improvement on the existing excise and royalty regime. This package is intended to reduce the Government's interference, which was to some extent a necessity under the existing regime. Henceforth, investment decisions should be made on the quality of the resource, with taxation and interference by government hopefully being minor considerations in the investment decision. The mining industries should be put on notice that there is a wider implication to this legislation, in that the Government will probably use this legislation as a model in its bid to apply RRT to the mineral industry. That is a very controversial question, about which I have serious reservations, and a matter which will be addressed further down the track. We are, in the context of this legislation, simply addressing the switching from excise and royalty in the Bass Strait to RRT of oil and gas and, in effect, ethane. It does not go beyond that parameter-and that is an important point which I emphasise to the House.

Let me now examine some of these issues in detail. The existing excise and royalty regime applying to Bass Strait has distorted investment decisions and hindered development, because the level of taxation is unusually high, and the structure of the taxation is, frankly, inappropriate. As a result, oil was shut off in 1988 until the settings of the excise were relaxed. At present, some 200 million to 300 million barrels of oil are locked up because of the lack of investment incentive resulting from the existing taxation regime.

All parties agree that some change to the secondary taxation regime on Bass Strait is required if-and this is the threshold question-there is to be secondary taxation on Bass Strait. Once we have resolved that there is to be secondary taxation, of course, RRT has much to commend it as a form of taxation. But it is all taxation and, by definition, impacts on the decisions of companies involved. The simple option of relaxing the excise would decrease government revenue without providing the opportunity that occurs under RRT for the companies to offset exploration expenditure elsewhere.

I have had considerable consultations with the two key companies involved-BHP and Esso-in Bass Strait. I have also consulted widely with users of the products flowing from Bass Strait and with many others, including the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association. I have to say that this whole process would have been helped, as I mentioned earlier, if in fact the RRT legislation had been introduced prior to Christmas following on the Budget announcement and had not been allowed to lie on the table of the House for a very short period of time before it became necessary to debate it and force it through the lower House and into the Senate before the cut-off resolution pertains, thus denying its passage before 30 June 1991.

Another key aspect in looking at the legislation is the commencement date-1 July 1990. I point out to the House that, if that date were changed to the date of assent of the Bill, there would be a very negative impact on the benefits flowing to BHP and Esso-the encouragement to them to properly develop and produce from Bass Strait. We have looked at this question in some detail. The coalition is of the view that, there being a generally interpreted convention which operates whereby both a decision and the commencement date of that decision are announced in the Budget, there ought to be some flexibility under that convention. The legislation therefore will operate from 1 July 1990. The coalition is not opposed to the legislation and, indeed, feels that if this legislation is to exist 1 July is the correct date, for various reasons stated both in this debate in the House and elsewhere.

Turning to the question of exploration expenditure deductibility to be company-wide, the broadening of exploration deductibility from being limited to a particular project to being company-wide-that can roll right across Australia to the various locations in which companies are involved-is a significant reform which will encourage exploration in frontier areas, since companies with revenue streams from successful ventures will be able to immediately reduce their RRT liability by offsetting exploration expenditure in any offshore area against revenue.

Industry groups, by and large, welcome this change. There will initially be a cost to government revenue, but this should be outweighed by increased revenue-helping the Government's revenue-hungry attitude-in the future as a result of the incentive given to companies with revenue streams to explore in key prospective areas and reduce their RRT liability as a result of this expenditure.

Related to this-and this argument has been touched upon elsewhere by the Minister and by the Treasurer in his second reading speech-is the reduction in the compounding rate for development expenditure. The reduction in the compounding rate for non-exploration expenditure, commonly called `development expenditure', will be reduced from 15 per cent plus LTBR to 5 per cent plus LTBR. This raises an important issue which highlights the difference between the coalition and the Government on industry development policy. The coalition believes that government should interfere as little as possible in the operations of the industry. In the case of the oil industry, apart from ensuring that environmental and safety procedures are followed, and that the community receives a reasonable return for the depletion of a community resource-important consider- ations-we believe that the industry should be able to get on with the job and make investment decisions as much as possible on commercial grounds.

Whereas the Government thinks that it is appropriate to determine the rate of return that an industry should have, and hence has decided that the oil industry might keep too much potential government revenue if the development expenditure rate were not lowered, the coalition believes that, once simple rules for conduct of the industry along the lines already mentioned are in place, it is then time for hands-off from the Government.

Industry should be allowed to develop its full potential without government interference and the threat of sovereign risk. Accordingly, we will reserve our policy on these issues to allow them to be properly debated and aired in the Senate legislative committee process. In particular, the reduction in the development rate could adversely impact on gas projects, since these are characterised by limited profitability, with long operating times and high development costs.

The same applies with the so-called five-year rule. In this case, exploration expenditure which is incurred less than five years before the issue of a production licence and which has not been written off against receipts is compounded forward each year at the rate of 15 per cent plus LTBR. However, if more than five years elapse between the expenditure and the issue of a licence, the expenditure can be compounded forward only at a lower rate, the GDP deflator, and none of the expenditure greater than five years old can be compounded at the higher rate.

This results in a considerable drop in the value of eligible expenditure incurred over five years before the issue of a licence. Conceivably, this will prevent many explorers from gaining a benefit from the wider deductibility provisions for exploration expenditure. Therefore, very careful consideration must be given to the five-year rule and the mechanism and point in time at which the five-year rule commences, because delays can occur along the path with regard to the issue of licences. Of course, this will impact very heavily with respect to the provisions in this legislation so far as the five-year rule is concerned.

I now turn to the effect of the RRT on gas. This is a critical and controversial area which, I know, is of great concern to the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), to the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Riggall) and to honourable members representing many electorates in Victoria who will participate in this debate.

I do not think that the Government fully realised, before deciding to implement this RRT decision on Bass Strait, that taxation on gas as a consequence would increase considerably. This is at a time when the economy of Victoria could not be in a worse state, under both State and Federal Labor governments. The situation is that this decision was announced in August. We had the curious situation of provisional invoices being introduced into Victoria on large and small recipients of gas. They were advised that their invoice was provisional and subject to the passage of this legislation.

One would have thought that that would have been incentive enough for the Government to set a scorching pace to bring forward this legislation and implement that Budget decision, a decision made last August. But no, we had to wait until May before we finally saw the RRT Bill. Well, pressure on the Government has mounted. It has come from many sources, not the least of which is the Victorian State Government-what is left of it-and also from many others in the community at large. That has resulted in a significant change as announced by the Treasurer in his second reading speech, namely, that Victoria will be granted $60m over two years-$30m per year-to ease the burden of the transitional effects of the increased taxation on gas.

Victoria will receive this additional special grant, but this is not referred to in the legislation; and the first of many concerns I have about this is an absolute assurance that in fact the Victoria State Treasury, in its hard-pressed period of great grief, will spend the $30m on that to which it has been allocated by the Federal Government, namely, easing the transitional effects of the impact of RRT on gas. I invite the Minister to consider carefully this question of the $60m-$30m to be provided in this financial year ending on 30 June 1991 and $30m next year-and to say in his response what assurances he has been given by the Victorian State Government that these two lots of $30m will in fact be used for the purpose of easing the impact on hard-pressed gas users in the hard-pressed Victorian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Check with the Opposition too!

—That is a good point, because the Victorian State Government has little life left in it. There will be a change of government in Victoria shortly and the Minister might like to check with both Government and Opposition in the Victorian State Parliament, because this Federal Parliament has been advised of a decision to spend some $60m for a specific purpose. We want some assurance, some guarantee, that it will actually be used for that purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that further relief with respect to this complex matter may yet be afforded by decisions of the Victorian State Government itself. The Victorian Minister for Manufacturing and Industry Development, David White, has indicated that `there should be no gas charge increase as a result of the RRT legislation'. That is significant. That must mean that he is going to tap the massive public authority contribution of some $300m which exists each year, which is raked off Bass Strait, and which will have to be used because the real impact of RRT on gas has been estimated at anywhere between $50m and $80m per year, not just the $30m to which the Government has owned up. Indeed, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy itself found a figure of $50m; the Victorian Gas and Fuel Corporation suggested $70m. There is a range of estimates. It seems to be a vague figure to be accurately determined, but certainly it is something more than $30m.

There must be a contribution from the Victorian Government in respect of this if hard-pressed gas users in Victoria are to get a fair go in the circumstances of the consideration of this legislation. I might add that this aspect will also be raised in the Senate legislative committee process so that we can obtain more information, especially with regard to assurances as to the use of the two lots of $30m.

Finally, in terms of detailed aspects, ethane is also picked up by this legislation. It is now clear that the $30m annual grant will not apply to ethane and that the users of ethane are in a delicate position, given the recession. I think their circumstance is legitimate for consideration in the discussions of this legislation. I invite the Minister to respond with regard to the circumstances of the key users of ethane. There are not many in Victoria, but they too--

TALK.START.PARA: —There are high profit levels on ethane.
—The Minister refers to high profit levels--
—Extraordinary high levels of profit on ethane, and the fact that the company might, in looking at the overall package, take into account the wider national interests in that context.

—The Minister's interjection is noted. It is of interest, but he cannot afford to take a Pontius Pilate approach completely. Let him go down and sort out that little tangle, because he has some responsibility as the supporter of this legislation, as the relevant Government Minister handling it in detail, to sort it out and see that perhaps the right thing is done along the lines that he might indicate. I challenge the Minister not to take a Pontius Pilate role. He has just made a very significant statement on the record, saying that it is perhaps within the profit margins of the company involved to make the necessary adjustments direct. Of course, there is no guarantee in this legislation that that will happen. So, that is up in the air; yet another aspect of this complex legislation is up in the air.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition does not oppose this legislation overall. We do reserve our own separate policy positions, particularly with regard to the changes to 15 per cent plus LTBR, the reduction down to 5 per cent plus LTBR, and the changes relating specifically to the five-year dimension, on which we seek further information; each will be examined in more detail in committee.

We want to see in place in this country more consistent rules. If there is going to be secondary taxation, it should be at the lowest possible level so that there will be genuine encouragement for oil exploration and production in Australia. We have been lucky, and a lot of that luck has flowed from the good work which has been done, especially in Bass Strait. We do not want to stretch our luck and cause a collapse in the viability of the oil industry, which makes such a great contribution to the standard of living of all Australians, especially where oil is being found within Australia and around the offshore area. It is in that context that I move:
That all the words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House calls on the Government to review the issues of reducing the compounding rate for augmented bond rate general expenditure, and the application of the socalled `five year' rule for calculating the amount of eligible expenditure carried forward from previous years, noting-
(a) the possibility of excessive taxation unduly influencing commercial decisions and impeding the natural development of the oil industry; and
(b) the potential loss of eligible deductions arising from the `five year' rule for the oil and gas exploration industry;

caused by the Government's failure to give appropriate consideration to the issue of reducing the compounding rate for augmented bond rate general expenditure, and the application of the `five year' rule.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member representing an electorate in the State of Victoria, I rise tonight to congratulate the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) and the Government on creating with this Bill-the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill-massive confusion in the minds of the public, in the minds of honourable members of this House, in the minds of the Victorian Government, in the minds of industry and commerce, and in the minds of gas users in the bankrupt State of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is complex. It was introduced in August 1990 along with the Budget and, with taxation implications, it was backdated to 1 July 1990. It is just this week-in May 1991-being debated in Parliament, and under the guillotine. The Government and the Minister responsible for the legislation, the Minister for Resources, should really be ashamed to bring such complex taxation legislation which discriminates against one State of the Commonwealth into this place, without proper consultation and a proper period for debate, many months after announcing in the Budget that the legislation would proceed. Shame, Minister!

There are serious concerns in Victoria among many Victorian manufacturers that there will be a massive price-cost increase on natural gas as a result of this legislation. I have no major concerns with the concept of the resource rent tax because the concept itself will allow us many more useful years and much more production from our oil and gas field in Bass Strait. For that reason, generally I support the concept and the thrust of the legislation--

TALK.START.PARA: —You had me confused there for a moment.

—I do not want to confuse the Minister, but I maintain that there are a number of conflicting ideals inherent in the legislation. One of the conflicts is that the legislation encompasses Bass Strait only, a single offshore oilfield and gas field. It does not apply to gas fields or oilfields onshore within Australia, and it does not apply to the gas field in the North West Shelf. The Victorian economy, as all of us in this place know, is in a state of disaster. Unemployment in Victoria has risen more rapidly than any other State in our nation. The lag time in trying to find out the numbers of unemployed, the numbers of those devastated by this Government's policy and the recession that we `had to have' is very long and those figures are very difficult to come by, but in my electorate of La Trobe, at the Commonwealth Employment Service office next door to my office, the figures show that last month the level of unemployment was four times what it was two years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Businesses within my electorate are disintegrating left, right and centre. Bankruptcies occur regularly. Black and Decker (Australasia) Pty Ltd, which is just down the road, gave up finally as a Victorian and Australian manufacturer of produced hardware goods. It has taken its operation offshore. It is but one of many companies in Victoria-the heart of the manufacturing industry of our country -which are disappearing from Australia. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has the gall to come into this place and say what a terrific job he has done of restructuring the economy and how, with low inflation, we are now going to recover from this recession with great strength and vigour. I say to the Treasurer: the infrastructure has gone, and it is disappearing even more rapidly today in Victoria, and in my electorate.

I note for honourable members' attention the fact that we have a terrible situation in Victoria in terms of the drop in apprenticeship intake. The national apprenticeship intake was down by nearly 40 per cent in the first three months of this year according to the figures released yesterday by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, and as reported in this morning's Age. The figures, from the Vocational Education, Employment Training Advisory Committee, show that Victoria was hit hardest, recording a 51 per cent drop.

A submission to me recently by the Victorian Gas Users Association and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures proposed that there should be no cost impact on Victorian manufacturers from the proposed resource rent tax (RRT). There are contradictory opinions on how the RRT will be applied, whom it will affect and its cost impact. I note that those questions are not resolved by this legislation in the House. Major consequences that they see with the legislation are as follows: firstly, the resource rent tax affecting all Victorians through higher prices for goods; secondly, an increase in the price of gas for the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria industrial gas contract consumers of up to as much as 20 per cent, which now may be-and I note may be-negated to some degree by the offer of the $30m per year for two years. The cost of ethane purchased directly from the producers is also like to increase significantly.

Other consequences are: thirdly, higher industrial gas prices seriously disadvantaging Victorian manufacturers against interstate and overseas goods and reducing the potential to export goods; fourthly, industrial gas prices of the extent foreseen leading to reduced employment levels, cutbacks in production and delays in investment in additional production capacity; fifthly, overseas manufacturers who use North West Shelf gas and export goods to Australia having a competitive benefit not available to Victorian manufacturers; sixthly, retrospective costs not being recovered-this retrospectivity is unacceptable; lastly, resource rent tax introducing a major policy conflict with environmental goals.

The Victorian Minister for Manufacturing and Industrial Development, Mr White, told the thirty-first annual conference of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association in Melbourne that the State had been lobbying hard against the resource rent tax on gas and expected a resolution. He said that the State was totally opposed to the tax imposed in the August Budget last year because of the additional costs faced by Victoria's Gas and Fuel Corporation and commercial, industrial and domestic users. He said that the tax on gas was inequitable, that it did not apply to the North West Shelf, et cetera. I would expect the Minister for Resources to get a commitment from Minister White that the $30m will go to the Gas and Fuel Corporation and will not go into government coffers.

In my electorate there is Australia's largest manufacturer of ceramic tiles, with a turnover of approximately $25m. It has gas costs of $1.5m. The name of the company is Johnson Tiles Pty Ltd. I will read a brief portion of a letter that I received from that company on 12 October 1990.
Dear Sir . . . My Company is overseas owned, employs approximately 400 people and is Australia's largest manufacturer of ceramic wall and floor tiles with plants at Bayswater and Croydon in Victoria.

We have recently been informed by the Gas &Fuel Corporation of Victoria to expect increases in gas tariffs following the promulgation of legislation relating to the above matter. We further understand that the proposed tax initially only affects Victoria and being large consumers of natural gas we are most concerned.
The ceramic tile market is dominated by imports and you are, of course, well aware of the downturn in the building industry affecting all markets for building products nationally-
and specifically in Victoria-

At a time when we are having to cope with a high level of imports, a loss of consumer confidence, a collapse in the building industry and ongoing increases in all Government charges, we surely wonder whether there is any end to the difficulties being imposed on businesses by Governments in their thirst for revenue.
In a letter to Mr Collingwood of Johnson Tiles dated 3 October 1990, among other things, the Gas and Fuel Corporation said:

Because the new legislation may not be proclaimed until April 1991, it is not yet possible to assess the extent of any tax or its effect on the Producers, the Corporation or you our customer. We feel an obligation however to advise you of this situation and of the possibility that your tariff may have to be increased to offset . . . costs imposed on the Corporation by this Federal action.
The next paragraph-and this is the hooker-reads:

Any such increase will be from 1 July 1990, and all accounts and payments after that date are hence provisional only, and the Corporation reserves the right to readjust invoices or bill separately to take account of any effects of the Resource Rent Tax as from 1 July 1990.
I urge the Minister to consult carefully with the Victorian Government to make sure that the $60m is applied properly and that we receive no increase in gas price, which would bankrupt Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support my colleague the honourable member for Latrobe (Mr Charles) in his representations. I am pleased that the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) is at the table in discussions on the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Its impact on Victoria will be quite dramatic, particularly on the large number of natural gas consumers in that State. I want to make some comments about the Hon. David White, the Minister for Industry and Economic Planning in the Victorian Government, who made a statement in the Legislative Council on 29 November 1990 regarding a resource rent tax and the impact that it would have on Victorian gas consumers. He said:

If the Federal government introduces a resource rent tax in the autumn session of 1991 it will have the impact of increasing costs in real terms by eight per cent for large industrial consumers and five per cent for domestic consumers. It will also have the impact of increasing costs by between 1 and 2 per cent for State Electricity Commission consumers because of the purchase of natural gas by the SEC.We have pointed out to the Federal government in the strongest possible terms that we are opposed to the application of a resource rent tax on natural gas in Bass Strait particularly when there is an exemption for natural gas from the North West Shelf and from the Cooper Basin. We also pointed that out to Senator Cook, who gave an assurance of exemption to Victoria when he was the responsible Minister.

We make it clear that the Federal government did not consult the Victorian government prior to its incorporating the proposal in the Federal Budget. We do not oppose the application of a resource rent tax to oil in Bass Strait, nor does BHP. But we are opposed to the application of the tax on natural gas; we believe it would be inappropriate because it would undermine the competitiveness of our industry. We also do not believe it is appropriate for the Federal Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, to suggest that Gas and Fuel Corporation losses need not be passed on because we can lower the public authority contribution.
It is quite obvious that the Minister has not been to Victoria lately because if he had, he would know how dramatic the economic situation is there. The speech continues as follows:
In that case the application of the resource rent tax would mean that the Commonwealth would introduce the tax at the expense of a Victorian tax base.

I want to give the House a practical example of the impact of the retrospectivity of this legislation. Let us take a brick manufacturer in Victoria, who would be a large gas user. Bricks made and sold at any time between 1 July 1990 and now, 16 May 1991, would attract this resource rent tax. The gas has already been consumed at a total cost of perhaps between $50,000 and $100,000. The bricks have been sold to a builder at a firm quoted price and then used in the construction of a home for a young couple, also at a firm quoted price. The young couple obtained their home loan and entered into an agreement to purchase the completed home at a fixed final price. The Gas and Fuel Corporation in Victoria would then move to recover the additional cost of the gas. Who would it recover it from-the manufacturer of the bricks, the builder or the young couple?

The Federal Government has indicated that it will make $30m available for two years to offset the impact this will have. It is my view that this amount would be inadequate, and I have had it on authority from other people within the industry that $30m for Victoria would be inadequate. I seriously doubt that it would be enough for the Gas and Fuel Corporation. Gas and Fuel would then attempt to recover the additional costs from either the manufacturer or some other source. That would place the brick manufacturer in an extremely difficult position, because he would have to bear the full cost of the gas that he had consumed at any time from 1 July 1990 until the Gas and Fuel Corporation decided to recover that money.

I do not think that I need to impress upon the House just what an impact this would have on the economy of Victoria. There are many thousands of manufacturers, businesses and domestic gas users throughout Victoria. If this were to be imposed as an additional cost on them it would have further impact and would drive Victoria further into the economic mire that has already been created by the Cain-Kirner governments in Victoria, and added to by the Hawke-Keating policies at the Federal level.

I want to impress upon the Minister just how serious this situation is for Victoria, and I ask him to ensure that this resource rent tax is not passed on to the Victorian gas consumers. Manufacturing in Victoria is experiencing an extremely hard time at the moment and if this charge were passed on to manufacturers, it would have a dramatic impact on the Victorian manufacturing base. I have already had representations from a number of manufacturers, including a brick manufacturer, and from the Australian Chamber of Manufacturers acting on behalf of the whole manufacturing sector in Victoria. I ask the Minister to ensure that Victorian gas consumers are not affected by this legislation.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill is to give legislative effect to the package of measures associated with the petroleum resource rent tax announced by the Government in the 1990-91 Budget. The Bill will extend the resource rent tax to Bass Strait from 1 July 1990, replacing the existing complex and arbitrary excise royalty scheme. The aim of the legislation is to provide both an equitable return to the community from the production of petroleum products and to encourage producers to efficiently drain Bass Strait of its reserves.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation builds on the recurring motifs of this Government, emphasising greater economic efficiency and international competitiveness. The natural resources of any economy are amongst its most fundamental assets. Their development is a prime generator of economic growth. The wealth derived from such activity is a long-established source of taxation revenue.

Tax revenues from resource sector related activities in most countries, including Australia, are derived from levies on economic activity in the form of direct taxes on corporate and individual incomes and indirect product taxes on the sale of goods and services to final consumers-commonly termed primary taxation-and from charges in the form of taxes and royalties on production of the resource. Resource rents and royalty regimes are levied in addition to income tax and should be viewed as the price paid to government for the grant of exclusive rights to extract natural resources owned by all Australians. This Bill will explicitly tie the price paid for this exclusive use of our resources to the producer's capacity to pay.

The Bill also introduces a generous concession for exploration activities, permitting the deduction of exploration expenditure incurred after 1 July 1990 in respect of all offshore operations subject to the resource rent tax, rather than, as at present, only those projects undertaken by a company in the relevant permit area. Such a write-off is similar to the tax regime allowed in the United Kingdom North Sea projects. Furthermore, the new regime will tax by reference to achieved profits rather than production levels and is therefore responsive to market influences, prices and costs.

The legislation is the product of a broad-ranging examination of a number of specific matters: the principles of resource taxation as they apply to petroleum; a consideration of the impact of varying structures and levels of resource taxation on the economy; and a review of the existing taxation arrangements regarding resource taxation. This resulted in the development of options for the future taxation of petroleum resources.

This process, initiated in May 1989, included the consideration of many submissions received from interested parties, including industry and State governments. As well, extensive modelling was carried out by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to determine the financial implications of the various petroleum taxation options that were on the table. The catalyst for this review and the resulting legislation was the phenomenon of falling oil production in Bass Strait-by far the most important area of oil exploration in Australia to date-and a likely overall decline in oil production in the years to 2000 and beyond if no new large petroleum discoveries were made and developed.

The review of petroleum production taxation has also been conducted against a background of government policy having as its broad objective rational resource allocation and growth. In keeping with general taxation principles, the resource rent regime before the House today will increase economic efficiencies, minimise the distortion of commercial decisions, enhance equity between the community and resource developers, secure the reliability of reserves derived from resource changes and, finally, be administratively simple.

Economic rent is defined as the surplus revenue over all costs incurred in the extraction of a natural resource, including a return on capital that recognises the risks taken. The current excise and royalties regime in place in Bass Strait places considerable restraints on obtaining economic efficiency. The major failings of the present system are the disincentives to maximise recovery from existing oil fields and the lack of flexibility at low oil prices.

The legislation before the House today will send an important signal to petroleum producers. Smaller fields will again become viable and a new era of exploration and resource development will begin. The Government's decision to change the resource rent tax legislation, most fundamentally to allow oil companies to deduct exploration expenditure on a company group basis, will alter the economic viability of many of the smaller oil and gas prospects in Australia. It will ignite a new boom in oil exploration by Australian companies.

The progress made on the issue of resource rent tax has come to be seen as a test of the seriousness of the Government's desire to renew Australia's dwindling oil reserves. Once the new regime contained in the legislation is in place, the oil exploration and production industries will be able to get on with the next phase of development in Bass Strait. The Government believes that these changes will act as a catalyst to stimulate the search for oil-a search that could result in as much as two billion barrels of oil during the 1990s.

The new fields that will become viable when the resource rent tax changes are introduced will include West Tuna, which is estimated to contain about 42 million barrels of oil and will cost about $500m to develop; East Bream, which will produce perhaps 11 million barrels of oil and cost $150m; Tarrum, which has 10 million barrels of oil and will cost $250m; and Yellowtail, which has less than six million barrels and will cost $100m to develop.

Quite obviously, the costs incurred and borne by oil companies in exploring the oilfields of Australia are considerable. Those costs, however, will reap rewards for Australia. Australia again will have certainty in the knowledge that oil supplies will be available for all Australians. The current disincentive to explore frontier areas, therefore, will be removed, leading to the further potential for enhanced and economically viable petroleum self-sufficiency.

These changes to the resource rent tax have an estimated cost to revenue of some $305m in 1990-91 and $450m in 1991-92. A revenue positive outcome is expected in 1992-93 and beyond. However, the Government believes that this is a legitimate trade-off for greater efficiency and certitude which these taxation arrangements provide.

The oil and gas industry is vital to this country. Australia-wide it directly employs over 9,500 people, contributes over $7 billion to our income through exports and import replacement each year, and provides government revenue of $1.5 billion, which is channelled into the provision of social services and other Commonwealth Government services to all the community. Clearly, the oil industry has an important place in the Australian economy. The measures before the House today will encourage efficient resource allocation and will increase the industry's international competitiveness, thereby enabling it to maintain its important role in the Australian economy. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to talk about the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill. It is interesting that not one member of the Government from Victoria chose to speak on it. I can understand why when we look seriously at this Bill. Superficially, it looks quite a nice Bill. In the second reading speech, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) states that this is a form of taxation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . which has greater regard to the producers' capacity to pay.
I think that is a fair and reasonable principle. He then goes on to say:
The resource rent tax is based on achieved profits rather than production levels and is, therefore, sensitive to changes in prices . . .

Once again, people would find that difficult to argue with until they have a look at the impact of the tax on the State of Victoria and its impact in an Australian context. The Treasurer goes on to say:
It is important, therefore, that the elements of the resource rent taxation regime be held constant in future years when the new RRT arrangement starts to recoup revenues for the nation.

Put more bluntly, the producers will have secured a windfall benefit in these early years of the new arrangement and will not be entitled to change of arrangements when the RRT starts to bite in subsequent years.

What that means in quite simple terms is that producers will be given a windfall benefit so they can reinvest in the oil industry somewhere else in Australia-not necessarily in Bass Strait and certainly not necessarily in Victoria. The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) recognises this. The Treasurer also says in the second reading speech:
. . . with possibly disruptive consequences for industry and domestic consumers.
I think that should be repeated:
. . . with the possibility of disruptive consequences . . .
He is talking about Victorian industry here:

The Government has, therefore, decided to provide the Victorian Government with a special grant of $30m for each of the first two years of application of resource rent tax, to minimise any transitional pressures on gas prices.

Put in simple terms, the Government will subsidise the incompetent incumbent Government in Victoria for this current financial year and the next financial year when it knows full well there will be an election in Victoria and the coalition parties in Victoria will have to wear the full impact in their Budget of this draconian piece of legislation.

If honourable members do not think it is a draconian piece of legislation, let me give an example of what will happen to one of our major producers of paper in my electorate. The Australian Paper Manufacturers (APM) Ltd Maryvale mill currently uses $2m worth of gas per month. It has estimated that under the new regime, in this mill alone, there will be an extra cost of some $5m. Let us put it in other terms. This $5m is worth 5,000 truck loads of pulp delivered to the factory.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a lot of jobs.

—It is worth a tremendous number of jobs, as the honourable member for Gippsland said. In actual fact, it has been estimated that it will be the cost, including overheads, of employing 100 people for 12 months.
—But do you support the legislation?

—The company goes one step further, and the Minister for Resources, who is at the table, should listen to this, and listen very carefully. The company also goes on to say that this legislation, which is not Australia-wide, does not apply to the North West Shelf. The company points out the very salient fact-and I think the Minister should take this in-of the impact on Australian industry, and Victorian industry particularly. It goes on to say that in the North West Shelf the gas is transhipped to Japan and that people there will not suffer a resource rent tax. Why? Because they have long term contracts which make that area marginal, and to put a tax on the oilfield in the North West Shelf might interfere with the viability of the gas field.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in Victoria, because there are not long term contracts, the Government is able to transfer the tax arrangement directly onto the Victorian producers. We go down the step of finding that the very people in Japan who are producing paper and who are in competition with the Maryvale mill do not have to pay the resource rent tax when our own producers do. It is a disincentive for exports.

Let us go a little bit further. I think this is well worth recording and I am sure the Minister will be very interested. The mill at Maryvale provides approximately 35,000 tonnes of corrugated medium paper to mainland China and is selling in what is a very competitive market at absolute minimum costs. The projected gas increases would turn this large contract for a marginal profitable undertaking to a loss. Associated with this export is the employment of approximately 50 people at Maryvale, together with 35 in the forest; 15 in transport, shipping and loading; and 20 in waste collection. One unique characteristic of this export is that it contains 15,000 tonnes of old newspaper which has been recycled and is being shipped across.

Two things are put in jeopardy there. One is an export market worth many thousands of dollars. The second thing is a recycling industry. This Government says it is very interested in recycling paper but, when we look at it seriously, when it comes to incentives for people to export recycled products, the Government imposes a resource rent tax, which is totally unfair to Victoria.

Let us look at the resource rent tax and its estimated value of $60m. How did the Government come to this figure? The Minister has not in any of his speeches said how people got to the figure of $60m. We do not know. We know that the Victorian Minister in his press releases has stated that the figure would be $80m, not $60m. Other estimates have put the figure as high as $90m. That is the estimated disadvantage for Victoria over the next two years.

The truth of the matter is that that disadvantage will go on year after year and will put the industries of Victoria, which have enjoyed the advantages of the natural resources of their State, at a disadvantage in comparison with the rest of the world. The Minister may be interested to note that the gas prices of Victoria are not exceptionally cheap; in fact, they are very much in line with the gas prices of New South Wales.

Considering that the debate has a guillotine on it, I just want to reiterate the basic points. They are very simple and straightforward. This resource rent tax Bill is a Budget Bill, and for that reason the Opposition and I take leadership from the Minister for Resources and the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer), who says we will not be opposing it. Therefore I support it because it is a Budget Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a Traralgon boy and he should know better.
—He should know better than that; I believe his father used to work at APM. Had he worked there today, he might have found his job would be very much in jeopardy.
—Not with my resource security legislation, it wouldn't.

—The Minister's resource security legislation has holes that a bulldozer could drive through. He should know that the resources in Victoria in integrated harvesting are sawlog driven and have nothing to do with the pulp and paper industry. He knows that, unless he overcomes that simple point, the Bill that he is proposing is a nonsense. I thank the Minister for that interjection.
—He backed away from it--
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will cease interjecting or he will not be around here to speak next.

—There is a guillotine, so I will conclude my remarks. This Bill is very much anti-Victorian; it will have an impact of some $30m to $50m a year against Victorian industry; and it will favour Japanese industry directly in competition with that in Victoria. It also has the nasty political sting that when the current Victorian Government loses government, as it surely will at the next election, the current Opposition will have to make up this money in the Budget. For that reason, I urge the Minister when he brings in this legislation to come to some agreement with Victoria so that it is compensated for its massive loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given Australia's continuing dependence on the now declining Gippsland Basin, it is imperative that the taxation regime applying to the two joint venturers-Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Esso, which have developed the province-be recast, firstly, to ensure the maximum practical production of remaining reserves from Bass Strait; secondly, to provide the appropriate flow of resources for maintaining a high level of exploration, particularly in light of Australia's very poorly explored offshore regions; and, thirdly, to underwrite Australia's strategic energy security. Honourable members will agree that this final concern ought to be extremely significant, given the precarious position of import dependent countries during recent events in the Gulf.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not an exercise in providing artificial incentives which have a distortionary effect on the economy or add to the cost borne by other industries. The joint venturers have long been subject to a rigid secondary taxation regime which has failed to provide adequate responsiveness to changing oil prices and the high risk/high investment character of the industry. This has long been an unstated or, at best, a poorly understood issue. The incidence of secondary taxation itself is largely neglected in discussions of the financial status of the oil industry.

This is not an exercise in providing artificial incentives which may prop up inefficient players. Instead, I believe that the object of the legislation before the House ought to be to remove, as far as possible, any distortionary influences caused by the taxation system. The joint venturers engage in a very high risk industry and nobody should underestimate the high risk nature of exploration investment in the industry, nor the massive costs associated with the development of wells.

In Australia it costs $6m to drill an average depth offshore oilwell. To sink a wildcat well-that is, a well sunk into untested rock-the cost can, in some offshore exploration areas to Australia's north-west, reach in excess of $10m. This compares to average costs of about $1.5m per well in the United States of America. Moreover, it is usually the case that construction costs for production platforms require expenditures in the order of $300m. Even the comparatively modest Harriet offshore field in Western Australian waters cost some $270m to develop. All up, the petroleum industry committed some 40 per cent of its available capital expenditure to exploration in the year 1987-88, compared with 15 per cent for the mineral sector as a whole.

These are staggering investments, and any taxation regime applied to the industry must pay due respect to the need to guarantee the revenue flows which allow for continued reinvestment and exploration. There is great optimism in the industry that Australia's offshore regions could conceivably yield ongoing commercially viable reserves which will retain our nation's necessary self-sufficiency in crude oil for decades to come.

The latest seismic mapping of Australia's offshore geological formations has overturned a great many of the earlier presuppositions concerning our oil prospectivity. But if the petroleum exploration production industry is to capitalise on this enhanced understanding of offshore prospectivity, it must be able to respond to the inherent risk factors in a rational manner. The structure of the taxation regime applying to the industry, the matter which is currently before the House, is therefore of enormous significance.

But there is more to this than simply a basically sectorial taxation policy. Government policy must also ensure that the surrounding cost environment is conducive to investment. If well costs in Australia are not competitive with those elsewhere in the world, it is not just because of the difficulties with operating in our offshore marine environment; it is also because of the surrounding domestic cost structures.

The oil industry is no different in these respects from any other industry. Its investment strategies are severely compromised with the skewed nature of resource allocations in this country. Indeed, the nature of its offshore operations, including its onshore processing and distribution networks, is acutely sensitive to labour market and waterfront concerns as well as a host of other input costs. Providing a balanced and rational economic environment for the industry is therefore critical-not just for its own commercial viability, but for the energy security of the nation.

On current supply and demand scenarios, Australia is in for a rough time in respect of meeting its crude oil needs in the coming decades. Most immediately, we face a sharp decline in production in the coming two or three years. Though the discoveries off north-west Australia will boost Australia's self-sufficiency in the latter half of the decade, they will not come on stream quickly enough to cover the supply shortfalls caused by the declining Bass Strait reserves. By about 1994 Australia's crude oil self-sufficiency is predicted to fall from the current 88 per cent to 60 per cent; that is, local production will fall by 25 per cent.

While many factors determine the extent to which these predictions will be realised, Australia nevertheless requires a strategic vision, a long term perspective, in respect of its energy needs. The investment context and the long lead times through initial discovery, development and production phases necessitate such a policy response.

The reality of the challenge before the oil industry to retain even modest levels of self-sufficiency, as I have just discussed, is daunting. The Government's own Bureau of Mineral Resources, BMR, and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, ABARE, have indicated that the Government expects the industry to come up with some 560 million barrels of hitherto undiscovered oil by the year 2005. In order to have access to production of this magnitude by this time, the industry will have to find and develop a field or fields carrying two billion barrels. This in turn will require, in current terms, expenditure of about $20 billion to $26 billion on exploration and development over the course of the decade.

Again, the extent to which Australia can tap these currently undiscovered reserves and bring into production those reserves in Bass Strait which are currently considered by the industry to be uncommercial will rely to an important degree on the appropriateness of the taxation regime applied to the industry. While barrel prices and other factors will remain an important determinant of exploration incentive, taxation is not without its significance. Indeed, it can be said to be fundamental. It, like the other cost structures which compromise investment, requires a serious reappraisal by way of the legislation currently before the House.

While I accept the principle that companies have an obligation to make a community return on the resources they develop, there is an ill-defined line between that principle and the exploitation of an industry by government for revenue raising concerns. Moreover, there is a good deal of understandable dispute as to how the principle of community return itself is defined. Does a taxation system which impedes the capacity of an industry to reinvest and further develop its capabilities justify itself on the basis of the immediate returns it makes to Consolidated Revenue? It is the task of good government to define such issues and to articulate the nature of the concept of return, especially in a strategic investment sense.

Given that we are operating under a guillotine which limits all speakers to only a handful of minutes, regrettably I will draw my remarks to a close. However, I cannot allow the opportunity to pass without registering my strongest protest that the debate on this very significant legislation, the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill, is being curtailed. This Bill is of such tremendous economic and, eventually, social importance to the nation that it warrants proper examination. It is something of a great tragedy for the processes of the Parliament and for proper examination of crucial legislation that members are so restricted. The measures in the Bill need to be addressed in detail, particularly as this admittedly complex legislation was hurriedly introduced into the House. Accordingly, the Opposition will seek to have the matter properly reviewed by a relevant committee in the other House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a few things that I wish to add. I commend the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) for his demonstrable concern about the changes included in this Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill. As most people would know, within the honourable member for Gippsland's electorate lies that enormous Bass Strait oilfield. That has been a godsend and yet a matter of the concern. Because of the nature and character of the field, it has attracted a great deal of attention.

SPEECH.PARA: The oil and gas that has flowed from there has opened up enormous alternative energy resources for Australia, yet the problem has been that there were difficulties in ensuring maximum extraction from the oilwells there. There have been difficulties in the nature of the seas and the problems in trying to ensure that the product is going to be sufficient to maintain the present level of self-sufficiency in Australia.

The points that I wanted to make are threefold. I am well aware of the guillotine and the constraints thereupon. The first is that I am delighted to see that the Government has accepted the amendment that I moved as shadow Minister in the days gone by suggesting that exploration expenditure should be deductible for the purposes of resource rent tax against the RRT liability of any of the projects held by the individual licensee.

At the time the original petroleum resource rent legislation was introduced I thought it was nonsense to have it restricted as it was in the first package. It seemed to me that the character and nature of our need for self-sufficiency were too great for us to indulge in the luxury of trying to restrain deductibility peculiarly to any particular field or any particular licensed area, as was the original program. For that reason I moved that amendment, and I am delighted to see that the Government, although belatedly, has accepted it.

Secondly, I want to echo in part the concerns expressed in more general than detailed form by the honourable member for Gippsland. I am not convinced, in spite of the Robertson report, to which the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), referred in a debate on the related packaging yesterday, that there is not going to be an adequate measure of successful exploration to ensure an availability of oil for Australia in the future. It is a subject which many have debated in the past.

I can recall that John Carrick, who was formerly the Minister for Resources, on many occasions in Cabinet and in the House debated this subject and expressed his concern that the figures did not add up. I know we have had various projections which have waxed and waned. There has been a belief that perhaps we are better off now than we were. I do not believe that. I think the nature and character of the demand for petroleum products set aside all the exigencies of the Gulf and the problems that flowed from it.

Our concern in Australia has to be with self-sufficiency. We are not sufficiently self-sufficient and I am very concerned that the onshore-offshore program has not been adequate. The RRT legislation, as I commented yesterday, is a secondary tax which imposes a burden on exploration, which I doubt is justifiable. I do not believe that supplementary taxes applicable to the development of our resources in the long term produce the returns that many believe. I cannot see that in Australia we are going to be able to develop and maintain this country while we impose an undue burden of taxation.

That leads me to the third point that I want to make. I represent producers and productive industries in Australia. The burden they bear in the price they pay for fuel, in all their transport costs, certainly is significantly affected by the failure of the Government to pursue adequately infrastructure reform. They are affected also by the costs of fuel, by the input costs of the energy that they use on their farms, in their factories and in their mines.

This legislation is supposed in some sense to be an amendment. The Minister said in the closing part of his second reading speech that the changes will have an estimated cost to revenue of $305m in 1991 and $450m in 1991-92. He continued on to point out that the price is essentially one which in future years, when the new RRT arrangement starts, will recoup revenue for the nation. My concern is that the Government has not been sufficiently predictable in the introduction of this package; that it is a secondary tax; and that producers and those who depend on energy resources to produce the wealth on which this country more and more depends are finding it harder to survive.

I have fundamental concerns about the manner and form of this legislation and, therefore, support the amendment that has been seconded by the honourable member for Gippsland, and I support the inquiry which he has indicated will take place in the other House. I believe the Government needs to look at not only the producers, nor just the immediate package, but the consumers as well. The consumers right throughout Australia at this stage are going broke, and the more we impose costs on them, the less likely they are to recover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might begin by commenting on some of the comments by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). There is an old adage that success has many fathers, failure is an orphan. There are many people who are now claiming either authorship of or significant involvement in the package that was referred to in the last Budget session-I know that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) will recall this vividly-by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association as representing the `decisive moment' in the Australian offshore oil and gas exploration industry. I think it is fair to say that the Opposition has been charitable enough to acknowledge the import of these changes taken together as a package and the potential impact on this important industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) indicated that the package would have an important positive effect in terms of exploration in frontier areas. I am absolutely convinced that that is the case. I think there is a clear bipartisan sentiment which cuts through all the political verbiage that we have heard and which, in the nature of this game, is understandable. But right through the contributions both by the Government and by the Opposition members it is clear that in any substantive sense this package is acknowledged for what it is; that is, a major reform by any measure.

I suppose that one test of the Government's commitment is revenue forgone. This package will cost the Commonwealth Government directly, by way of revenue forgone, some $775m over a two-year period. Then there is the additional $60m, which has been referred to earlier, by way of a facilitating package to the Victorian Government. I have heard also in earlier comments that the Victorian Government was not consulted. The matter now is accepted by the Victorian Government. In my view, there was plenty of opportunity for the Victorian Government to contribute to the review. It did just that. As an aside I might say that I think one of the problems in this country is that people want to consult a little too much, and that is not something that commends itself to me personally. I think that if we make our minds up on something, we should bat on with it and get much-needed changes in.

A whole raft of issues was raised by Opposition members. There are a couple in particular that I should refer to. The Leader of the National Party-obviously in specific reference to the amendment that he put, which I flag my opposition to-related to--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought we convinced you.
—The Leader of the National Party is a powerful advocate for his cause. On this occasion I am afraid I was not convinced.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government fully considered appropriate compounding rates for the augmented bond rate structures prior to the 1990 Budget. The underlying rationale for this package is the efficiency of the taxation arrangements and the obvious-and I think this would be a matter of bipartisan agreement-benefits to the industry of company-wide deductibility. Where we would differ from some members of the Opposition is on the need to ensure adequate community returns, because it seemed to be a theme in some of the contributions that it was at least open to debate whether the community should achieve a reasonable return for its resources. The Opposition and I would be at loggerheads in relation to that. I have a fundamental view that the community is so entitled.

The composite carry forward rate was modified to reflect the lower risk that losses would not be recouped against resource rent tax (RRT) liability following the introduction of the company-wide deductibility. Obviously, we can look at this issue in two separate contexts that reflect the level of risk that goes with exploration. In a later context, once production is under way, clearly, as a matter of logic and definition, the risks are much less. The reduction from 15 per cent to 5 per cent two-tier rate for exploration in general expenditure now also fully recognises the different risk characteristics of the two stages. That was fundamental.

The five-year rule, with the augmented bond rates and the RRT tax rate, combine to provide an appropriate return to the industry for its exploration risks. The risks are quite considerable. One of the things that I have tried to ensure is accepted in my time in this portfolio is the need to encourage people to partake in those risks. Organisations such as Greenpeace try to close down the industry, but if there were to be a situation where we had a lower level of self-sufficiency in the future then I think there would be a public backlash against those who argue that proposition.

In relation to the production figures that were indicated by the honourable member for Gippsland, it is worth making the point that production will be at about the same level, on current predictions, at the end of this decade. The clear difference is that during that period it is envisaged that rates of consumption will increase and that is where the gap comes about. If we are half successful in our energy efficiency programs-and we all have a vested interest in that as Australians-we should be able to narrow that gap considerably.

Reference was made by the right honourable member for New England to the Robertson survey. Most objective observers would accept that, if we are talking about the attractiveness or otherwise of offshore Australia for oil and gas exploration, then the final arbiters of that issue ought to be those who are going to be involved in offshore oil and gas exploration. The Robertson survey is a survey of the 66 key international companies involved in oil and gas exploration. The survey indicated that Australia was not one-hundredth, it was not fiftieth, it was not twentieth, it was number four on the international league for being the most desirable destination of exploration funds.

I think it is important that this House not talk down the industry; it is too important. Whilst we may have differences of opinion, as Australians we have a clear interest in ensuring that where we have a good story to tell-where that is accepted internationally by those who have the greatest interest in these matters-it is inappropriate for us to talk that situation down.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should always expose reality.

—I think that is right, and I would have thought that the Robertson survey did just that. When we strip all of it away, I think that the Leader of the National Party would accept that it is of importance to encourage this industry. He did have the decency and the objectivity to acknowledge the important parts of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties welcome the introduction of the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991, otherwise known as the plain English version of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I speak to this legislation on the eve of the fiftieth anniversary of the battle of Crete reunion on the island of Crete in Greece in the Mediterranean. Quite a large delegation of veterans from a number of electorates around Australia-including your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker-have gone to Greece to participate in a number of ceremonies and commemorations to follow the campaign through Greece and across to the island of Crete. That will culminate on Sunday, 26 May with a major service and commemoration on the island of Crete.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish everyone involved with that commemoration well. It is a very important anniversary-the fiftieth anniversary of the culmination of a massive campaign in Greece, which saw a large amount of courage and valour, and determination of effort by so many of the Allied forces in the harsh circumstances with which they were confronted in that very difficult year of World War II, namely, 1941.

I am delighted that the Parliament will be represented at the battle of Crete reunion. It is a rare privilege for the four who are going: the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs-the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock)-and myself. I am involved as a Vietnam veteran, quite apart from being Federal Leader of the National Party. I will take the opportunity in Crete to salute veterans of another war for the contribution they made to the Allied effort at that time.

I am confident that the commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the battle of Crete will go off successfully. I believe that it is part of our heritage-our military heritage especially, but our heritage more generally-in terms of the effort that Australians made in World War I, World War II, Korea, Malaya, Vietnam and other conflicts in which Australia was involved.

These key anniversaries are just that-very important anniversaries. It was in that context that the seventy-fifth anniversary of Anzac Day took place at Gallipoli last year. It involved a bipartisan effort including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), myself and many others, and the 57 World War I veterans who rightfully took centre stage for that particular commemoration. Now, in 1991, some of us, luckily, will be returning to attend-in my case for just 72 hours-the fiftieth anniversary of the battle of Crete.

In saying that, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am aware of your watchful eye ensuring that I do not stray too far from the plain English version of the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. This I now return to in fulsome terms and add that I am particularly delighted, on behalf of the Opposition, to signify that we do not oppose this legislation. I add that the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs in the Senate, Senator Jocelyn Newman, will take up a number of matters in more detail.

For my part, I was closely associated with the birth of the original Veterans' Entitlements Bill, which became the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 after a long and sometimes tortuous path through Parliament. It bounced between the two Houses for a period nigh on 12 months, for good and proper reasons, leading to a number of amendments being accepted to the legislation in the final stages. The legislation before the House this night aims to simplify the wording and arrangement of the service pension provisions so that that section is more accessible. This follows the lead taken by the Social Security Bill 1990, in which a plain English approach to legislation was adopted.
