I note that the Bill has been widely welcomed by the ex-service community, including all the major organisations such as the Returned Services League (RSL), Legacy, the Australian Veterans and Defence Service Council (AVADSC) and, importantly, the War Widows Guild of Australia. It should be noted that the AVADSC has engaged Mr Justice Toose to analyse this Bill for any unintended interpretative changes, and I am advised that he will be reporting back to the AVADSC in the near future. I understand that Senator Newman will take on board any submission arising from that, and that will be taken up further in the Senate debate on this legislation.

During my time as shadow Minister for veterans' affairs there have often been instances where veterans or war widows from across Australia, or constituents from my electorate, would write to me or speak to me about their entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. For any member, especially those who have had no experience of dealing with veterans' legislation, this can become a daunting task in lodging those representations. I therefore commend this attempt to bring about plain English legislation.

I would like particularly to commend the RSL, in this its seventy-fifth anniversary year and on the eve of its seventy-fifth anniversary conference in Melbourne, for the way it has approached the task of repatriation legislation and updating repatriation legislation over the decades. Many hundreds of sub-branches of the RSL have acted as voluntary counsellors and have given great assistance to veterans in helping them to interpret and understand their entitlements under the somewhat complex existing Veterans' Entitlements Act.

In this regard it must never be forgotten by this Parliament, especially when so few parliamentarians in the 1990s are veterans, that when we deal with veterans' entitlements we are dealing with compensatory payments and not welfare. For that reason, I am pleased to see that the Minister has given a written undertaking to the peak ex-service organisations that there will be no erosion of the existing entitlements in the rewrite this Bill represents.

The most significant aspect of this Bill is a set of rate calculators which provide an algorithm for calculating service pension rates under a variety of different circumstances. Also included is a comprehensive index of definitions applicable to the entire Veterans' Entitlements Act and grouped in subject order. I say to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who has just joined us: Hallelujah! The simplification and the ranking in order of those provisions is most welcome-although, looking at some of the wording of the legislation, just how simple, just how plain English, is it?

Let me read a clause from this Bill to the House-to the nation, in fact. I quote from page 27 of this plain English amendment Bill in respect of a number of definitions that are given in subclause (2):

Where the value or amount at a particular time of a market-linked investment included in an investment product is equal to or less than the value or amount of that market-linked investment 12 months previously, the annual rate of return at that first-mentioned time for market-linked investments included in that investment product is to be taken, for the purposes of a determination under this Act, to be 0%.

Before the Minister jumps up and accuses me of selectively quoting this important legislation, I do not dwell on the point. Obviously there has to be exact phraseology to ensure that there is no litigation, no misunderstanding and no confusion; that is part of the equation of this plain English legislation, However, I will say to the Minister: it might be plain English to him and it might even be plain English to me, as people used to dealing with legislation by and large, but to a lot of veterans it is still going to be a reasonably complex equation as they examine this lump sum calculator, for example, on page 95 and how they go through five steps in calculating what might be their entitlement in relation to the module listed.

For all that, it is a step in the right direction. It is difficult to draft, in the plainest of all English, what might be the intent of Parliament and the intent of the Government. No doubt, as we go down this plain English legislative path, there will be further improvements as the style of drafting is developed, and this would be welcomed by the Liberal and National parties. It would help close the gap that exists between this Parliament and its legislative process and the people at large, particularly those beyond the cocoon of Canberra. That gap is real. It is relayed to me and many other members as we go around our electorates on weekends. Now that people receive the live telecast of Question Time they find they cannot understand or relate to many aspects of the deliberations here in Parliament. Adopting plain English legislation will help break down the gap between the Parliament and the people of Australia, and this legislation is an important step forward on that path.

Having welcomed this Bill, I now highlight two particular matters for which I believe the Government does deserve criticism. The Minister will remember that during all my time as shadow Minister for veterans' affairs the Government consistently has said that there would be no integration of the repatriation hospitals without the consent of the RSL. It is plainly obvious-in plain English-that the Government is pushing ahead with integration, despite the fervent opposition of the vast majority of the veteran community and most levels of the RSL. The Minister cannot blame the RSL for truly representing the ex-service community. That is what it is there for. The ex-service community in 1991, at this stage of the cycle at any rate, wants to retain the repatriation hospitals. More particularly, there is a justifiable case for the retention of the repatriation hospitals ahead of the peak demand of veterans on the repatriation hospital system.

It is a complex area. I do not rule out change down the track to maximise the quality of life for veterans in their elderly years and the quality of health service and health care that might be available to them. Equally, there is massive concern over this issue of transfer of the repatriation hospitals to the State hospital system. The Government has not been successful in communicating to Australian veterans its case for hospital integration. It has gone back on its promise that it would not go ahead without the veterans' consent. For that the Government stands condemned.

Can I also say to the Government that its tactic of going around the RSL on this subject with a huge mail-out to some 360,000 veterans and war widows will raise much anger in the ex-service community. This question of mail-outs has been raised from time to time, and raised in a critical way in relation to a former member of my Party. I just want to say: let us put all our cards on the table in regard to mail-outs and the nature of the letters that have been sent out by certain Labor senators, by the Prime Minister and others. Here is another example of a mail-out to some 360,000 veterans and war widows, with the associated cost tag. The pamphlet sent out is entitled The Repatriation Private Patient Scheme-How you will benefit . . . I say to the Minister that the benefits of the repatriation hospital scheme are already well known to the ex-service community.

I believe that the RSL will continue to heavily criticise the Government for its steamrolling tactics. I make the point to the Minister that under a coalition government there would not be such a breakdown in relations between the Government and the RSL and other key veterans organisations.

The Government on other occasions has been fond of boasting of its consensus approach when it comes to its mates in the union movement and more generally. However, when it comes to Australia's veterans' community, it seems that a steamrolling approach is acceptable-and I say again to the Minister that such an approach is not acceptable to the coalition. There have been some very large meetings on this issue and I think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs went to a recent meeting at the Sydney Town Hall. He therefore would be aware of the widespread concern about the issue of integration of the repatriation hospitals. It is an issue which must be carefully examined because of the many very serious ramifications involved.

I also point out to the Minister that back in 1989 the Government received the McGirr report into the needs of Australian mariners, Commonwealth and Allied veterans and Allied mariners, merchant seamen and others. Since that time the Government has responded to only two of the more marginal recommendations of that report. The Minister has been saying to mariners and the veterans' community that the Government will respond `when government business permits'. I say to the Minister that this approach is just not good enough, as many of these veterans are passing away and will not have the benefit of fairness and justice extended to them.

The Minister will be aware of the age group affected by the McGirr report. Many of these deserving veterans and mariners, as I have mentioned, have passed away, and key elements of the McGirr report should be dealt with and responded to quickly-not tomorrow, not next year, but today. In fact, it should have been responded to before now.

I accept that these are not new issues and I accept that governments of both persuasions have been slow in coming to grips with these issues. But I do not accept that after the Government receives a report-in this case, the McGirr report back in 1989-nearly two years should elapse before it responds, in May 1991, to the vast majority of its recommendations on the grounds simply that government business does not permit it.

We started this session with a light legislative program. The House has sat in every month of this year, including January for the special two-day sitting on the Gulf. It now seems that we will sit in every month for the rest of this year-June, July, August, September, October, November and December-although the sitting dates for July are up in the air a little bit. But Government backbenchers have been warned about the possibility of sitting in July and of electing new parliamentary leaders for the Australian Labor Party and other matters in the aftermath of its Hobart conference.

I simply say that it is not a good enough excuse to state that government business does not permit a response, and a comprehensive response, to all of the aspects of the McGirr report. After all, the McGirr report was written by a person of singular significance. She accomplished a great deal of work in her contribution to the Repatriation Commission. Therefore, the report was prepared in a way which lent itself to implementation. So I ask the Minister in his response to indicate when there will be a more comprehensive and adequate response to those elements of the McGirr report which have not yet been dealt with by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you got in tomorrow, would you go on with the report?

—I am pleased that the Minister concedes the prospect of the Liberal and National parties coming to government at an early date. We will give the veterans a fair go; we will give the merchant seamen a fair go; and we will indeed produce a response to the McGirr report. We will do that through announcements including policy announcements which, quite properly, at the proper time, will be made by the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, Senator Newman. Our policy at the last election provided some specific initiatives and these will be added to by the other elements of the McGirr report. However, I think it is essential to recognise that we are in opposition, sadly; honourable members opposite are in government and they have the absolute responsibility of these matters.
—You had better help me!

—I will be happy to help the Minister persuade Cabinet on some of the crucial issues which are dealt with in the McGirr report. In closing, I welcome the plain English version of the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991 as a more sensible legislative approach to veterans' entitlements.

SPEECH.PARA: I say just one other thing about this legislation. As I mentioned at the outset, it is the eve of the fiftieth anniversary of the Battle of Crete. Whether the veterans of this battle are here in Australia, whether they are already over in Greece or somewhere else in the world, as many of them are-they have chosen to live elsewhere in their retirement-or whether they are in large country towns, small country towns or capital cities, wherever they might be, I, as Leader of the National Party, my coalition colleagues and, in fairness, honourable members by and large on both sides of the House acknowledge and salute the contribution our veterans, our ex-service personnel, have made to Australia.

More particularly, we salute the contribution made more recently by those who served in the Gulf with principally the Royal Australian Navy; our ships which went up there-HMAS Westralia is still there-and also the elements of the Army and Royal Australian Air Force which attended as part of the Gulf war task force. Of course, they are now returned service personnel and have entitlements which will be picked up in part by the legislation before the House.

I add that one of the veterans who will not make it back to the fiftieth anniversary of the Battle of Crete is a Mr Bob King, a former member of the House of Representatives seat of Wimmera, in Victoria. That seat has since been redistributed out. Bob does not enjoy good health, but he is a man of determined spirit. He is in hospital-I think the St John of God Hospital in Ballarat-and I send to him a special greeting and message. In one sense, I send a special greeting and message not only to Bob King but to the hundreds of Bob Kings around Australia whose thoughts would want to be and who would physically like to be on the island of Crete over the next 10 days-and that is understandable. Of course, all of us will be thinking of them as the very important and significant fiftieth anniversary reunion takes place.

I believe honourable members on both sides of the House will give consideration to this legislation in a thoughtful way and will be generally supportive of it. All that is left is for me to highlight to the House those words of Ben Chifley which I have used on other occasions, when I was shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, and which I will always continue to use, because I think they are most relevant. Many years ago, in the aftermath of World War II, he said:
Upon this House rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done to those who served their country in time of War.

That is an absolute obligation which we are all duty-bound to uphold. By and large, the legislation before this House, the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991, providing a plain English version of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, is a positive step towards upholding that very important dictum of former Prime Minister Ben Chifley.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Leader of the National Party will carry with them the best wishes of all members of the House when they go to Crete.
—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) for certain parts of his speech, particularly the concluding part in which he was quite generous. I join with the honourable member for Farrer in wishing well those Australian ex-service personnel who are returning to the Crete anniversary celebrations. I will have more to say on anniversaries shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill, which seeks to repeal part III of the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 and to substitute new part III dealing with the payment of service pensions and associated benefits for veterans, spouses and other dependants as at 1 July 1990.

I am pleased that this Bill will not be opposed by the Opposition. The main feature of new part III is that it is written in plain English, the removal of outmoded expressions making the legislation easier to read and understand. Thus, veterans' organisations and other users of this legislation will not find the Bill as confusing and difficult to interpret as had previously been the case. Certain sections will be shorter and it will be much easier to follow the structure and layout of provisions, with each category of pension dealt with in a separate, concise division.

As with the social security legislation previously amended to plain English, I welcome the Hawke Labor Government's initiative in adopting this practice of using clear English and a better format for providing information. It is important to note that the rewrite of part III was undertaken in consultation with the ex-service organisations, which have been involved from the outset in its planning and organisation. I acknowledge the assistance provided by ex-service organisations, whose comments have been both constructive and helpful in redrafting the legislation, which will pave the way for more effective administration.

The ex-service personnel in my electorate of Hunter are wonderful men and women all, and they are no slouches when it comes to knowledge, but not many of them have been trained in legal studies. They have as much trouble as I do with legal jargon. At last, they will be provided with information about service pensions and associated benefits which they can easily understand.

The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) has drawn one example of legalese to our attention, and I am sure that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) will have that matter looked at with a mind to improving it. Praise the Lord for this Government's pursuit of plain English and simple to understand concepts! The members of this Government who have held the portfolio of Minister for Veterans' Affairs have done a wonderful job on behalf of veterans and their spouses, and the present Minister's performance has been exceptionally outstanding. The Minister is a sympathetic man and someone to whom veterans can relate. They appreciate the fact that he is approachable and is prepared to give sympathetic consideration to their concerns.

Recently the Minister came to my electorate of Hunter to present plaques to the RSL sub-branches in Maitland, Cessnock and Singleton. I am proud that a large number of veterans and their spouses turned out to welcome the Minister, and I was delighted at their acceptance of the concept behind the move to make the repatriation general hospitals State based. The veterans in my electorate of Hunter and, I am sure, the veterans in almost every other electorate would prefer to be treated locally, where they have their family and friends close around them, rather than travel to Sydney, some other State capital or some other far away place to get service at a repatriation hospital.

The transfer of repatriation hospitals to the States had to happen. The honourable member for Farrer admitted that change would be necessary. He even conceded that, should the Opposition, by some stretch of the imagination, happen to gain office, it would initiate change; but the change that it would initiate, he has assured us, would cause the ex-service and veterans' organisations to sing hallelujah! Well, some people might believe that, but I find it rather hard to swallow.

The transfer of repatriation hospitals to the States will ensure the Government's previous guarantee to the service community of access and quality of health care. Under the scheme, entitled veterans and war widows will continue to receive free treatment from the Department of Veterans' Affairs local medical officers. They will have a choice of local specialists at no cost to them, subject to the specialists' fees being in accord with or less than the Medicare benefit schedule fee. Veterans and war widows will have free treatment as private patients in a public hospital of their choice without requiring prior approval from the Department. Where the public hospital system cannot meet their medical needs within a reasonable time, private hospital care in a shared ward will be available. Veterans and war widows will continue to have access at repatriation hospitals where there are special requirements. When the above matters are considered, it will be seen that ex-service men and women can be assured that there will be no diminution of medical services.

It is very interesting to read the most recent issue of the RSL national newsletter. It is unfortunate that the National President is quite critical of the Government's decisions, but we find elsewhere that some people find them quite easy to live with. I notice that the President of the Queensland branch of the RSL says:
If integration-
`rationalisation' would be a better word-
does go ahead, we are in a position to ensure that the veteran and the widow are not disadvantaged.
The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister have both given that assurance.

The joint venture scheme established in 1985 has assisted veterans' organisations to provide services which help veterans and their dependants continue to live at home when they could otherwise be placed in nursing home care. Some of the sub-branches in my electorate of Hunter have availed themselves of funding under the joint venture scheme. For example, the Maitland RSL sub-branch, together with Legacy in Maitland, was able to purchase a small bus to perform a variety of services for their members. I note that the payment of non-taxable lump sums of $10,000 to Australian ex-servicemen who suffered illegal internment in Nazi concentration camps has been negotiated between Australia and Germany. I understand that there is a difference between a concentration camp and a prisoner of war camp, but most people would agree that that distinction would indeed be a very fine line. I am a little disappointed that the Government so far has not supported an independent group which is endeavouring to seek reparation from the Japanese Government for Australian prisoners of war held by the Japanese during the Second World War. Apart from that comment, I am pleased with the wide range of initiatives provided for ex-service personnel in recent Budgets.

As I have said, I reject the contention by the RSL National President, Alf Garland, that the transfer of repatriation general hospitals to the States is a pennypinching approach by the Government and that the private patient status proposal is a sham. This Government has tremendous regard for RSL personnel and their concerns. We do consult with them and do not use, as was suggested by the honourable member for Farrer, a steamroller approach. Unfortunately, however, on many occasions we do have to go around with a fire extinguisher putting out brush fires. Who starts these brush fires? The honourable member for Farrer and Senator Newman. Half my time in the veterans' community is spent going around explaining the true facts after these people have been led up the garden path for political ends only, trying to confuse them and cause them anguish.

Those people without a jaundiced view will recognise that this Government in difficult economic times has done more for veterans than could possibly be hoped for under the user-pay principles espoused by the Opposition. I would rather walk away from politics altogether than be part of any legislation that deprived veterans from benefits. Fortunately, whenever I face the veterans in my electorate, I can always hold my head high and be extremely proud of the benefits and the advantages that this Government has provided for veterans. I know that we have not been able to meet all their demands but, gee whiz, we have certainly gone a long way towards placating their fears and concerns and to keep them in a position where they are able to enjoy life and not become victims of poverty or any other abuses or neglect.

This nation leads the world in the provision of benefits and care for those gallant men and women who have served this nation of ours in times of conflict, and while we have men of great compassion such as the Minister for Veterans Affairs and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) protecting veterans' interests, this nation will continue to lead the world on that score. Veterans will always get a fairer go from this Government than they would receive from those so lacking in compassion who sit opposite. Indicative of the Opposition's hypocrisy is its farcical about-turn on the Australian War Memorial issue.

I am pleased that veterans welcome the changes to the Defence Services Home Scheme. I engage in a lot of dialogue with veterans in my electorate and I endeavour to address their concerns. I hope they are happy with the assistance I endeavour to provide to them.

Finally, there are about four or five veterans in my electorate who were members of the 2/19 Infantry Battalion serving in Darwin at the time of the Japanese attack on 19 February 1942. Ern Akers, Ken Berthold, Laurie Barnes, Col Nowlan and a dozen or so other fellows in New South Wales were members of the original Darwin Infantry Battalion. They copped the brunt of the first bombing attack on Darwin. These brave fellows were later incorporated into the 2/19 Battalion.

These men want to return to Darwin for the fiftieth anniversary of that tragic day. I know that the Minister for Veterans Affairs and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) will be sympathetic to my approaches for assistance to ensure that these veterans get the opportunity to take part in the commemoration. One Royal Australian Air Force plane from each State would save these brave guys $1,000 each for the cost of a plane ticket. They certainly cannot afford that. It would be small repayment for their efforts 50 years ago.

I feel that this action is as important as the return of the Anzacs to Gallipoli last year or the return of veterans to Crete this year. This legislation before the House will be of great benefit to veterans, and I have pleasure in commending it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to take part in this debate on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. In fact, as the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) said in leading for the Opposition, we welcome the legislation and we commend the Government for the action that it has taken. I note in the second reading speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) that he points out that the most important features of the new part III include provisions expressed in plain English. I think everyone commends the Government for that action and also for the fact that the Bill contains shorter sections than does the current legislation; it is easier to follow, with the layout of provisions for each category of pension dealt with in a separate division. It all adds up to its being presented better and easier to understand. The Leader of the National Party has already commended the Government on at least that aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that veterans are a very important section of our community. In some respects they are an ageing and shrinking sector of the community. They remain, I think as far as the Government is concerned-I know as far as the Opposition is concerned-a very important sector of the community. They will remain so for a long time to come. I have reminded the House on a few occasions-there will come a time when I stop doing it-that I have had a close association with veterans in a number of ways. I am always proud to say that my late father was a member of the 6th Division of the 2nd AIF and served right through the Middle East. I am very proud of that. My little six-year-old boy wears my father's medals on Anzac Day. That is terrific. I am very proud to wear mine as a Vietnam veteran and as one of only three veterans in this place. The Leader of the National Party is one of the others. I have pleasure in talking in this place about veterans' affairs matters because they are very close to my heart.

I believe that Anzac Day this year was a wonderful day. It was a day that in my electorate at least, and probably right across Australia, saw the services and functions very well attended. I suppose there was some impetus to the day, given the fact that we had just successfully completed an action in the Gulf war. Once again, Australians had held their heads high and performed creditably.

I, along with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), the Minister and others, was very fortunate to go to the mouth of the Brisbane River to meet HMAS Sydney and HMAS Brisbane.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was there.

—The honourable member for Oxley was there, as he reminds me. What a moving occasion it was, particularly when I reflect on my own homecoming from Vietnam. It was a very moving occasion for me on that day as we came up the river on the ships and as they docked. The excitement and atmosphere were wonderful to experience. I want to thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) for inviting me to attend on that occasion, because it was a wonderful opportunity. I enjoyed very much talking to the sailors and officers on both ships. They did a tremendous job for us overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose Anzac Day received an impetus from that, but I do not think it was that alone. People are starting to see Anzac Day as being a very significant day and there is a lot of interest in Anzac Day not only from the older people, the older veterans-the diggers themselves. This year I was very pleased to see at many of the Anzac Day commemorations that I attended the interest of younger people who obviously had fathers and grandfathers who were veterans. There were young kids there representing probably their late grandfathers. I think that is terrific because it all augurs well for the future of Anzac Day.

In my own electorate I attended two dawn services, one a little before dawn and one a little after. I also attended four other commemorative services. They were all very well attended. I would also commend, with a little bit of licence, the scouts, the guides and others who participate so actively on Anzac Day. I commend and encourage them for doing that.

As a matter of interest for honourable members, I felt that we ought to have a commemorative service at Parliament House in the lead-up to Anzac Day. I realise honourable members are committed in their electorates, but I wrote to the Speaker after this last Anzac Day-it is the first one I have attended since I came here-and asked him could we have a commemorative service in Parliament House in the lead-up to Anzac Day. Perhaps we could invite local Returned Services League of Australia personnel as well as service personnel who live and work in this town. I am sure that such a commemorative event would be welcomed. Certainly it would be welcomed by veterans and others who have had connections with the Defence Service, and of course by members of Parliament. It would not have to be a long service, but it would be a fitting one. Perhaps the Minister for Veterans' Affairs will undertake to follow that up with the Speaker. I am waiting for a response, but I wrote in only the last few days.

Anzac Day is a special day-a wonderful day-which is a tribute to veterans. I was very disappointed that Sir Alan Walker, for whom I have always had a great deal of respect as a churchman and citizen, suggested that Anzac Day should not be observed because it is a glorification of war. I think that many people, perhaps better equipped than I am, have managed to put that in perspective. Suffice it to say that I believe he is quite wrong on that subject. I believe that Anzac Day is a day that brings Australians together. It is a day that we can all relate to, when we look back not just to Gallipoli but also to a number of theatres of war since then where Australians have served their country and given their very best for it. As I say, it is a special day for veterans and their families.

All veterans await with great interest the statement to be made by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in respect of the restructuring of the Defence Force. I will be looking very closely at what he has to say because I believe-and I am sure that I am speaking for the Opposition here-that any lessened commitment to the defence of Australia will be deplored throughout the community and certainly by the Opposition. I look forward to hearing what Senator Robert Ray does say. I and, I know, many others will be listening closely, because my analysis of defence expenditure under this Government is that it has fallen behind in real terms, and that is something to be deplored.

Further, on that matter, I believe that the important matter of defence should have been the subject of a Green Paper to promote discussion and to allow full input from the community at this important time. In many respects we have never got defence right; we have been fiddling around with it-perhaps I use that word a bit loosely; we have been dealing with it-for 90 years and we are still in the process of trying to get it right. Maybe we never will get it right. Nevertheless, it is of concern to a lot of people that we do not lessen our commitment to defence. I believe that the experience of veterans should not be ignored. They have first-hand experience and are a valuable resource who ought to be consulted fully.

We are approaching a number of significant fiftieth anniversaries as we head into the 1990s, when we will be commemorating a number of famous confrontations which occurred during the Second World War. Recently we had the fiftieth anniversary of the siege of Tobruk. I was fortunate enough to welcome a number of the Rats of Tobruk to Canberra, mostly from my electorate. Tobruk was almost the Second World War equivalent of Gallipoli, with the siege of Tobruk lasting for eight months and representing a magnificent action which was commended by Prime Minister Churchill. Next year we will commemorate the bombing of Darwin, when the Second World War came very close to Australia. We have learned lessons which emphasise the need to maintain a well equipped and well trained defence force.

I notice that the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) did not understate his praise of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in his comments. I believe that the Minister is a compassionate man in respect of veterans' affairs, from the dealings that I have had with him. I have made a number of representations to him, and they have always been answered fully and completely, although perhaps not always to my satisfaction. Nevertheless, I thank the Minister for the way in which he has approached his portfolio and for being the conscientious Minister that he is.

Having said that, I am about to whip the rug out from underneath the Minister's feet because I still do not believe that this Government has given sufficient priority to veterans' affairs. The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) spelled out a number of areas, and I pick up the point that in many respects the Department of Veterans' Affairs can be a little insensitive. Stronger words have been used, but the honourable member for Hunter talked about putting out brush fires started by the Leader of the National Party and by Senator Newman, as the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs. I suggest that if the honourable member means that raising issues of concern to veterans is starting brush fires he has it all wrong because our role is to do exactly that. The sort of brush fires that the honourable member for Hunter talked about are not really brush fires at all-some of the things we have managed to point to are really bush fires.

The honourable member for Hunter talked about the transfer of repatriation hospitals to the State health systems and told us how great that is going to be. I remind him that the Returned Services League still has some concerns about that activity. As far as I am concerned, there needs to be a further process of resolving those concerns-putting out that particular brush fire, putting it in the terms of the honourable member for Hunter.

The honourable member for Hunter mentioned the entry fees to the Australian War Memorial. However one wants to look at that, I think that it was an insult to many veterans that entry fees should be considered. We are all aware of the financial exigencies of government and the difficulties there are in making ends meet in any enterprise of any sort, but in a way it was like charging pilgrims to go to Mecca. The War Memorial is a very special place, and it commemorates a lot of wonderful things. I believe that the Opposition made the right decision and I applaud the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) for the position he ultimately took when he was confronted with a very strong argument about why the Memorial should be made available free of charge to anyone who wants to go there.

The honourable member for Hunter also mentioned the defence service homes scheme. Sure, that has improved-there is greater access to it and portability, and the Opposition applauds those things-but I put it to the Minister that the limit on the loan is becoming a bit unrealistic at $25,000. Surely there is some mechanism for reviewing that, because it will be inadequate in the short term.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Force has a newer one-a better one-now.
—I thank the Minister for that information and perhaps I can get some more details about it.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a case recently where a drug was refused to an entitled veteran and the Department of Veterans' Affairs was ultimately forced to admit it had made an error of judgment. I do not use that to lambast the Department, but I believe that veterans deserve the very best of consideration and the benefit of any doubts. These are people who not only have served their country-with great distinction in many cases-but also have lived through the exigencies and harshness of service life, some for many years. Anyone who has served in the forces understands the difficulties and challenges there are for people who choose to serve in the armed forces-the dislocation to family life and the prospect of overseas or active service at any time. People who serve in the defence forces are very special people and they deserve special consideration.

I think the Leader of the National Party referred to the brochure on the repatriation private patients scheme which is now being distributed to veterans and war widows. It is entitled `Repatriation health care'. Once again, perhaps there has not been as much attention to detail as there might have been, because as a result of that brochure there remain some unanswered questions. For example, no definition is given of `reasonable time' in respect of the policy about access to private hospitals.

The important question, which the Minister might take on board while he is being so cooperative, is: will repatriation general hospitals continue to provide the same level of outpatient care post-integration as occurs now? If not-I am talking now about the scheme-where will veterans and war widows obtain such care? Will they need prior approval to attend clinics in their own regions? The answers to these questions are crucial when considering issues such as priority of access and quality of care for veterans and war widows in an integrated health system. The brochure distributed by the Department on behalf of the Repatriation Commission fails to answer a number of difficult and important questions associated with integration.

Finally, just underlying what I have said about the need to give special consideration to veterans, I turn briefly to Vietnam veterans. They have some special concerns, of course, and I believe that those concerns need special attention. At the moment Vietnam veterans are particularly concerned that, despite a Government commitment to maintain staffing levels for the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service, the Repatriation Commission has reneged on that promise. I think the Minister is aware of what I am talking about. The Department of Veterans' Affairs seems to have some problem with the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service because it has attempted to undermine the service and has attacked it on a number of occasions. I believe that the counselling service is extremely cost effective-however one looks at cost effectiveness-and it ought to be supported. I challenge the Minister while he is in the chamber, if he is going to take on board my points, to restore the staffing level of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service to 49, which was the agreement it had with the Government.

Having said all that, I summarise by commending the Government for introducing the Bill we are dealing with. As has been said, the revamp of part 3 to plain English is a step forward in making the process of veterans' affairs legislation understandable by more people. That is a very positive step.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) in this debate on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. We were not the best of friends last night, but I think we have made amends tonight. It is good to hear the honourable member speak at length here tonight and make his contribution to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The care of former members of our defence forces is something that the Hawke Government has taken great pride in, for it is only fitting that the people who have made such a great contribution to this country should be rewarded with the benefits they deserve. It is with great pleasure that I rise tonight to speak in this debate on a Bill that will do much to improve the efficient operation of the Department of Veterans' Affairs-just as a recent rewrite of the Social Security Act will be helpful for beneficiaries in that area.

There is something unique about our defence forces. I refer to the one word that evokes emotion for both current and former defence personnel and members of the non-defence community alike. Of course, that is the word `Anzac'. While the history books show our military involvement in international conflicts before the battle of Gallipoli, Australians of all ages regard the Anzac spirit that was born at that time as something more than another page in our military history. Some people even regard it as the true birth of our nation-as has been said by other members tonight.

I know that those honourable members who were present just over a year ago at the commemoration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of Gallipoli-I mention the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), who is at the table, and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer)-would have felt the eerie presence of fallen soldiers at Anzac Cove. They would have left Anzac Cove with a very tangible reminder of the commitment made by our defence forces in times of need.

Although the original Anzacs reduce in numbers year by year, it is important to note that the recognition of their effort is certainly not diminishing. That has been highlighted tonight by previous speakers. I believe that on Anzac Day this year some of the crowds were even bigger than they had been for the seventy-fifth anniversary. As I attended Anzac Day services around my electorate of Oxley-I think four or five of them, beginning with the dawn service; I had quite a day out with some of the old veterans-I noticed an increasing number of young people showing a genuine interest in and respect for present and former members of our defence forces. I too join with the previous speaker, the honourable member for McPherson, in recognising the contribution made by some of our younger people in the scouting movement and the Girl Guides, et cetera, who were involved on the day.

In my electorate it was a beautiful sunny day and everyone came out for the occasion. The officials I spoke to at the dawn service believed that there was a larger crowd this year than there had been last year for the seventy-fifth anniversary of the landing at Gallipoli. It is significant that this respect for the contribution of the military is something that has not been eroded by time. If anything, I believe it has been enhanced. I certainly notice in my visits to schools around my electorate that students of very young ages are increasingly asking questions about the Government's role in the defence area and the meaning of Anzac Day. That same spirit is something we can be proud of in the case of the men and women who have served in our defence forces since that time. It is for that reason that the legislation before us is of such significance.

The unique and differing needs of Australia's veteran community, given their distribution of ages, means that the framework that serves them well on their return to Australia must be, first and foremost, a flexible one. Although there have been many amendments, there is no escaping the fact that the basic infrastructure of caring for today's veterans was born more than 70 years ago. Since then the men and women of our defence forces have been involved in another world war, the Korean War, the Malayan campaign, the Vietnam war and the recent conflict in the Middle East. That is to name just a few of the conflicts in which our forces have been involved at times when Australia has been called on to exercise its responsibility in the international community. I saw on the television news tonight our young troops heading off to the Middle East once again to play a very real role there in assisting the people, who are certainly in dire straits.

There have also been numerous occasions when our defence personnel have been involved in United Nations peacekeeping operations. It is important to note that the significance of Anzac Day was just as real this year with the return to Australia, close to 25 April, of HMAS Brisbane and HMAS Sydney from their tour of duty in the Middle East. I, like other members of the Parliament-and the honourable member for McPherson mentioned this-was pleased to have been present at the arrival of the ships at Hamilton Wharf in Brisbane and to see several servicemen from my own electorate of Oxley being reunited with their families. It was a very important occasion for the families welcoming the young sailors home. The sailors were obviously very pleased to be home as well.

I too would like to record my thanks to Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Defence, for his assistance in having those ships call into Brisbane. That visit was very important for the people in the south-east corner of Queensland, particularly the people in the city of Ipswich in my electorate. Both the Minister for Defence and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have my sincere thanks, and I am sure I speak on behalf of the families of those sailors who returned from the Gulf. The welcome those young sailors received revealed the true recognition by the community of the contribution made by defence personnel. This is something on which all members need to be congratulated.

With each of the conflicts Australia has been involved in since Gallipoli have come new forms of weaponry and warfare that, once the conflict has passed, leave the service personnel with differing needs when they leave the Services. It is just not good enough to combine the needs of ex-service personnel in the same basket with those of the rest of the community. These people have given a lot and they now deserve something in return. That is why I found it so surprising that the Opposition will not commit itself to recognising the individual needs of our ex-service men and women by supporting the Government's reforms in hospitalisation for veterans.

I know that there are honourable members on the other side of the House who have served in the defence forces, and they deserve the highest accolades. I acknowledge that the Leader of the National Party of Australia and the honourable member for McPherson are two such members. However, that fact also makes the Opposition's stand ever harder to believe. While I have not served in the Australian defence forces myself, as the son of a Second World War Royal Australian Air Force veteran-my father was in 10 Squadron during the war and served in the United Kingdom and the Middle East, and I am very proud of his efforts-I am very familiar with the unique aspects of defence families, growing up with such a father.

Coming to this place with that background, I am proud to stand on the side of the House that represents the true interests of veterans and their families. Australia's veterans have benefited from many initiatives introduced by the Hawke Government, and will continue to do so. Veterans have not been forgotten when it comes to the bigger planning picture for our increasingly ageing population, as can be seen in the increases they have received via the Government's better incomes policy for retirement.

Some of these include the realisation of the Government's longstanding commitment to increase single rate pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings (AWE). This one initiative has seen the rate of pension paid to single service pensioners and to war widows rise from 23.3 per cent of AWE in 1984 to a level above 25 per cent of AWE since April 1990.

Veterans and war widows have also benefited from the twice-yearly indexation of pensions, in line with the consumer prince index, as was brought out in the latest round of increases on 21 March this year. The maximum single rate for single service pensioners from this date is $301.60 a fortnight, with the equivalent rate for married couples being $251.50 per fortnight per person.

Recognising the contribution of defence personnel and the legacy left on surviving spouses, the war widows pension is currently $325.60 a fortnight. The incapacities that many ex-service personnel live with after leaving the defence forces are extremely varied and it is therefore appropriate that they should be supported by a similarly varied system of financial support. To this end, there are in place a number of disability pension rates, ranging from $20.90 for 10 per cent disability to $554.10 for a special totally and permanently incapacitated rate.

Given the importance of caring for the veteran community and the increasing proportion of veterans that will be in need of adequate hospital care, it would be remiss of me not to address the benefits the Government would like to offer to veterans via the Commonwealth's repatriation private patients scheme. It is sad that on this all important issue for veterans the Opposition has evaded the problem at hand and instead decided to get bogged down with pedanticism, with the poor veteran meanwhile being left not knowing where the future lies for veteran care. I put it to the Opposition to join with the Government to work together on this initiative, an initiative which will give veterans greater independence and dignity in their health needs. The two previous Opposition speakers, the honourable member for Farrer and the honourable member for McPherson, have been very supportive, and I acknowledge that.

The centrepiece of the changes which would see the integration of repatriation general hospitals (RGHs) into the State health systems would give entitled veterans and war widows something they do not have at present-private patient status. In addition to public hospitals and integrated repatriation hospitals, it is intended that veterans would also have the option of going to private hospitals contracted to the Department of Veterans' Affairs if no public hospitals can treat them within a reasonable time.

These benefits would affect more than 360,000 veterans and war widows across Australia. It would mean better options for many thousands of veterans and war widows who already choose admission to public hospitals as public patients or as privately insured patients rather than travel to RGHs.

I know that these benefits would mean a lot to the large number of veterans in my electorate of Oxley. When the families and friends of veterans who are hospitalised at the Greenslopes Rehabilitation Hospital wish to visit them during their stay, they have to either travel some distance in their own vehicles-and quite often they are elderly people who do not wish to drive in busy traffic-or catch a train to the centre of Brisbane, followed by a bus trip to Greenslopes, which is a time consuming exercise and quite exhausting for elderly people.

This also works in reverse, as indicated in the comments I have received from many veterans that if they ever required hospital care they would much prefer to be cared for close to their families and their mates. Instead of getting behind this reformation of hospital care for veterans, the Opposition has been totally opposed to genuine improvement. This dogmatic stand has been spearheaded blindly by the Opposition spokesperson from the other place, Senator Jocelyn Newman, who claimed in a totally negative media release that a national mail-out to all entitled veterans and war widows failed to answer crucial questions.

The brochure being posted to veterans explains the new arrangements in simple language and reassures them on major issues of concern. For Senator Newman's information, just to make sure veterans are able to understand the changes, the Government is inviting those who have further questions to telephone for further information. The call is toll free to veterans outside capital cities.

Importantly, this information campaign is based on solid research-research that indicates that veterans need more information about the proposed new arrangements. For all the fear that has been drummed up by some members of the Opposition who still claim to have the interests of veterans at heart, in most cases the private patients scheme would give veterans a better deal than any private medical insurance they could buy.

I note that there is some sign of the Opposition being more positive. In the March issue of the national newsletter of the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL), Senator Newman stated that the Federal Opposition policy was that integration should not occur until the concerns of the ex-service community and the States were properly addressed. I welcome that statement and I am sure it is a view that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is at the table, would support as well. After all, it is a course the Government is already pursuing.

We have set up extensive consultative bodies with the ex-service community and hospital staff, and, of course, are negotiating with the States. We have no intention of integrating the hospitals if the ex-service community expresses reasonable concerns. Of course, we cannot bulldoze the States. It is a cooperative effort and more vocal members of the Opposition would do well to join in that cooperative effort and put their thoughts of political expediency aside. Certainly the cooperative effort expressed here tonight by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Farrer, and the honourable member for McPherson are well received. They appear to have taken a bipartisan approach here this evening. I hope that they will have some influence with the other members of the Opposition and let those who disagree with the stand of their colleagues know by supporting the Government in this pivotal reform. I understand that the Opposition is supporting the Bill tonight, which is welcome.

The hospitalisation issue is one of a number that are of concern to veterans and war widows. It is one of the myriad of others already in place that will be greatly assisted by the plain English re-write of the veterans' affairs framework before us. A speedier processing of decisions, an easier determination of claims and a clearer understanding of the regulations are all ways in which those who have given their contribution to Australia will gain from the Bill. However, the degree to which veterans stand to gain from legislation still to be included in that framework will depend very much on the willingness of a selfish few to put political gain aside and recognise the true contribution made by the men and women of our defence forces.

As I said when I started, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak on this Bill because of the recognition of the work of my local RSL groups and the veterans in my community who work extremely hard for the benefit of their mates -both men and women. That includes groups like Legacy and many RSL groups.

I would like to make one point which has a lot to do with veterans. I was extremely concerned when I read in my local newspaper-the Queensland Times-during the week a report about an RSL club in Redbank Plains, a suburb in the City of Ipswich. The club had a ceremony on Anzac Day, which I was unable to attend because I was at other Anzac Day services. Some people who were obviously not very caring towards our veterans community took it upon themselves actually to borrow, for want of a better term, the Australian flag, which was at half mast at the Redbank War Memorial. The President of the RSL club has expressed his great concern about that and the veterans have been shattered by such a terrible thing happening, particularly on Anzac Day. I hope that the person or persons who took that course of action will wake up to themselves and return that flag without delay. I will certainly do my best to get them a flag as soon as possible, and I am sure the Minister would not mind me doing that. RSL clubs always fly their flags with great pride.

Things like that do a lot of damage, particularly to elderly people but to all our veterans and to the broader community. It is not a very good example, particularly to our young people. The honourable member for McPherson mentioned earlier, as I did, the young people who were out on Anzac Day, including the young people in schools who participated in Anzac Day activities. I thought taking the flag was a pretty disgraceful action. I hope the persons who did so will return the flag and apologise to the broader community for the offensive manner in which they have carried on.

Once again, I am very pleased to have had the opportunity to speak on this legislation. I certainly commend the Minister at the table for putting together what I think is extremely worthwhile legislation. The Department has obviously worked extremely hard with it. The Minister, of course, has a very caring attitude towards our veterans, as the honourable member for McPherson acknowledged before.

In closing, I would also like to pay tribute to the final remarks tonight of the Leader of the National Party for his reference to a former great Prime Minister, Ben Chifley. I think that shows the measure of the bipartisan approach the Leader of the National Party is prepared to exercise when dealing with veterans. I hope he uses that influence on other members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -Like other speakers before me in this debate on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991, I welcome the decision to simplify the language and format of part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 so as to render it more understandable to the people it affects. I know that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), who is at the table, is very conscious of the needs of the veterans' community and the ex-services community and has made every endeavour to ensure that all the literature to do with veterans is put in understandable terms.

SPEECH.PARA: In the year in which people have been talking about literacy so much in this country, we cannot overlook the fact that many of our veterans were not that well educated at school and do need assistance when it comes to reading what is effectively complex legislation. I know that the ex-service and veterans' community across Australia will also welcome the changes in part III of the Act.

As with the social security legislation, the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act are extremely important to the well-being of hundreds of thousands of people around Australia who fought for their country or were at least prepared to do so if called upon. Their advocates and support groups may have been familiar with the contents of the old Act, but it was a mystery to many of the ex-servicemen and ex-servicewomen who depend upon it for their financial support and medical coverage on a day-to-day basis.

I, like other members in this place, I am sure, have a great number of people who come into my office from time to time seeking assistance with the understanding of their entitlements or their ability to get a disability pension through the veterans' Act. I think that this Bill, if we have it in our offices, will assist us-along with, at some stage, the wonderful computer program, `The General', with which the Minister is very familiar, as is the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I hope at some stage that will also be extended to members of parliament to assist them in helping veterans in our community at the local level. We all need some simplification of legislation, and particularly very complex legislation which undoubtedly the Veterans' Entitlements Act has become because of the additions that have occurred over the years.

Extensive consultations with the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL) and other representative organisations and groups were undertaken and their approval of the Bill ratifies the claim that no changes in meaning or entitlement have occurred, only a rewrite so as to render such entitlements more easily understood. This was a very important point in the Minister's negotiations on the rewrite. The veterans, quite rightly, fear any change, because they think that a change may lead to a reduction in their benefit, even if only accidentally. So those sorts of checks by the RSL and other organisations were crucial to the acceptance of the rewritten legislation-and I for one support them, as I know the Minister does.

Part III of this Bill, as in the parent Act, provides for pensions and associated benefits to be paid to veterans, spouses and other dependants as at 1 July 1990. It is very easy to follow the structure and layout, and it will be useful to members of the veterans' community. Many veterans will be pleased to thumb through the legislation to see how it is now worded and to see whether in fact they can understand it. We have told them that they should be able to.

This rewrite does not involve any changes in policy, though, and has no financial impact or effect on the veterans' pensions or entitlements. Neither does it alter in any way the responsibilities of the Repatriation Commission to the veterans' community and their dependants.

In years gone by, I have been privileged to represent the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when it was not possible for him to attend at wreath laying ceremonies at the Kings Park War Memorial in Perth. The most recent occasion was the anniversary of the Royal Australian Air Force. These occasions are always a moving reminder of the loss of life that occurs in war-and I take that message very seriously.

Some people, unfortunately, make the mistake of thinking that, because I and others-perhaps on this side of the House-champion the cause of peace in this place and elsewhere, I must be anti-veteran. Nothing could be further from the truth. I strongly support the extension of care, respect and benefits to Australia's soldiers, sailors, airmen and auxiliary personnel, together with those who participated in other areas of work such as the merchant navy.

In fact, as a child of a sailor in the New Zealand Royal Navy, I can recall the disruptions in my early life occasioned by my father's profession and the difficulties it caused to my mother. As a consequence, I have taken an interest in my electorate in Balgirra House, which the Department has funded. This provides a place for ex-service and service spouses to go so that they can have support in the new community.

This is something which is often overlooked, but during the years of our Government the way we look after the spouses of our service personnel has become a feature. This little house is very useful. It has a place where children can play; it has facilities, usually for women but not always, for people to come and have a cup of tea or to have a discussion. We had an International Women's Day luncheon there on 8 March and the men organised the champagne. The women proceeded to drink it and enjoyed some festivities and food.

Those support services are essential. There are very many people who are separated from their families, because they know very few people, when they follow their spouse to another State in the course of their work with the services. So this sort of network-which is what it is-assists people to come to grips with the new place in which they are living, and it also provides them with a way into the community for the receipt of training or the seeking of work. I know in this particular house there is a very good link with the person who comes and advises spouses of our service personnel on how they may get training or look for work in their new area.

I believe that many veterans are anti-war, having lived through it and having witnessed its consequences. In Western Australia in particular-I do not know about the other States-a lot of speakers who come to the schools to speak to the children about Anzac Day are either Vietnam veterans or veterans from previous wars, the Second World War or the Korean War. I think that adds an element of reality to the children's schooling and to their understanding of war, because these people do not pull any punches. They quite honestly say that when they went to war they thought it was going to be a glorious adventure. Whilst they do not condemn the war, they certainly do not glorify it. That is a very important position for veterans and ex-service people to take.

These children will have to make decisions in the future as to whether they wish to go to war, and we do not want them going for the wrong reasons. There are a lot of war movies and things like that on television. Many children do get a very wrong approach to war and think that it is simply a glorifying experience, not realising that it is in fact death and destruction-although, there is no doubt, with some wonderful comradeship involved.

Some members in this debate have dwelled on the subject of Anzac Day. As a naturalised Australian born in New Zealand, I myself do have a special interest in that tradition. In Western Australia at the present time the commemoration of Anzac Day occurs unfortunately during the school holidays. This has caused quite a few problems in allowing children to participate, or at least ensuring that children participate, in the ceremony. I notice that one of the local members in my area organised a pre-Anzac Day ceremony to coincide with the end of school before the school holidays began. This is a way of getting around the problem, but I think it would be better if we could have the holidays altered so that they coincide with Easter. Anzac Day would then not fall in the school holidays as it does at the moment. It is a problem because many of the children do enjoy the Anzac Day ceremony. It is teaching them something.

At the Wanneroo ceremony that I went to last 25th, there was a person doing the prayers and ensuring that people understood what was happening and what we were commemorating. I think he had a very good message to tell. He said that we should be waging peace in our lives. That is my view exactly. I noticed that the people who were there, including the veterans community, agreed with what he was saying. I think that is a very important point and a message that should be given to as many Australians as possible.

The Minister has indicated that the rewrite of part III has been undertaken in consultation with the ex-service organisations, as I mentioned earlier. In November of last year an exposure draft of the partially completed Bill was provided to these organisations for examination. The comments that have been received were both constructive and helpful in the redrafting of the legislation. This process that has been undergone does show that the Minister recognises the concern of veterans over every change to the Act and their fear of loss of benefits.

This plain English Bill represents a very significant advance in making legislation more accessible to ageing veterans in our community. It is, as the Minister has said, an aspect of access and equity which the Government pursues and of which we can be proud. A great deal of effort has been made in completing the Bill to allow for a more effective administration. I personally commend the Bill to the House and congratulate the Minister on his perseverance in seeing this lengthy task through and for his stewardship of the veterans' entitlements in our community and in our Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is good to see that you contributed to the debate on this legislation, and it is nice to see you now in that very high position that you hold of Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991 which has just taken place brings nearer to conclusion another step in making veterans' affairs legislation more accessible. This Bill, with its simplified English expression and the logical arrangement of its main parts, has general bipartisan support. I thank those honourable members who have contributed to this debate and expressed general acceptance of the thrust of the plain English legislation.

I would like to make a few remarks about the contributions made by honourable members. I might start with the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), and thank him for his very kind remarks. As always, he is very supportive of the Government's legislation and not very critical. When he is being critical, he is usually doing a bit of shadow boxing, but he mainly supports the Government's policy in relation to veterans' affairs.

I was very interested to hear his contribution in relation to the McGirr report on the merchant mariners. Whilst I was trying to challenge him to say exactly what he would do if those opposite were ever to win the treasury bench, he was very careful not to say that they would implement those recommendations of the McGirr report that he was asking me to implement. I would like to hear from him again, and I would like to point out also that it was the Government that commissioned the McGirr report. Whilst he was not here-and I appreciate that the veterans probably would have been looked after if he had been here-in 30 years of coalition government we never got too far with the merchant mariners. I enjoyed his remarks when he said that he would help support me in encouraging the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Cabinet Ministers, when we have the McGirr report, to have some of its recommendations accepted. We will be doing that in the very near future. I will be happy to report to the House when we get around to doing that.

I point out also to the Leader of the National Party-because he had a few concerns about the plain English rewrite-that there is an explanatory memorandum that will explain fully all of those little concerns. I would also like to say that it is going to be great for me to be able to go over to Crete with the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), and Senator Bolkus for the commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the battle of Crete. I will be looking forward to his contribution there also.

I would also like to thank the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) for his contribution in this debate. He is always interested in veterans' affairs and does a great job in his electorate on behalf of the veterans. I have visited his electorate on several occasions and, as he was pointing out, he is always well received by the veterans in his electorate. They do, as he pointed out, fully support hospital integration. Why would they want to come from the Hunter down to Concord when they can be treated locally? It is also nice for them to know that, if they wish to come to Concord, to the city, they will be able to do that also under the new arrangements.

The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) is also, like the Leader of the National Party, a Vietnam veteran. I am proud of them for that. They served their country well. They are constituents of mine, as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, and I will be happy to look after them if they ever have to make a claim against the Department of Veterans' Affairs while I am the Minister. I would be very happy to see what we could do on their behalf.

I would like to point something out to the honourable member for McPherson, and especially to the Leader of the National Party and other members of the Opposition and the Government who are here tonight. The honourable member for McPherson was very concerned about the War Memorial charges. Whilst it is nothing to do with the rewrite in plain English of part III of the veterans' entitlements legislation, I would ask him to check on the shadow Minister's press release in which she was suggesting not only that there be charges but that the turnstiles be shifted from where the Council had recommended they be to the car park so that people on buses and people being taken around the War Memorial with guides could be charged. What we would be doing then would be charging people to go not only into the displays but also into those very sacred areas of the War Memorial. So those opposite do have a policy on charging, but I do not think that the honourable member read the shadow Minister's press report on that.

The honourable member was concerned about outpatients in relation to the repatriation and general hospitals (RGHs). Once again, that does not have a great deal to do with the legislation, but it was a broad ranging debate, which I think was a good idea. He was concerned about the outpatients at RGHs. I should let him know that veterans will still be able to go to the outpatients departments, as they will be able to go to the repatriation hospitals. He has 23,000 veterans in his electorate, and I am sure that they do not want to travel from that beautiful Gold Coast up to the pollution in the city when they could all be treated on the Gold Coast, where they live, where their loved ones are, where their families are, and where they can be visited in their local hospitals. That is what you were saying, Mr Deputy Speaker, in respect of your constituents in Ipswich.

I should explain to the honourable member for McPherson that last year 41,000 veterans were treated in RGHs throughout Australia and 50,000 veterans were treated in public hospitals. I would say to the honourable member for McPherson and the Leader of the National Party that, once integration takes place, all those 50,000 veterans that were treated in public hospitals-and many of them were treated as public patients in public hospitals-will be able to be treated as private patients in public hospitals. I cannot see what we would find wrong with that. There were also another 30,000 veterans treated in private hospitals. So, there were 41,000 in RGHs and 80,000 in public or private hospitals. I should think that should show the Leader of the National Party and the honourable member for McPherson that the veterans are voting with their feet and being treated where they live and being part of their own community. I am sure that the honourable member for McPherson and the Leader of the National Party appreciate that and, whilst they are shadow boxing and playing politics, I know that they agree that we should integrate the hospitals sooner or later.

I was a bit disappointed in the honourable member for McPherson saying that we were not looking after the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. I will have to send him a little note on what we have done for the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. I do not know who he was saying was attacking the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. I cannot recall that ever happening. The Department and I are very supportive of the Service. The Department has done a great job on behalf of the counsellors, and the counsellors have done a great job on behalf of not only the Vietnam veterans of Australia, but all veterans in Australia. I will have to send him a letter in relation to that.

The honourable member for McPherson spoke about the pamphlets that we sent out to explain in plain English to those many veterans-over 600,000 who are entitled to be treated in repatriation hospitals-what we are really offering in relation to integration. I am sure that the Leader of the National Party would be interested in the fact that there were 2,000 calls taken in response to the brochure. The overwhelming majority of the calls were very supportive. They were asking us, `When can all this happen?'. I was saying to them, `You write to the Leader of the National Party and tell him you want it, and to the leaders of the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL), to explain that you would love to be getting into this private health insurance and that you will take advantage of the offer that the Government and the Department are making'.

Finally, I thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your contribution and the hard work you do in your electorate of Oxley on behalf of the veterans community. I understand that you are well accepted there by the veterans. I have visited you in your electorate. I know of the hard work you do on behalf of them. I also thank the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) for her remarks. She is the very powerful chairperson of the caucus community services and welfare committee. She is always there when we are putting legislation forward. Like the true democratic party that we are, we go to the committee with all of this legislation that we are introducing on behalf of the veterans community. We put it to the committee and it is given very close scrutiny by the committee and, in particular, by the chairperson, the honourable member for Cowan.

It was great to hear the remarks of the honourable member for Cowan in relation to The General, the computer program. We will be doing everything we can to have that made available to all honourable members and senators of whatever political persuasion. I am sure it is a great idea. As soon as we can we will be able to make available the rewrite in plain English of part three on the computer program. That program was named after a very famous Australian general and a repatriation commissioner, Major-General Alan Morrison, who has done a great job not only on behalf of his nation and his country but also on behalf of the veterans community. I thank all honourable members. It was a great debate.
