Last, but by no means least, I wish to acknowledge the contribution to the final Bill by the veterans community through its representative organisations. Consultation with these bodies remained constant throughout the development of this legislation. It was particularly heartening to witness the spirit of cooperation which marks this progress. I thank them for the positive contribution they made to the Bill, and especially the national Vice-President of the Returned Services League of Australia, Mr Bruce Ruxton, who passed on his personal thanks to me for the cooperation he had from the departmental people in making sure that they were quite happy with this rewrite of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not always kind to you.

—He is always very kind to me. We get on well together, as I do with the President. We are entitled to disagree, but I can assure the Leader of the National Party that they are very cooperative on many occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to thank particularly the officers from the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel for the hard work they did in bringing this Bill to its final stage. Finally, I thank the departmental officers who are all here this evening. I thank them very kindly for the work they have done and the long periods that they spent on it. They put in many months of hard work. It was not easy to do but they worked tirelessly on behalf of the veterans community. The majority of letters we get in the office are complimentary of those persons who work in the Department on behalf of the veterans community. As all honourable members have said, I thank them once again for their contribution.

It is not because I have received some accolades from the RSL members that I say we can be very proud of the work of the RSL over 75 years-it is the RSL's seventy-fifth anniversary this year-and also the work of various governments of all persuasions to ensure that we have in Australia the best repatriation system in the world. I have spoken to many people from both sides who agree with me, as the Leader of the National Party knows. That is not to say that we cannot make it better; we should make it better if we can. We do have the best repatriation system in the world. It is up to each and every one of us, as it is up to the RSL. I am sure all honourable members will ensure that we continue to have the best repatriation system in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a perception in some areas that Wayne Goss, Labor Premier of Queensland, is somehow not as bad as the Australian Labor Party in the rest of Australia. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the only difference is that he has not been there long enough. Give him time; he will deliver on his election promise, `I will do for Queensland what John Cain did for Victoria'. He has already imported failed bureaucrats from Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania. Bannon's economic advisers are now Goss's economic advisers.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's Victoria is bankrupt. Labor's Western Australia Incorporated is in receivership. In New South Wales, Nick Greiner struggles to recover from the Labor-Wran debacle. In Hobart, Labor and the Greens are trying to turn that State into a jobless national park. South Australians are learning to live under Labor's John Bannon and learn what it is really like to eat crow-boiled, stewed and roasted. Wayne Goss inherited the best run economy in Australia, but sadly for Queenslanders there is a limit to how long even it can survive under Labor management. The cracks are already so wide that even the Courier-Mail is having difficulty papering over them.

Let us look at something of Labor's short record in Queensland. Labor promised no new taxes, but there have been many tax increases, some of more than a 1,000 per cent. Land tax is up 40 per cent and charges by more than 25 per cent. In spite of all those increased taxes, Queens- landers could still have their first unbalanced budget in decades. Development has stopped. Not a single new project has been announced since the election of the Goss Government. There are no cranes. The $2 billion Boyne Island alumina refinery has been shelved and, indeed, the existing one could still close. The China steel mill was given away. The Yabulu nickel refinery could close with the loss of 750 jobs. Even the multi-function polis that nobody else wanted, we succeeded in giving away. And sadly, the Cape York space base, one of the most exciting projects on Australia's horizon, could be lost.

Investment is already down over 10 per cent. The Goss Government was very critical of the former National Party Government at the time of the election campaign about unemployment. When the Goss Government came to office unemployment in Queensland was 97,000. What is it today? One hundred and sixty-four thousand. What Labor is supposed to be best at, it has failed at in Queensland. Bankruptcies are up 60 per cent. For revenge, the Government has closed many country courthouses, hospital boards, fire brigade boards and rail lines; road funding has been slashed; technical and further education courses cut and $7m worth of new charges imposed.

What about corruption? This is the Government that was going to end corruption, yet as the Cooke inquiry goes on we learn more about the appalling record of the trade unions in that State-election rigging, misappropriation of funds and the like. What about the Minister's holidays, or the $8,000 train trip to Barcaldine? Remember the Government jet Labor was going to sell? It did not sell the Government jet, it went and bought another one, retaining the original jet merely to recapture escaping MLAs, like the ex-member for Nundah who ran away. He had had enough. He has made it quite clear that he did not quit because of any love triangle, or because of his wife's relationship with the golden haired boy, Wayne Swan and his wife. He did not quit because of any delicate battle over conference representation. He quit because he was fed up with Wayne Goss and the Labor Government. So now we have a by-election.

Let us look at Labor's achievements in Queensland. There are certainly a few. Poker machines and many more casinos are promised. In fact, I am told that we are going to have a gambling-led recovery in Queensland. That is Labor's wonderful new solution for our State. There are 100 new committees. Industrial relations have been put back to the Dark Ages. Queensland, once the leader, is unfortunately now, as a result of the `Minister for Revenge and Bowls', going back to the 1940s and 1950s. The people of Nundah and Toowoomba South are going to have the first opportunity to pass judgment on the record of the Goss Government in Queensland and we all know what judgment they are going to apply.

Labor is also on the run in Queensland and it is the beginning of the end of its last area of hope. Labor is a disaster for all Australians and it is a disaster wherever it has tried to govern. Let us hope that Queensland can survive long enough for Labor to be tossed out in that State also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1991 the shareholders of New South Wales Inc will be holding their general meeting. We have been asked to consider the tremendous turnaround in our company's financial position since the old board was shown the door in 1988. The advertisements on our televisions and radios are telling us that this is a bunch of whiz-kids at the helm who are going to take our State into the big league-a board of directors that knows how to run a business at a profit. What a load of absolute rubbish.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that in New South Wales we have a Government of extraordinary incompetence, greed, callousness and naivety. Take, for example, the Liberal Party of Australia's signature picture of Nick Greiner proudly standing in front of the Sydney Harbour bridge with an oversized `Last and final payment' cheque for $8m glued to his chest. That sums up this Government brilliantly. The Liberals intended that photograph to be a symbolic representation of the new business-oriented Government getting on with the job. The question is, what job? Sending New South Wales broke.

Here we have Nick Greiner, the great managing director, paying out a loan which was incurring almost non-existent interest while he owes millions of dollars at top line interest rates. This little exercise has cost the taxpayers a cool $375,000 a year in interest. Any managing director of a private company would have been shown the door on the spot.

If we thought that was bad, it was only the beginning. Let us not forget that in 1988 Mr Greiner said that New South Wales was addicted to debt. For his information, the debt has increased by $2.6 million-by $45 for every man, woman and child in the State. Also, using Mr Greiner's new accounting format-that is, financial transactions-Labor left a budget surplus of $315m in March 1988, which was not bad for a Labor government by any standard. From 1989 to 1990 Mr Greiner had a budget deficit-listen to this, my friends-of $340m and this financial year the deficit is around $600m. How about that? It is $1.5m if we look at the sums on a national basis.

Since 1988 taxes and charges have increased by $850m a year. Who can forget the massive increases in petrol tax, tobacco tax, pub poker machine tax and financial institution duty tax? That is the calibre of the economic managers of New South Wales-increased State debt, increased taxes and increased budget deficits; a miserable trifecta for New South Wales. What we have done, of course, is put the lunatics in charge of the asylum.

How about the Government's financial approach to this year's statutory corporations, which could be described as Farmer Greiner's milking cows? This year's deficit is to be offset by a $400m milked from Elcom and $500m milked from the Government Insurance Office of New South Wales to shore up the mess that it has made. That is asset stripping on a scale that would make the bottom-of-the-harbour cowboys of years ago go red with envy.

Then, of course, we have the Greiner Government's asset disposal experiment, which would also rank with the bottom-of-the-harbour stunt. We have the Black Stump in Sydney being sold so that public servants can stay in the building, or its replacement, and pay rent instead. That would not necessarily be a bad move if the liquidity released by the sale generated a higher productivity return. Not likely. In the case of the whiz-kids, any capital raised will simply go towards balancing the New South Wales budget and will be eaten away by the deficit spiral that has engulfed New South Wales. So much for responsible management for the future.

Why has New South Wales got itself into this mess? Is too much being spent on the provision of services to the community? Hardly. Cutbacks have been the name of the game in every community sphere. But not everybody has suffered. Over a billion dollars worth of assistance has been meted out to those who need it least, such as the $98m stamp duty concession given to the Fairfax Group, the $200m paid to consultants for their advice and the $40-odd million paid to George Herscu. Everybody has heard of George and the least said about that the better.

It is a pity that some of the $200m paid in consultants' fees was not distributed amongst the working class people of my area-but of course it was not-where they have had to pay a $270 increase in rail fares since 1988 and electricity has gone up by $107, water rates by $168, car registration by $151--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday evening I received a telephone call from one of my constituents, Mrs Carol Ashmore. I have subsequently received a letter from her husband and also two other constituents, a Mr Bill Couch and a Mr Robert Scott, on the same subject. Mr Ashmore is a classic example of this particular problem, because he is employed as a carpenter at the Clayton Services Centre of the State Bank of Victoria. He is a long term employee and he is married with a family. I will read some extracts from his letter-it is too long to read it all in the time that we have available. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the staff of State Bank Victoria, trading as the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, wish to express most vehemently our total disappointment at the forthcoming retrenchments to effect all workers in the Services areas of the Bank.
Since the announcement of the sale of the State Bank to the Commonwealth, there have been numerous statements made to the media stating that the merger would not create any retrenchments.
The announcement made on Thursday 9th of May, by the Deputy Chief Manager Personnel, Mr John Murray, stated that total retrenchments will in fact be made in the Technical and Trade areas.
This announcement is of grave concern. Job assurance had been given by Government and senior Bank personnel with the eventual purchase of the State Bank by the Commonwealth Bank in January.
He goes on to say:

There is no just reason why we have been singled out for total retrenchment. Further, no offers of redeployment or retraining have been made. We believe this to be contrary to Government and Bank policy.

An additional concern expressed in the letter is that this will add on to the current unemployment figures, and we are most obviously unhappy that 6,000 employees-so we are told by Mr Murray-are to be `done away with'. No time frames or details were given on how this staff reduction would be achieved.

A number of issues are raised by the Ashmores' situation and that of my other constituents. First is the morality of giving assurances when the Commonwealth Bank took over the Victorian State Bank that there would be no redundancies. Whatever the actual words used, there is no doubt that both Federal and State governments intended to give and did give this impression to the employees and the community at large. Whilst many of us were doubtful of the value of that statement-it ranks with Mr Jolly's assurances in respect of Pyramid-nonetheless, staff accepted these assurances in good faith.

The second issue is the way in which staff have been treated. They have been told that they are to be thrown out of their jobs in the middle of a recession, and I understand that there has been no indication of the dates or the terms and conditions of that termination; no safeguard in respect of their mortgages held with the State Bank; and, having been pressured when the takeover took place to transfer to the Commonwealth Bank's health scheme, they are now to have that facility denied to them.

To say that this is intolerable management behaviour is, I believe, an understatement. Mr and Mrs Ashmore and my other constituents, together with many thousands of Australians and particularly Victorians, are already suffering grievously as a result of Federal and State government policies. I suggest that this particular matter needs urgent, decisive leadership and action from the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I urge the Treasurer, in the strongest possible terms, to act on behalf of my constituents and all the other employees of the State Bank who equally are being so shamelessly treated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to talk about electoral bribery and propriety in government in New South Wales. Members of the House will recall that, subsequent to the 1988 election in New South Wales, the Liberal Party mounted a major court case against the successful Labor candidate for the State seat of Port Stephens, Mr Bob Martin.
—Good member.

—An excellent member. The case was based on the fact that Mr Martin had distributed some cheques to community organisations for $30,000 to $40,000. The Liberal Party was successful in pursuing its allegations that this amounted to electoral bribery. The court ordered the election overturned, and history now records that Mr Martin won the subsequent by-election with a massive swing.

SPEECH.PARA: It now seems that the Liberal Party in New South Wales and Premier Greiner have undergone a substantial transformation of attitude. We watch almost daily as he and his colleagues, his Ministers, wander around New South Wales handing out cheques like drunken sailors. Just the other day he presented a contribution of some $10m for an entertainment centre in Newcastle. This was not a straight grant; this has to be paid back. However, that day he was to present a cheque for $11m for earthquake repairs. Surprisingly, half of it was from the Commonwealth, but no Federal members were notified or even invited. Unfortunately, through sheer incompetence, the handover was fouled up and the cheque had to be sent by post a few days later.

These actions stand in stark contrast to the Liberal Party's claims in 1988, but they really do set the scene for a most shameful and sordid matter. Before going to the substance of the Liberal Party's actions, I remind the House of the convention that exists in the Federal Parliament called the caretaker convention. This requires that, following the proroguing of the Parliament, the government of the day accept that its role is that of a caretaker and that it should make no decisions of any significant nature that could bind an incoming government. This convention is observed by both sides of the Parliament and it has been in existence for quite some time. However, its existence appears to have escaped Mr Greiner's attention, which is surprising, given his previous sensitivity to government activities during election periods.

This is particularly relevant to a decision made by the New South Wales Government just last week, when it let a tender for $22m to North Queensland Engineers and Agents, a shipbuilding company, for the supply of ferries for the Parramatta River. While I and my colleagues, and particularly the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), would not be in any way opposed to a ferry service being established between Parramatta and Sydney, we should all be appalled that this decision was made and that the tenders were let half way through an election.

I raise this matter particularly because, when these tenders were originally called, Carrington Slipways of Newcastle was one of the companies to submit a tender. Subsequently, it went into liquidation and was unable to follow through the tender process by the required date of 14 February. In early March Senator Button approached the Minister for State Development to alert him to the fact that this tender could be vital for the possible sale of Carrington Slipways. Subsequently, I and my State colleagues have strenuously called on the State Government to extend the tender period to allow a prospective buyer of Carrington's to follow up the original tender. I am also aware of at least one company having raised the matter with the State Government some weeks back. No-one is suggesting that the tender should be granted automatically, but rather that a purchaser of Carrington's would need to be competent and competitive to win the tender.

All these representations have now been refused, and last Friday, while the Premier was in Newcastle handing out cheques, Mr Baird, the State Minister for Transport, announced in Parramatta that the ferries would be built in Queensland. Incidentally, this is only the second ferry order ever placed by this Government and both have gone to Queensland. Yet every day thousands of commuters on the harbours and rivers of Newcastle and Sydney ride in those superb ferries built by Carrington Slipways.

This is a case of astounding impropriety. If a government decided to govern, make decisions, let tenders and commit funds during an election period in this House, we would all be critical. Yet my colleagues opposite and in New South Wales are silent. It is important that New South Wales adopt the Commonwealth convention: when elections are called the government is a caretaker, not a hander out of cheques or a letter of tenders.

—The shadow Minister says he has never met him. I am sure that that speaks in his favour, but a Premier of his political persuasion has appointed this man to chair the Maritime Services Board in New South Wales. The Maritime Services Board has a turnover of $300m, with assets of $1 billion and more than 2,000 employees, yet we have a gentleman with this record being appointed by the Greiner Government to chair the Maritime Services Board. It is also interesting to note that Mr Yong is a former business partner of Mr Greiner. Together they were involved in a company called Riverside Holdings. Mr Greiner was involved in this company until 1989. Apparently, it was a turf farm in the Colo River area, and Mr Greiner has admitted in the New South Wales Parliament that, as late as 1989, he was still staying there on the odd weekend using Riverside Holdings as a place for a weekender.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple point I make here is that the McCusker report said of Mr Yong, who was involved in an assessment of the assets of Rothwells, that it is a pity that Mr Yong did not disclose the existence of a loan, which had been made by a company associated with the Rothwells company, to Mr Yong.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Rothwells company?

—If the honourable member for Bruce were aware of the McCusker report, he would be aware that it states that it is a pity that this was not declared to the Ministers involved in the negotiations in the bid to rescue Rothwells.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I finish, I wish to remind the House of the existence of an organisation called Community Polling, an organisation used to launder funds which were used for the Liberal Party at the 1980 State election. Mr Greiner has admitted that it used his own office in Parliament House to do polling. It has come to my attention that a number of donations were made to Community Polling. One donation in particular was a donation of $100,000 by Mr Bill Roach. I ask the House: is it a fact that Mr Roach took various donations from a number of individuals and allowed Community Polling to declare that single donation from him? Is it a fact that Mr Roach has been used in effect as a clearing house for donations to Community Polling before the last election? Mr Greiner has said that, before this election, he would ensure there was disclosure of donations. That is another broken promise.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: New South Wales: Proposed Toll Road

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Somlyay Mr A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the last opportunity before the New South Wales State election, quite obviously, for members of the Federal Parliament to have their say and to try to get some publicity on behalf of their candidates. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has demonstrated that tonight. I would like to get involved in this debate concerning New South Wales. I have been following the debate very closely on the proposed toll road in New South Wales. I heard the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) stand up in this House and decry the Greiner Government for its proposal to introduce a toll road. He said that that would force traffic through suburban streets; that there has been a massive backlash; and that the New South Wales Leader of the Opposition has said that that toll would be abolished under a Labor Government. That is to win votes.

SPEECH.PARA: I inform the House of the experience that we had in Queensland of a very similar situation. In my electorate of Fairfax, a toll road, a motorway, was introduced by the previous State Government. The now Premier of Queensland, the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Goss, wrote to every person on the roll in the State seat of Cooroora. In his personally signed letter, he stated:
If my Government is elected, we will abolish that toll on the Maroochy River Bridge on the Sunshine motorway.

Surprise, surprise! Mr Goss's candidate in the seat of Cooroora was elected, against his own expectations. They then found themselves in the position where they had to abolish that toll. Everybody expected them to do so. But did they abolish the toll? No; they realised that, all of a sudden, they were up for approximately $90m as a cost to revenue for that toll. But did they abolish that toll? No; they in fact increased the number of toll gates by building two new ones.

An organisation in my electorate called the `Toll Busters' has been fighting that tollway ever since. There is clear evidence and written statements to honourable members in my electorate right throughout the Sunshine Coast that that toll was to be abolished, and it has not been. I warn the people of New South Wales that that is the sort of treatment they can expect and not to take seriously the threats of the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an opportunity to add to some of the comments I made earlier about the disclosure of donations to political parties-and I thank the House for that opportunity. It is quite clear that, unless the community has confidence in the honesty of our political parties, the whole concept of democracy is placed under a cloud. I say to the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) that it is long time that all political parties at Federal, State and local government level declared where their political donations were coming from. It has been very clear that it is only Labor governments in New South Wales and at the Federal level which have been able to introduce legislation requiring the disclosure of donations.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the honourable member of an inquiry by Justice Roden of the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales, which said that the current electoral laws in New South Wales were a joke because it was very clear that individuals and companies-and unions for that matter-could escape the disclosure of provisions by channelling funds through bodies outside New South Wales and by making donations for allegedly administrative purposes. Justice Roden recommended very strongly that the health of our political system would depend on our having disclosure of donations to political parties. That is something which I support absolutely.

Mr Greiner said before this State election that he would introduce legislation requiring the disclosure of donations. He said that before the people of New South Wales went to the polls all donations for the 1991 New South Wales election would have to be disclosed. That was Mr Greiner's promise, and it is another promise that he has broken. Mr Greiner established a parliamentary committee to look at Justice Roden's recommendations, gave them funds to go on a junket to the United States, and bank-rolled them for a second proposed visit to Europe. So Mr Greiner obviously set out with the deliberate intention of ensuring there was no recommendation from that parliamentary committee before the proposed New South Wales State election.

There is one reason for that: the Liberals and the Nationals in New South Wales do not want the people, the voters, of that State to know who is funding their current State election campaign. That is the reason why the Greiner Government has failed to introduce the legislation which Justice Roden said was necessary so that we could ensure that there are proper standards of conduct amongst all the political parties. I suggest to honourable members opposite that, before much longer, they will have a chance to say whether they support full disclosure of political donations. That is something which should be required, not only in New South Wales and at the Federal level but in all States and also in local government. I suggest to the honourable member for Fairfax that, when it applies in Queensland, I hope it is retrospective, to ensure that donations during the Bjelke-Petersen years come to public notice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Have any members of the advisory committee to the Attorney-General on matters relating to companies and securities regulation, appointed at or since its inception, been subject to inquiry from the (a) National Companies and Securities Commission, (b) National Crime Authority or (c) Australian Securities Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) &(c) The National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) was responsible for the administration of Companies and Securities laws until 31 December 1990. The Australian Securities Commission (ASC) commenced operations under the new Corporations Law on 1 January 1991 and on that date assumed responsibility for the functions and powers previously exercised by the NCSC. This includes investigations and inquiries commenced under the previous law.

The ASC has advised that the only relevant inquiries conducted by the NCSC that relate to the honourable member's request concern the following three matters, each of which has previously been the subject of public report.

The first matter concerns questions raised by the NCSC in 1984 about the role of Baring Brothers, Burrows and Partners (Baring Brothers) as financial adviser to Allied Mills Limited in connection with a takeover offer for the company, and its preparation of an expert's report on the takeover to shareholders under the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980. Mr Mark Burrows, the convenor of the Advisory Committee was, at the time, executive director of Baring Brothers and was personally involved in the provision of advice to Allied Mills.

Following discussions with the NCSC, Baring Brothers agreed that it would not hold itself out as being independent from the target company in any report where it had acted in a professional capacity for the company during the previous twelve months. Nor would it prepare an expert's report where it acted in a professional capacity in relation to the takeover in which the requirement for the report arose.
No further action was taken in relation to the matter. I am advised that the NCSC considered that the undertakings were subsequently honoured.

The second matter concerns the hearing conducted by the NCSC in December 1988 into trading activities which had occurred at the time of the settlement of the September 1988 Ten Year Bond futures contract on the Sydney Futures Exchange.

A number of market participants were involved in the hearing. One of those participants was Bankers Trust Australia (BT Australia). Mr David Hoare, presently the deputy Convenor of the Advisory Committee, was at the time and is still, the Chairman of BT Australia. I am advised that at no stage was Mr Hoare's conduct the subject of any inquiry in relation to the matter.

The NCSC and BT Australia agreed to settle a number of matters arising out of the hearing. The settlement involved several staff of Bankers Trust Asset Management, a subsidiary of BT Australia. It was agreed that 2 employees would not act as authorised persons for specified periods-12 months in one case and 3 months in the other. A third employee received a letter concerning his conduct during the course of trading. It was also agreed that the Commission would receive reports for the following four Bond Futures contract close-out periods on the strategy used by participants during the close-out. BT Australia met the costs of the Commission's investigation.

The Chairman of the ASC, Mr A.G. Hartnell, who is an ex officio member of the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, acted as solicitor for BT Australia in relation to the above matter. This occurred prior to Mr Hartnell's appointment as Chairman of the ASC. As solicitor for BT Australia, Mr Hartnell was not himself the subject of any NCSC inquiry in relation to this matter.
The third matter concerns inquiries into the operations of certain companies in Western Australia, with which Mr Alexander Emil Vrisakis was involved.
Following the sharemarket crash in October 1987, Mr Vrisakis joined the Board of Rothwells Limited as part of a management plan settled with the NCSC.

In August 1988 the NCSC examined the role of Mr Vrisakis in the Bond Corporation Ltd/State Government Insurance Commission acquisition of securities in Bell Group Ltd. The NCSC did not take the matter any further.

In February and March 1989, the conduct of Mr Vrisakis as a Director of Rothwells Limited was investigated by the NCSC as part of its broad investigation of the affairs of Rothwells prior to the establishment of the McCusker Special Investigation of Rothwells. Further inquiries were made in March 1990, following the establishment of the Special Investigation. The matters investigated by the NCSC are addressed in Part 1 of the Report of Inspector on a Special Investigation into Rothwells Ltd, 1990 which was tabled in the Western Australian Parliament in August 1990.

Following publication of the McCusker Report, Mr Vrisakis elected to stand aside temporarily from his position as a member of the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee and as Chairman of the Legal Sub-committee of the Advisory Committee.

(b) In accordance with well-established policy, I will not confirm or deny whether any particular individual is or has been the subject of inquiry by the National Crime Authority unless that fact becomes publicly known, for instance, through court proceedings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the guidelines by which members of the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee may spend the sum allocated to them in the Budget.
(2) What sum was spent from the $200 000 allocation to the Advisory Committee in the 1989-90 Budget.

(3) Further to his statement (Hansard, 19 September 1990, page 2161) that no members of the Advisory Committee take the sitting fee to which they are entitled, how was the sum referred to in part (2) spent.
(4) If no members of the Advisory Committee took their sitting fees in 1989-90, why has funding for the Advisory Committee been increased from $200 000 in 1989-90 to $470 000 in 1990-91.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The guidelines under which members of the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee ('the Advisory Committee') spend the sums allocated to them in the Budget are set down in sections 159 to 170 inclusive of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989.
The central provisions are sections 161, 163 and 164 of the Act.

Section 161 sets out the manner in which the Advisory Committee can apply its money. The section makes it clear that the Committee's funds can only be used to pay remuneration or meet expenses, charges, obligations or liabilities incurred or undertaken in connection with the Committee's functions and powers. Pursuant to subsection 161 (3) any money not immediately required for such purposes must be placed on deposit with a bank, invested in Commonwealth securities or applied in a manner approved by the Treasurer. Under subsections 161 (5), 161 (6) and 161 (7) provision is made, where necessary, for the return of funds not immediately required by the Committee.
Section 163 prevents the Committee from entering into a contract involving a sum exceeding $50,000, or a lease for a term exceeding 10 years, without prior approval by the Minister.
Section 164 makes the Committee a public authority subject to Division 3 of Part XI of the Audit Act 1901. Division 3 comprises sections 63j to 63m of that Act.

Section 63j provides that a public authority must maintain an account with an approved bank, being the Reserve Bank of Australia or another bank declared by the Treasurer, and pay all moneys received into that account.
Section 63k requires a public authority to keep proper accounts and do all things necessary to ensure that all payments from its funds are correctly made and properly authorised.
Section 63l makes a public authority subject to regular audit by the Auditor-General.

Section 63m requires a public authority to prepare and submit, as soon as practicable after 30 June in each year, an annual report of its operations together with financial statements concerning that year. Pursuant to subsection 63m (2), before submission to the Minister the annual financial statements just referred to must be referred to the Auditor-General, who shall report to the appropriate Minister-
(a) whether, in his opinion, the statements are based on proper accounts and records;
(b) whether the statements are in agreement with the accounts and records;

(c) whether, in his opinion, the receipt, expenditure and investment of moneys, and the acquisition and disposal of assets by the authority during the year have been in accordance with the enactment establishing the authority; and
(d) as to such other matters arising out of the statements as the Auditor-General considers should be reported to the appropriate Minister.

(2) &(3) am informed that a total sum of $61,659 was spent from the $200,000 allocated to the Advisory Committee in the 1989-90 Budget and that a breakdown of the sum spent in the year 1989-90 is as follows:
Members could have but did not claim payment for $19,400 in sitting fees during this period.

The Advisory Committee has also informed me that the figure of $400 described as remuneration represents sitting fees paid to two Committee members. The sum of $400 was part of travelling allowance payments made to those two members for expenses incurred by them in attending an Advisory Committee meeting. After these payments were made it was found that the total sum was in excess of their allowable rates. The members were unaware of the approved rates at the time the expenses were incurred. The members were, however, entitled to sitting fees for the meeting attended and the Advisory Committee determined that the excess payments made ($400) would be charged to the remuneration item.
(4) The funding allocation for the Advisory Committee has been increased from $200,000 in 1989-90 to $470,000 in 1990-91 for the following main reasons:
(a) The year 1990-91 will be the Committee's first full operational year.

(b) The Committee has hired permanent and contracted staff for the first time. In the year 1989-90 the Executive Director was retained as a consultant, and administrative support was provided by the ASC free of charge to the Committee. The Committee now employs the Executive Director, a Senior Legal Officer and a Secretary (Administrative Service Officer Grade 3) on a full-time basis.
(c) The Committee now has to pay $30,000 for its accommodation, whereas last financial year this accommodation was provided free of charge by the Australian Securities Commission.

(d) Increased provision has been made for the hire of consultants ($30,000) and the conduct of research ($60,000) in preparation for the increased workload which is expected to follow the commencement of the Corporations legislation.

(e) It is necessary to make provisions for the payment of fees to which members of the Committee have a legal entitlement pursuant to the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989, even though some or all such members may not claim these fees. Funds not spent at the end of the financial year for whatever reason can be returned to Consolidated Revenue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) are the roles of and (b) sums were allocated in (i) 1989-90 and (ii) 1990-91 to the (A) Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, (B) Companies and Securities Law Review Committee and (C) Liquidators Disciplinary Board.

(2) Did his predecessor, in the process of drafting the Australian Securities Commission legislation, establish a steering committee, a wider consultative committee and a group of subcommittees; if so, (a) what was the name of, (b) who were the members of, (c) what funding was received by and (d) what has become of, each committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) (A) The role of the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee is outlined in section 148 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989. Section 148 provides that the Advisory Committee's functions are, on its own initiative or when requested by the Minister, to advise the Minister, and to make to the Minister such recommendations as it thinks fit, about any matter connected with:
(a) a proposal to make a national scheme law, or to make amendments of a national scheme law;
(b) the operation or administration of a national scheme law;
(c) law reform in relation to a national scheme law;
(d) companies, close corporations, securities or the futures industry; or
(e) proposal for improving the efficiency of the securities markets or futures markets.
Subsection 5(1) of the Australian Securities Commission Act defines ``a national scheme law'' as:
(b) a law of a kind referred to in subsection 11(1) of the Australian Securities Commission Act;
(c) a provision of the Australian Securities Commission Act or a provision of a law of a kind referred to in subsection 11(1) of that Act.
Subsection 11(1) refers to a law of the Commonwealth that deals with, or with matters including, any or all of the following:
(a) the formation of companies or close corporations;
(c) the regulation of acquisitions of shares in a body corporate;
(d) the regulation of the securities industry;
(e) the regulation of the futures industry;
(f) matters incidental to a matter referred in a preceding paragraph.

(B) The Companies and Securities Law Review Committee was established pursuant to sub-clause 21 (2) of the Formal Agreement which enabled the establishment of the co-operative companies and securities scheme. The role of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee was to undertake research and advise the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities on reform of the co-operative scheme companies and securities legislation. The Committee was wound up in December 1990.

(C) The honourable member's reference to the ``Liquidators Disciplinary Board'' is understood to be a reference to the Australian Capital Territory Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board established under section 4 of the Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board Ordinance 1982.

The Australian Capital Territory Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board was responsible for disciplining auditors and liquidators who transgressed their responsibilities under the Companies Act 1981. There are equivalent bodies in each of the States and the Northern Territory, but the Commonwealth has no role in relation to these. These bodies have a continuing role after 1 January 1991 in relation to proceedings commenced before 1 January 1991. In respect of proceedings commenced on or after 1 January 1991, for transgressions of the former Companies Acts and Codes or the Corporations Law, the role of the Boards has been superseded by the Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board established by Part II of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989.

(1) (b) (A) (i) The sum allocated to the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee in the Budget for the year 1989-90 was $200 000; (ii) The sum allocated to the Committee for the year 1990-91 is $470 000.
(B) (i) The sum allocated to the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee in the year 1989/90 was $139 950.10; (ii) The sum allocated for the year 1990/91 is $89 000.

(C) Funding for the Australian Capital Territory Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board was provided on an ``as requested'' basis by the Australian Capital Territory Corporate Affairs Commission. No formal allocation of funds is made. Members of the Board were paid sitting fees as prescribed under section 13 of the Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board Ordinance 1982.
(2) My predecessor did establish a Steering Committee, a wider consultative Committee and a group of subcommittees to assist in the process of drafting the Corporations legislation.
The ``Steering Committee'' referred to was established in September 1987 and known as the Companies and Securities Steering Committee. Its membership consisted of the following persons:
The Steering Committee was wound up in September 1989.

The wider consultative committee referred to was known as the Companies and Securities Consultative Group. The Group was established in November 1987. Its membership consisted of the following persons:
The Institute of Directors in Australia

The Consultative Group met on only one occasion, in December 1987. At that meeting, the members of the Consultative Group decided that the best way to allow for meaningful discussions on the legislative proposals before them was to divide themselves into four specialist subcommittees. The Consultative Group thereupon ceased to operate as a group.
These are the subcommittees referred to in the honourable member's question. Membership of the subcommittees was as follows:
The Institute of Directors in Australia
Head of the Dept. of Law The University of Sydney
All four Committees had ceased to operate by October 1989.

I am informed that no budgetary allocation was provided for the Companies and Securities Steering Committee, the Companies and Securities Consultative Group or the four subcommittees. Some expenditure associated with the conduct of meetings of these bodies was met from the funding allocated to the Attorney-General's Department. I am informed that the amount of this expenditure cannot at this stage be readily separated from general Departmental expenditure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 11 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action is the Government taking to prohibit importation of asbestos and its use

(2) Has the Government instituted inquiries into the health effects of asbestos through (a) the National Health and Medical Research Council or (b) elsewhere; if so, what conclusions have been reached

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The views of the members of National Occupational Health and Safety Commission have been recently sought on the occupational health and safety aspects of the importation of crocidolite and amosite asbestos. It is anticipated that the Commission will consider the issue at its September 1991 meeting and report to me at that time.

(2) (a) An examination of available records does not show any Government initiated review through the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). The Council did, however, review the health effects of asbestos on a number of occasions prior to 1985 and produced some important statements and publications including:

Report on the health hazards of asbestos, prepared by the Asbestos Subcommittee of the NHMRC which was adopted by Council in June 1981 and published by the Australian Government Publishing Service in 1982.
Asbestos: Statement by the National Health and Medical Research Council, June 1984.
Statement on health hazards associated with the use of asbestos in the construction industry, October 1979.
Code of practice for the safe removal of asbestos-based thermal-acoustic insulating materials, October 1979.
In respect of NHMRC supported research a study is currently being funded at the University of Western Australia on the health effects of mesothelioma; funding is of the order of $100,000 for 1991.

(b) Under the Australian Mesothelioma Research Program, a research study of six years' duration (1 January 1980-31 December 1985-under the auspices of Worksafe Australia since 1 January 1985), notification of all cases of mesothelioma diagnosed in Australia during that period was sought. The original objectives of the Program were to:

Since 1 January 1986, the Australian Mesothelioma Register has continued to receive advice on all cases of mesothelioma in Australia. The Register notification enables continued monitoring of the incidence rate, the percentage of cases with asbestos exposure and the geographic and industry/occupation distribution of mesothelioma cases in Australia.

I have been advised by Worksafe Australia that research projects based on the Mesothelioma Program and control data have shown a clear dose-response effect (ie, the higher the dose the higher the risk) when fibre dose is measured by fibre concentration in the lung. The highest risk is associated with long crocidolite (blue) asbestos fibres and long amosite (brown) asbestos fibres.

I am advised that there is also a risk with chrysotile (white) asbestos fibres, but the magnitude of the risk is difficult to estimate from fibre concentrations in the lung, because of clearance of chrysotile from the lung (ie, the amount in the lungs at death does not necessarily reflect the exposure). Research has also shown that fibres are often found in the lungs of people with no history of asbestos exposure. This implies that absence of history does not necessarily mean absence of exposure.

In May 1988, after extensive expert consideration and a three month public comment period, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission declared a code of practice and approved associated guidance notes as follows:

Code of Practice for the Safe Removal of Asbestos-outlines the basic principles which should be followed in selecting the most suitable technique for the safe removal of asbestos-based thermal or acoustic insulation, including friable asbestos boards, and is aimed at minimising the concentration of airborne asbestos fibre;

Guide to the Control of Asbestos Hazards in Buildings and Structures-provides the methods, procedures and work practices recommended for the identification, evaluation and control of hazards from in situ asbestos in the working environment; and

Guidance Note on the Membrane Filter Method for Estimating Airborne Asbestos Dust-outlines the appropriate exposure standards for asbestos and the principles of result reporting and employer-employee consultation.
As a result of recent research findings on the effects of exposure to chrysotile, Worksafe Australia has commenced a re-evaluation of the exposure standard in the Code of Practice.
